Title: Nirbhaya case: Plea seeks papers to file curative petitions
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A plea was filed in a Delhi court on behalf of the Nirbhaya death-row convicts on Friday seeking relevant documents from Tihar Jail authorities.

The petition, filed through advocate AP Singh, urged the court to direct the authorities concerned to provide the required information so that the curative petitions of convicts Pawan Gupta and Akshay Thakur could be filed. The plea also stated that convict Vinay Kumar Sharma’s mercy plea could not be filed as his personal diary, which was sought from the jail authorities, was not provided. “Sharma expressed desire to attach his 170-page diary to the mercy petition,” it added. Supreme Court had earlier dismissed the curative petition of Sharma and Mukesh Singh.

Seeking an “urgent” direction to the jail authorities to provide the diary, the plea stated that in the case of the other convicts, Pawan Gupta and Thakur, relevant documents, including their medical records, need to be provided. The matter is likely to be heard on January 25.

On January 7, a court said that the convicts were given “sufficient time and opportunity” to exhaust their legal remedies. It had issued fresh death warrants and direction for their hanging to take place on February 1 after President Ram Nath Kovind had rejected the mercy plea of Singh on January 17.

Nirbhaya’s mother, through her advocates Jitendra Kumar Jha and Seema Kushwaha, had filed a plea in Patiala House Courts seeking death warrants against the four men on December 13, 2018.

In its January 7 order, the court said that the convicts had either exhausted their remedies or hadn’t resorted to them despite being given sufficient time and opportunity. “In these given facts and circumstances, when reasonable time and opportunity has been afforded, there is nothing to delay passing of the order on the applications seeking issuance of death warrants,” it added.

Title: Maharashtra: Free legal assistance for distressed homebuyers
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

The free assistance will help litigants who can’t afford high lawyer fee (File photo)

PUNE: Lawyers registered with Maharashtra Real Estate Regulatory Authority ( MahaRERA ) have decided to help homebuyers with free legal consultancy and representation before the tribunal from February 1.

In the logjam between builders and homebuyers, the advocates of the Bar Association-run Legal Aid Cell will assist those in need of help. The members conducted several workshops to raise awareness about the RERA Act, 2016, and MahaRERA.

The Legal Aid Cell is a natural extension of a social cause, said the secretary of the Bar Association, Anil D’Souza.

The free legal aid will help litigants, who cannot afford high lawyer fee as well as those who are not conversant with legal procedures. The petitioner will only have to pay Rs5,000 as fees to MahaRERA to file the complaint. This is in addition to the conciliation option already being offered by MahaRERA as an alternate dispute redressal (ADR) mechanism to litigants. This option is also cheaper as the buyer needs to pay just Rs1,000 as the fee.

The Bar Association is readying a list of 15-20 members, who will help assist consumers. The list will either be put up on a separate website created by the association or on the MahaRERA website.

While the first step would be to cover Mumbai, the remaining cities will be covered with the help of the association members, stated D’Souza.

With the MahaRERA seeing the highest number of project registrations at 23,795, the number of cases that have been disposed of is 7,000 as against the total 9,490 registered cases. D’Souza said although self-representation by litigants is encouraged, some litigants are unable to present their grievances in the right manner and format.

Members have noticed several anomalies in the case representation, like buyers not giving the entire data and proper information upfront in their complaint.

This information includes the exact amount paid, dates of payment, specific details in the registered agreement like date of possession and, importantly, if there is a grace period allowed in the registered agreement.

Besides, there are other terms and conditions in the registered agreement, which the flat purchasers have already agreed and signed upon. Such important details surface when the presiding/adjudicating officer interrogates the parties concerned.

“All this leads to a huge time lag and exasperates the system,” D’Souza shared.

Title: Cold no bar for protesters at Roshan Bagh
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

united in dissent

Allahabad: The cold temperature — which dropped to 7.6 degrees Celsius on Friday— failed to hamper the courage of protesters gathered at Mansoor Ali Park in Roshan Bagh against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Wrapped in shawls, the protesters, most of whom were women, were seen seeking comfort from the cold while sipping on cups of tea.

Meanwhile, Allahabad police has served notices to around 30 more people for participating in the protest.

“We have served notices to around 30 persons because although the protest is peaceful, we have inputs that several unscrupulous elements have started participating in the dharna. This could disturb the peaceful atmosphere of the city,” said SP (city) Brijesh Kumar Srivastava.

Women from different groups came out of their houses to lead a small procession, which was even joined by some minors.

Many local residents flocked to the park to distribute water, snacks and food packets among the protesters who were braving the cold weather.

Title: Ajmer pledges to educate everygirl child in district
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Ajmer: Secretary of the District Legal Aid Authority and additional district judge Shakti Singh Shekhawat on Friday said if a single girl was left uneducated, then there was no use of celebrating the National Girl Child Day.

On the occasion, rallies were organised in all the block headquarters with the message that girls should be educated.

The day was celebrated in 1,700 schools of the district, both government and private, and even in hospitals, railway stations and different departments where people took a pledge to abide by the Constitution. It was also decided to bring dropouts back to school.

Shekhawat said awareness was necessary and every child should know the child helpline number and they should use their rights against any crime in society. He added that if a girl child was safe, it proved society was safe and people were civilized. He said it was the duty of every girl child to stand for their rights. He also flagged off a rally in which hundreds of students participated under the banner of ‘save the girl child’. Such rallies were also held at Kekeri, Sarwar, Pushkar, Bijaynagar, Nasirabad, Kishangarh and Beawar.

The district legal aid authority took this as a mission in Ajmer. Member secretary of Rajasthan Legal Aid Authority Ashok Kumar Jain and district and session judge and president of the authority Anoop Kumar Saxena asked authorities to organise awareness programmes at village level with help of legal aid committees. District collector Vishwa Mohan Sharma said such programmes will bring awareness on educating girls in the district.

Title: ‘Adaptiveness key to overcoming challenges’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) Trichy chapter on Friday conducted a workshop for entrepreneurs and employees in the manufacturing and engineering sectors to overcome the challenges they face during a decline in the economic activity.

The workshop on ‘How to increase bottom-line during slowdown’ focused on the cost control, minimisation of waste and sustaining profit during an economic slowdown

“Desirable success can be achieved only by adaptiveness, constant improvement and innovation. We are in a transition period. Technology is evolving, so we should adapt to the change for the overall organizational improvement and growth,” S Sampath, chief executive operations, Velmurugan heavy engineering industries said.

“The response to process the abnormalities in our operations should be immediate. If we leave a problem alone, small problems will accumulate and becomes a complicated issue,” Sampath added. The entrepreneurs to sustain profit even during the period of an economic slowdown were encouraged to apply one proven countermeasure at a time to deal with the problems faced.

Title: RSS veteran Tyagi dies
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

RSS veteran Dhanprakash Tyagi died here on Friday at the age of 103. Tyagi, who joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh in 1943 in Delhi, worked in Ambala, Hisar, Shimla, Aligarh, Jaipur and several other places and was in jail when the RSS was banned. BJP state president Satish Poonia and other RSS and BJP leaders paid tributes to Tyagi. His funeral will be held on Saturday.

Title: No additional FAR charges on 300 private schools, rules Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Right to education is in a position to prosper and thrive and one must bear in mind the fact that, at the end of the day, the voiceless students are the ones who are sacrificed in the tussle between the bureaucracy and the educational institutions. Delhi high court said this on Friday, when it held that private schools built on Delhi Development Authority ( DDA ) land were entitled to run senior secondary level classes without paying additional charges to the authority.

“In a welfare state, such as ours, this is unthinkable,” said Justice C Hari Shankar referring to the plight of students. The court also highlighted that it would be wise to remember that cases dealing with educational institutions had an “overwhelming element of public interest”.

Action Committee Unaided Recognised Private Schools, a society comprising around 300 such schools, had petitioned HC saying that they be allowed to run as senior secondary schools without requiring to pay additional charges. The society, which argued through advocated Amit Sibal, claimed that DDA had refused additional floor area ratio (FAR) to various primary and secondary schools despite the grant of recognition by the Directorate of Education (DoE) and Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE).

The court noted that DDA had stipulated that a site, which was allotted for establishing a primary school, could not, in any circumstances, be used for setting up middle, secondary or senior secondary school.

It also came on record that the schools that had fulfilled the requisite area criteria to function as senior secondary schools were unable to do so owing to the fact that the original lease deeds executed by DDA, stipulated that the land was allotted for setting up primary or middle schools. The court noted that it had already held that schools, which were entitled to income tax exemption, would not be required to pay any charges for availing additional FAR.

The authority, through advocate Rajiv Bansal, argued that the terms of the original lease deeds executed by DDA with the petitioner schools could not be altered in order to allow them to function as senior secondary schools without paying additional charges.

Justice Shankar, however, emphasised that the right to education also stands statutorily sanctified in what came to be popularly known as the Right to Education Act. “Maximising the reach of education is therefore, not only an avowed constitutional objective but is, indeed, a treasured constitutional imperative. Every effort has to be made towards achieving this end and financial considerations of the government, though undoubtedly entitled to their due weight, have to cede place to the right to education,” added the judge.

It was noted that DDA was willing to allow additional FAR to the petitioner schools, but in case the latter desired to have its lease deeds amended, they required to pay the charges demanded by the authority. “To my mind, this stand is completely unreasonable and amounts to an attempt to take away, with the left hand, that which is given with the right,” the court said.

The authority was accordingly directed to modify the lease deeds, executed with the individual societies. “However, it is clarified that the right of the societies to run their institutions at the senior secondary level would not be conditional, or dependent, upon such modification,” the court held.

Title: Pune: Gaanasaraswati Mahotsav to start on February 7
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vocalist Arshad Ali will be awarded the Gaanasaraswati Kishori Amonkar Yuva Puraskar

PUNE: The three-day Gaanasaraswati Mahotsav featuring a host of young vocalists in Indian classical music is set to start on February 7 at the Mahalaxmi Lawns near Rajaram bridge .

The festival is named after late Kishori Amonkar , who is known by the honorific title of Gaanasaraswati. Over the years, the festival has become the hotspot of up and coming talents, the organisers said on Friday.

During the music festival, vocalist Arshad Ali will be awarded the Gaanasaraswati Kishori Amonkar Yuva Puraskar. The award, instituted in the memory of Amonkar, recognises young exponents in the field of Indian classical performing arts. Ali will also perform on the morning of February 9, the closing day of the festival.

Other honoraries include Gwalior and Kirana gharana vocalist Venkatesh Kumar, who has been chosen as this year’s recipient of the Gaanatapaswini Mogubai Kurdikar Puraskar. Besides, tabla exponent Yogesh Samsi who will receive the Gaanasaraswati Kishori Amonkar Sangatkar Puraskar.

The organisers said they had tied up with two ticket aggregators to distribute donation passes for the show, which will also be available at Balgandharva Rangmandir on JM Road, and Tilak Smarak Mandir in Sadashiv Peth.

The festival will open on February 7 with a performance by Dhrupad Gayaki exponent Uday Bhawalkar, followed by a sitar recital by Kolkata-based Kushal Das. The second day will feature, among other performances, a taal recital by Suresh Talwalkar, along with his group Taal Yatra.

The festival will close on February 9 with a performance by the veteran vocalists Raghunandan Panshikar and Devaki Pandit, and will present a number of rare compositions by Amonkar.

Title: Move to cap liquor, cigarette quota to hit Chennai airport revenue
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chennai airport

CHENNAI: The government’s move to limit quantity of liquor and cigarettes purchased from duty-free shops at airports and the order waiving fee paid by oil companies for jet fuel sold to airlines could affect commercial revenue earned by the Airports Authority of India (AAI) at Chennai airport .

A new order that has exempted oil companies from paying a fee of Rs 1,000 per litre of aviation turbine fuel lifted by flights from the airport from mid-January has dealt a severe blow to the airport which is struggling to generate revenue.

Duty-free shops bring a good percentage of the total non-aeronautical revenue earned by the airport as retail shops are not a big draw among passengers.

If passengers are allowed to buy only a single one litre liquor bottle instead of two bottles, the revenue earned by duty-free shops is expected to dip by almost 50%. Sale of liquor and cigarettes constitutes more than 80% of the revenue generated by duty-free shops. The company that runs the duty-free shops pays around Rs 5crore a month to AAI.

An airport official said, “The licence fee given to the airport will become unviable if the new rule is implemented. They may have to renegotiate the fee so as to reduce it. This will cause a loss to the airport. They may ask for a cut in the fee to the extent of Rs 2crore or less if the proposal comes into effect.”

Chennai airport has two-duty free shops. One at the international terminal, which witnesses the maximum sales, and another at the domestic terminal.

The move has come at a time when private airport operators and AAI suggested that passengers should be allowed to buy more liquor from duty-free shops.

AAI is struggling as it controls only Chennai and Kolkata airports where it can boost non-aeronautical revenue. The scope to earn money from retail, food and beverages and duty-free shops from small airports is minimal. “It has been a struggle to promote retail business in small airports as passenger footfalls are low. At the same time, fuel charge and landing and parking charges are waived at small airports for small planes to promote regional connectivity scheme,” said an official.

A senior official said this would go against the idea of Airports Economic Regulatory Authority that higher earnings from commercial entities can be used to retain aeronautical charges such as landing and parking charges levied on airlines low.

Duty-free shops are being closed at small international airports.

Title: Pune: Kickstart your Sunday with fun-filled activities at Kharadi
Content:
Children can draw with chalks on the road

PUNE: Head to Happy Streets in Kharadi this Sunday from 6.30am to 9.30am for a ‘fun’tastic Republic Day morning with an array of activities lined up for the young and old.Put on your dancing shoes and head to the main stage to shake a leg to the latest hits, while the instructors from Core Zumba and Bollybeats guide you through an early morning exercise regime. Once you’ve warmed up, head down the road to engage in the games and activities lined up for one and all.Test the scientist in you with some tangram puzzles or the art of robotics, brought to you by Skillovate. There will also be fun games such as dart board and hopscotch organized by SWaCH outreach. The organization has also arranged for a recycle drive and waste quiz for the participants.Further down, Chaitanya School will organize games and activities. Wind stick activity, life-size snakes and ladders and ludo, tattoo making, hula hoops and more await the children. The school will also organize “Fitness Mantra” to keep the adults occupied. The other games include musical chairs, Big Foot Race, Tic Tac Toe.Parents and children can learn Taekwondo under the guidance of instructors from KDKBA. You can head to the family photo booth. Children can draw with chalks on the road, which would be closed for traffic movement in the morning.A special addition to Happy Streets this week would be the traffic activity and equipment display organized by the Pune traffic police to raise awareness about road safety.Yoga and meditation by Pause N Learn and Sahajayoga would ensure a refreshing start to the week for elders and senior citizens. Meanwhile, the children can grab cycles and pedal around the cycling arena.Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India, in association with the Pune police and Pune Municipal Corporation , powered by Nyati Group.

Title: Bhopal Co-op Bank former MD’s bail plea rejected by HC
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal/Jabalpur: A single-judge bench of M P high court on Friday dismissed a bail application filed by former managing director of Bhopal Central Cooperative Bank, Ramashankar Vishwakarma, arrested by economic offences wing (EOW) of police in connection with Rs111 crore scam.

Opposing bail to Vishwakarma, EOW counsel said that the investigation into the scam could be influenced if he is released on bail. The court of Justice RAJEEV Kumar Dubey, while upholding EOW’s objection dismissed Vishwakarma’s petition.

Vishwakarma was arrested by EOW sleuths on December 18, 2019, on charges of corruption under the provisions of Prevention of Corruption Act and criminal breach of trust under section 409 of the IPC.

He was charged with investing bank’s money in private firms in connivance with investment committee of the bank during the period he was managing director of the bank i. e. from July 2017 to Jun 2019. The total amount thus invested amounts to Rs111 crore. Advocate H S Chawda appeared in the case on behalf of the EOW.

Title: Experts: Focus on training to avoid sports injuries
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

PUNE: For children aspiring a career in sports , proper guidance and training are necessary to avoid injuries.

The sports medicine experts were speaking on the sidelines of a workshop organised by Sancheti Institute for Orthopaedics and Rehabilitation on lower limb dysfunctions. The workshop saw participants from over 110 doctors last week.

Apurv Shimpi, head of the department of community physiotherapy at Sancheti Healthcare Academy, said, “While any aspiring athlete has coaches and trainers, a physiotherapist is often missing from their team. Many of the common sports injuries are avoidable with guidance from a physiotherapist.”

Medical expert Annie Neurohr, running specialist and conditioning expert from Baltimore (US), said, “Professional athlete or an enthusiast, one must consult a physiotherapist. Our focus is not only to prevent injuries, but also better movement.”

Madhan Ramanathan, sports physiotherapist (UK), said, “There have been marked improvements and advancements in the way we train athletes with the help of physiotherapy. Everybody has a different bio-mechanism and the training techniques have been developed according to that.”

Title: Delhi assembly polls: AAP, Congress poisoning minds, says Prakash Javadekar
Content:
Prakash Javadekar

NEW DELHI: Referring to the ongoing sit-in at Shaheen Bagh against the Citizenship Amendment Act, Union minister and Delhi election in charge Prakash Javadekar on Friday accused Aam Aadmi Party and Congress of “poisoning” the minds of the minorities.Addressing a press conference, Javadekar said it was for the people of Delhi to decide if they wanted “Jinnah wali azaadi” or “Bharat Mata ki jai”. He added that AAP and Congress were “instigating” violent protests against the CAA in Delhi.With just two weeks to the Delhi assembly elections , the BJP leadership has sharpened the attack on the ruling AAP and Congress over the CAA and continuing protests at Shaheen Bagh. At his first public meeting since the polls have been announced, Union home minister Amit Shah on Thursday targeted the two parties accusing them of instigating riots over the issue.Javadekar said the people of Delhi should ask both AAP and Congress why did they instigate violence. “The nexus of AAP and Congress is behind the Shaheen Bagh protest. Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and his deputy have supported the protest,” Javadekar alleged. “They are misleading and poisoning the minds of the minorities,including children.” Javadekar asserted that CAA was not going to affect the citizenship of any Indian and blamed the other two parties for raising the bogey of the CAA and NRC to defeat BJP.

Title: Hinjewadi cop lands in ACB net
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune: The state anti-corruption bureau (ACB), Pune, on Friday arrested Milan Kurkute (32), a sub-inspector attached to the Hinjewadi police, while accepting a Rs25,000 bribe from the complainant in a cheating case.

An ACB team led by superintendent Rajesh Bansode laid a trap and caught Kurkute red-handed. An ACB officer said Kurkute was probing a cheating case registered with the Hinjewadi police. The complainant in the case wanted to book some bank officials too in that case. “Kurkute demanded Rs50,000 from him to book the bank officials. Later, he agreed to take Rs25,000,” the officer said.

After ACB received the complaint, they laid a trap in Wakad. “We caught Kurkute as he was accepting the money,” the officer said.

Title: 43-yr-old coming from Jodhpur in bus found dead
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: A 43-year-old man was found dead in a mysterious condition on his berth in a private passenger bus on Friday morning when it reached the Indore from Jodhpur.

The deceased was identified as Kamlesh Gurjar, a resident of Scheme no. 78. Police have registered a case.

Investigating officer ASI Pawan Kumar said that they had received information about the death from MY Hospital at 10.15 am. The bus driver had taken the body to hospital after a cleaning staff found him on his berth even after the bus reached the stop, said Kumar.

“The doctors declared him brought dead and the body was sent for a postmortem. The reason for death, however, couldn’t be ascertained and we are waiting for the postmortem report,” he said.

Gurjar’s mobile phone was found near his berth in the bus which helped in ascertaining his identity. Gurjar worked in a private company and had gone to Jaisalmer because of official work, he said.

He travelled from Jaisalmer to Jodhpur and boarded a bus to Indore. At 10 pm on Thursday, he told his brother over phone that he had boarded the bus and would reach Indore in the morning.

His kin was trying to contact him since morning but couldn’t connect until a bus staff member answered the call.

When asked whether he was suffering from any disease or had any family problems, Kumar said that for the time being, they had found nothing concrete.

Title: Gujarat: BJP MLA threatens to slap government officer
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Madhu Shrivastava

VADODARA: Gujarat Agro Industries Corporation (GAIC) chairman and MLA of the ruling BJP from Waghodiya, Madhu Shrivastava, finds himself in the midst of another controversy.

This time around it is over threats to slap an official of the revenue ministry and entering into a scuffle with media persons.

Even Shrivastava’s own party condemned his actions. Bharat Pandya, Gujarat BJP spokesperson said that, “We condemn Waghodiya MLA’s behaviour with media persons. Persons in public life must have control over their conduct.”

The issue revolves around a project to erect an idol of Lord Hanuman in the Mahadev Talav in Wadi in Vadodara. The project was funded by the Amit Educational and Charitable Trust (AECT). Shrivastava is a devotee of Lord Hanuman and the AECT has his blessings and his family members were involved in the project.

Shrivastava courted controversy when he tried to toe the line of Savli BJP MLA Ketan Inamdar by saying that officials were not heeding to MLAs, something that Inamdar had also said in his resignation that he subsequently withdrew after intervention of the party top brass.

The Waghodiya MLA said that he had been seeking permission for the 31feet high Hanuman Idol from the revenue department, but a secretary had been misleading minister of state for revenue Kaushik Patel sighting a Supreme Court order. He said that he had gone to look for the secretary, but could not find him. “Had I seen him, I would have slapped him,” Shrivastava said. He argued that while the party was willing to work, there were some officials who were creating problems.

The controversies did not end here, Shrivastava even pushed media persons and their cameras around on Friday when they asked him some uncomfortable questions. He even used abusive words in a fit of rage. Later, however, he argued that he was angered as they were speaking against Lord Hanuman whom he had been worshipping since 40 years.

Shrivastava had sought permission from the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) and the district collectorate for a 108feet high Hanuman idol. He subsequently decided to reduce the size of the idol. While VMC gave him permission for the idol, he had to seek permission from the state revenue department too as the idol was to be erected in a waterbody.

Work on the bridge connecting the embankments of the pond to the platform where the idol will be erected has already started. Shrivastava says he has already spent a large amount on the project. “I will be handing this over to the government,” he said.

Title: Young Chef Olympiad 2020 on Jan 30
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune: The sixth edition of the international culinary contest Young Chef Olympiad (YCO) 2020 will be held in the city from January 30 at International Institute of Hotel Management (IIHM), Vimannagar.

The contest will be held from January 28 to February 2 across New Delhi, Bengaluru, Pune, Goa and conclude at Kolkata. Altogether, 55 countries will participate. The winner will receive a cash prize of USD 10,000, a trophy and a gold toque. The IIHM is the institutional partner of the International Hospitality Council (IHC).

The theme this year has been borrowed from the United Nation’s seven sustainability goals — Zero Hunger. Suborno Bose, IHC CEO, said, “Pune is hosting rounds one and two of the YCO. Since our theme is sustainability, we want to educate youngsters in schools and colleges about the importance of the same.”

There will be 21 judges from across the world, including UK, France, Singapore, among others. Rupinder Singh Khurana, IIHM director, said, “On January 28, the YOC will start with an opening ceremony at New Delhi. Each country sends one participant with a mentor chef, who will shadow and help them. For rounds one and two, the contestants will be sent to different cities like New Delhi, Bengaluru, Goa and Pune. The first two rounds will decide the top ten contenders for the finale. They will all get together for the results to be declared on February 2 in Kolkata.” Every participant will have to give a presentation on how sustainability is promoted in his or her country.

International chefs Andreas Muller and Andy Varma will be technical judges in Pune. Chefs Enzo Oliveri and Karen Anand will be presentation judges in the city. Principal judge for YCO 2020 is chef Sanjeev Kapoor.

Title: High-voltage drama after AGM cries ‘hostage’ situation
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal: The power discom officials and policemen are at loggerheads in Morena town after an additional general manager of the discom was summoned to the Kotwali police station on January 22 and held captive for over three hours and pressured to waive off electricity bill worth Rs 1.47 lakh.

After the AGM apprised senor officials, the managing director of the discom Vishesh Gadphale wrote to the state’s director general of police while the power engineers’ association met the DGP on Friday and gave a strike call in Morena on Saturday.

Kotwali police station incharge, Kaushlendra Bhadoria however denied the allegations.

AGM of MP Madhya Kshetra Vidyut Vitaran Company’s, Morena city circle Rajesh Singh Bhadoria while talking to TOI said, “I was in office at around 11 am when four policemen came to me saying that TI Kotwali has summoned me. When I enquired in what connection, the cops told me it was related to some power bill. I informed my senior officials and went to the police station with a colleague in the police jeep.

At the police station, I was shown a bill and the police station in-charge asked me to waive off the bill, instructing his subordinates not to let me go. On verification, it was found that the bill had already been waived in the past. Then the police station in-charge asked his colleagues to not to let me go and came up with another bill of Rs 1.47 lakh after an hour and half. On checking the details, it was known that the consumer had not paid a single month electricity bill ever since he took the connection which was informed to the SHO. Later, at around 2.30 pm, someone called the SHO, and he asked to sign a receipt of application wherein it was written that an application was given for rectification of power bill. I wrote everything that had happened on which he snatched the paper and let us go.”

“After coming out I informed senior officials about the treatment meted out and informed our association office bearers. Action should be taken against him,” he said.

Denying the allegations, SHO Kaushlendra Bhadoria told TOI, “more than a dozen employees of police lines have been receiving inflated power bills. Bills as much as Rs 1.47 lakh are generated, but despite attempts no officer was paying heed for rectification.

“So, he was summoned. He came on his own and also left the police station on his own. No one forced him. He told us that he cannot rectify without seeing records and he needs time and left the police station,” he added.

Convener of the Madhya Pradesh Vidyut Mandal Abhiyanta Sangh VKS Parihar said, “We have met the DGP and apprised him of the situation. He had assured us of appropriate action. In the meantime, we have called for a strike in Morena town on Saturday. On Sunday, the strike would be extended to Morena district if no action is taken against the police official.”

Title: PCMC mulls startup hub
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune: The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation has partnered with the Mahratta Chamber of Commerce Industries and Agriculture (MCCIA) to transform the twin township into a startup hub and drive economic growth in the region.

The civic body would host a hackathon where start-ups and innovative companies could join hands to solve issues faced by the township.

"The theme for the hackathon is centred around bettering the lives of citizens and addressing real-life issues faced by the PCMC. Winners of the hackathon shall receive cash prizes up to Rs 9 lakh. They will also get an opportunity to implement their solutions as paid projects with the PCMC," the civic body said in joint statement with MCCIA.

Title: Delhi assembly polls: AAP, Congress poisoning minds, says Prakash Javadekar
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Prakash Javadekar

NEW DELHI: Referring to the ongoing sit-in at Shaheen Bagh against the Citizenship Amendment Act, Union minister and Delhi election in charge Prakash Javadekar on Friday accused Aam Aadmi Party and Congress of “poisoning” the minds of the minorities.

Complete coverage on Delhi elections

Addressing a press conference, Javadekar said it was for the people of Delhi to decide if they wanted “Jinnah wali azaadi” or “Bharat Mata ki jai”. He added that AAP and Congress were “instigating” violent protests against the CAA in Delhi.

With just two weeks to the Delhi assembly elections, the BJP leadership has sharpened the attack on the ruling AAP and Congress over the CAA and continuing protests at Shaheen Bagh. At his first public meeting since the polls have been announced, Union home minister Amit Shah on Thursday targeted the two parties accusing them of instigating riots over the issue.

Javadekar said the people of Delhi should ask both AAP and Congress why did they instigate violence. “The nexus of AAP and Congress is behind the Shaheen Bagh protest. Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and his deputy have supported the protest,” Javadekar alleged. “They are misleading and poisoning the minds of the minorities,including children.” Javadekar asserted that CAA was not going to affect the citizenship of any Indian and blamed the other two parties for raising the bogey of the CAA and NRC to defeat BJP.

Title: Braving chill, over 1 cr devotees take holy dip on Mauni Amavasya
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

sea of humanity: Devotees throng the Magh Mela ground on Mauni Amavasya on Friday

Allahabad: Battling the chill, over one crore devotees took holy dip at the Sangam on Mauni Amavasya during the ongoing Magh Mela on Friday.

A sea of humanity had started converging at the Mela area since Thursday evening. The third snan of ongoing mela concluded peacefully amid chants of Har Har Gangey.

While devotees took holy bath, officials of district administration showered flower petals on them from a chopper.

The city recorded maximum 21 degrees Celsius and minimum of 7.6 degrees Celsius while wind speed touched a maximum of around 40kmph.

Mela Adhikari Rajnish Kumar Mishra said, “The devotees started taking holy dip since the wee hours of Friday, the auspicious muhurat of Mauni Amavasya was between 2.17am (January 24) and 3.11am (of January 25). By Friday evening, around one crore devotees had already taken bath. The number of devotees continues to rise as the Muhurat is till wee hours of January 25.”

“According to our estimate, around 1.3 crore devotees will take bath on Mauni Amavasya. We will be able to give the final estimate on Saturday morning (January 25),” he added.

Though chilly winds swept the mela area in the morning, bright sunshine in later part of the day made things easier for devotees.

Besides devotees and kalpwasis, members of Kinnar Akhara, led by its head Laxmi Narayan Tripathi, took a holy dip at sector 5. It was a picturesque view as pilgrims filled up the space around Sangam and took holy dip in specially designed ghats. The Mela administration has set up 20 ghats.

Meanwhile, devotees who had come from other states had a tough time in reaching their destination as they were stopped about 5-6 kms away from the Mela area and asked to proceed on foot.

A visitor from Gorakhpur, Nityanand Jha, who had come to take a holy dip along with his family was angry over the fact that they had to toil for nearly 10 kms given the route diversions to reach the Sangam.

“Yeh kaisa intezam hai ki Parade maidan ka pura area khaali pada tha aur hamare saadhan (conveyance) ko bahut pahle hi rok diya,” he said.

Mela police had ensured separate entry and exit routes for pilgrims and implemented diversions on roads leading to Sangam area. Police had regulated the movement of pilgrims on five pontoon bridges with each being used for entry and exit routes. At least 50 special trains and 2,500 buses were operated to deal with the rush of devotees.

“Major bathing day of Mauni Amavasya concluded peacefully and no untoward incident was reported from any sector of Magh Mela area,” said nodal police officer, Magh mela, Ashutosh Mishra.

Title: Cop on double duty, undertrial escapes from hospital ward
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bengaluru: An undertrial admitted to Victoria Hospital escaped from the jail ward in the early hours of Thursday when his guard, who was on double duty, fell asleep. Rajan, 25, a resident of Bangarpet in Kolar district, was arrested in a theft case. He was admitted to the hospital after he complained of a health issue. Constables Venkatesh and Amar Pranje were deputed for his security.

On Wednesday, Venkatesh reported for duty and was to be replaced by Amar for night shift. After Amar called in sick, Venkatesh continued to work in the night. Around 2.20am, Rajan asked Venkatesh to remove the cuffs from his leg as he had to go to the toilet. Venkatesh dozed off and woke up around 5.20am to find Rajan had escaped. He then complained to VV Puram police . TNN

Title: Delhi: First list out for nursery admissions, second on February 12
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The first list for this year’s nursery admissions was released on Friday and the parents can register their grievances with individual schools from January 27 to February 3. The second list for the general-category aspirants will be released on February 12.

Many parents returned home disappointed in the afternoon. Sambhavi Sahni had applied in 15 schools for her daughter and was hopeful of securing at least one seat. But her daughter’s name is in the waiting list and Sahni is not sure about her next step.

The nursery admission in Delhi is held on the basis of points allotted by each school against different criteria, which can’t be discriminatory. In that list, neighbourhood — those living within 0-3km range of a school — receives the highest point.

“My daughter is part of the waiting list in most schools despite getting a good score for neighbourhood. But as she is my first child, she missed the points for certain criteria such as siblings,” said Sahni, who lives in Sector A, Vasant Kunj. There are many others like Sahni, who put in a lot of effort but have missed a seat by a few points.

For Nitin Mahajan, a resident of Greater Kailash, too, the admission has turned out to be a difficult affair. “I will let him continue at the play school and try again next year. But due to the upper-age limit, I can only try for KG class. For higher classes, the seats for general category students are fewer,” said Mahajan, who had applied in 10 schools. “This is the situation even after south Delhi having so many schools,” he added.

The admissions for the 25% reserved category section will start on Saturday. It is a centralised admission process conducted by the education department for admissions in close to 1,600 private schools.

Title: CWIS launches survey to assess sanitation needs in city slums
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: The survey by the city-wide inclusive sanitation (CWIS) initiative has commenced in slums through public participation to prevent open defecation. The assessment will include improvements needed in public and community toilet infrastructure and shall be shared with the Trichy Corporation to implement corrective measures to ensure public hygiene in around 260 slums in the city.

Trichy is one of four cities from India, and the only city from Tamil Nadu, to have been selected under CWIS in February 2019, a project involving multiple stakeholders including international agencies to evolve best sanitation practices.

CWIS working alongside Indian Institute of Human Settlements (IIHS) and Scope Trichy NGO has selected Anna Nagar, RMS Colony, in ward 39 for the first assessment exercise. The slum has a population of 500 and 100 households. Through participatory appraisals such as group discussion, transect walking and social mapping, Anna Nagar was studied by CWIS for two days since Wednesday.

“We encouraged the families in Anna Nagar slum to map their locality with Kolam powders for locating community toilet, vacant land and open defecation prone areas. Such participation will sensitise slum-dwellers to be on vigil against open defecation,” said Yohananthan S, senior associate (practice), IIHS.

Social mapping of Anna Nagar slum in front of Sellmuthu Mariamman temple has also revealed the need to equip houses with individual toilets using subsidy from the individual household latrine scheme. The field study covered the availability of water resources in the community toilet.

During the study, CWIS Trichy found out that septic tank (containment) in the community toilet in Anna Nagar is getting filled frequently. “Corrective measures are required in the septic tank or the soak pit of the community toilet. We will intimate the local body to overhaul the toilet’s infrastructure,” Yohananthan added.

CWIS sources said that such need assessment exercise will be gradually extended to all the notified and unnotified slums in the city in coming months to ensure public hygiene in slums.

Title: Behmai case verdict postponed again, likely on January 30
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kanpur: Pronouncement of judgment in Behmai massacre case was once again postponed on Friday in view of work boycott by lawyers.

The special court has now listed the matter for January 30.

According to district government counsel Rajeev Porwal, hearing was adjourned in the case as advocates are not participating in court proceedings in protest against an order of district judiciary.

“Advocates have no chambers on the premises of Kanpur Dehat court. They sit in corridor or verandah of the court to perform legal work. Recently, the judge asked them to vacate the corridor and verandah after which the court staff seized chairs and tables of some advocates,” Porwal told TOI.

He said advocates were protesting against that decision since Thursday and were not allowing anyone to enter the courtroom.

Earlier on January 18, the court had postponed the matter to January 24 as the case diary was found missing. The judicial officer had sought explanation from the clerk concerned and had asked him to find the case diary and place it in the case file.

Prior to this, on January 6, the court had fixed January 18 for delivery of judgment and January 16 for submission of ruling by the defense.

Though the case was lodged against three dozen people, including bandit Phoolan Devi, hearing is presently being heard against four dacoits —Posa, Bheekha, Vishwanath alias Krishna Kumar alias Putani and Shyam Sundar. Four dacoits are absconding and remaining, including Phoolan Devi, have died or killed in police encounters.

On February 14, 1981, Phoolan Devi, with the help of four gangs led by Ram Autar, Mustaqueem, Ram Kesh and Lalloo, raided Behmai village to avenge alleged sexual violence perpetrated on her by men of Thakur caste who dominated the village and shot 20 people.

Title: STF registers three more FIRs in Vyapam scam
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal: Madhya Pradesh STF on Friday registered three more FIRs related to Vyapam scam. Cases have been registered against three doctors of Gandhi Medical College Bhopal.

Accused have been identified as Shiv Singh, Pankaj Kumar and Sunil Sonkar. All three have been accused of using unfair means in the PMT-2009 and 2010. This agency has registered 13 cases related to the infamous scam so far.

Vyapam whistle-blowers say that STF should look into the larger conspiracy angle in this scam. Ashish Chaturvedi, claims no action has been taken so far on his complaint seeking police investigations into a missing laptop, which he says had considerable evidence against top political leaders.

Chaturvedi said this laptop belonged to accused Nitin Mohindra and was deliberately concealed by the then crime branch officials. They had lodged a formal complaint about this laptop with the Sanyogitaganj police.

“I am surprised as to why everyone is silent on this matter. STF should look into the laptop if they are serious about Vyapam scam,” he said. Madhya Pradesh STF had started investigations into the 1,200 pending Vyapam complaints that haven’t been taken up by the CBI, starting with notices to the whistle-blowers.

Chaturvedi and Indore-based whistle-blower Dr Anand Rai were summoned by the agency with documents relevant to around 150 complaints of the Vyapam ‘scam’. These were filed with the agency in the last four to five years.

Title: Swachh Indore No. 1 Smart City in green initiatives too
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: Indore has scored maximum marks on national level in a climate rankings survey conducted by Union ministry of housing and urban affairs about a year ago. The survey showcases initiatives taken by Smart Cities to ensure sustainable development and a green future.

Results of this survey were made online on Friday. “Out of 1000, Indore has scored 570.55 marks on national level, while Thane and Surat scored 479.80 marks 447.20 marks respectively,” Indore Smart City Development Limited (ISCDL)’s chief executive officer Sandeep Soni told TOI. Soni said that government conducted this survey on different indicators of all 100 Smart Cities across country in January last year.

“The government collected data from different departments on basis of various indicators and the data was analyzed for about a year only after which this score-sheet has been released,” said Soni.

“This was for the first time when government has conducted this kind of a survey, but it has not given any rankings to avoid discouraging non-performing cities,” he claimed. This survey was conducted on indicators like energy and green buildings, urban planning, green cover and biodiversity, mobility and air, water resource management and waste management. Each of these indicators comprised marks ranging from 100 to 300.

Indore has been positioned among top-three cities in four of these indicators except water resource management.

“This survey is meant to make cities aware about climate resilience and climate change which would also help them understand where they stand in terms of climate impact,” officials said.

Title: Delhi assembly polls 2020: Amit Shah must talk to protesters, say Arvind Kejriwal, Manish Sisodia
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

(Left-right) Arvind Kejriwal and Manish Sisodia

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Friday at a town hall that Union home minister Amit Shah must try to resolve the impasse at Shaheen Bhagh by holding talks with the protesters. About the AAP government’s stand on CAA, Kejriwal said, “We have expressed our opinions from time to time on different platforms and also in Parliament.”

Complete coverage on Delhi elections

Asked about the issue, deputy CM Manish Sisodia said the protests were being organised with some demands and the home minister should talk to the protesters. “It is the job of the home minister to maintain law and order in Delhi. He should answer in case of any lapses. Unfortunately, he is busy trying to find Wi-Fi on a switched-off phone and searching for CCTV cameras. I feel he should talk to the protesters,” he added.

Sisodia’s remark stating that he stood with the protesters had triggered a controversy on Thursday following which BJP functionaries attacked him and the CM. Asked on a talk show about the absence of AAP functionaries at Shaheen Bagh, Sisodia had said he stood with the protesters, but it was beyond him to open the road closed due to the protests.

AAP has been opposing CAA from a distance and maintaining silence about Shaheen Bagh for a long time. However, Sisodia’s remarks backing the protests provided fodder to BJP, which called AAP an anti-Hindu party.

Title: Court orders attaching 11 flats of Jitu Soni
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: A local court on Friday issued notice of attachment of absconding businessman Jitu Soni ’s 11 flats of horizon studio apartment.

The court of chief judicial magistrate first class Bhupendra Arya had given last opportunity to be present before court to Soni by January 17. MIG police had booked Soni under Sections 420, 467, 468, 471, 120-B of Indian Penal Code for fraud, making fake documents and conspiracy on complaint of Ravindra Pandit in December last year.

The court had issued warrant for arrest of absconding accused under Section 73 of CrPC. But, when he couldn’t be arrested, police moved court with panchnama against absconding accused.

The court issued proclamation notice under Section 82 of IPC for Soni’s presence in the court on or before January 17. But as he failed, court on Friday issued order for attachment of his property at horizon studio apartment for his presence.

Soni had been on run since November 30, when a joint team of over 200 officers from police and six other departments conducted at the residence, hotel and bar, cafe and office and registered four cases against him under IT Act, immoral trafficking and Arms Act. Later, police booked Soni in over 56 cases including fraud, forgery of documents, human trafficking, arms act, rape case, abetment to suicide at over a dozen police stations of the city.

Title: Handbooks to mark girl child day
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

State education minister Govind Singh Dotasra released two handbooks one each for teachers and students at a private hotel here on Friday to mark the National Girl Child Day. The handbooks deal with new life skill training for girls. The event was organised in association with a foundation which is running a few skill programmes in the state. Some beneficiaries of the life skills programme were also invited to the programme to narrate how they were benefitted. “I was a very shy girl before joining the programme, which includes several confidence-building exercises,” said Guddi. Reacting on the development, the minister said the state was open to taking help from NGOs and corporates with CSR funds provided that they would take up projects which are essential for the state.

Title: Human chains against CAA on Mahatma Gandhi’s death anniversary
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Mahatma Gandhi

NEW DELHI: A group of eminent citizens and activists has made a public call under the umbrella of ‘We the people of India’ to form human chains on January 30, the death anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi , to express solidarity with the nationwide protests against Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens .

Rajmohan Gandhi, grandson of Gandhi; Swaraj India chief Yogendra Yadav, social activist Medha Patkar and former chief election commissioner S Y Quraishi are among the people who have made the appeal for various activities on that day.

RTI activist Anjali Bhardwaj said people were coming out spontaneously to protest in public places. “Women-led protests are happening across India with 10 such protests taking place 24x7 in Delhi alone. ‘We the people of India’ is an open banner.... Anyone who shares our values can use this banner,” she said.

On January 30, human chains (Hum-Bharat Maala) will be formed from the afternoon at suitable venues, preferably with some association with Gandhi, said Bhardwaj. “The activity will end at 5.17pm, the exact time of Gandhiji’s martyrdom, by singing the national anthem,” she added.

Various individual activities such as day-long fasts and lighting of lamps/candles by families outside their houses have also been proposed under ‘Bharat Jodo’. The call has been endorsed by the working group members of All-India Coordination of over 100 protesting organisations across India. Some of the members are Jignesh Mewani, Kavita Krishnan, Umar Khalid and Yogendra Yadav.

Title: Delhi election 2020: Rich want to be powerful too: 164 crorepatis in the fray for Delhi polls
Content:
From left: Dharampal Lakra, Parmila Tokas, Ram Singh Netaji.

NEW DELHI: Not only are the candidates for the February 8 assembly polls richer than the last time around, but they are also older. From 143 candidates with assets worth Rs 1 crore or more fielded by AAP, BJP and Congress in 2015, the number has gone up to 164 in 2020 for the three parties or their allies.As many as 13 candidates have declared assets of over Rs 50 crore. The four richest candidates are from AAP. At the top of the list is the party’s Mundka candidate, Dharampal Lakra, with assets worth Rs 292.1 crore, making him one of the richest ever to contest an election in Delhi. In the second position is Parmila Tokas, who will fight for the RK Puram seat. She has declared assets worth Rs 80.8 crore in her own and her family’s name. Tokas is the richest among the sitting MLAs to contest the polls.Close on the heels of Tokas is AAP’s Badarpur candidate, Ram Singh Netaji, with total assets of Rs 80 crore. Netaji, formerly with Congress, is a two-time MLA. The fourth richest candidate — Raaj Kumar Anand — is fighting for the Patel Nagar seat. He has declared assets worth Rs 76 crore. At the fifth position is Priyanka Singh of Congress, who will be in a faceoff with Tokas and has declared assets of Rs 70.3 crore.The sixth, seventh and eighth richest candidates are all from BJP. Brahm Singh Tanwar from Chhatarpur with assets worth Rs 66.3 crore, Anil Goyal from Krishna Nagar with Rs 64.1 crore and Sat Prakash Rana from Bijwasan at Rs 57.4 crore. At the ninth and tenth positions are AAP candidates Dhanwanti Chandela from Rajouri Garden with assets worth 56.9 crore and Naresh Balyan from Uttam Nagar with Rs 56.3 crore.AAP’s Chandela has an impressive collection of jewellery. She and her family own 5.9kg gold worth Rs 2.3 crore, apart from 2kg silver worth about Rs 2 lakh.Of the 13 candidates in the Rs 50-crore+ club, AAP has six, followed by Congress at four and BJP three. At the other end are candidates with modest assets: the five poorest candidates have assets of Rs 1 lakh or less. The poorest also happens to be the youngest: Congress’ Rocky Tuseed, who was president of Delhi University Students’ Union in 2017. Tuseed is vying for the Rajendra Nagar seat and has declared assets worth Rs 55,574, which include bank deposits and cash in hand. He doesn’t own any vehicle, jewellery, land or property.Richer than Tuseed by a sum of Rs 326 is BJP’s Kondli candidate Raj Kumar Dhillon, who has declared assets worth Rs 55,900. Dhillon, who lives in a Kalyanpuri slum, is a shopkeeper by profession and doesn’t have any immovable assets. Of the declared assets, Rs 50,000 are in cash owned by Dhillon and his wife, apart from Rs 1,000 in bank and 100gm of silver.The third poorest candidate is AAP’s Rakhi Bidlan. In the 2015 assembly elections, she had declared assets worth Rs 18,000. That has now gone up to Rs 76,421, including Rs 40,000 cash in hand.The candidates are older too. The average age of AAP candidates was 43.1 years in 2015, but has now gone up to 47.3. For BJP, the number has gone up slightly from 51.7 in 2015 to 52.8. But for Congress, it has come down from 53.3 to 51.2 years.AAP has fielded 20 candidates below the age of 40, Congress 12 and BJP 6. Apart from Tuseed, Shubham Sharma (29) of Congress from Tughlaqabad and Kuldeep Kumar (30) of AAP from Kondli are in the 25-30 age group.The largest number of Congress and BJP candidates — 25 — are in the 51-60 age group, AAP has 21 candidates each in 41-50 and 51-60 brackets. The senior-most candidates are Narender Nath of Congress (75) from Shahdara, SC Vats (74) of BJP from Shakur Basti, Ram Niwas Goel (72) of AAP, again from Shahdara, and veteran Congressman Ashok Kumar Walia (71) from Krishna Nagar.

Title: GSVM student’s body fished out from Ganga
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Crowd at Ganga Barrage. The scooty of Amrita Singh a MBBS final year student at GSVM medical college who went ... Read More

Kanpur: The body of final year MBBS student of Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi Memorial ( GSVM ) medical college was fished out from river Ganga in Shuklaganj area of Unnao on Friday evening a day after she went missing. During the investigation, her scooty was found parked at the Ganga Barrage area.

Earlier on Friday afternoon, scores of GSVM students reached the Ganga Barrage area and staged a protest accusing police of an insensitive approach in the investigation of their missing counterpart. The students were pacified after senior police officials rushed to the site and assured them of prompt action into the missing case.

Amrita Singh (24), a native of Jhansi, who was pursuing MBBS final year at GSVM medical college in the city, disappeared under mysterious circumstances after leaving her hostel on a scooty on Thursday afternoon.

Police said the body of a girl was spotted by locals of Ravidas Nagar in Katri area in Shuklaganj area of Unnao on Friday evening, and it was confirmed to be that of the missing GSVM student Amrita. “Her body was shifted to morgue for the post-mortem examination. We are awaiting the report to corroborate cause of her death,” said SP (West) Anil Kumar.

Police said that the girl had last spoken to her mother on the mobile phone at 12 noon on Friday. “As per her mother, she was normal when she had last spoken to her,” said inspector Swaroop Nagar Ashwini Pandey. “We talked to her batch mates and teachers and they all stated that Amrita was a good student and had cordial relations with them”, he added

An investigation was underway to determine whether she took her own life, according to a police official privy to the investigation.

A group of GSVM students said they were shocked at her sudden death. Our thoughts and prayers for her family and the loved ones.

To recall, Amrita, a native of Jhansi district, had left the hostel room on Thursday afteroon. “She used to live with Anushi, her room partner at the GSVM hostel,” the inspector said. Her mobile phone and a purse were recovered from her the dicky of her two-wheeler, he added.

“Despite repeated attempt to call on her phone, when her roommate Anushi did not get any response, she alerted the GSVM authorities, who in turn informed Swaroop Nagar police,” the police officer further said.

Following this, a missing case was registered at Swaroop Nagar police station and the police had formed several teams to trace the girl.

Title: HC: Stop all commercial activities in Kuldhara
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Jaisalmer: The Rajasthan High Court bench of chief justice Indrajeet Mahanti and judge Dr Pushpendra Singh Bhati on Thursday, while hearing the public interest petition filed by Sunil Paliwal over the commercial activities in Kuldhara, resolving the case accepted the report submitted by the ASI and ordered to stop all kinds of commercial activities at the historical site. The order stops all commercial activities at the places where there are structures and where there is the memorial. However, commercial activities can be carried out at the vacant areas in the village. The court has also ordered to remove the guard room and gave detailed directions for renovation and conservation of Kuldhara village. TNN

Title: Missing boy’s body found
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Udaipur: Tension built up in Bikawas gram panchayat area of Amet block in Rajsamand on Friday when people spotted a 15-year-old boy's body hanging from a tree in the forest area. Villagers protested over the incident and suspected it to be a murder. Shantilal, son of Mangilal Bhil, resident of Bhilwadi basti in Hakyawas village, had been missing since January 16. TNN

Title: Residents plan march for opening Delhi's Kalindi Kunj road
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

A group of residents met senior police officers and gave them a memorandum

NEW DELHI: Residents of Sarita Vihar are planning to carry out a protest march on February 2 from their colony to Shaheen Bagh to demand access to Kalindi Kunj road if police fail to convince the anti-CAA protesters to allow the right of way. A group of residents met senior police officers of the district and gave them a memorandum to open the stretch to traffic.

Road number 13A at Kalindi Kunj remains shut with protesters occupying both carriageways despite giving assurance that school buses and emergency vehicles would be allowed to pass. The road opposite the protest site — which was proposed to be opened for traffic at least for local residents, like what has been done near Jamia Millia Islamia — is blocked with street art.

On Friday, a group of residents met ACP Sarita Vihar Ajab Singh with a memorandum asking police to hold a dialogue with the protesters. “They must arrive at a solution by next week, otherwise we will hold a march from Sarita Vihar to Shaheen Bagh and hold the protesters accountable. It will be a non-political rally. As residents of Sarita Vihar and Jasola, we too have the right of way just like they have the right to protest,” said Gabbar Singh Chauhan, a resident of Sarita Vihar.

Ved Nagar, a social activist and a resident of Sarita Vihar, said that the decision to hold the march was taken after a court rejected a petition seeking shifting of the anti-CAA protest to another location.

The protesters claimed that they were still in the process of deciding on whether the road would be opened for commuters. In fact, the adjacent road was fortified after representatives of the protesters assured lieutenant governor Anil Baijal about opening the road to traffic.

Some of the protesters said that even if the barricades are removed, the street art, including a 40-feet metallic map of India, cannot be shifted without the help of a crane. “It would take a few days to dismantle the map since it has been welded and fixed with semi-permanent structures dug into the ground. We will not remove it until we arrive at a consensus,” said Asif, a resident of Shaheen Bagh, who was frisking people trying to enter through the barricades.

Locals said that after the meeting with the LG, the movement of two-wheelers and pedestrians was also blocked. “I was going home after picking up my son from school when I was stopped and asked to go through Madanpur Khadar. After much pleading, the protesters allowed me to go,” said a resident.

Sandeep Kumar, the member of a village panchayat, said when they met police for a resolution, the cops expressed their helplessness in dealing with the mess.

Title: Road caves in again, civic body staff clueless
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: A portion of road measuring about 3 ft near Hukumchand Ghantaghar Square has started to cave-in posing threat to thousands of motorists those come from Geeta Bhawan Square. Officials seem to have no idea about the incident. Local shopkeepers of the area have raised a concern as the road remains busy most of the time with both two-wheeler and four-wheeler traffic.

“I noticed this cave-in three days ago and asked local traffic cop to place a barricade. The size of this pit is increasing day by day,” said a shopkeeper of the area.

This is for the second time when such an incident has occurred at the same site. In October 2019, a sewer chamber on the same spot had caved-in and IMC had to reconstruct the chamber, which was nearly 24ft deep and was constructed during Holkar era. This had affected vehicular movement of the area for about a week. Now, at least 3ft portion of the road at the same location has caved-in posing a threat to locals as well as commuters.

Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC)’s public works department officials had no idea about the incident until it was bought in their notice by TOI. “The cave-in seems to have occurred due to settlement of the road. A new chamber was constructed in the area, and the road was also reconstructed,” said IMC’s executive engineer NS Tomar.

“Instructions have been issued to restrict traffic, and repair the cave-in site,” he added.

Title: Gang attempts to rob a bank, fail to open strongroom
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: A five-member gang attempted to rob a bank at Kasturba village, Tejaji Nagar on early hours of Thursday.

Two members of the gang held the security guard captive for hours. Police station in charge Neeraj Kumar Meda said that incident happened around 2 am at Kasturba village branch of Bank of India.

The guard on duty Nand Kishore Yadav heard a sound behind the bank. He went there to check but was attacked by the gang members and became unconscious. They tied him with a rope and he remained there lying unconscious until dawn. As the sun began to rise, the thieves fled the spot, he said.

The miscreants began breaking the rear wall of the bank. They entered the bank and reached the strongroom which had Rs 50 lakh cash but failed to open it, he said.

Police found a two minute long CCTV footage of a miscreant carrying a screwdriver in his hand. The footage, however, is not clear. The thief was wearing a cap and had covered his face. “His identity couldn’t be ascertained yet. We have registered a case in the matter,” he said.

The statement of the security guard and other officials were recorded. In his statement, the guard said that he had seen two thieves, who attacked him. But he is clueless about rest of the details, he said.

Title: High court notice to Rajasthan govt over relief to acid attack victims
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A division bench of Rajasthan High Court on Friday issued notices to the state government for not giving compensation to acid attack victims in accordance with the scheme of National Legal Services Authority and not checking the sale of acids by shopkeepers without following rules.

Hearing a PIL advocating the need of framing rules and regulations to safeguard the rights and interests of acid victims and on the malpractice of selling acids without maintaining a register of buyers, the bench comprising Justice Sabina and Justice NS Dhaddha issued notices to the state government including chief secretary, secretary of department of personnel, principal secretary (home affairs), principal secretary of social justice and principal secretary of medical and health. Petitioner Shalini Sheoran, an advocate, in her petition stated that since the state government had not yet framed rules pursuant to the Poisons Act, 1919, no action has been taken to curb the sale of acids by shopkeepers without licenses.

“For selling poison, the shopkeeper should have the license and should also maintain a register of those purchasing it. Also no compensation has been given to acid attack victims,” she said.

She added that no posts are kept reserved nor been carried forward for acid attack survivors in terms of Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016. “Acid attack victims should be treated as disabled and there should a separate reservation for them. Thus they are deprived of various government schemes,” she added.

“The posts for the acid attack victims need to be identified and also they are entitled to get free treatment in private hospitals and should also be made aware of it,” she added.

He doesn’t own any vehicle, jewellery, land or property.Richer than Tuseed by a sum of Rs 326 is BJP’s Kondli candidate Raj Kumar Dhillon, who has declared assets worth Rs 55,900. Dhillon, who lives in a Kalyanpuri slum, is a shopkeeper by profession and doesn’t have any immovable assets. Of the declared assets, Rs 50,000 are in cash owned by Dhillon and his wife, apart from Rs 1,000 in bank and 100gm of silver.The third poorest candidate is AAP’s Rakhi Bidlan. In the 2015 assembly elections, she had declared assets worth Rs 18,000. That has now gone up to Rs 76,421, including Rs 40,000 cash in hand.The candidates are older too. The average age of AAP candidates was 43.1 years in 2015, but has now gone up to 47.3. For BJP, the number has gone up slightly from 51.7 in 2015 to 52.8. But for Congress, it has come down from 53.3 to 51.2 years.AAP has fielded 20 candidates below the age of 40, Congress 12 and BJP 6. Apart from Tuseed, Shubham Sharma (29) of Congress from Tughlaqabad and Kuldeep Kumar (30) of AAP from Kondli are in the 25-30 age group.The largest number of Congress and BJP candidates — 25 — are in the 51-60 age group, AAP has 21 candidates each in 41-50 and 51-60 brackets. The senior-most candidates are Narender Nath of Congress (75) from Shahdara, SC Vats (74) of BJP from Shakur Basti, Ram Niwas Goel (72) of AAP, again from Shahdara, and veteran Congressman Ashok Kumar Walia (71) from Krishna Nagar.

Content:
The organisers, under the banner of ‘Dilli Dhadakne Do’, will be conducting a similar exercise in Delhi’s mark... Read More
