Title: Bhupendrasinh Chudasama’s poll win: Gujarat HC reserves verdict
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhupendrasinh Chudasama

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Friday completed hearings and reserved its order on a petition challenging the victory of state education minister Bhupendrasinh Chudasama in the 2017 assembly elections from Dholka constituency.

Before he delivers his verdict, Justice Paresh Upadhyay asked all parties, including the Congress candidate and petitioner Ashwin Rathod and Chudasama, to supply their written submissions by February 10.

Rathod challenged Chudasama’s 327-vote victory arguing that the returning officer committed errors during the counting. He claimed that more than 400 ballot votes, were not counted and were invalidated by the returning officer, Dhaval Jani.

During the proceedings, Chudasama was rebuked by the court for his filing an affidavit in the Supreme Court in connection with this case and raising questions about the credibility of the court. The judge came down heavily on Chudasama for his lack of confidence in the judiciary, particularly since Chudasama himself is the Gujarat law minister. Another highlight of the case was the deposition of the returning officer, Jani, who admitted to various errors during counting of votes. The HC had noticed that the returning officer did not follow Election Commission of India (ECI) guidelines during the vote counting and the HC made adverse observations about the officer’s conduct. The state government had to withdraw the promotion it gave Jani because of the HC’s observations. The HC also ordered the government to take action against Jani for the alleged irregularities that came on to the court’s record.

Title: Parliamentary standing committee discusses scope for increasing country’s cotton productivity
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: The parliamentary standing committee on agriculture , on the second day of its tour to Nagpur visited the Indian Council of Agriculture Research (ICAR) labs in the city. These included institutions like the Central Institute of Cotton Research (CICR) and National Research Centre for Citrus (NRCC).

At CICR, the members of parliament (MPs) discussed the scope of increasing cotton productivity in the country by using newer variety of cotton seeds. At NRCC too, information was sought on the probability of increasing orange cultivation in the region and development of new varieties of citrus fruits.

On Thursday, a meet to review the prime minister’s crop insurance scheme was held. Suggestions were invited about the changes needed in the scheme. Farm activists had demanded that the geographical unit for calculating crop losses should be reduced.

Title: 4 controversial irri tenders worth Rs2,473cr cancelled
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: Yet another decision of the BJP regime has been reversed by the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government.

In the latest move, four controversial tenders worth Rs2,473 crore for building piped distribution network and lift irrigation system (LIS), under Jigaon dam project on Purna river in Buldhana district, have been cancelled. TOI had access to the cancellation order.

The tenders, issued in September 2019, were among the last decisions of the previous government. The move had drawn flak because the tenders for building distribution network and LIS, needed at a later stage, were issued even though the main head work of the dam remains to be built.

After the head work, land coming under submergence has to be acquired followed by resettlement of project affected persons (PAPs). Building distribution network and LIS comes at a much later stage, said sources. TOI had reported the matter on December 27, 2019.

The Contractors and Builders Association of Vidarbha had sent a complaint letter to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and water resources development (WRD) minister Jayant Patil alleging that the tenders were issued only to accommodate a group of contractors. When the fresh cost for building the dam was approved in August last year, the amount needed for the four tenders was especially included.

Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar was also under scanner for other tenders granted under this project during his tenure in the Congress-NCP government. He was later granted a clean chit in the case by anti-corruption bureau (ACB). The ACB inquiry continues against private contractors.

Pravin Mahajan, president of contractors’ association, said apart from Thackeray and Patil, he had written letters to the WRD secretary IS Chahal, former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis and Girish Mahajan, WRD minister in previous government, too.

“It is not that the distribution network and LIS will not be needed, but the works need to be taken stage wise. At this stage, acquisition of majority of land coming under submergence remains to be done. After that the PAPs have to be rehabilitated. The question of distribution network and LIS comes later,” he said.

“The hurry in clearing the tender proposals has been apparent. In a single day, on September 3, 2019, the cases were cleared from the level of executive engineer, superintending engineer, and then by chief engineer. For clearing the papers, at least 1,000 pages need to be gone through first, which could curiously happen in one day in this case,” said Mahajan. The point has been mentioned in the complaint letter filed by him, he said.

Mahajan said the association has suggested that works should be split so that it is not blocked up if a single contractor gets a chunk of order. Instead of engineering procurement and contract (EPC) tenders, Vidarbha Irrigation Development Corporation should issue B1 type tenders in which the contractor has to only take up work implementation, having no say in design.

The Jigaon dam project was cleared in 1989, at a cost of Rs394 crore. In August 2019, the cost was hiked to Rs13,000 crore. This was the third hike. Though a state-level technical committee had only recommended hike up to over Rs11,000 crore, the state government okayed an estimate of Rs13,000 crore. This was done to accommodate the four tenders that have been cancelled now, said Mahajan.

Title: Mining case: No court relief for Singhvi & co
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Jaipur: In a major jolt to former IAS officer Ashok Singhvi and six other accused of multi-crore mining racket, the Rajasthan High Court on Friday dismissed 11 revision and criminal petitions.

The bench comprising Justice AK Gaur also gave a nod to the cognisance taken by the special court dealing with ED cases In these petitions, the accused including Singhvi challenged the order of the special court of ED cases dated January 21, 2019 in which it summoned them with non-bailable arrest warrants after taking cognizance of the Prevention of Money laundering Act. In the petitions, the accused had also pleaded to convert their non-bailable warrants into bailable ones. The accused maintained that there were no evidence against them for making the offence of money laundering, thus the lower court order against them is contrary to the law.

The defence said in this particular case, Singhvi had neither demanded nor taken money. “In a money laundering case, prosecution must bring substantial evidence that money has been taken by the accused and is been used in illegal activities,” said the defence.

On behalf of the ED, additional solicitor general RD Rastogi and advocate Anand Sharma said the court had taken cognisance against the accused on the complaint by the agency investigating money laundering. TNN

Title: Illegal basement filled with concrete
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) on Friday conducted an anti-encroachment drive in Veer Sawarkar Market area and removed illegal construction from a three-storeyed building on busy MG Road area.

A team of IMC’s removal wing on Friday morning reached the area and started removing illegal construction from basement of a residential building located in front of Ganesh Cap Mart.

When the team reached the area and started the action, building owner and his relatives came out and started arguing with officials claiming that there was no violation in the construction.

This halted action for about half an hour and the drive could be resumed only after intervention of senior IMC officials.

“The building owner was found to be making constructions in the basement of the building for commercial use, while there was no permission obtained by him from IMC. The entire basement was illegal and we had to fill it,” IMC’s additional commissioner Shringar Shrivastava said.

He said that two teams along with an earth moving machine were pressed into service.

“The concerned building owner was issued a notice about two months ago with instructions to stop construction, but it did not stop. This left us with nothing but to take action,” he said.

On being asked if other buildings of the area also had the same violation, Shrivastava said that the action was taken on basis of a complaint. “Other buildings would also be checked and action would be taken accordingly,” he added.

During action, officials spotted other violations in the building and on basis of owner’s request, three days’ were given by officials to clear all illegal portions.

Title: Meat shops to remain closed in city on Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kanpur: All meat shops (mutton, fish) in the city will remain closed on the occasion of Republic Day (January 26). According to veterinary officer of KMC Dr AK Singh, the shops would remain closed in compliance with the state government's order.

Meanwhile, the anti-encroachment squad of zone-4 on Friday took action against two building owners for dumping building material at Brijendra Swarup Park and realized Rs 37,000 from them. The squad also realized Rs 12,000 from a builder in the Arya Nagar area for dumping building material on road.

A fine of Rs 25,000 was realized from NLK School at Khalasi Line for placing generator and dumping building material on the road.

Title: Cops foil abduction bid of girl
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Alwar: Bharatpur police foiled an abduction attempt of a Class XII girl here on Friday. The incident took place under Udyog Nagar police station area.

According to police, “The girl was returning home when a car stopped in front of her and the accused took her in the car with the intention to sexually assault her. The girl managed to roll down the window and shouted for help. The traffic police personnel fortunately heard her and gave chase. After chasing the car for about a kilometre, the accused stopped and fled leaving the girl behind,” said a police official. Although the girl was returned home safe, the cops are yet to find the alleged abductors.

Title: Delhi polls 2020: Activists demand pledge for clean air from candidates
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

The organisers, under the banner of ‘Dilli Dhadakne Do’, will be conducting a similar exercise in Delhi’s mark... Read More

Title: Chaos reigns at Shaheen Bagh, scribes attacked
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Journalist Deepak Chaurasia and a Doordarshan reporter and a cameraman were attacked and beaten up by a group of protesters at Shaheen Bagh when they were covering live programmes from the site on Friday afternoon.

A ruckus broke out when some protesters tried to stop the journalists from shooting at the venue. They even broke three cameras and confiscated another before allowing the journalists to leave. The videos of both the incidents have gone viral on social media.

A TOI photojournalist was also threatened when he tried to click photos of the men trying to stop a two-wheeler from crossing by the opposite lane.

Later, an FIR was registered at the Shaheen Bagh police station on Chaurasia’s complaint. Chaurasia told the cops that he had informed the protesters about his programme and had even made an announcement from the stage asking the protesters to stay away from the crew. “When we reached, some of the organisers even reached out to our crew and escorted us to the stage. They then introduced us to the crowd, following which the programme started,” Chaurasia said.

However, when Chaurasia started his show, a few men suddenly approached him from behind, placed their hands on the camera lens and asked him to leave. They then thrashed the cameramen, Vikas Rai, Kamal Kishore and Harish Sharma and snatched their equipment. “We were dragged out of the venue to a shop at a basement when someone stopped the protester. They kept threatening us and sought our cameras,” said Chaurasia.

The eyewitnesses said the others at the site tried to stop them, but the group kept thrashing the crew, who then ran into a CRPF van parked at a distance for protection. The crowd was finally dispersed after police intervention. A case under sections of assault, criminal intimidation, criminal conspiracy and robbery was registered. Police said that they have also received a complaint from the Doordarshan reporter and an FIR would be lodged.

Title: Delhi elections 2020: Pact with LJP, JD(U) will help BJP get 95% of migrant votes, says Manoj Tiwari
Content:
Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari on Friday said that the strategic alliance with Janata Dal (United) and Loktantrik Janashakti Party (LJP) for the assembly elections has been done to woo Poorvanchali voters, who form over 30% of the vote bank.Tiwari said BJP has given tickets to 11 Poorvanchali candidates this time, up from five in the 2015 polls, which will pay dividends. He added that chief minister Arvind Kejriwal’s barbs on him and Poorvanchalis at least thrice in the last 4-5 months have angered the migrant population from Bihar and eastern Uttar Pradesh. As a result, the saffron party is likely to get “at least 95%” of their votes.With a larger representation, Tiwari said the community feels that they are respected in the saffron party. “The people of Poorvanchal have never been given tickets in such a large number by any party. They always had a feeling of being ignored during the ticket distribution process. This will definitely help us,” said Tiwari.There are more than 20 seats where Poorvanchali voters are in substantial numbers and their strategic voting may influence the poll outcome. While BJP’s oldest ally, Shiromani Akali Dal, has stayed away from the polls, JD(U) has got two seats — Burari and Sangam Vihar — and LJP the reserved constituency of Seemapuri. Both Burari and Sangam Vihar have a large population of migrants from Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.The state BJP chief said that Poorvanchalis were feeling insulted by an alleged campaign run by AAP against him. “Kejriwal insulted Poorvanchalis thrice. First, he said that people from Bihar buy a Rs 500 (train) ticket and come to Delhi to get free treatment here, which increases the burden on the city. Then he said if NRC is implemented in Delhi, Manoj Tiwari (who is a Poorvanchali) will have to go,” Tiwari added.“NRC, if it is ever implemented, will be to identify illegal immigrants from other countries. Kejriwal’s statement was meant to show that all Poorvanchalis are illegal immigrants. He also made fun of Bhojpuri songs, something that made a small-town boy like me a popular face. On December 8, Kejriwal himself will become a joke,” said Tiwari.

Title: 3 robberies in 24 hrs push looting cases to 13 in Jan
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal: Despite strengthened security arrangements ahead of Republic Day, three looting cases were reported in the city on Thursday — all in a span of six hours. Cases of looting have seen a rise in the New Year — with as many as 13 incidents reported in January.

In the first incident, four unidentified accused on two bikes attacked a 23-year-old collection agent, who was on a two-wheeler, with a baseball bat. The accused robbed Rs 24,000 from the youth and fled. The visor of the victim’s helmet broke in the attack, and its shards injured his face. The youth’s hand was also fractured, said police.

Police said the victim, Kailash Lodhi (23), works as a collection agent at an automobile company. He told TOI that he was returning home on Thursday evening with the day’s cash collection in his pocket when the incident occurred. He said he reached Vivekanand Colony in Piplani around 6:30pm. As he reportedly stopped to urinate, four unidentified accused reached the spot on two bikes. They hit him on the helmet with a baseball bat and both his hands, before robbing him of the cash and fleeing. Lodhi immediately reached the police station to file a complaint. SHO Piplani, Rakesh Shrivastava, said the police have filed a case and recovered CCTV footage from the area, where they were spotted. Police have got some leads and the accused will be nabbed soon, he said.

Meanwhile, on the other side of the city in Hanumanganj, two bike-borne accused allegedly robbed the smartphone of a 34-year-old Gwalior-based sales executive, who was in Bhopal for work. When the victim, Ajay Sharma, resisted the attackers, the accused allegedly kicked him and fled. The youth was near Alpana Trisection on Hamidia Road at 10:30pm, when the incident took place.

A police personnel deployed at a nearby spot noted down the bike registration number and cops have tracked the attackers and they will be nabbed soon, said police. In another incident, two bike-borne accused allegedly snatched the mobile phone from a 36-year-old kiosk owner while he was walking home.

Investigation officer, SI Raghavendra Singh, said that the victim Naved Khan, 36, a resident of Islami Gate in Shahjehabanbad, in his complaint, stated he was walking home and reached Sindhi Colony Square around 11.45pm.

He was answering a call when two bikers reportedly came from behind and snatched his mobile. Speaking on the rise in the number of looting incidents, DIG Irshad Wali said the police have got some vital clues in all the cases and the accused will be arrested soon. Some suspects have already been detained, he added.

Police have announced a reward of Rs20,000 for any information on the three cases.

Title: Memorials of language martyrs in neglect
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: While various political parties and Tamil organizations will be carrying out a rally today (Saturday) to commemorate the sacrifice of language martyrs against Hindi imposition in Tamil Nadu, there are no information boards at the memorial in the city to convey the significance of the historic anti-Hindi agitation that shaped the political course of Tamil Nadu in the late 1960s.

The memorials of language martyrs namely Keezhapaluvur Chinnasamy (1937-1964) and Viralimalai Shanmugam (1943-1965) near Uyyakondan canal in Thennur were installed to commemorate their sacrifice for the cause of Tamil language. Chinnasamy immolated self at Trichy on January 25, 1964, while Viralimalai Shanmugam killed self by consuming poison on February 25, 1965, both for a common cause, in protest against the Hindi imposition.

The memorial is filled with liquor bottles and litters due to lack of periodical maintenance except during the commemoration day. “Several representations have been made to the government to install information boards at the memorials but in vain. There is not even a proper shelter at the memorials,” N Rasa Ragunathan, central committee member, Tamil Kalai Ilakkiya Peravai.

Similarly, a granite stone installed at the Palakkarai bridge here on November 2006 naming the bridge after the two language martyrs Chinnasamy and Shanmugam is currently exploited to stick posters. Pro-Tamil groups that have been demanding the restoration of the granite stones claimed that Trichy Corporation and highways department have been blaming each other in maintaining the bridge. Trichy Corporation officials when contacted have agreed to look into the demand of installing information and signage boards at the memorial.

Title: Jawaharlal Nehru University classes on, mostly in the open
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Sharad Baviskar, a professor at Centre for French and Francophone Studies, takes a class on French literature ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Even though the winter semester at Jawaharlal Nehru University commenced a little over 10 days ago, classes have yet to pick up steam. Most of these have been organised outside the classrooms. The backlog from the monsoon semester, marred by constant strikes and boycotts, has yet to be cleared.

While vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar has, in a series of statements, maintained that normalcy has returned to the campus, teachers allege that there is no clarity about the future. After the students secured an interim relief from Delhi high court over registration on Friday, there is some hope that the months of agitation may end soon.

JNUSU had given a call for the boycott of classes and end-semester exams in December in protest against the hostel fee hike effected after an Inter-Hall Administration meeting on October 28.

On January 16, Kumar stated at a press conference: “A great number of faculty members are actively working to make sure that academic interests of the students are addressed.” Teachers, however, disagree. The unofficial line of JNU Teachers’ Association has been to either refuse to conduct classes altogether or do it of their own accord after discussions with students.

On Friday, too, some classes were held in the open. Sharad Baviskar, a professor of Centre for French and Francophone Studies, took a class on French literature on the stairs of Language Laboratory. He told TOI that he was clearing the backlog from the previous semester.

Many classes for graduate, postgraduate and pre-PhD courses were taking place in the same manner, “but only after coordinating with the teachers and only to clear the backlog from the previous semester”, said Raj Kishor, a student at School of Languages.

Preeti Umrao, a student at School of Life Sciences, said even exams had started, but these were not being conducted online or via WhatsApp as desired by VC. “MSc and pre-PhD scholars are coordinating with the teachers and planning their own tests. In our school, we sought a week’s buffer to finish the syllabus from the previous semester. We are now waiting for JNUTA’s call to start the classes for the new session,” she said.

A student at School of Computer & Systems Sciences, who wanted to remain anonymous, said: “We have been asked to clear the exams and, then, start the classes for the next semester.”

Some students of management, engineering and Sanskrit, however, claimed that it had been business as usual all along and there was no backlog of classes.

Title: IIM-Bangalore hikes MBA fee from Rs 21 lakh to Rs 23 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indian Institute of Management-Bangalore (IIMB) will increase the fee for its flagship MBA programme for the u... Read More

BENGALURU: Indian Institute of Management-Bangalore ( IIMB ) will increase the fee for its flagship MBA programme for the upcoming academic year from Rs 21 lakh to Rs 23 lakh for domestic students. The batch size is expected to touch 505 this time.

The increase in intake is due to introduction of a course called MBA Business Analytics. Currently, there are 439 students in the PG programme. While the institute is yet to decide on the break up for both the courses, MBA (BA) is expected to have around 60 seats.

Students can opt for either MBA or MBA (BA) during the interview round. The new MBA (BA) programme aims to help students define problems, use analytical tools and techniques to identify patterns, gain insights and develop business strategies. “In the first year, the two programmes are significantly common,” said G Raghuram, director, IIMB.

The other reason for increase in intake is to accommodate the quota for the Economically Weaker Section (EWS). Apart from IIMB, even other IIMs have increased their batch size. IIM Indore, for instance, intends to increase it 540 from 450. However, the fee remains the same at Rs 16 lakh. At IIM-Udaipur, the intake will go up from 282 to 325. A fee increase is proposed and will be finalised only next week. IIM-Lucknow is also proposing a fee hike and higher intake.

Title: Rs 267cr road project DPR awaits civic seal
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Aurangabad: The civic body is yet to complete the detailed project report for the Rs 267 crore road project, which was supposed to be sent to the state government for approval.

The construction of 30 roads under Rs 100 crore road project has also not been completed.

The previous state government had announced the Rs 267 crore road project in January 2019, but it has not reached its first phase due to the ignorance of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation.

After the directive of the state government, the AMC is now identifying and inspecting the development plan (DP) roads in the city.

Around 100 city roads will be taken up under the project. Once the inspection is completed, the DPR will be sent to the state government.

The Public Works Department (PWD) will scrutinise the DRP for technical sanction. Once, the DPR gets the approval from the state administration, tendering will be done. It would take at least six months for the project to begin.

Citizens have to suffer daily due to the poor condition of roads.

Meanwhile, three years after the approval of Rs 100 crore for the cement concretisation of the roads by the state government, the AMC has not been able to complete the project. Of the 30 roads, 17 have been completed, construction of the nine are in process and four are stuck due to encroachments, electric poles on the road and other issues.

AMC executive engineer Hemant Kolhe said that the project will be completed before March. “The work has gained progress over the last two months. Issues like shifting of poles, utilities and encroachments are obstacles in the way of the construction,” Kolhe said.

When asked the quality of the project, Kolhe said that the project has been scrutinised by the Project Management Consultant and a third party inspected it so there is no question of poor quality.

Title: Delhi elections 2020: Pact with LJP, JD(U) will help BJP get 95% of migrant votes, says Manoj Tiwari
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari on Friday said that the strategic alliance with Janata Dal (United) and Loktantrik Janashakti Party (LJP) for the assembly elections has been done to woo Poorvanchali voters, who form over 30% of the vote bank.

Complete coverage on Delhi elections

Tiwari said BJP has given tickets to 11 Poorvanchali candidates this time, up from five in the 2015 polls, which will pay dividends. He added that chief minister Arvind Kejriwal’s barbs on him and Poorvanchalis at least thrice in the last 4-5 months have angered the migrant population from Bihar and eastern Uttar Pradesh. As a result, the saffron party is likely to get “at least 95%” of their votes.

With a larger representation, Tiwari said the community feels that they are respected in the saffron party. “The people of Poorvanchal have never been given tickets in such a large number by any party. They always had a feeling of being ignored during the ticket distribution process. This will definitely help us,” said Tiwari.

There are more than 20 seats where Poorvanchali voters are in substantial numbers and their strategic voting may influence the poll outcome. While BJP’s oldest ally, Shiromani Akali Dal, has stayed away from the polls, JD(U) has got two seats — Burari and Sangam Vihar — and LJP the reserved constituency of Seemapuri. Both Burari and Sangam Vihar have a large population of migrants from Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.

The state BJP chief said that Poorvanchalis were feeling insulted by an alleged campaign run by AAP against him. “Kejriwal insulted Poorvanchalis thrice. First, he said that people from Bihar buy a Rs 500 (train) ticket and come to Delhi to get free treatment here, which increases the burden on the city. Then he said if NRC is implemented in Delhi, Manoj Tiwari (who is a Poorvanchali) will have to go,” Tiwari added.

“NRC, if it is ever implemented, will be to identify illegal immigrants from other countries. Kejriwal’s statement was meant to show that all Poorvanchalis are illegal immigrants. He also made fun of Bhojpuri songs, something that made a small-town boy like me a popular face. On December 8, Kejriwal himself will become a joke,” said Tiwari.

Title: Nithyananda case: Father seeks footage from high commission
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nithyananda

AHMEDABAD: The petitioner who has sought custody of his two missing daughters from Nithyananda and his associates, asked the Gujarat high court on Friday to direct the ministry of external affairs to provide CCTV footage from the Indian high commission in Kingston, Jamaica.

The petitioner’s daughters swore their last affidavits at the Indian high commission in Kingston on January 8. A high commission attache (admin and DDO) M P Khar, was witness to the affirmation of the affidavits. The petitioner sought directions to the foreign ministry to get video footage and other details from the high commission, to know what had happened on January 8, when his daughters visited the office.

The petitioner filed another application in the high court, and said that the CCTV footage is required to know who accompanied them to the high commission, and whether the officer, Khar, ascertained the wish and free will of his two daughters.

The petitioner claimed that his younger daughter was in the Ahmedabad ashram and upon his filing a police complaint on November 1, 2019, was “smuggled” by Nithyananda and his associates from Ahmedabad to Kingston via Nepal, Mauritius, Equador, Trinidad, Virginia and Barbados.

The high court said it would hear the issue further on February 4.

Title: HC issues contempt notice to Sehora ADJ
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

BHOPAL/JABALPUR: In a rare instance, a single-judge bench of MP high court has issued contempt notice to an additional district & sessions judge (ADJ) of Sehora town in Jabalpur for non-compliance of its order.

The single-judge bench of Justice JP Gupta sought to know why ADJ Vikram Singh did not comply with an order issued by him and why contempt of court proceedings should not be undertaken against him. The case would now come up for hearing on February 4.

In a revision petition, Ashok Kumar Yadav , a retired employee of Gun Carriage Factory, Jabalpur, had prayed the court that he has been charged for abduction and murder of a child by Gosalpur police station and a chargesheet was presented in the court of ADJ, Sehora. The presiding judge RK Dinkar famed charges against him under same sections of the IPC.

Yadav had filed a revision petition against framing of charges by the court.

During hearing, the high court had asked the ADJ court to pass a ‘speaking order’ seeking evidences and charges framed against petitioner Ashok Yadav. However, Vikram Singh, the new ADJ judge at Sehora, framed charges against Yadav without passing a ‘speaking order’.

Following this, Yadav moved the MP high court again accusing the ADJ of contempt of court. In response, the court issued show-cause notice to ADJ, Sehora.

Title: RNP tigress charges at tourist vehicles, safaris shifted to another zone
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Jaipur: Safaris in Ranthambore National Park (RNP)’s zone-1 were shifted to another zone on Friday after a three-year-old tigress, Sultana, allegedly chased vehicles, including a forest department’s Gypsy, twice earlier in the day.

This is the third incidence of the tigress charging at tourist vehicle.

The RNP management issued an order — a copy of which is with TOI — closing safaris in the particular zone until further notice. Authorities are looking into the matter.

“On Friday, Sultana first charged at a forest department Gypsy which had ventured too close to her near Khariya Ki Talai. After a while, she furiously ran behind a canter as well,” said a source. As per norms, a vehicle should maintain a minimum distance of 50m from any wild animal.

Even as the forest department claimed that the closure was for wildlife management, sources cited the move as a precautionary measure since the same tigress had charged at an open top vehicle carrying tourists last month. A video of the incident on December 1, 2019, had gone viral on social media. It showed Sultana coming perilously close to the tourists before sprinting alongside their vehicle.

Sources said Sultana’s behaviour will be monitored and the zone shall remain closed for visitors till further orders. For now, the safaris scheduled at zone-1 will take place at zone-4. In October last year, Sultana had suffered a thorn injury and disappeared for a while before returning to zone-1 in December.

Title: AAI to fund boxing ring at Anna Stadium under CSR programme
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: The Airport Authority of India, Trichy, will provide funds to build a boxing ring at the Anna Stadium in Trichy under its Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) programme. Airport director K Gunasekaran along with heads of various departments of the airport handed over a cheque of Rs 13.17 lakh to district collector S Sivarasu at the collector office here on Thursday to execute the project. The Public Works Department (PWD) will be responsible to build the facility, officials said.

“We have handed over a cheque of Rs 13.17 lakh to the district collector S Sivarasu to establish a boxing ring with shelter and to procure necessary accessories like glove and punching bags. So far, there is no such permanent facility at Anna Stadium. So, this boxing ring would be beneficial for students who aspire to become a boxer,” K Gunasekaran added.

When contacted, district sports officer K Prabhu told TOI that more than 50 students practise at Anna Stadium and the new facility would be useful for them. Trichy airport has already spent crores under the CSR programme, from construction of toilets at two government girls’ schools, ambulance for a primary health centre in Pudukottai and compound wall for a government school.

Title: PIL in Gujarat HC against PSU bank strikes
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: A few days after public sector banks gave a two-day strike call for January 31 and February 1, several trade and industry associations in Gujarat came together to file a public interest litigation (PIL) in the high court against such repetitive strike calls given by bank employees and officers. The trade and industry bodies have cited severe difficulties in carrying out financial transactions in the wake of such strikes.

Bank employees have also called for another three-day strike from March 11 and have also threatened an indefinite strike from April 1 onwards if their demands over wage-revision and re-initiating recruitments in are not adhered to.

“The petition has been filed in the interest of consumers as well as trade and industry bodies because hampering of financial transactions due to frequent strike by bankers adversely impacts business operations from time to time. Payment commitments, issuing of letters of credit – everything gets delayed which impacts goodwill of traders and industrialists,” said Jayendra Tanna, president, Gujarat Trader Federation (GTF), which is one of the eight petitioners in the case. “Such illegal strikes would cause huge financial losses to the nation and strictest actions are proposed to be taken against the employees who support strikes,” states the petition. When contacted, Janak Rawal, general secretary, MGBEA, said, “Bank employees have so far gone on strike in public interest, to strengthen banks and economy. However, bankers have gone on strike for the first time for their wage revision which is pending since two years. We hope trade and industry supports us in our endeavour.” MGBEA estimates suggest that over the two-day strike on January 31 and February 1, transactions worth Rs 30,000 crore may be hampered.

Title: Ready for 143 days, CM to open Metro Reach III on Jan 28 through video link
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: After a prolonged wait of 144 days, the Reach III of Nagpur Metro (Sitabuldi to Lokmanya Nagar stretch) will be opened by chief minister Uddhav Thackeray, Union minister for housing and urban affairs Hardeep Singh Puri and Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari on January 28 through video link.

Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety (CMRS) had cleared the stretch on September 5, 2019. Prime Minister Narendra Modi was slated to open the line on September 7. However, his visit was cancelled due to heavy rainfall warning. Since then, MahaMetro was waiting for VIPs to open the line.

Thackeray was expected to inaugurate the line during winter session of the state legislature in December, but it was postponed due to unknown reasons.

Both former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis and his successor Uddhav Thackeray are responsible for the delay, said a Metro official requesting anonymity. “After PM Modi’s visit to Nagpur was cancelled, he could have opened the line through video link, but CM Fadnavis wanted his physical presence at the function. Then Uddhav Thackeray first decided to inaugurate it in person, but later changed his plans and decided to do it through video link. This could have been done at least a month ago,” said the official.

On why MahaMetro waited for so long when PM and the CM were not coming to the city to open the Reach III, a spokesperson said, “We do not decide the date of opening. It was decided by the chief minister’s office. We received communication from Mumbai on Friday evening.”

Metro officials said that Thackeray and Puri would flag off the train from Subhash Nagar station at 10.45am through video link. Gadkari would be present at the station. State urban development minister Eknath Shinde, home minister Anil Deshmukh, guardian minister Nitin Raut, dairy development minister Sunil Kedar and mayor Sandip Joshi will also be present on the occasion.

Reach III is 11 km long and has 6 stations — Lokmanya Nagar, Vasudev Nagar, Subhash Nagar, Institution of Engineers, Jhansi Rani Square and Sitabuldi Interchange.

A Metro official said that many educational institutions and Hingna MIDC area were situated near Lokmanya Nagar station and they would get fast connectivity to Sitabuldi. “Vasudev Nagar station is also quite far from Sitabuldi and people living in that area will also benefit from the Metro,” he added.

Work on Reach III had started in December 2016. Trial run was held from Subhash Nagar to Sitabuldi on August 15, 2019. The CMRS inspection for the entire stretch was held on August 30, 2019. The commissioner issued the clearance certificate on September 5.

Title: Watchers keep litterers at bay near Uyyakondan canal
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: The appointment of sanitary watchers by Trichy Corporation to prevent public littering and open urination along the banks of Uyyakondan canal, passing along Kulimikkarai road, has been yielding the desired results for residents of the civic body. The sanitary workers along with self-help groups have been surveying the spots prone to littering and have kept polluters at bay.

Falling under ward 50 of K Abishekapuram zone, Kulimikkarai road connecting Anna Nagar in Thennur with Alwarthope is frequently polluted by the public and commercial establishments. Recently, the stretch was cleaned by corporation workers and volunteers with Citizens For Uyyakondan (CFU) and the walls of the corporation’s micro compost centre was painted with awareness messages. However, as the littering continued, the sanitary workers have been given the duty to supervise the area during the hours when littering was rampant.

On Friday morning, as a couple of men were trying to pollute a cleaned vacant space on Kulimikkarai road, a sanitary worker, A Jayalakshmi, supervising the stretch drove them away with a warning. “Sanitary workers are cleaning the stretch every day but people are not cooperating. We were told to supervise the road to ensure cleanliness,” Jayalakshmi said. The corporation officials said that the practice would continue in the days to come. “Though we cannot cover all the stretches prone to littering, sanitary workers, equipped with safety gear and whistles, have been told to prevent open defecation and public littering in the area where they are deployed,” a corpoation official said.

Title: Opposition MLA gift-packslocusts, brings them to Rajasthan assembly in protest
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nokha MLA Bihari Lal with locusts at Assembly on Friday

JAIPUR: In a novel protest, a BJP legislator entered the Rajasthan assembly building with a gift-packed container full of locusts on Friday.

The unconventional protest was to highlight the Congress-led government’s alleged failure to contain the locust menace which played havoc with Rabi crops in western Rajasthan.

The dissent by opposition legislator and Nokha MLA Bihari Lal caught everyone’s attention. He entered the assembly building with the container on his head accompanied by woman legislator from Anupgarh Santosh who wore a banner of demands by locust-affected farmers on her body.

However, all were left stunned after he showed the gift packed container of locusts. The grasshoppers have been damaging the agricultural crops in western Rajasthan. “It’s a gift sent by the farmers of border districts of Bikaner, Ganganagar and Hanumangarh to the government, which failed to protect them,” he alleged.

Speaking to the media, he said, “Farmers have suffered the worst. However, the state government seems all focused on protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. Compensation should be distributed fast as the farmers have suffered heavy losses due to locust attacks on their Rabi crops.”

Nokha MLA Bihari Lal said, “Compensation should be distributed fast as the farmers have suffered heavy losses due to locust attacks on their Rabi crops.”

Farmers in 11 out of 33 Rajasthan border districts have suffered huge losses in the locust attacks, described as the worst in the last three decades. These insects had entered the villages in western Rajasthan crossing the Indo-Pak border. He said the loss to farmers has been estimated at Rs 80,000 per hectare. They have also demanded aerial spray of pesticides on locust swarms.

Farmers have been beating vessels, lighting fires and playing loud music through the day and night to drive the insects away, but without much success. The government has still not fully succeeded in containing the menace, despite spraying of insecticides.

Title: AVS busts brothel in Shanmuga Nagar
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: Anti-vice squad (AVS) attached to Trichy city police busted a brothel racket and arrested two pimps and rescued two women in Trichy city on Thursday. The team led by inspector Uma Maheswari arrested A Karthika, 25 from Adhavathur Sandhai and her husband S Aravindhan, 37, from a house in Shanmuga Nagar on Vayalur road in Trichy .

Acting on a complaint from a 45-year-old man from Marudhandakurichi, the AVS team searched the house and confirmed that sex trafficking was taking place in at the house. The police rescued two women, aged 42 and 33, who were forced to prostitution by the couple who acted as pimps.

Police said the owner of the house had let the house on rent to the couple, unaware of their ploy to run brothel in it. The rescued women were manual labourers who were lured into the profession by offering money.

The police booked the couple under immoral traffic prevention (ITP) Act and produced them in court. The court remanded them in judicial custody. The rescued women were sent to a government home in Trichy for rehabilitation.

Title: National Voters Day observed
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kanpur: National Voters Day was organised in Kanpur Nagar district court on Friday. Though the National Voters Day is celebrated on January 25 every year but since it is a holiday on January 25 therefore in compliance with the directives of UP state Vidhik Sewa Pradhikaran, the Voters Day was held on Friday said secretary Zila Vidhik Sewa Pradhikaran Harendra Kumar Ojha.

VK Singh IV nodal officer National Lok Adalat and additional district and session judge addressing the participants said that for a healthy democracy people should cast their votes without fear.

District judge Ashok Kumar Singh III described the object of National Voters Day and asked the judicial officials and office staff and advocates to take a pledge to always cast vote.

Title: Bangladeshi teen flees captor after four days, files rape complaint
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

Title: Explain sacking of employee, HC tells Gwalior civic body
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal: MP high court has issued notice to the Gwalior municipal commissioner seeking explanation over the termination of a computer operator of Gwalior Municipal Corporation who had alleged flaws in the performance audit of various cities during 2019 Swachh Survekshan and sought an inquiry by the Prime Minister’s Office (PMO). The officer has been asked to submit reasons with relevant documents by January 28.

He was not only terminated from service on charges of “conspiring against a government department” but it is alleged that a complaint was lodged against him with local police after which he was detained by crime branch sleuths and questioned for around eight hours. Sandeep Sharma, the computer operator, had then filed a petition challenging his termination.

Sharma’s termination order said he violated civil services rules by “misusing his official position” and “creating a confused relationship between state and the central government”. Sharma claims he has been targeted for speaking up against wrongdoings. Various associations in Gwalior have also protested against Sharma’s termination.

The termination order also accuses Sharma of moving court without the state government’s permission — which he did by submitting documents he was not authorised to access.

Title: Telangana: TRS upbeat; Congress, BJP keep fingers crossed
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Saturday’s outcome is going to be crucial for all political parties. The ruling TRS seems to be sitting pretty, confident of repeating its success show — having won all the elections held in the last five years. On the other hand, Congress and BJP are keeping their fingers crossed and hoping to turn a new leaf by upstaging TRS.

Interestingly, the election results are set to impact a possible change of guard in Congress and BJP state units. If the results turn out to be in favour of BJP, the party leadership is likely to retain K Laxman for another term. Whereas Telangana Congress president Uttam Kumar Reddy has already made his intentions clear of quitting the post after the results and a search for a new TPCC chief is already on.

However, the January 22 election was never taken lightly by the three contenders — TRS, Congress and BJP. The state had zilla parishad elections in May 2019.

TRS wants to prove its dominance and that there is no anti-incumbency wave in the state. Congress and BJP, which could not produce the desired results in assembly, local body elections and Huzurnagar bypoll, are keen to establish that people are angry with the ruling TRS and also emerge as a viable alternative to TRS.

TRS president K Chandrasekhar Rao put ministers on notice and had even warned them that they would lose their berths in the cabinet if they fail to ensure party candidates’ win in their respective wards. He was equally forceful on party MLAs if they do not get the desired results.

TRS general secretary Palla Rajeshwara Reddy said the ruling party would set a new record by winning successive elections. “In the assembly polls, we received 46.87% of votes and secured 88 seats. Congress got 28.43% of votes and won 19 seats while BJP got only 6.98% of votes, he said.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: 62 per cent votes cast in Karimnagar civic elections
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

File photo of voters waiting for their turn to exercise their voting rights at a booth in Telangana

HYDERABAD: Elections for Karimnagar municipal corporation, that was held on Friday, saw low turnout. The election commission also conducted repolling in four polling stations of Nizamabad, Kamareddy and Mahbubnagar districts.

Election officials said only 62% votes were polled in Karimnagar, while it was 73% in Nizamabad, 59% in Mahbubnagar, and 68% in Kamareddy districts.

Indirect election for the mayor’s post in Karimnagar corporation will be conducted on January 29, while counting of votes in the three polling stations will be held on January 27.

Title: After Uttarakhand CM Trivendra Rawat order, PWD’s performance report to be changed
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trivendra Rawat

Dehradun: To fix accountability of projects undertaken by Public Works Department engineers and lay more focus on performance, the body’s Annual Confidential Report (ACR) will undergo a change. The move comes after CM Trivendra Rawat issued orders in this regard to additional chief secretary Om Prakash, a communique said.

The new ACR would cover Principal Engineer, Chief Engineer (Headquarters), Chief Engineer (Zonal), Superintendent Engineer (Civil), and other engineers of the department. Presently, 80% weightage is given on performance assessment and the parameters of performance and achievement are filled by the officer concerned.

There is no provision which could help the reporting officer adjudge the actual performance of the engineer. The remaining 20% weightage is reserved for “Personal Attributes” and grading is done on a scale of 0 to 10.

However, the new Performance Appraisal Report has different categories and marks have been fixed for each performance parameter. Also, the reporting officer can alter the “Personal Attributes” marks under the new system, if he feels that the performance of the officer concerned isn’t qualitative.

The new performance report will also have 20% weightage reserved for “Personal Attributes”.

Title: 600 rightful owners to benefit after action against land mafia: Minister
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal: The anti-mafia campaign of the Kamal Nath government will continue, minister for law PC Sharma said on Friday. Speaking to reporters at the PCC office, the minister gave an account of all actions initiated and taken by the state government to control the alleged mafia and extortion rackets.

“On Republic Day, chief minister Kamal Nath will hand over possession of 600-800 plots to rightful owners,” Sharma said. “This is possible after the action against land and cooperatives mafia that has been undertaken by the government,” he claimed. In Bhopal 80 persons have been given possession of their land by the district collector after action against the co-operative mafia, he said.

“Madhya Pradesh was once regarded India’s cultural capital. But in 15 years of BJP rule, the state has become the centre of criminal and mafia activities,” PC Sharma alleged. “There are 11 types of mafia that have been identified including the drug mafia, land, extortion, liquor, adulteration, chit-fund, illegal colonizer, blackmail, mining, transport and cooperatives mafia. The Nath government has started demolishing all the mafia raj,” he said.

PC Sharma claimed that the government initiated action in 615 cases of land mafia, 694 involving liquor mafia, 150 adulteration, 65 cooperatives, 149 extortion cases and 1,053 vehicles involving the transport mafia. “Kamal Nath government has taken strict action against these and many culprits have been put behind bars,” the minister said.

He said the government is on the rampage against the mining mafia. “More than 1330 cases of illegal mining have been registered, 8294 cases of transport attached to illegal mining and 531 for storage have been registered. As many as 10155 cases have been registered for a mafia-free Madhya Pradesh,” he said.

“In the 15 years of BJP rule, an approximate Rs 15,000 crore was usurped from the state exchequer. Till 2018, the annual revenue from sand mining was a meagre Rs 223 crore. Kamal Nath government has stopped this robbery of sand and with a new sand mining policy the revenue now is Rs 1234 crore,” the minister said.

Title: Job fair to be held inTrichy on February 1
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: A job fair will be conducted at the district employment office in Trichy on February 1. Eligible candidates can participate in the fair, Trichy district collector said in a statement here on Friday.

District collector S Sivarasu will inaugurate the fair at Musiri Institute of Technology (MIT) Polytechnic College at 9 am on coming Saturday. Around 100 employers from various private companies will participate to select eligible candidates.

Candidates who have completed Class VIII, X, XIII passed or failed, ITI, diploma, nursing, para-medical, hotel management, engineering students within the age limit of 18 to 35 can participate with required certificates like TC, mark sheet, aadhar card, ration card and two passport size photos.

Special bus service has been arranged to the job fair venue at 8 am from various spots such as Chathiram Bus Stand, Mannachanallur, Thuraiyur, Thottiam, Kulithalai, Thogamalai, Pettaivaithalai and Lalapettai. Several bus services have been arranged from Kulithalai bus stand in Karur district to MIT college, a release from Trichy district collector office said.

For further details, candidates are requested to contact 0431 - 2413510 or through WhatsApp number 9499055902.

Title: Rawats trade potshots over 'chowmein pe charcha'
Content: Dehradun: Former Uttarakhand CM Harish Rawat and his successor Trivendra Singh Rawat have shared an “unusual” relationship, which is hard for many to understand. When Harish was hospitalised on two occasions — once when he fell ill and another time when he was hit by a motorcycle — Trivendra was among the first to visit him at the hospital. Not just that, but Trivendra also attended the mango party hosted by his predecessor and Harish returned the courtesy by visiting CM’s residence on the occasion of Holi.However, when it comes to taking potshots at each other, both have never backed out. In a recent incident, a video had gone viral where Harish Rawat is seen making chowmein in a shop with his supporters. To which, the CM said he would love to taste the chowmein but advised Harish to send some to Congress state chief Pritam Singh. The former CM and and Congress state chief reportedly share strained relations. In retaliation, Harish said, “I will definitely send chowmein to Pritam but will send double the quantity to Trivendra as he might like to share it with Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank and Ajay Bhatt.”Trivendra, in his statement, not only made fun but also used it to highlight the differences between Harish and Pritam Singh. “Unse kaho kuch hamare liye bhi bhej dein, hum bhi taste kar le ki kaisi bani hai...nahi to kam se kam Pritam Singh to khila dein (Ask him to send some to me so that I can taste and judge its quality, if not then he should at least send it to Pritam Singh.”The CM’s statement was an indirect swipe on the two senior Congress leaders who are said to be at loggerheads over some issues. Harish in a recent Facebook message has announced a three-month break from active politics and said that he will take a call on his future in March.Reacting quickly on the situation, Harish made a short Facebook video on Friday in which he thanked the CM for expressing desire to eat noodles prepared by him and also took a jibe. “I will send noodles made of Mandua and if possible momos also to Trivendra. I will also send chowmein to Pritam Singh but the quantity to Trivendra would be more as he might like sharing it with Ajay Bhatt, Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank and Bansidhar Bhagat,” the former CM said.

Title: Tamil Nadu, Kerala plan joint study at Keeladi, Muziris archaeological sites
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Minister K Pandiarajan (3rd from right) during a visit to Keeladi in Sivaganga district last year

CHENNAI: In an effort to explore the ancient links between their states and identify commonalities, the governments of Kerala and Tamil Nadu plan to undertake a joint study of the archaeological sites at Muziris near Kodungallur and Keeladi in Sivaganga district.

Kerala tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran and Tamil Nadu minister for Tamil official language and culture K Pandiarajan, echoed this idea after a meeting on Friday at the secretariat here.

Archaeologists involved in the excavation of Muziri had been frequenting Keeladi and vice versa for a long time. “The archaeological departments of the two states will soon carry out a joint study to look for commonalities,” said Surendran.

Surendran along with senior officials of the tourism department of that state met Pandiarajan, TN environment minister K C Karuppannan and officials of the Tamil Nadu pollution control board and Town and Country Planning to seek a ‘no objection’ certificate for the Kerala government to construct a Rs 15 crore guest house in Kanyakumari.

Pandiarajan said a massive excavation exercise was going on in Muziri and officials of the two states had decided to work together to compare the findings of Muziris and Keeladi. The joint study would help evolve a joint narrative of Tamil civilisation, he said.

“We are also planning to bring out a collaborative book on the rich history of Tamil civilisation. It will be done parallel to avoid delay in publishing the books on the excavation.”

T Udayachandran, commissioner of the TN archaeology department, said a team led by P J Cherian of the Kerala Council for Historical Research was doing a methodical excavation in Pattanam. “The best practices can be exchanged and it would shed more light on the Sangam era and the life of the Tamil people. The artefacts unearthed in Keeladi can also compared with the artefacts found in Muziris and better research can be carried out.”

The fifth phase of excavation was completed at Keeladi, and preliminary study is going on to take up the sixth phase, he said, adding that the report on the findings of the fourth phase would be out soon.

Pandiarajan said they had requested Kerala government to lay an approach road to the famous Kannagi temple in Idukki district, along the inter-state border, and to promote it as a tourism site.

Surendran said the issue would be soon sorted out and also stated that both the governments had been maintaining a cordial relationship.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: Congress offers mayor, municipal chairperson posts to TRS rebels
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a clever strategy to outwit TRS, Congress is offering posts of municipal chairperson and deputy chairperson, mayor and deputy mayor to TRS rebels having winning prospects.

The strategy is aimed at stopping the TRS rebels from going back to the ruling party after it started cajoling them to win the top posts. Congress is issuing a whip to the party members to vote for the candidates nominated by the party for these posts, sources said.

Corporators and councillors will elect one among them as mayor and chairperson and their deputies as it is an indirect election for these posts. The State Election Commission has notified that indirect elections to mayors and chairpersons and their deputies will be held on January 27.

If election of mayor and chairperson is not possible on January 27, the indirect election will be completed the following day. Also, the election of deputy mayor and deputy chairperson shall be held only after the election of mayor and chairperson is completed, SEC sources said.

Congress is confident of winning a good number of wards and divisions in the urban local bodies in the districts of Medchal-Malkajgiri, Nalgonda, Bhuvanagiri-Yadadri, Sangareddy, Nagarkurnool, Rangareddy and Khammam.

TPCC president N Uttam Kumar Reddy said it was an election between “Congress and TRS distributed cash, liquor and gifts.”

Congress legislature party leader Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka said the democratic institutions were being destroyed in order to allow only the rich to take part in politics and prevent the poor from entering politics.

Title: BJP MLA Patwa sentenced in cheque bounce cases, later released on bail
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Surendra Patwa

BHOPAL: A special court here on Friday sentenced BJP MLA, Surendra Patwa, to six months of rigorous imprisonment and asked him to pay to four litigants, who had sued him for giving them the cheques that bounced.

According to complainants, Patwa had given a cheque of Rs five lakh to Anita Devi Mittal , Rs 9.5 lakh to Sarika Jain, Rs 9 lakh to Sanjay Kumar Jain and Rs 6.5 lakh to Maya Jain three years ago. All of them are residents of Indore. After cheques given to them by Patwa bounced, they filed separate complaints in the court of special judge Suresh Singh , who is the presiding officer in the special court set up for trial of politicians.

On Friday, the court held Patwa guilty and sentenced him to six months of rigorous imprisonment in each case and ordered him to pay one-and-a-half times of the amount of cheque to each of the litigant. The sentence will run concurrently. He was, however, granted bail after the sentence to allow him go in appeal against the court order in the high court.

Title: Corpn to hold ‘ploggathon’ on February 2
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chennai: Greater Chennai Corporation will conduct a ‘ ploggathon ’ at Elliot’s Beach in Besant Nagar on February 2 , said an official release on Friday.

Plogging is a concept borrowed from Sweden where residents jog while picking up waste. Corporation officials said not only would it help in creating awareness on keeping public spaces clean, it would also be a fitness initiative. It was first begun in Sweden in 2016.

The ploggathon will begin at 5am at Elliot’s Beach, the release said. Participation is free and those who wish to register for it may log on to www.chennaiploggathon.com. So far 1,500 people have registered to participate in the initiative. Corporation officials estimate that around 3,000-4,000 people would participate. Corporation officials as well as many private companies would participate in the ploggathon, the release said.

Corporation commissioner G Prakash said residents should adopt the slogan ‘My waste, my responsibility’ to ensure that surroundings are clean. Plogging aims to spread awareness about this, he added.

Title: New traffic plan put in place in Doon to facilitate Smart City work; several roads made one-way, lead to jams
Content: Dehradun: A new traffic plan was put in place in the city on Friday to facilitate the work on various Smart City projects across the city. As part of the plan, several roads were either blocked or made one-way. Traffic on prominent stretches like EC Road, Rajpur Road, Chakrata Road, Buddha Chowk, Darshan Lal Chowk and Lansdowne Chowk among others was affected leading to slow-moving vehicles and increase in commute time for many people who had to take longer routes to reach their destinations.Traffic congestion was reported at several places in the city especially during school closing time. Arun A, a school student, told TOI, “Our school van could not come on time to pick us up as it got stuck in the traffic and as a result, all of us got delayed in returning home. This affected the rest of our day’s schedule.”Mohit Kapoor, a resident, added,“I was following the traffic route map released by police while going to pick my son from school but I got stuck in the traffic and many routes that weren’t supposed to be blocked according to the map were also not open for vehicular movement.”Drivers of Vikram tempos said they were also adversely affected. “Most of us witnessed a dip of more than 50% in our earnings because we were forced to make less trips due to getting stuck in snarls caused by the traffic restrictions,” said Yogamber Singh Rana, president (route 1) of Vikram Jan Kalyan Samiti.Meanwhile, there was a mixed response from the business community regarding the initiative. Several businessmen TOI spoke to, claimed that they suffered heavy losses due to less people coming to their shops because of the traffic diversions while many said that they were satisfied with the new plan as it was being implemented for the greater good of the city. “On Wednesday, around 50 traders of the city had met with DIG Arun Mohan Joshi and he assured us that everything is being taken care of regarding the special traffic plan. Today, there was a lot of congestion as many routes were blocked. I believe that there has been a decline of around 50% in revenue in many establishments. The arrangements were good but there was room for improvement,” said Vipin Nagalia, president of Doon Udyog Vyapar Mandal.

Title: BJP workers gherao collectorates across MP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Ex-CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan with BJP workers at the collectorate on Friday

Bhopal: The BJP on Friday held state-wide protests against Congress government’s alleged targeting of party workers under the ongoing drive against land mafia. BJP gheraoed collectorates across the state and registered their protest.

In Bhopal, the protest was led by former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan. In Indore, state BJP president Rakesh Singh led the protest while former state president and MP Nand Kumar Singh Chouhan led the protest in Khandwa. Former ministers Narottam Mishra protested in Jabalpur and Bhupendra Singh led the protest in Chhatarpur.

Several BJP workers were reportedly arrested in Indore and other parts of the state during the protest.

Rakesh Singh said, “The government mafia is working in the name of action against land mafia. But BJP workers would not get afraid. Poor people and BJP workers are getting targeted in the drive.” He alleged there is atmosphere of fear in the state for past one year ever since Congress came in power.

“Congress is trying to target people and settle scores. To intimidate BJP workers, the Congress government is bulldozing their houses while properties of Congress leaders are spared. BJP workers would not get afraid and will fight till their last breath,” Singh added.

Former Lok Sabha speaker Sumitra Mahajan and several BJP workers were arrested in front of district collectorate.

Former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan said in his address outside Bhopal collectorate that the chief minister should clarify who is the mafia and how many of them have been targeted so far. He demanded government to make public the list of mafia. “BJP is against atrocities meted out to people in the name of anti-encroachment drives. By conducting campaigns like drive against mafia and shudh ke liye yuddh, the government is trying to divert people’s attention from its failure. It is like collecting sample from one shop and taking money from remaining shops. No one had thought that the government that came into power in the name of change would trouble people,” Chouhan said.

Title: Son traces Telangana worker in Kuwait after 27 years, gets news of his death
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Twenty-seven years after he left Telangana in search of a job in Kuwait , a man from Nizamabad district died in that country on Thursday.

After he had left India in 1993, Chakali Bhoomaiah (65) never visited his native Lingapur village in Indalvai mandal . He died just when his son, Suresh (28), thought that he had traced his father after nearly two decades.

Bhoomaiah’s family came to know about his whereabouts from a video that was circulating. “On Wednesday night, I identified my father from the video. A group of persons spoke to him where he had mentioned the name of his village as Yellareddypalli, which is close to our village. After checking the name on the passport copy, we recognised him as my father,” Suresh told TOI.

Sources said Bhoomaiah stayed back in Kuwait and did not attempt to get back home even once. He could not return as he was cheated and did not have his passport, sources said.

In the video, NRIs from Telangana noticed his failing health and were seen telling him that they would like to sponsor his trip back home.

“The next morning after I saw the video, I called them up only to be informed that he had passed away,” Suresh said.

Getting the body of Bhoomaiah from Kuwait is a task now. The Indian embassy in Kuwait is in touch with the family.

“We were informed that my father was not even in possession of the passport,” Suresh said. Gulf Telangana Welfare and Cultural Association president Patkuri Basanth Reddy said he was in touch with some volunteers, who were trying to send the body to Nizamabad.

When Bhoomaiah left for Kuwait in 1993, his elder daughter Sunitha was four years and younger daughter Laxmi was three years. Suresh was one year old then. It was only once, in 2007, that Bhoomaiah had called up his family.

“He probably did not want to return as there were huge debts to be cleared,” Suresh said. Even when he was asked in the video by the group of Telangana volunteers if he would like to return home to see his family, Bhoomaiah evinced no interest.

Title: CAA: Chancellor gheraoed at Maulana Azad National Urdu University
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Firoz Bakht Ahmed

HYDERABAD: Trouble erupted on Maulana Azad National Urdu University ( Manuu ) campus, on Friday evening, after a group of students gheraoed chancellor, Firoz Bakht Ahmed ’s vehicle, and shouted slogans against him, while he was leaving the premises. The chancellor had taken a police party with him to enter the campus as his own vice-chancellor had advised him against visiting the university.

In December, Ahmed issued an appeal urging Muslim community to maintain calm and assuring them that the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) would not uproot them from India, where they have been living since time immemorial. “Since then, I have been threatened with dire consequences by students,” the chancellor told TOI.

Alleging that the students were instigated by Manuu vice-chancellor Mohammed Aslam Parvaiz , Ahmed said: “It was absolutely peaceful when I came in, earlier in the afternoon. It was only when I stepped out of my quarters to leave, did these students gather near the gate. It is certainly the handiwork of the V-C and registrar.”

The tussle between the two administrative heads of India’s only Urdu university has been going on for a long time now, with both accusing each other of fraudulent practices, on public platforms. In November last year, Parvaiz even tendered his resignation to the President attributing it to continuous harassment by Ahmed who claimed that the V-C decided to quit to avoid inquiry into his actions, including charges of sexual harassment.

When contacted, the V-C confirmed that he had asked the chancellor to stay away from the campus. “That is because I knew something like this could happen… Why did he unnecessarily need to come to the university and disturb the peace? Students have finally settled down and concentrating on their academics. There was no need for him to rake up the issue again,” said Parvaiz.

He said the Chancellor had to be escorted out through back door to avoid further trouble.

Title: All-round edu must to make society safe for women: SP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: Referring to incidents of violence against women and children, Trichy district SP Zia-ul Haque highlighted the role of educational institutions in creating better citizens. Speaking at the National Girl Child Day event at Jamal Mohamed College (JMC), he called for contribution from every section of the society to curb such incidents.

The event was organised by JMC gender champion club along with Bharathidasan University’s department of women studies. Speaking on the status and challenges faced by girls in India, he cited incidents of violence and stressed on the need for protecting girls. He said institutions like JMC have a vital role in imparting moral education to curb such incidents. He said that human development cannot be achieved without achieving gender equality and that declining sex ratio, early marriage and lack of equal opportunity is a major concern. He said a century ago, ‘Sati’ was an accepted norm, it is not only unaccepted today and is a crime. “In the same way, female feticide, child marriages and gender issues still exist despite measures to counter them. But appropriate changes will occur. The change therefore should come from households, from individuals,” he said. Speaking on prevailing gender discrimination in society, Manimekalai, director and head of department of women’s studies, said gender inequalities prevailing in society manifests into violence.

“Historical disadvantages witnessed by women for generations were not questioned rationally, which is a reason for gender inequality sustaining in the society ,” she said.TNN

Title: Telangana civic polls: Fate of over 11,000 civic poll candidates to be known today
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Polling for 120 municipalities and nine municipal corporations was conducted on January 22

HYDERABAD: The fate of over 11,000 candidates in the municipal elections will be known when counting of votes will be taken up at 8 am on Saturday.

The first results are likely to be out by 10am. All the results are set to be released by the afternoon.

Polling for 120 municipalities and nine municipal corporations was conducted on January 22 amid sporadic incidents of violence.

Of the total 2,727 wards in municipalities, election in 80 wards was unanimous and polls were held in the rest 2,647 wards. In nine municipal corporations, there were 325 wards and election in one ward was unanimous.

Telangana State Election Commission (TSEC) chief V Nagi Reddy on Friday said that guidelines had been issued to the election authorities on counting. “Election of mayors and municipal chairpersons will be held on January 27. Since Karimnagar municipal corporation polling was held on January 24, mayoral election will be taken up on January 29,” Nagi Reddy said at a press conference here.

He said political parties will have to submit form-A and form-B by 11 am on January 26 and 10 am on January 27. “Parties can issue whip during thee mayoral election. If the mayoral candidates get equal votes, the winner will be elected through a draw of lottery,” Nagi Reddy said. He said the model code of conduct for the election of mayor and chairpersons would be in force till January 27.

Ex-officio members like MPs, MLAs and MLCs could also vote in the indirect polls in their respective constituencies. “If there is more than one civic body in their constituency, the MLAs will have to give an option along with MPs and MLCs by January 25 evening,” director of municipal administration TK Sridevi said.

Title: Republic Day: Road closure in Secunderabad Cantonment areas puts commuters in tight spot
Content:
File photo of Wellington Road

SECUNDERABAD: Night restrictions have been imposed on four arterial roads — Gough Road, Wellington Road , AOC Road and Entrenchment Road—at AOC Circle in Secunderabad Cantonment , from 10pm on Friday to 6am on January 27. Road closure will also to apply to Bolarum military establishment from January 24 to January 27.A high security alert by Ministry of Defence (MoD) ahead of Republic Day led to the road closure forcing over 1.5 lakh commuters to look for alternate routes.The defence PRO wing released an official statement of Friday attributing the closure to the alert issued across the country and to the fact that military establishments could be potential targets of anti-national elements.“However, ambulances or emergency medical cases, will be permitted after proper check and verification,” the official statement said.Based on official communique from the MoD, the local military authority (LMA) has made arrangements to implement the night restriction. LMA has set up notice boards on the four civilian roads and deployed army personnel at various points.A daily average of 1.5 lakh commuters from Safilguda, Neredmet, Sainikpuri, Yapral and adjoining areas use the four arterial roads under closure. The four-day road closure will force commuters to make a detour of at least six to eight kilometres.Commuters said that the LMA should have announced the closure in advance.“We welcome the decision of road restrictions in view of national security. But LMA must alert people at least two days in advance. They must issue a detailed notification including names of the roads, time of closure etc. Only then can people make alternate arrangements,” said Amarender Reddy, a resident of Safilguda.K Harshini, a techie from Neredmet who works in Gachibowli said, “Army personnel must allow women commuters who work till late in the night to use these four roads. They must allow us to pass through after checking our employee Id cards, keeping in view the issue of women’s safety.”The LMA requested civilians to cooperate with military authorities by abiding by the road closure restrictions.

Title: Hyderabad: Man killed by friend over money dispute
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A sheep seller was stabbed to death by a financier at Kulsumpura on Thursday following an argument over borrowed money. The victim J Sachin, 26, a resident of Jiyaguda in Kulsumpura, started selling sheep and goat at Kamela market in Jiyaguda. Recently, he borrowed Rs 2.5 lakh from a friend cum private financier, Karthik, but did not return the amount. At around 8pm on Thursday, Karthik visited Sachin’s house. While leaving with Karthik, Sachin told his wife that he would consume liquor.

Sachin and Karthik left the former’s house on a bike. They purchased liquor and started consuming it at Kamela goat market. While the two were drinking, Karthik had an argument with Sachin over money. “During the argument, Sachin roughed up Karthik and the latter, who had come prepared to kill Sachin, sprinkled chilli powder on his face and then stabbed him with a knife in the neck and chest. Sachin died on the spot,” Goshamahal ACP M Narender Reddy said.

Alerted by the locals, police rushed to the crime scene and shifted the body to Osmania General Hospital for postmortem. Police seized the murder weapon near the body. A case was registered under Section 302 of the IPC and the police took Karthik into custody on Friday night.

Title: National Girl Child Day: Uttarakhand government gives 307 smartphones to girl students
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image
