DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand government gave 307 smartphones to girl students on the occasion of National Girl Child Day here on Friday. Women and child welfare minister Rekha Arya distributed the smartphones to the girls who performed well in their Class X and Class XII board exams.

The event was attended by over 1,000 girl students, their parents, and teachers from all across the state.

Besides mobile phones, the girl studentsat Taj Chauraha were also given sanitary pads and other awareness material. “Smartphones will not just help these girls in studies but will also be a helpful tool for their security,” said Rekha Arya while speaking on the ocassion.

While some were excited to get the phone, others were critical of its utility. Speaking to TOI, some beneficiaries claimed that they already have a better smartphone than the one given by the state government. Some even said that they will gift the phone to their siblings.

Deeksha Pandey, who had come to Dehradun from Almora, claimed that she will give the new phone to her brother. Similarly, Neha Pant from Pithoragarh said that she will gift her old phone to her brother and will use the new one given by the government.

The girl students and their parents pointed out that without internet connectivity, smartphones alone won’t be of much help in studies. Some parents also expressed concern about excess usage of phone. “My daughter is a Class XI student. I give her a phone when she goes for her coaching class but I don’t think letting her keep a phone for the entire day is a good idea,” said Vinay Agarwal from Tehri, whose daughter had scored 97% marks in her Class X board exams.

Title: SC commission seeks action against admin, police in Doon for ‘taking Dalit girl’s murder case lightly’
Content: Dehradun: Reacting to the incident in which a Dalit girl’s charred body was found on the outskirts of Dehradun on January 4, Swaraj Vidwaan, member of the National Commission for Scheduled Castes who was in the city on Friday told mediapersons that there were several lapses in the way the case was handled. She also sought action against district administration and police for ‘taking a Dalit girl’s murder case lightly.’“It took almost five days for police to include provisions of the SC/ST Act in the FIR while sections pertaining to rape are still missing. We demand action against police and the administration for the delay and the lapse,” Vidwaan said.Vidwaan, who handed over a relief cheque of Rs 4.12 lakh to the victim’s mother, also alleged that this money should have been handed over to the family along with ration of three months within 24 hours of the incident. Citing this, too, as a lapse, she added that the administration and police neglected the fact that the victim was the only earning member in the family on whom her elderly mother and teenage sister were dependent.“There has been no sensitivity displayed in the way investigation in such a heinous crime was conducted. I have read the panchnama report of the case in which it is clearly mentioned that blood stains were found in the victim’s undergarments and her private parts were mutilated too. The killer had burnt her face and half her body to hide her identity and still, police hasn’t included relevant sections pertaining to such brutality in the FIR,” she said.When contacted by TOI regarding the matter, Anuj Kumar, circle officer (sadar), who is also the investigating officer in the case, said, “There was some miscommunication due to which the police took three days to included provisions of the SC/ST Act. Also, we have told the SC Commission that the police has already sent samples to forensic lab and we will include relevant sections of the IPC including those pertaining to rape in the FIR after getting the report.”To recall, the girl’s body was found in a half-burnt state in Arcadia area of Dehradun on January 4 after which the family had blamed a neighbour for the act. Two days after the incident, the police arrested the accused Usman Qureshi and claimed that the victim and the accused were in love and the man killed her after he learnt of her getting engaged to another man.

Title: Aqueel targets Chouhan, Imarti fires salvo at BJP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bhopal: Two ministers of the Kamal Nath government on Friday trained their guns on the BJP and former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan. Backwards and minorities welfare minister Arif Aqueel on Friday targeted Chouhan saying, “Sattar (70) chuhe khaakar billi haj ko chali (a hypocrite pretending to be holy).”

Aqueel was talking to reporters in Sehore on Friday and was asked about the former chief minister’s allegation that a minister of the Kamal Nath government has connections with sand mining in the Narmada.

“Chouhan does not have the right to accuse others of illegal sand mining,” Aqueel said. “A person whose family has thrived on sand mining does not have the authority to accuse others. Who does not know about dumpers? Every dumper had Chouhan Builders inscribed on it and RTO officials did not had the courage till now to stop these dumpers.”

About himself, the minister said, “I have told officials that if anyone involved in such activities takes my name then immediately seize his vehicle and take action against him.”

Minister for women and child welfare Imarti Devi also fired a salvo at the BJP. When reporters asked her for a reaction on the recent offensive remark by BJP former minister of state Badrilal Yadav for the district collector of Rajgarh, she said, “I don’t know what was said since I was not here for several days. But, we Congress persons are like elephants. We walk and dogs bark. Makes no difference for us.”

Asked about the BJP’s allegation of land grabbing by senior Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia, the woman minister argued, “Everyone knows who is mafia and who isn’t. What is Scindiaji’s dearth in life that he should become mafia. What dearth has Kamal Nath that he should become mafia? Whether in Gwalior or anywhere else, see BJP leaders who were on bicycles and see where they have reached. They are called mafia. Parents of Scindia and Kamal Nath have left so much, they don’t need to be corrupt.”

Title: Reprieve for Fadnavis as CJM adjourns hearing till Feb 10
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: In yet another reprieve for former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis, the chief judicial magistrate (CJM) here on Friday adjourned the hearing on summons issued to him in a case filed by lawyer Satish Uke.

Agreeing to Fadnavis’ counsel Uday Dable’s request for seeking extension, pending review petition in the Supreme Court, CJM Renuka Satav adjourned the hearing till February 10. Earlier, the leader of opposition in state assembly, twice skipped the hearings on December 4 and January 4 citing ‘official’ reasons.

The applicant, who was arguing in person, strongly opposed Dable’s request to adjourn the plea for the third time. Uke had claimed that Fadnavis allegedly suppressed information about two pending criminal cases while filing affidavit for nomination form during 2014 assembly polls. TOI has been following this case since first publishing it from November 14, 2014, when Uke had filed it in the JMFC.

When hearing started, Dable informed the court about Thursday’s review petition filed by the former CM in the apex court which consented to hear the case in an open court. “Application seeking oral hearing of review petitions in open court is/are allowed,” a bench comprising justices Arun Mishra, Deepak Gupta and Aniruddha Bose held.

On October 1 last year, the top court ruled against Fadnavis clarifying that a candidate must disclose all criminal cases in which court has taken cognisance at the time of contesting election. The SC then remanded back the case to JMFC court for retrial. The trial court of judge SB Mehta had issued summons to the ex-CM as an accused and asked him to remain present on December 4 for seeking bail.

“Since SC judgment has no further appeal, the petitioner losing the case can only file a review petition for correction. As per rules, the review is taken by the same set of judges inside their chamber, but there are no arguments from either complainant or respondent’s side. If they reach consensus that the review needs to be heard, they refer the case to an open hearing, else they straightway reject the case in a minute,” Dable told TOI.

The South Nagpur MLA had contended before the top court that lower court verdict would have several repercussions and could be misused against the candidates. He apprehended that frivolous cases could be filed days before election is announced to harass the contestants. Therefore, he demanded that they should be asked to disclose only those criminal cases in which charges have been framed or charge sheet has been filed.

Title: TSBIE to offer new vocational courses on healthcare
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Hyderabad: To address the acute shortage of manpower in health industry, the Telangana State Board of Intermediate Education (TSBIE) has decided to offer new vocational courses in intermediate for students to be assistant for dialysis, operation theatre or anesthesia.

Telangana Hospitals and Nursing Home Association (THANA) requested TSBIE commissioner to offer two-year vocational courses. The courses will also be offered in radiography, liaison officer, front office management from 2020-21 academic year. TSBIE officials said they are preparing the curriculum. “THANA governing body requested BIE to offer courses as there is acute shortage of manpower,” said M Laxma Reddy, TSBIE deputy director.

TSBIE officials said apprenticeship training will also be restored from this academic year and students can apply for apprenticeship at hospitals and nursing homes. “Nearly 10,000 students aiming to become multi-purpose health workers (female) and 9,000 aspirant medical lab technicians can avail the benefit in April or May 2020 through centralised apprenticeship selection melas,” said TSBIE commissioner Syed Omer Jaleel, adding that apprenticeship will be for a year and students will be offered stipend of Rs 7,000 per month.

Title: EVR College students allege bungling in exam valuation
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: Early this month, final year BSc Mathematics students of Periyar EVR College were in for a shock when their semester exam results were out. Out of the 80-odd students in the class, 35 had failed in Algebra paper. What’s more, most of the failed students had secured marks in single digit.

Since they had passed in the other five subjects, eleven of the failed students sought a scanned copy of their answer scripts from the controller of examination of the college.

The copies revealed that all of them had passed but were given less marks in the valuation. “We took the answer script copy to our teachers. Five of them valuated the copy and gave us over 30 marks which is the minimum passing mark out of 75,” said one of the students who was failed.

B Gayathri, head of the Mathematics department (in-charge), acknowledged that many of the students had indeed passed when the scanned copy of the answer script was valuated. Based on the scanned copy of the answer scripts, students applied for revaluation on the hope that they would pass. However, they were informed by the controller of examination that there is no change in their marks, said the student. The students accused the staff overseeing the valuation of having messed it up.

“And to silence them and cover up their mistakes, one of the staff members in the department even gave money to the students to apply for re-valuation,” said one of the students.

The students alleged that when they raised the matter with the principal, she along with other staff members asked them to reappear for the paper in the coming semester exam instead of speaking about the goof-up. When contacted, college principal I Julie said the valuation is done twice and if the difference between the two marks is more than 10, they go for a third valuation. She said the valuation was carried out by qualified staff from other colleges.

On students carrying out protest seeking transparent revaluation and highlighting the flaws in the valuation with evidence, she said students will have to reappear for the exam.

She denied threatening the students for raising the issue.

The students have now sought the intervention of the regional joint director of collegiate education (RDJCE) Trichy to probe the irregularities in the semester exam evaluation process.

Title: Man booked for damaging tomb complex
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Secunderabad: A case of trespassing and damage to property was registered against a person for carrying out illegal construction activity at Sri Mah Laqa Chanda Bai Tombs complex in Moula Ali.

The case was registered after assistant director, heritage department, Madhavi Chennuti filed a complaint with Malkajgiri police. “During inspection, a man was found carrying out illegal construction at the complex,” Madhavi said .

An archaeological consultant found that the accused, Md Suleman had broken down an old compound wall at the complex and raised pillars to build his house. Malkajgiri SI Linga Swamy said, “A case has been registered under Sections 448 and 427 of the IPC.”

Title: New traffic plan to be in force till Monday, says Dehradun SSP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

DEHRADUN: Defending the move to implement a new traffic plan in the city, police officials said that proper arrangements were made before implementing the special traffic plan on Friday. “We had given prior information about the special traffic plan and the message was well-circulated among the general public. There might have been some confusion among people on Friday, but I am sure they will get used to it over a period of time,” said Prakash Chandra Arya , SP (traffic).

DIG Arun Mohan Joshi, SSP Dehradun , meanwhile termed the introduction of the traffic plan as a successful measure. “It was a successful trial run on Friday. Therefore, we have decided to continue it for the next three days as well, till Monday. We had deployed senior officers and our personnel at key locations and they were guiding commuters in the right direction. Signboards were also installed to inform people about the change in routes,” he said.

Title: Sumitra, Rakesh Singh arrested
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Indore: Former Lok Sabha speaker Sumitra Mahajan, Indore MP Shankar Lalwani and BJP state chief Rakesh Singh were among 357 leaders and party workers arrested in Indore on Friday after a protest rally against alleged political bias in the ongoing crackdown on mafia.

BJP has alleged that its leaders and workers are being targeted in the name of action against mafia.

On Friday, around 1,000 BJP protesters marched towards the collectorate and tried to remove barricades.

Indore mayor Malini Gaud and MLAs Ramesh Mendola, Akash Vijayvargiya and Mahendra Hardia were also at the forefront. They were arrested and taken to the district jail in police vans. Later, SDM Rakesh Sharma granted them bail on the promise that they would not breach peace in the next six months.

“Under Kamal Nathji’s leadership, a chaotic government is operating in Madhya Pradesh and people of the state are unhappy. If anyone is happy, it is Nath’s ministers and Congress MLAs as they are looting the people of Madhya Pradesh. In the name of mafia eradication, they (government) are involved in extortion,” alleged Singh, accusing the government of not taking action against illegal construction by Congress leaders.

“We will not tolerate this biased behaviour. We had already informed the administration of our plan to enter the collectorate, but they arrested us,” Singh said.

On Bhopal MP Pragya Thakur receiving a threat letter and BJP general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya showing concern over his safety, following his claim that a Bangladeshi terrorist was keeping a watch on him, Singh said, “The Madhya Pradesh government should seriously investigate it. If BJP leaders have shown such concerns, there must some reasons behind it. The government should probe it without discrimination and ensure their security.”

Title: Human dam not at cost of tigers, corridor: Govt
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: Maharashtra chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Friday sent a clear message to the irrigation department officials that the Human major dam, proposed 3.5km from the boundary of Tadoba, should not be at the cost of the tiger corridor and ecology.

He was addressing a high-level meeting called at the insistence of former forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar, who is desperately pushing the project in its present form. The project would need 1,925 hectare forest land, leading to felling of over 1.51 lakh trees, destroying 6-7km functional corridor.

The four-member NTCA committee in its November 2014 site appraisal report had recommended three options if at all the project was to be taken up.

The recommendations included shifting the project 5km upstream from present site at Sirkada. The other two options were procuring private land and rehabilitating villages to restore structural corridor of 2-3km downstream, and convert it into forest by planting native species, or develop lift irrigation schemes, barrages, small dams etc instead of a major dam.

However, the irrigation department ruled out the other two options and insisted on Option II by pitching to develop 1km corridor by acquiring 200 hectare land. It was not ready to talk about the other two options. Sources said CM Thackeray was clear and expressed his intention to save forests and corridors, just like he stopped tree felling in Aarey forest in Mumbai. “I will allow projects but at the same time saving tigers will also be my priority,” he said.

Sources said since no solution was working out, some experts of the state wildlife board asked the CM why Option I was not being implemented? “If the dam is shifted 5km upstream, the project will generate 6 TMC water, 3 TMC less than what has been proposed. So, what is the harm? It will save tigers and corridor, and project will also come up,” said sources.

To this, Thackeray agreed and asked the irrigation department to come up with a fresh proposal. Sources said irrigation officials will now work out five separate proposals, with scenarios for the project shifting 5km to 1km upstream.

While making these proposals irrigation officials said they will have to get forest clearance afresh. To this, Thackeray is learnt to have said that Mungantiwar can expedite it with the BJP government at the Centre and state will play its role here.

Title: 12 held for running illegal lottery biz
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Trichy: The city police arrested 12 people for selling banned lottery ticket numbers in Trichy on Thursday.

The Fort police arrested M Prakash, 32, from Gandhi market, S Senthilkumar, 40, from Gandhi market, and M Ponnaian, 55 from Rock fort.

The Gandhi market police arrested M Abbas, 37, from Varaganeri, S Siva alias Sivakumar, 30, from Chinnasamy Nagar, A Vaitheeswaran, 27, from Varaganeri.

One more accused Nagalingam is yet to be arrested.

The Srirangam police arrested V Murugan, 30, from Thiruvanaikovil, and M Ramachandran, 42 from Thiruvanaikovil.

The Palakkarai police arrested B Raja alias Elayaraja, 39, from Sangiliyandapuram, while Thillai Nagar police arrested N Mariappan, 36, M Krishnakumar, 38, and M Kesavaraj, 40, all from Woraiyur.

All of them were found selling three digits of the lottery tickets to customers for Rs 30 and Rs 60.

The police caught and arrested them.

The winner of the lottery will be decided based on the draw result of the Kerala lottery published online.

Even though the police have been cracking the whip at regular intervals, the illegal trade continues to lure a large group of addicted people as the kingpins continue to operate from behind.

City commissioner of police V Varadharaju said that the special drive against illegal lottery will continue till the key people behind the network are nabbed.

“Yesterday’s drive was done based on the input about the sale of illegal lottery numbers. Our team will continue to crack down on them,” CoP Varadharaju told TOI on Friday.

Deputy commissioner of police (law and order) N S Nisha who led the search said that they were on the hunt for the kingpin operating from behind the screen.

“We are on the lookout for the key people,” she said.

Title: Heavy security in Vijayawada for R-Day
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vijayawada: Krishna district administration and Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) are making elaborate arrangements for the Republic Day celebrations, which will be held at Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium (IGMS) in the city on Sunday.

“We are working round-the-clock to make sure the programme is a success. The state government has given us clear instructions to complete the works on time,” collector A Mohammed Imtiaz said. Health wing officials were directed to arrange for first-aid centres and medical camps at the venue.

Around 10,000 students from educational institutions across the city will participate in the programme.

Elaborate security arrangements will be in place on Sunday as state governor Biswabhushan Harichandan, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and high court chief justice JK Maheswari will be attending the flag hoisting programme.

Special forces will be deployed at problematic areas due to ongoing protests of Amaravati farmers. Bishop Azariah school and Swaraj Maidan will be used as parking spaces for the VIPs and the spectators.

Fourteen departments of the state government will be presenting tableaus during the parade.

Title: Need counter-narrative to balance hate: Vikram Kapur
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vikram Kapur

HYDERABAD: India needs a counter-narrative, promoting harmony across religions, to balance the hate that’s seeped into our society today, said Vikram Kapur , an author and associate professor of English at the Shiv Nadar University .

Referring to partition and how it continues to be used “as a way to sustain and perpetuate the narrative of hatred”, he said: “Apart from only talking about who killed who during that time (or the 1984 riots for that matter), we should also talk about who saved who...what we need is harmony as we are becoming a very fractious society.”

Kapur was speaking on the sidelines of the three-day Hyderabad Literary Festival that began in the city on Friday. Among other things, the author has researched and written extensively about the 1984 riots in his novels.

“Three generations have grown up after partition. Then why is it still brought up again and again, either in the political or intellectual discourse, as sort of raison d'être for the path that we are on?... If we start pushing people of a certain community against the wall, there will come a point when they will retaliate,” the author said, while discussing the recent string of anti-CAA and NRC protests across India.

Pessimistic about India’s future, in case the climate of hate continues, he added: “While it is heartening that the recent protests saw people across faiths and backgrounds, and not just Muslims, come out and speak up, it is too early to say what will come out of it. How long can it be sustained? Will it lead to any real change in the way things are? We still don’t know.”

Title: Fishermen in Visakhapatnam fear harbour shift
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

The tug boats towing a Andaman passenger ship Nicobar enter the port harbour channel in Visakhapatnam (File ph... Read More

VISAKHAPATNAM: With the port city all set to become the state’s executive capital, there are apprehensions over the shifting of fishing harbour from beach road to the city’s northern outskirts. Fishing associations have already written to the state fisheries department to desist from taking any such step.

“Over 53,000 people, from Vizianagaram district in the north to Payakaraopeta in the south, depend on this fishing harbour, which is strategically located. It should not be shifted,” said Arjilli Dasu, executive director of Fisherfolk Foundation, a community body for AP fishermen.

Many fishermen have settled down in Jaalaripeta neighbourhood along the harbour over the years and it would difficult for them to shift base with their families, he said. “We have written to the fishing department commissioner in Vijayawada voicing our apprehensions. We request the government not to shift the fishing harbour from its present location,” added Dasu.

Title: Political parties condemn vandalism
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chennai: Political parties on Friday condemned the defacing of Periyar statue in Kancheepuram district. DMK president M K Stalin, MDMK chief Vaiko, CPI and CPM state secretaries, VCK chief Thol Thirumavalavan, TTV Dhinakaran and others demanded immediate action against those responsible. “Damage to Periyar statues has been happening continuously in the state and it must be condemned. The state government should act immediately against those who are involved in damaging the statues,” said Stalin. “Even when he was alive, he was successful after facing several hurdles. Thus, by damaging his statue, his contribution to society cannot be forgotten,” said Vaiko in a statement. Vaiko wanted the government to take action against those involved in the vandalism. CPI state secretary R Mutharasan, in a statement, condemned the damage to the statues and said a protest will be held on Saturday against the vandalism. “The protest will be held at Chepauk and the party’s youth wing, women’s wing and others will participate,” said Mutharasan. PMK founder S Ramadoss, in a statement, said if there is opposition to what Periyar said, they should be opposed only in the form of debates or policies. “In the last few months, there have been several such incidents of statues of Thiruvalluvar and Periyar being damaged. The government must take strict action against those involved,” said Ramadoss. VCK chief Thol Thirumavalavan, AMMK leader TTV Dhinakaran and several other party leaders condemned the act. TNN

Title: Hyderabad: Osmania University will now evaluate PhD thesis online
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Osmania University

HYDERABAD: The Osmania University (OU) will now evaluate PhD thesis submitted by research scholars from all departments online following an online evaluation system launched by examination branch on Friday.

The move comes nearly a year after the university piloted onscreen evaluation system for undergraduate and postgraduate courses. The new evaluation system launched by the examination branch will not only enable students to submit their final PhD thesis but will also help them keep track of its progress.

“After clearing their thesis through plagiarism software, the students will have to submit a soft-copy on the website. Evaluators will have access to the thesis being uploaded on the website through which they can commence evaluation,” said Prof Sriram Venkatesh, controller of examination, OU.

The university receives nearly 400 thesis on an average every year. The system is likely to speed up the evaluation process as evaluators would no longer have to physically check dozens of hard-copies. The website will address postage delay, reduce use of paper stationary and students visits to the examination branch for regular updates. While supervisors can concentrate on evaluation, scholars can plan career in advance during the process.

For the next six months, the university will provide both online and offline evaluation of PhD thesis before it completely shifts to the online version.

It may be recalled that in 2018, the examination branch had launched a similar PhD thesis online monitoring system which helped research scholars and supervisors know the status of thesis evaluation from time to time. “The monitoring system launched back then could not take off due to some technical errors. This time, we have integrated several processes such as selection of PhD thesis by supervisors, generation of final certificate etc.,” said Prof Venkatesh.

Title: Resident associations lead Vizag’s Swachhta efforts
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Resident Welfare Associations (RWAs) in the city are leading the charge in making Visakhapatnam do well in Swachh Survekshan 2020. Adjudged the third cleanest city in 2017, the city had slipped to the seventh position in 2018 and subsequently to the 23rd position in 2019.

The Andhra Pradesh Federation of RWAs (APFERWAS) joined the campaign on January 19 to spread awareness about submitting citizen’s feedback for SS2020, to improve the city’s chances this year. Members from all 130 RWAs from the city’s six zones gathered across major parks and rythu bazaars and distributed pamphlets explaining the procedure of submitting feedback.

There are four ways to submit feedback: giving a missed call to 1969, through the Swachhata app, through the Vote For Your City app or by logging in to www.swachhsurvekshan2020,org, informed representatives of APFERWAS.

The members also explained the manner in which the eight questions have to be answered, especially with regard to the ODF (Open Defecation Free) and GFC (Garbage Free City) status of the city. Speaking to TOI, vice-president of APFERWAS said, “Citizen’s feedback has high weightage and serves as a performance indicator in the overall ranking. Therefore, we have made it a point to sensitise people.”

“Waste segregation is also a major component in the survey. Hence, the RWAs have been striving to implement waste segregation in their respective wards,” Murthy added.

The APFERWAS president further said that while most colonies like JR Nagar and Kirlampudi layout are segregating wet and dry waste and preparing their own compost, there are some RWAs still which need to follow suit.

Title: Leopard knocked dead on NH7 outside Pench
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: Death of an adult female leopard in road hit on NH-44 (NH-7) on Friday morning has once again raised the issue of curtailed mitigation structures by Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Dehradun, under alleged political pressure.

The full-grown leopard was knocked dead by an unidentified speeding vehicle from Madhya Pradesh near Harnakund Nalla in Paoni range. The area is part of the unified control of Pench Tiger Reserve (PTR), Maharashtra.

This is the same spot near compartment number 582 in Palora beat of Paoni where a tiger was knocked down by the vehicle of a former BJP MLA from Ramtek on February 3, 2019. It is close to a minor bridge and mitigation structure number 6. This is the fourth accident in last 17 months involving big cats in the region.

On July 16, 2018, a full-grown leopard died in road hit while crossing the road outside Mansinghdeo Wildlife Sanctuary, now part of Pench. On December 16, 2018, another leopard died after it was hit by a vehicle near Deolapar, a few kilometres away from the spot where Friday’s leopard died. Similarly, on July 9, 2019, a tiger crossing the widened NH-7 had jumped the crash barrier to cross over to the other side.

One of the reasons greens blamed to such mishaps involving wild animals was curtailed mitigation measures. “It is true that some animals will die until they become familiar to underpasses. But the structure number 6 near Paoni, where the leopard was hit, was originally to be built 200 metres but it was curtailed to 65 metres. Height of the structure was also reduced from 7 metres to 5 metres,” said Udayan Patil, one of the petitioners in PIL on NH-7.

“The NHAI is also not paying heed to the demand for noise barriers at vulnerable spots. Secondly, height of 50-metre-long structure number 9 near Chorbahuli was to be 5 metres but it has been reduced to 3 metres. There is water logging and the issue has still not resolved. Many more such mishaps involving animals cannot be ruled out,” Patil cautioned.

On the contrary, WII tiger scientist Dr Bilal Habib, who prepared the mitigation report, said, “If you want 100% prevention of animal deaths then fencing is the option so that animal is diverted to cross the passes.”

“At low traffic, animals tend to cross but the time when the leopard was hit is the time when vehicles are in speed. In such cases, areas between crossing zones need to be fenced to avoid deaths,” said Habib.

Habib argued, “If the underpass would have been 200 metres and death would have occurred, still people would have said it should have been a 300 metres underpass.”

However, wildlife lover Sandeep Singh says, “Fencing is not the complete solution as it will block the corridors and block free movement of animals.”

Title: SCR: Inspection at Lallaguda rly unit
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

SCR: Inspection at Lallaguda rly unit

Secunderabad: Advanced work stations and machinery were inaugurated at Lallaguda carriage workshop during an annual inspection by Gajanan Mallya, GM of SCR .TNN

Title: Telangana: Three students injured after auto overturns
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

The auto driver lost control after he had to swerve to avoid hitting a dog

HYDERABAD: Three school students were injured when the auto they were travelling in overturned at Chowdarguda near Shadnagar on Friday. The auto left Prashanti Vidyaniketan School with 12 students. As it was heading towards Padmaram, the driver lost control after he had to swerve to avoid hitting a dog.

Initially, the injured students were rushed to Shadnagar government hospital. Later, they were shifted to a private hospital for better treatment. “The students suffered minor injuries and are out of danger. A case has been booked against the auto driver under Section 337 of IPC and MV Act,” said Shadnagar rural inspector MGS Rama Krishna.

Title: Telangana: Man held for intimidating Balapur tehsildar
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Police arrested real-estate businessman M Purushotham , 35, for trespassing into Balapur tehsildar’s house and intimidating him. A few days ago, Balapur tehsildar D Srinivasa Reddy lodged a police complaint, stating that on January 20 he noticed that an Innova Crysta suspiciously stopped in front of his house. “A person entered the premises of my house and started clicking photos. I noticed another person sitting in the car was also clicking photos,” Srinivasa said.

Srinivasa told police person sitting in the car was M Purushotham. “He alleged that Purushotham is a land grabber. When Srinivasa was posted as revenue inspector at Serilingampally, Purushotham interrupted him many times from discharging duties. Purushotham confessed to have taken photos of Srinivasa’s house,” LB Nagar inspector V Ashok Reddy said.

In the past, CCS police had registered case against Purushotham after a complaint by Ranga Reddy district collector.

Title: Hoteliers in Vizag anticipate boom in biz with capital shift
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The hotel industry in the city is hoping for a boom in business once Vizag becomes the executive capital of the state.

Speaking to TOI, president of the Andhra Pradesh Hotel Association (APHA), T Satyanarayana said the floating population in the city is likely to increase once the capital shifts to Vizag. At present, the city has over 600 restaurants, but the number, including high-end hotels, will rise to accommodate the demands of a growing population, he said, adding that another 100 restaurants are expected to set up shop soon.

Dismissing rumours that prices at restaurants and hotels will see a sharp rise, Satyanarayana said a ten per cent increase is likely at most and competition among businesses would ensure that prices remain at a uniform level.

O Naresh Kumar, CEO of a city-based IT firm, said the state government should take steps to boost nightlife by increasing police patrolling and providing adequate public transport, along the lines of the Maharashtra government’s decision to allow shopping malls and restaurants to remain open round-the-clock. “We expect the executive capital to change the face of Vizag and attract investors,” Naresh Kumar said and added that a separate wing of the police for tourism, another cybercrime police station and a police station to deal with property-related cases are needed to make the city safer and investor-friendly.

A few hoteliers said the government had issued an order allowing licensed restaurants, hotels and eateries to remain open till midnight, extending closing hours from 10.30 pm, to ensure visitors arriving late at night face no inconvenience. The police, however, are closing businesses by 11 pm but hoteliers expect at least 30 per cent of restaurants to remain open round-the-clock once the capital shifts to Vizag, they said.

Title: ANU hosts convocation, 567 students graduate
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Rajahmundry: Adikavi Nannaya University (ANU) conducted its 11th and 12th convocations at its campus near Rajahmundry on Friday. Governor Biswabhushan Harichandan, who was the chief guest of the ceremony, awarded eight gold medals, six PhDs and degrees to 567 students.

An honorary doctorate was conferred on Prof KC Reddy, the vice-chancellor of Rajiv Gandhi University of Knowledge Technologies.

In his keynote address, the governor called upon the young graduates to stand up for the ideals of the country, the constitution and India’s heritage. “The highest education is that which does not merely give us information but makes us live in harmony with all existence,” the governor said.

Harichandan further said that educating the mind without educating the heart is not education at all, while adding, “After you leave this university, your consciousness and your soul will be your teachers. Keep your mind open. A closed mind is a stagnant pool.”

Prof KC Reddy discussed the demographic advantage India has in terms of its youth population. tnn

Title: Youth made to regulate traffic for drunk ride in Trichy
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

A 19 year old youth booked for traffic violation regulates vehicular movements at Head post office signal in T... Read More

TRICHY: This 19-year-old youth from KK Nagar would not have imagined that he will be asked to regulate traffic in Trichy city on Friday for blatantly violating road rules by riding a bike drunk with four friends on the pillion seat at Kattur in 2018.

The youth was the cynosure of all those who crossed the traffic signal MGR statue roundabout from 9 am as he appeared on the road with the jersey of traffic police over his plain clothes. A few curious people who enquired with the policemen were told that it was indeed a punishment. “I was 17 years old then and was riding the bike drunk with my friends on the pillion. Our bike skidded, we fell on the road and were caught by the police for violating the traffic. I realize now the danger that rash and negligent riding poses for others,” said the boy at lunch break on the first day of his two-day traffic duty.

“As we got the order yesterday, he has been assigned the task of regulating traffic under the supervision of traffic police,” said assistant commissioner of police, traffic Arunachalam. Juvenile Justice Board (JJB), Trichy which passed the order a week ago termed the assignment a community service to make the boy realize his violation. Carrying out the trials of cases of juveniles in conflict with law, JJB headed by a chairperson and two members will forgive the juveniles after confirming their crime.

A former member of JJB, Trichy M Padmavathy, said the objective of JJB is to ensure that the juvenile in conflict with law is socially integrated and not singled out in the society. “Social integration of the juvenile in conflict with law should be paramount or the concept of the juvenile justice Act will fail if he/she is left without any measure of rehabilitation,” she said.

Title: Ministers propose lifting liquor ban in Chanda, imposing it at Yavatmal
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chandrapur/Yavatmal: State minister for relief and rehabilitation and guardian minister of Chandrapur Vijay Wadettiwar on Friday directed setting up of a committee to review the liquor ban in Chandrapur district. Just a day earlier, water conservation minister and NCP state president Jayant Patil had supported NGO Swamini Daru Bandi Samiti’s demand for a ban on liquor in the farm suicide capital Yavatmal.

Chandrapur collector Kunal Khemnar will form a seven-member committee, including government and non-government members, by next week to review the liquor ban. Wadettiwar wanted the committee to evaluate the status and success prohibition, before the government takes a call on lifting prohibition.

“Formal directives with details of number of members, scope of committee and its timeline is expected in next couple of days,” Khemnar told TOI.

Sources close to Wadettiwar said the panel will have seven members and get a month to submit its report. The committee will analyse any improvement in health of citizens, and reduction in addiction after the ban. It will also scrutinize reports of rise in drug smuggling and addiction, including use of small children in this.

The BJP-led government had declared liquor ban in Chandrapur on April 1, 2015, following the initiative of then finance minister Sudhir Mungantiwar. Now, over five years of ban, police have booked 37,214 offences in connection with liquor smuggling, sale and possession, and arrested 41,995 accused by the end of 2019. Illegal liquor worth Rs93.70 crores was seized and 8,024 vehicles confiscated for the smuggling. The total booty seized is worth Rs219 crore.

Meanwhile, on Thursday, Patil forwarded a memorandum submitted to him by the delegation of Swamini Daru Bandi Samiti of Yavatmal to excise minister Dilip Valse Patil. Patil was move the crying old tribal woman, Motibai Todsam of Ghatanji, who cried while asking the minister, “How long should I suffer and face the thrashing of my drunkard hubby?”

The Swamini Samiti had, during the ‘Hallabol’ padyatra of NCP by MP Supriya Sule, Jayant Patil and Dhananjay Munde, extracted a promise to ban liquor in Yavatmal if their party comes to power. On July 17, 2018, Jayant Patil had also raised the issue in the legislature and demanded a ban.

Patil has now again assured the Swamini activists he would support liquor ban in Yavatmal.

BJP state president Kakasaheb Danve too had, at the behest of then chief minister Devendra Fadnavis, given a written assurance to Swamini Samiti to appoint a commission to study the liquor ban in Yavatmal. Nothing had come out of the assurance.

Title: AMC selects 3 sites for PMAY scheme
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has finalised three sites for housing projects under ‘the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY). The civic body has submitted a proposal to the district collector seeking permission for acquiring the sites at Teesgaon, Brijwadi and Kanchanwadi.

“The sites shortlisted by the civic body will be used to raise affordable housing projects under the central governmen’s PMAY scheme. A 52-acre land in Teesgaon surrounded by hills and a water body has been finalised for the PMAY project,” said mayor Nandkumar Ghodele.

“We have submitted a proposed to the district collector for the acquisition of the land. The proposal is likely to get approved,” Ghodele said.

The municipal corporation has also identified a 22.5 acre land in Brijwadi and 2.5 acre land in Kanchanwadi for the housing projects. The proposal for land acquisition will soon be sent to the district collector for approval.

Meanwhile, land in Mitmita on the outskirts of the city and a site in Karodi on the Mumbai highway which were earlier considered for housing projects have been struck off.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey had visited the said lands and assessed the sites for feasibility of the project.

The AMC is also seeking to acquire 72-acre in Mitmita for tiger and lion safari park. This will be in addition to the 123-acre that has already been earmarked for the safari park.

As many as 85,000 residents of the city had applied to the civic body seeking benefit of the Centre’s housing scheme.

However, the AMC found that only 52,000 applicants were eligible for the scheme. The beneficiaries will get affordable housing through different components of the PMAY.

In April 2019, the municipal corporation conducted a camp for 731 applicants who had applied for financial support of Rs 2.5 lakh under the PMAY for building a house.

The AMC is also responsible for building a township for applicants from economically weaker sections. The civic body will seek help of other agencies for the project. It is currently in the process of acquiring land for the same.

Title: Oncologists raise paediatric cancer concerns
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Aurangabad: Oncologists on Friday said changes in lifestyle, use of pesticide and exposure to radiation could not be ruled out as reasons for paediatric cancer.

Addressing a a workshop at the Government Cancer Hospital on Friday, the oncologists said cases of paediatric cancer have doubled in the developing countries over the past 10 years.

The paediatric oncology department of Government Cancer Hospital (GCH) held the workshop in association with NGO CanKids Kidscan, Aurangabad Academy of Paediatrics and Indian Academy of Paediatrics- Haematology Oncology Chapter.

Aditi Lingayat, organising secretary and head of the paediatric oncology department, GMCH Aurangabad, said the rise in the number of paediatric cancer patients could be attributed to the changes in lifestyle, use of pesticides and exposure to radiation.

The experts said hematolymphoid (blood and blood components) tumours and cancers of kidney, liver and brain were most common among children. “There is 70% cure in usual cases and the percentage goes up to 90 in the early stage of diagnosis,” said Farookh Aziz, an associate professor at GMCH.

Title: With borrowed wheels, Trichy girl places third at national school games
Content:
A Radhika

TRICHY: For 16-year-old A Radhika, it was a dream-come-true when she secured the third place in her debut national event in road cycling at Pune on December 29. Born to daily wagers, the girl who studies in a government school in Trichy district, however, thanks her friend for lending his carbon wheels for the 65th national school games 2019-20 where the tough and better-off show their mettle.Though she had bagged several medals in state-level tournaments Radhika knew that her alloy wheels may not help at the national school games. Organized by School Games Federation of India for under-19 girls, the event sees participants from across the country with better road bikes.Radhika has been getting good support for her endeavour from elder brother A Muruganandam, 27, a mechanic. However, they could not afford a pair of carbon wheels worth Rs 50,000. “We managed to assemble her whole cycle for Rs 50,000 after much hardship. Getting a pair of wheels alone for that much money was simply unimaginable,” said Muruganandam. It was then that a friend offered the carbon wheels and he is overjoyed to see his sister making her national debut impressively.Her win has now given them hope and he expects her to keep the momentum in the upcoming events as well. Rajesh C, an international cyclist and Radhika’s coach for the last four years, said cycling is all about equipment. Radhika could do wonders if she got a better road bike and also better diet for intense training. “She is extremely promising and we look forward to equipping her with some better techniques,” he said.Radhika says she was aiming for the first position at the 21-km event but just couldn’t make it. The tournament was very useful as she could experience the intense competition at the national level. “I find it a good beginning but I see Olympics as my destination. I am already a bit late to aspire for the international level because of my age, but I wish to make it,” she said.

Title: BDA launches crack down on illegal colonies
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bareilly: The Bareilly Development Authority (BDA) has identified around 200 under-construction residential colonies being developed illegally within the city and its outskirts.

According to BDA records, nearly 230 residential colonies have come up in different parts of the city, of which, around 40 colonies are developed or being constructed under the BDA guidelines. BDA officials said that “warning” notices are being served to builders, following which, demolition of these unauthorised colonies will be initiated.

A recent survey stated that several residential colonies were developed against the development authority’s guidelines. BDA vice-chairperson Divya Mittal said, “Around 40 residential colonies, in areas such as Ramganga Nagar, Biharman Nagla, Transport Nagar, and other colonies registered in Real Estate Regulatory Act (RERA) are developed as per the rules while the rest have made serious violations. They are either developing the structure against the approved building plan, occupying government land such as using greenbelt area or setting up commercial development on layout passed under residential category and vice-versa.”

Unauthorised residential colonies have come up at Pilibhit Bypass road, Dohra road, Biharman Nagla, Kargaina-Budaun road, Jogi Navada, Lal Phatak road and Shahjahanpur road Chawni, among others. Mittal added, “Legal action will be initiated against all such unauthorised construction.”

The BDA VC further said, “An action plan is being prepared against unauthorised construction. Besides, we will apprise other government authorities such as municipal corporation, power department to mandatorily cross-verify the approved building plans ahead of giving water/electricity connections.”

In the past few days, the BDA has demolished three under-construction residential colonies in Bara Bypass, Izzatnagar and Bhojipura. Eleven under-construction shops being illegally developed on building layout plan approved by BDA under ‘residential category’ near Dohra road were also pulled down.

Title: MIM launches women’s wing before civic polls
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Aurangabad: The All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen (MIM) on Friday launched the party’s state-level women’s wing ahead of the civic elections likely to be held in April this year.

The unit will have women party workers from various sections of society, said party officials present at its launch ceremony at the Maulana Azad Research Centre here. MP Imtiaz Jaleel, who is also the state president of MIM, declared lawyer Asma Shaikh president of its women’s wing named after Razia Sultana.

A number of MIM women functionaries, including some corporators, attended the launch event. Addressing the event, Jaleel said women were leading various movements across the country, including the one at Shaheen Bagh. “We have had women corporators in the civic body, but there was a need for an organised unit. Our new wing will be instrumental in addressing the misconception that MIM is a party for only Muslims. If we want to contest the attempts to weaken the Constitution, we should come together forgetting caste and religions,” he said.

Title: Probe on slow track since SIT demand, but won’t be impacted much: Pune police
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The further investigation into the Elgar Parishad case , after filing of two chargesheets, slowed down ever since a demand for an SIT probe into the police action was raised, a senior officer, who is a part of the probe team, said on Friday.The officer told TOI, “As of now, a forensic analysis of the electronic devices seized during search operations at the residences of activists Hany Babu and Stan Swamy is going on. We are also awaiting the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s response to an appointment sought for the analysis of a broken hard disk recovered from the e-device of P Varavara Rao, one of the nine arrested activists.”Another officer from the Pune police probe team said, “The Elgar case is based on solid evidence collected against each accused. The police’s job has been, time and again, validated and appreciated by the superior courts, including high courts and the Supreme Court. We shall continue with our search for the absconding accused named in the chargesheets. We have secured the (Pune) court’s permission under Section 173 (8) of the Code of Criminal Procedure to continue with our probe. Supplementary chargesheet(s) will be furnished anytime during the course of or after the trial when we arrest the absconding accused.”Both the officers referred to Thursday’s review meeting before state home minister Anil Deshmukh and deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar and said, “We (police) briefed the ministers on the case background, factual details and the evidence collected. We also clarified the doubts raised during the meeting.”Senior IPS officer Ravindra Kadam , who was Joint Commissioner of Police in Pune when the case was registered and is well-versed with the state’s anti-Naxalite operations, told TOI, “The state’s review of the police probe into the Elgar case is distinct from the ongoing investigation. The review exercise is an administrative matter and the state has not yet taken any decision. The chargesheets are before the court and further investigation is continuing.”The case is at the stage of framing of charges before the special UAPA court in Pune and it is expected to commence after the court satisfies itself that the accused have been provided with all copies of the voluminous seized e-data.The court directed the prosecution on January 21 to file a written submission on a joint application moved by the nine arrested accused stating that it must be ensured first that the hash values of the copies provided to them matched with that of the originals in the devices. The matter is slated for a hearing on January 27.

Title: Lt Gen SK Saini appointed Vice Chief of Indian Army
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune: General Officer Commanding-in-Chief of Southern Command Lt Gen SK Saini on Friday relinquished the command of Southern Army. He has been appointed the Vice-Chief of the Army Staff of the Indian Army.

In a solemn ceremony on his departure, the Army Commander paid homage to the martyrs by laying a wreath at the National War Memorial at Ghorpadi.

“The Army Commander has given the required impetus to operational and logistics issues greatly enhancing the operational efficiency of the Southern Command whose area of responsibility includes 11 States and four Union Territories,” stated a press release issued by the command.

“Some of the major achievements during his tenure include the Indian Army winning the International Army Scout Masters Competition defeating formidable teams from Russia, Ukraine and China, orchestration of a large exercise with troops in the Deserts i.e. exercise Sindhu Sudarshan in November 2019,” it added.

Besides, the commander has played a crucial role in undertaking massive flood relief and rescue operations in 34 districts spread over five states, including Maharashtra. Over 45,000 people of these states were moved to safe locations during the operations.

“Multiple joint training exercises with friendly foreign countries, including the Africa-India joint field training exercise (AFINDEX) having 18 participating countries and joint tri-services exercise INDRA between India and Russia were conducted under his leadership,” the release stated.

The commander has also managed to resolve many pending land issues and enhanced synergy between the defence forces and defence civil organizations.

“Administrative issues like education, discipline, and medical were given due emphasis, wherein development initiatives involving schools, professional colleges and hospitals got initiated and executed at various locations including that at Pune,” the Army authorities said.

Title: Jagan’s mass contact programme Pallebata to commence from Feb 1
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Amaravati: Following in his father YS Rajasekhara Reddy’s footsteps, chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy is scheduled to start his village tours programme ‘ Pallebata ’ from February 1. The initiative is similar to the ‘Rachabanda’ programme started by YSR when he was CM of undivided AP.

Though Jagan has been addressing public meetings to announce the launch of welfare schemes, he has been out of mass contact since coming into power about seven months ago. Now that most of his government’s welfare programmes have been grounded, the CM feels the time is right to start his mass contact initiative, where he would get to interact with people directly and check if the welfare schemes were reaching the beneficiaries.

Interestingly, he will be touring the villages even while farmers continue their protests in Amaravati against the government’s decision to shift the capital. However, the YSRC believes the issue is confined to only 29 villages in the area and not in other parts of the state. In fact, Jagan is likely make a strong pitch on decentralisation of development during his mass contact programme.

The chief minister is also banking on the many welfare schemes launched by his government to make his standing among the people intact. Besides Raithu Bharosa for farmers, financial assistance to auto and taxi drivers, tailors, weavers and women from self-help groups, the government has disbursed nearly Rs 6,500 crore for Amma Vodi scheme. The process of identifying those who were left out of the scheme in the first phase is on, and the amount is likely to be remitted to the beneficiaries’ bank accounts in the first week of February.

The Arogya Sri scheme has been revamped through the addition of more diseases in the list and expansion of hospital chain to neighbouring states. The government’s initiative to renovate schools and hospitals has also gone down well with the people. Though there was some uproar over shortage of sand during the initial months of the government, the issue has now subsided after the government streamlined the supplies.

Title: Three booked for passing off 5 kg fake gold to get loans
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Kranti Chowk police have registered two case of cheating, forgery and criminal conspiracy against three suspects for allegedly duping two banks by passing off fake gold for obtaining two loans — totally worth Rs 1.05 crore.

The suspects obtained the said amount by passing off 5,199 gm fake gold.

Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad termed it be a full-fledged racket operated with the help of gold valuers. “We suspect it to be much bigger than what has come to the fore. We want banks to check and come forward with the complaints,” said Prasad.

The latest offence involves Samarthnagar branch of the Maharashtra Gramin Bank and Khadkeshwar branch of the Nagar Urban Co-operative Bank.

Crime branch inspector Madhukar Sawant said, “The suspects in the case have reportedly threatened a gold valuer and forced him to pass off fake gold weighing 2.5kg as original one. This resulted in to three suspects bagging gold loan of Rs 56.50 lakh from Nagar bank.”

“In the second case, it has come to fore that the suspects took loan of Rs 48.57 lakh by depositing 2.6kg fake gold,” he said.

Title: TN: Sewage enters housing board tenements in Pattinapakkam
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Sewage water in a house at Srinivasapuram in Pattinampakkam

CHENNAI: Residents of housing board tenements for economically weaker sections in Srinivasapuram , Pattinapakkam , face a hard time as sewage has entered their homes.

Toilets began flooding in at least six houses in a building on Wednesday night. The water mixed with raw sewage later entered the hall and kitchen. “We were sleeping on the floor when we realised that our room was filled with drainage water. It was disgusting and stinking,” said A Pushkala, a resident. Pushkala and her two daughters stayed up all night removing the water and cleaning their house. “Our house is a mess, but the water flow has not stopped,” she said Residents said last week their street was clogged with sewage. When they contacted local officials, they inspected the spot and said the pipes needed repair.

“We saw a few workers cleaning the drains, but now the same thing is happening inside our homes,” said A Suguna, another resident. Suguna lives in a one-room tenement with her four siblings, all aged over 35 and diagnosed with spinocerebellar degeneration, a rare genetic disorder often associated with poor coordination of eyes, hands and speech. Due to their condition, the four can’t walk and are confined within the house. “I have been trying to relocate them to a friend or a relative’s place, but everyone seems too busy to take them in,” said Suguna. She has now erected a small tent outside their home, where her brothers and sister can sleep. “There is only one bed in the house and due to the stench and sewage, mosquitoes are swarming everywhere. We sleep outside now,” she said. Some residents have moved their furniture to their friends’ homes to avoid damage and are using public toilets and having food from nearby stalls. They blame the local officials for ignoring their plight, despite repeated calls. “It’s been two days and we have been staying outside. Our house is not in a liveable condition, we hope the authorities repair sewage lines,” said Suguna.

A corporation engineer in the area said, “We suspect that something went wrong when the workers were clearing the blockage in the drains on the street. We will fix it.”

Title: Builder penalized for unfair trade practice
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune: The additional district consumer court here has directed the proprietor of a realty firm to refund amounts in the range of Rs6.70 lakh to Rs12.47 lakh with 18% per annum interest to four home buyers in a stalled housing project at Dongargaon in Haveli taluka.

In a recent order, the bench of the court president JV Deshmukh and members Shubhangi Dunakhe and Anil Jawalekar also directed Sumit Kumar Bhalotia, proprietor of Spark Realty, to pay Rs55,000 each to the four complainants towards compensation and legal costs. The court has given the proprietor a month from the date of receipt of the order to comply with the same, failing which an interest at 21% per annum will apply.

In January 2015, the complainants — Sameer P Deshmukh and Govind P Khatri from Akola, Prabhakar B Deshmukh from Buldhana and Vrishali V Deshpande from New Delhi — had booked flats in ‘Spark Urban Bliss’ housing project floated by Bhalotia’s firm. Deshmukh and Khatri paid Rs6.70 lakh each while Prabhakar Deshmukh paid Rs9.37 lakh and Deshpande paid Rs12.47 lakh towards part consideration, stamp duty and registration fees.

Lawyer Nilesh Bhandari, who represented the complainants, said, “An agreement to sale was registered between the builder and each of the four complainants. The builder had promised to deliver possession of the flats within 30 months from the date of agreement executed on January 6, 2015. However, the project never took off and the complainants started pursuing the builder for a refund. They approached the additional district consumer court when the builder failed to refund their money with interest.” Lawyer Mohnish Patekar also represented the complainants in the matter.

Along with their complaints, the home buyers had submitted all supporting receipts and documents showing their transaction with the builder and the same was not denied by the latter in his written version to the court. The builder had opposed the complaints on the grounds that the same were barred by limitation, but the court observed that there was a continuous cause of action owing to the builder’s failure to comply with the promise made in the agreement.

The bench held, “The complainants had paid the part consideration, though opponent (builder) agreed to deliver the possession of flat within 30 months from the date of execution of the agreement, opponent had not delivered possession to the complainants. Thus, there is a delay in giving possession of the flats. Therefore, complainants are entitled to receive the payment made by them.”

The bench further held, “Taking a huge amount from the complainants, not complying with the terms of the agreement and non-refund of the amount by the opponent are the reasons to conclude that the opponent is not only involved in unfair trade practice but caused harassment and mental agony to the complainants to which he is liable to pay compensation.”

Title: Goa’s growth potential yet to be achieved: Finance commission
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The 15th finance commission , which concluded its three-day visit to the state on Friday, said that Goa has a long way to go to achieve its growth potential. Commission chairman N K Singh said that the state faces “huge challenges” when it comes to solid waste management, drainage and sanitation.Aside from addressing legacy issues, Goa also needs to find efficient ways of resource mobilization if it wants to fund its growth, Singh said in his brief remarks.“Goa’s growth potential has yet to be fully exploited, although Goa has achieved notable progress,” said Singh. “Has it reached or is it close to reaching its growth potential?”My reply would be no, because I think Goa has huge opportunities and we need to have a combination of measures which will help it achieve its growth potential.”Singh was speaking to reporters after the finance commission concluded all stakeholder meetings. The commission will now study the state government’s financial proposals and then decide on the quantum of grants that need to be devolved to Goa.The commission has already finalised the allocation for the first financial year (2021), but will be giving an award for five more years from 2021-2026. The report on the award of funds for 2021 is expected to be released soon after Parliament’s budget session. The report for five years will have to be presented by October 30.The Goa government has asked for funds for agriculture, solid waste management, disaster management, tourism and renewable energy. The commission agreed on the identified sectors but made certain additional observations.“You cannot get improved demographic management without social sector expenditure,” said Singh. “With regard to solid waste management, drainage, and sanitation, Goa has huge challenges which lie ahead, apart from the legacy issues that Goa has inherited. That is something the Goa government must focus on.”The finance commission said that the Goa government also needs to prioritise agricultural productivity, diversification of crops and pattern of agriculture in the state.The Goa government, Singh said, has asked for a special package to compensate for mining losses, the sluggishness in the growth of tourism, sanitation and improved solid waste management. Singh also admitted that Goa had sought for greater devolution of funds, seeking 50% in the share of central taxes against the present 42%. The chairman also agreed that Goa voiced a concern that the state was not being recognized and incentivised for having better human indices and demographic factors.“We will see how best we can balance need, equity and efficiency,” Singh said. “We recognize the role Goa can play in improving India’s overall economic growth, and we recognize that Goa has achieved notable success in several parameters.”

Title: High court asks DGP for report on ways to check derogatory posts
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chennai: Taking note of increasing incidents of anonymous defamatory and derogatory statements/videos being uploaded and circulated on social media , the Madras high court on Friday directed the Tamil Nadu Director-General of Police to apprise it on the mechanism available to tackle the issue.

Justice M Dhandapani also directed the DGP to file a comprehensive report on the action taken against such persons by January 29. The judge passed the interim order while hearing the bail application moved by A Maruthachalam of Coimbatore who was arrested for uploading a video denigrating a sitting judge of the high court. When the plea came up for hearing, the petitioner submitted that he had no role in uploading the video and claimed he had been falsely implicated in the case.

Noting that the contention of the petitioner was not satisfactory, Justice Dhandapani said, “In recent days, defamatory statements criticising persons holding constitutional posts and their families are being circulated by several persons without any evidence to substantiate their claims.”

To curb such illegal activities it would suffice to issue directions to the cybercrime branch of police to ascertain whether there was any mechanism available to nab such offenders, the judge said and directed the DGP to file the report.

Title: Rs 50-cr boost to increase capacity of Nigdi WTP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The civic body has made a budgetary provision of Rs 50 crore for augmenting the capacity of the water treatment plant in Nigdi by 100 MLD, the work for which is expected to start before March 31.

The capacity boost aims at meeting the needs of the growing population in Pimpri Chinchwad and ensuring adequate water distribution in the areas reeling under low-pressure supply.

“There was no budgetary provision for the project in the current budget. With the allocation of Rs 50 crore now, we can invite bids for allotting the contract for the project,” Makrand Nikam, chief of the water supply department of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC), said.

The provision was made in the budget after the general body of the PCMC recently approved a short-notice resolution in this regard.

Nikam said, “The PCMC lifts water from Pavana river at Ravet bund through the pumping station, which has 20 pumps.”

“Of these, 16 pumps will be replaced to increase their pumping capacity,” Nikam added

A senior civic official said the PCMC would pay additional charges for lifting another 100 MLD from Pavana river.

Title: Pune: Survey for underground metro in final stages
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

The work on the underground tunnels has started

PUNE: The structural integrity audit of more than 1,600 buildings along the underground Metro alignment is in the home stretch.

Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) had embarked on the exercise six months ago, and officials said only 200 buildings were left to be studied. An official said they were speaking to the owners of these buildings in a bid to speed up the survey so that a report can be submitted to Pune Municipal Corporation .

“Our teams have finished the survey of most of the stretch between Budhwar Peth and Swargate. The owners of the 200 structures have raised some queries ... we are holding talks with them,” a MahaMetro official said.

Buildings that are within a 50m radius of the underground tunnel’s alignment come under the ambit of the survey, which includes a detailed inspection of the building’s overall state, the condition of each wall and cracks, if any. All these details are documented and photographed.

“During the inspections completed so far, the surveyors have identified four weak structures, all of them in the Kasba Peth area. We will be handing over a detailed report to the owners and also to PMC about these weak or vulnerable structures once the entire survey is completed. We have the option of rehabilitating the families in another location during the tunnelling work as a precautionary measure. MahaMetro will work on this along with PMC,” a senior MahaMetro official said.

The survey is a compulsory part of the underground tunnelling work. MahaMetro has already completed a similar survey on the Agriculture College-Budhwar Peth stretch, in which not a single structure was found to be dangerous.

The tunnel is being bored 20 metres below the ground level and officials said this minimizes the chances of any buildings being damaged. Two tunnel-boring machines have already been pressed into action and are drilling a tunnel through the layer of basaltic rock under Pune.

Title: RGUHS moots Rs 25 lakh fine for giving up seat to counter seat blocking
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: To put an end to the seat-blocking scam in medical colleges, the government is thinking of increasing penalty for candidates who reserve seats only to surrender them after the mop-up round.

Rajiv Gandhi University of Health Sciences submitted a report to the medical education department recently, recommending the existing rules be changed.

“We want to bring in a rule that no seat can be surrendered after the mop-up round,” said Dr CN Ashwath Narayan , deputy chief minister and minister for medical education. The minister said he will place the report before the cabinet for approval.

Seats surrendered after the mop-up round are transferred to the management quota and sold at high prices. Penalty would be exempted in certain cases when the candidate would surrender a seat even after the mop-up round in case s/he got a seat in a better medical college.

However, the provision was misused by some candidates and colleges, leading to the infamous seat-blocking scam. The RGUHS report said students must be discouraged from surrendering seats and the penalty be increased to Rs 25 lakh from the existing Rs 5 lakh. Further, no medical college should admit a student after the cutoff date to avoid misuse.

Title: Maharashtra: Woman, friend from Bahrain duped of Rs 3.45 lakh in job fraud
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A septuagenarian man from Hyderabad has come under police scanner after a 34-year-old woman from Khadki lodged an FIR on Thursday accusing him of duping her and her Bahrain-based friend of Rs3.45 lakh on the promise of giving them jobs.The elderly man took the money from the duo citing visa and ticket charges and duped them.After working in Bahrain from 2014, the woman quit her job and returned to Khadki in January last year after her father’s death. She started looking for a job again in some foreign country from May last year.The woman’s uncle gave her the contact of the 70-year-old man from Hyderabad and told her that he could help her in getting overseas job. “When the woman contacted him, the Hyderabad-based man told her that he would help her getting a job in Singapore and said he would charge Rs1.5 lakh as fees,” said an officer from the Khadki police.The woman transferred Rs50,000 to his bank account through two transactions on May 20 and 21 last year.She then contacted her friend and told him about her plans to get a new job in Singapore. “The woman’s friend then requested her to arrange a job for him too. When the woman contacted the suspect, he told her the he would charge her friend Rs2 lakh,” the officer said.The woman’s friend agreed and sent Rs2 lakh to her. Of it, the woman transferred Rs1 lakh to the elderly man’s account.“In September last year, the suspect told the woman that her and her friend’s jobs had been confirmed and they would have to be in Hyderabad for medical examination. He again took Rs15,000 from them,” the officer said.After the woman and her friend went to Hyderabad, the suspect got their medical examination done in a hospital. After a few days, he contacted the woman and took Rs50,000 for visas and Rs1.3 lakh for tickets. After taking a total of Rs3.45 lakh from the woman and her friend, the man from Hyderabad stopped accepting their calls.“When the suspect did not respond her calls after repeated efforts, the woman became suspicious and lodged the complaint,” the officer said.

Title: Sainik welfare board’s pension cell to shut down in Feb
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune: The Maharashtra Sainik Welfare Board plans to shut down its pension cell in February over ‘unsatisfactory performance’ in the last three months.

The cell had resolved 1.16 lakh cases, mostly related to pensions of ex-servicemen since it was set up in January 2013 and get about Rs 8 crore in arrears for ex-servicemen’s families.

The board’s officiating director Laxminaryan Mishra told TOI, “The decision to close down was taken after an assessment of the number of pension matters processed and resolved over the last three months and other factors.”

“It is imperative for the director to understand the complexity in a single case. It is tedious and time-consuming and resolving one case requires significant efforts,” Group Captain (retired) SS Phatak, who is an in-charge of the cell, told TOI.

According to the cell’s records, of the 1.16 cases, 16,540 cases were of widows of ex-servicemen and war widows of the soldiers who died in wars and operations.

“In many cases, the basic information such as date of birth, spelling of the name and qualifying service of individual soldier are wrong. We have to first process the papers with the records office of the unit or regiment. We then need to take it up with the principal controller of defence accounts. On many occasions, we have to maintain long correspondence. One needs to understand each case is peculiar and hence the difficulty level,” Phatak added.

A record of each case is being maintained by the cell. “We do a periodic analysis of each case and follow it up with the authorities to resolve matters,” Phatak said.

Some cases like Kashibai Yadav (85), a WWII widow, are unique. She drew a pension of Rs 8,000. “The pension cell followed up our case with the government for more than a year. Now, my mother gets more than Rs 30,000 as pension. Besides, we got Rs 24 lakh in four decades of arrears. My mother could get what was due to her only because of the cell,” Pandit, her son, told TOI over phone from Solapur.

The cell also helped 72-year-old Chitra Samant, widow of Vir Chakra awardee Lieutenant Suresh Samant, get her pension dues after a few decades.

Title: Techie loses Rs 37 lakh in fraud on dating website
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A software engineer (32) fell for a business venture trap of a trickster, apparently a woman from the UK he had got in touch with on a dating website , and lost Rs37 lakh.The Airport police on Thursday said the incident occurred between March 23 and 29, 2019. The police booked cyber crooks under the relevant sections of IPC and the Information Technology Act.The techie got friendly with the woman after he registered his name on the website in December 2018. The FIR stated that the techie had shared his networking site details in March 2019 and started chatting with her. “The woman told me that she was working as a manager with a private bank in London,” the techie said in the FIR.“The woman told the man that she had plans to start a business in India and would soon visit the country. She sent photocopies of her flight tickets to him on March 25, 2019, stating that she would land in India after two days,” the FIR stated.Police said the techie then received a call from a person impersonating as a Customs official, asking him if he knew the woman with a particular name.
