When the techie said he knew her, the man told him that she was held at the airport along with 10,000 pounds.“The second person told the techie to pay Customs charges, income tax and Goods and Service Tax to release her and the pounds. He told the techie that he has to procure anti-money laundering certificate,” a police officer said.“The techie did not verify the authenticity of the caller and deposited over Rs37 lakh in 23 bank accounts,” the officer said.The techie had initially filed a complaint application with the cybercrime police station. The cybercrime officials conducted preliminary investigations and registered the FIR. The case was transferred to the Airport police.

Title: ‘Ensure all beneficiaries get house sites by Ugadi’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Amaravati: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has directed officials to accept fresh application for house sites across the state to cover all eligible beneficiaries . He particularly asked them to ensure that every eligible poor family gets a house plot by Ugadi festival.

“Officials should work overtime if required to achieve the goal as giving house sites to the poor is the government’s top priority. All 25 lakh people should get house sites by Ugadi,” the CM said during a review meeting to check the progress of identification of beneficiaries and land availability, on Friday.

He told officials not to take the Praja Sadhikara Survey (PSS) as benchmark to identify the beneficiaries, but carry out physical field-level verification. “The sites identified for the purpose should be congenial for living. The beneficiaries should be happy about the plots allotted to them. Site allotment should be made only after the beneficiary is satisfied. He should be able to grow plants on the plots. I request you to take enough care so that no one is left out,” the CM said.

He also asked officials to allot suitable alternative plots to those who were living on encroached lands, adding he would make surprise visits to villages from February 1 to review the implementation of the programme.

Title: HC tells ex-cop to appear for probe in idol theft case
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has directed a retired police official, against whom the Madurai idol wing sleuths have registered a case, to appear before the investigating officer on his plea for anticipatory bail. The prosecution said petitioner K Balasubramanian, 74, a resident of Madurai, was working as SI attached to Moolakaraipatti police station in Tirunelveli district and was entrusted with the investigation of various idol theft cases while on special duty between 1977-78. The prosecution said it had received a complaint from a person named R Dhanasekaran that Balasubramanian had trespassed into a place of worship and stolen an idol during this period.

Based on the complaint, a criminal case was registered against him under IPC section 457 (2) by the Madurai idol wing police. The petitioner said he had discharged his duty diligently as the investigating officer as a result of which 14 notorious criminals involved in idol theft were arrested. He had recovered the stolen idols which have been marked as material object in the concerned criminal courts and he had assisted the prosecution resulting in the conviction of all the accused. All these recovered idols were returned to the concerned temples. He said he had retired from service as inspector of police in 2005. It is unfortunate that the police are suspecting an honest officer for the incident which occurred 40 years ago based on the complaint of a person. He stated he is suffering from heart disease and other age-related ailments.

He is ready to cooperate with the investigation but if he is arrested it would result in loss of his reputation. Hence he moved the HC Madurai bench seeking anticipatory bail in the case registered against him. When the petition was heard on Friday, Justice G R Swaminathan directed the petitioner to appear before the investigating officer on Monday and cooperate with the inquiry. The case was adjourned to January 29 for further hearing. tnn

Title: Headless for four years, Goa human rights commission finally gets chairperson
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

U V Bakre

PANAJI: After four years of being headless and six months of being non-functional, the Goa Human Rights Commission (GHRC) will soon be at full strength. The state government has cleared the file to appoint former high court judge U V Bakre as its new chairperson , with former district judges Pramod Kamat and Desmond D’Costa as its other members.

An official said the file has been moved to the governor for the constitution of the new commission. The only member of the commission, former judge A D Salkar, completed his term in July 2019.

Since then, the body has been non-functional.

But it had been headless since March 2016, when former Patna high court chief justice P K Misra retired. After the retirement, Salkar was appointed acting chairman.

However, whenever orders passed by Salkar reached the high court, it observed that the post could be only occupied by a retired chief justice of a high court or chief justice or judge of the Supreme Court.

A senior government officer said that later, the Centre permitted state governments to appoint a former high court judge as chairperson of the commission.

The commission had a single member since September 2018, when J A Keny expired. And after Salkar retired, the commission was rendered virtually defunct. It ceased to pass orders, issue noticed, conduct investigations and hold proceedings.

When functioning, the commission received an average of five complaints a week and hears up to 12 cases a day.

Title: Northerlies may bring chill back to parts of Maharashtra in early February
Content:
Forecasters say that beginning of February is still likely to register more instances of winter-like night tem... Read More

PUNE: The cold may return to most parts of Maharashtra at the start of February. But, north Madhya Maharashtra and central Konkan, including districts like Nashik, Jalgaon, border areas of north Pune district, may still see slightly warmer than normal winter nights, a fresh extended range forecast on Friday by the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said.Winter has a little more than a month left to recede from the country, but minimum temperatures have remained above normal levels during most days in north Madhya Maharashtra.The extended range forecast for the next two weeks seems to indicate that though minimum temperatures would be normal to below normal over vast regions of the country till February 6, north Madhya Maharashtra, central Konkan and parts of south India may not record a significant fall in minimum temperatures.The extended range forecast shows one patch (north Madhya Maharashtra, including parts of north Pune district) in Maharashtra that could still see slightly above normal minimum temperature till February 6 when the rest of the state may record below normal night temperatures. But forecasters say that beginning of February is still likely to register more instances of winter-like night temperatures than January.Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI, “During the week January 31 to February 6, though the night minimum temperatures are likely to continue to remain below the normal to near normal over major parts of India, we foresee slightly above normal minimums in parts of north Madhya Maharashtra and a small portion of central Konkan during that period. Meanwhile, coastal, south interior Karnataka, Rayalaseema, south coastal Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, are likely to be markedly above normal during some of the days.”He said the penetration of northerly winds in many parts of the state, except Vidarbha has been short-lived this season hence Madhya Maharashtra did not experience the cold this winter.“There has not been a period this winter when the penetration of cold winds from the western Himalayan region has been continuous in Maharashtra, especially parts of north Madhya Maharashtra, Marathwada and areas of Konkan. These winds can penetrate only for a couple of days and then they are cut off due to the position of the anti-cyclone over central India, time to time over Rajasthan and other time due to presence of easterly/south-easterly winds over the state,” Kashyapi said.

Title: PMC plans to come up with yet another traffic education park
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) plans to launch yet another traffic education initiative at Indraprastha garden in Yerawada at a cost of Rs4 crore, even though its earlier attempts at setting up such facilities at Chittaranjan Watika in Model colony and at Sarasbaug have come a cropper.

Vijay Kumbhar of Surajya Sangharsha Samittee, a citizens’ group, who conducts the ‘RTI Katta’ programme at Chittaranjan Watika garden, said that he has hardly seen anyone use the facility developed for traffic education. “I have been conducting the programme for around five years now. But I have not seen anybody use the facility. Even the upkeep of the infrastructure is not good,” he pointed out.

Civic officials said various equipment will be installed at the Indraprastha garden to educate children on traffic rules. Police and experts will conduct training sessions on traffic rules.

A proposal regarding setting up the park has been tabled before the city improvement committee. The park will have models of roads, signals, intersections and bridges. Pathways will also be created for pedestrians and bicycle users.

Simulators for two-wheelers, three-wheelers and four-wheelers will be installed to provide driving lessons to citizens. The park will also have a play area and a jungle gym. As per the civic body’s plan, around 2.5 acres of land will be needed for the project.

Activists said that though such projects are useful, the civic administration should make sure that the existing projects are put to good use before starting new ones. “The civic administration should check the usability of the project and footfall before spending public money. The PMC had started traffic education projects at parks here earlier as well but most of them are unused. Efforts should be made to ensure that earlier projects are used by people rather than starting new ones,” said Kumbhar.

However, the PMC officials said that the concept of the existing traffic parks and the one being proposed at Yerawada is different. “The new park will have actual training facility for driving along with traffic awareness. Other parks are confined to creating basic awareness about the rules and signages. The project will become a reality once it receives clearance from the civic committees,” the official said.

Title: Pune: Driver run over by own speeding vehicle
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 40-year-old tractor driver was killed after a stone came under one of the tyres of his speeding vehicle. He lost his balance and fell off it to eventually be run over by his vehicle at Yeolewadi in Kondhwa around 11.30am on Thursday.

The driver was transporting garbage and was driving the tractor at a high speed, the Kondhwa police said, while identifying the deceased as Pandurang Laxman Gaikwad of Yeolewadi in Kondhwa.

“Gaikwad had picked up the garbage from various places in the Kondhwa area and was heading to a closed quarry to dump the waste there,” assistant inspector DK Pawar of the Kondhwa police said.

Pawar said Gaikwad was speeding while he was passing a kaccha road gradient, where his tractor’s wheels went over a stone.

Pawar added that the impact of the accident was such that Gaikwad flung into the air .

When he fell on the road, his vehicle ran over him, killing him on the spot.

“The tractor ran amock for a few metres and stopped after it ascended a stone,” the assistant inspector said.

The Sassoon General Hospital in its advance post-mortem report certified the cause of Gaikwad’s death due to multiple injuries.

“We have registered an FIR against the victim Gaikwad after the investigations revealed that he himself was responsible for causing his death due to negligence,” Pawar said.

The assistant inspector of the Kondhwa police added that an offence has been registered against Gaikwad under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and the Motor Vehicles Act.

Title: Extension of CISF cover: Madras HC orders notice to Tamil Nadu government
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court on Friday ordered notice to the state government on a public interest litigation moved by a lawyer seeking to extend Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) protection to the entire high court premises and other subordinate courts in the state.

Advocate R Y George Williams also wanted the court to direct the authorities to install CCTV cameras in all the courts across the state to ensure effective surveillance.

Admitting the plea, a division bench of Justices M Sathyanarayanan and R Hemalatha directed the authorities to file their response by March 4.

According to the petitioner, the high court premises alone was brought under CISF protection since November 16, 2015. However, protection is not provided to other courts on the premises, including family courts, small causes court and labour court. Citing a series of crimes committed both inside and outside the subordinate courts on the high court premises, the petitioner highlighted the need to extend CISF protection to the other courts as well.

Title: Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray tells PMRDA to focus on CMP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Uddhav Thackeray

PUNE: Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Friday directed the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority officials to adhere to timelines for all the infrastructure projects and implement the Comprehensive Mobility Plan with emphasis on increasing public transport.

The CM, also the head of the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority ( PMRDA ), for the first time reviewed its projects on Friday after the new government was formed in the state.

Uddhav stressed on implementing the Comprehensive Mobility Plan (CMP) in phases to encourage people to use public transport after he learnt that 71% people used private transport for commuting. He told the PMRDA officials that land acquisition for the CMP projects should not be delayed.

Reviewing the proposed Hinjewadi-Shivajinagar Metro line, he said the other Metro lines mentioned in the CMP should be implemented at the earliest. A variety of issues like road, water schemes and more were discussed in the meeting.

Title: Will revive council after TDP comes to power, vows N Chandrababu Naidu
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

AMARAVATI: TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu on Friday vowed to revive the legislative council if TDP wins the 2024 assembly elections in the state. He, however, added that the YSRC government is unlikely to succeed in its plans to abolish the council considering the current political scenario in the country.

Naidu’s promise is seen as an attempt to keep his flock together in the wake of the ruling party’s efforts to create unrest among council members. Alleging that the YSRC government is scuttling democratic process because chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy is worried about facing the wrath of people, Naidu said council chairman MA Shariff upheld constitutional rights and ethics in public life by sending the three capital cities and CRDA repeal Bills to the select committee.

“YSRC leaders made all attempts to lure council members but failed as TDP members remained loyal to the party and people. The fighting spirit of the people of Amaravati inspired our party members in the council to stay together to protect the capital city. Some ministers even tried to attack the council chairman for not bowing down to their diktats. Jagan is working like a dictator and demolishing all democratic systems. He is upset as he was unsuccessful in bulldozing council members,” said Naidu.

Title: Accident deaths continue to dip in Madurai district
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Madurai: The number of people killed in road accidents in Madurai district police limits has come down by about 15% last year compared to the previous year. While the number of fatalities has been coming down in the last few years, a drastic decrease was recorded in 2018 when the deaths came down by 182 compared to 2017. In 2019, the deaths have dropped by as much as 45% compared to 2016.

A total of 282 people were killed in accidents last year compared to 330 in 2018. Police say various efforts like visible policing at accident-prone timings, awareness measures and increase in registration of traffic violation cases have helped bring down the deaths.

Madurai district superintendent of police N Manivannan told TOI that they could have reduced road fatalities further in 2019 as they were maintaining a 20% difference till September. However, things went slightly out of hand during Diwali and gurupooja as they had to concentrate on duties like bandobust. “With the important jallikattu events in Madurai district over, we are back to routine. They will start concentrating again on accident reduction soon,” he said.

The total number of accidents too has come down from 1,777 in 2018 to 1,694 in 2019, which is close to 5%. There are six sub-divisions in Madurai district, each led by a deputy superintendent level police officer. Among the sub-divisions, Melur (41%) achieved a drastic reduction in deaths last year compared to 2018. It was followed by Samayanallur with 21% and Oomachikulam 13%. Peraiyur and Usilampatti have performed badly as the number of deaths has increased by 9%. Thirumangalam recorded 3% more road deaths compared to the previous year.

An official from Peraiyur sub-division said they too had maintained good reduction till September in 2019. However, as many as seven deaths were reported within in one week during Diwali holidays. “Most of the deaths were from accidents involving bikes,” he said. An official from Melur sub-division said that most of the road deaths were taking place on the Madurai-Trichy four-way. Identifying black spots and introducing barricades to slow down vehicle speed have helped reduce the incidents. Villagers residing alongside the four-way were also sensitized to be cautious while using the road, he said. Pedestrians were told to use torch light while crossing the busy four-way road early in the morning and night to alert speeding drivers, he added.

Title: Accidents in city come down from 217 in 2018 to 183 in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Madurai: Deaths in road accidents have come down to an extent in the city with 183 people losing their lives in 2019, compared to 217 in 2018. City police officers said that most of them, who lost their lives, were two-wheeler commuters and pedestrians.

Deputy commissioner of police (traffic), Madurai city, K Sugumaran told TOI that efforts such as introduction of medians at important junctions and signals, increased registration of traffic violation cases and introduction of new signals have helped to reduce deaths due to road accidents.

He said that due to constraint of space in the narrow city roads, they had opted to use barricades to create medians as concrete ones will occupy more space. The medians have helped to streamline traffic movement and brought in some order among commuters, Sugumaran said.

Registration of traffic violation cases under six heads (signal jumping, using cell phone while driving, carrying passengers in goods vehicles, over speeding, drink and drive and rash riding) and two heads (helmet and seat belt cases) has increased in 2019 compared to its previous years. While 2,200 drunk driving cases were recorded in 2018, its double were registered in 2019, deputy commissioner said.

Traffic officials said that efforts taken during the New Year eve celebration this year helped to make sure it was incident free.

Title: Minimum temperature dips in Pune as cloud cover lifts
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pune recorded mainly clear skies on Friday morning

PUNE: Shivajinagar in Pune and Jalgaon were the coolest places in Madhya Maharashtra on Friday morning despite the above normal minimum temperature in the state.

Minimum temperatures are currently higher than normal in most locations in the state, including Pune, but there has been a slight fall in night temperatures. Pune recorded mainly clear skies on Friday morning, leading to a dip in its minimum temperature to 13.6 degrees C, the lowest in Madhya Maharashtra.

Jalgaon recorded a minimum temperature of 13.6 degrees C. Lohegaon’s minimum temperature was 15.9 degrees C on Friday. Both, Shivajinagar and Lohegoan’s night temperature was higher than normal by over 2 degrees C.

Gondia on Friday morning had a minimum temperature of 12.2 degrees C, followed by Osmanabad at 12.9 degrees C.

Minimum temperatures are expected to range from 13 degrees celsius to 15 degrees celsius till January 28. Haze at isolated places in the morning hours could be expected from January 27 for a few days as cloudy conditions may come back. Moisture in the air and consequent clouding are generally associated with haze in winter.

Title: Rupee Co-operative Bank plea to state co-operative commissioner to hasten merger proposal
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Sudhir Pandit , chairman, board of administrators, the Rupee Co-operative Bank , said that he had met the state co-operative commissioner and requested him to hasten the merger proposal with the MSC Bank .

The MSC Bank and Rupee Co-operative Bank submitted a joint proposal to the RBI last week. "I urged the new co-operative commissioner, Anil Kawde, to expedite the merger proposal," Pandit told TOI.

In case of co-operative banks, the states have an equal say (if not more), alongside the RBI. He further added that the bank would be able to give 2% interest on deposits that have been stuck since February 2013 when the RBI placed it under directions over poor financial health.

"Interest rates are at the bank's discretion. All through the period when the bank was under directions, we have not been allowed to lend. Since we have not earned, where can we pay the (higher) interest from," Pandit said.

Once the merger is through, the MSC Bank has offered a minimum interest rate of 6.5% on deposits. As per the proposal, customers can withdraw money in a staggered manner.

Title: ACB holds simultaneous raids at tehsildars’ offices
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vijayawada: Officials of the Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) conducted simultaneous raids at the offices of 21 tehsildars (mandal revenue officer) in all 13 districts of the state on Friday.

According to officials, they found several irregularities while checking records. Unaccounted cash of Rs 4 lakh was also unearthed during the raids.

ACB officials said that they also found several Meeseva applications regarding various grievances being kept pending beyond the prescribed time limits given by tehsildars.

In some cases, it was found that the applications were rejected without any valid reason and no register was maintained in this regard. Officials also found that a large number of title deeds-cum-e-passbooks received and ready for distribution were kept pending with deputy tehsildars and village revenue officers (VRO).

Sources also said that their raids could corroborate the fact that many officials only tend to hand over documents after receiving their share of the bribe.

Further, mandatory registers such as the mutation register and inward register were not maintained. In some offices, private persons were engaged by the tehsildar to carry out official work.

At several places during the raids, officials said that the petitioners complained of being made to run from pillar to post by tehsildars to carry out official work.

Title: Man dies as two cars collide near Kundadam
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Tirupur: A 45-year-old man was killed and four others, including a pregnant woman, injured in an accident after two cars collided with each other near Kundadam in the district on Thursday evening. Meanwhile, the pregnant woman delivered a baby in a private hospital.

T Gopalsamy of Seelanaickenpatti near Dharapuram was taking his cousin Manimegalai, who was pregnant, in a car to a private hospital in Coimbatore. The 26-year-old Manimegalai's husband Gowtham and her mother Saraswathi were also accompanying her in the car as Gopalsamy was at the wheel. When the vehicle was passing through Mettukadai near Kundadam on Coimbatore-Trichy Road, a car which was coming in the opposite direction collided with it, a police officer said.

Gopalsamy died on the spot as Gowtham sustained severe injuries while Manimegalai and Saraswathi suffered minor injuries. Sakthivel, 45, another car's driver, also sustained minor injuries. Manimegalai, Saraswathi and Gowtham were rushed to the private hospital in Coimbatore, to which they were heading earlier. Manimegalai delivered a baby in the hospital, the officer said. The Kundadam police registered a case against Sakthivel as preliminary investigations revealed that he drove the car negligently.

Title: TN Chamber seeks cut in I-T, GST rates in pre-budget memo
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Madurai: Reduction in income tax (IT) and GST rates are among the key demands put forward by the Tamil Nadu Chamber of Commerce and Industry (TNCCI) in their pre-budget memorandum to the finance ministry. TNCCI president N Jegatheesan, senior president S Rethinavelu and secretary J Selvam submitted the memorandum to the ministry in New Delhi on Wednesday.

In a bid to stimulate the economy by increasing purchasing power of consumers, the chamber suggested changes in IT slabs and rates. Pointing out that IT exemption limit of Rs 2.5 lakh fixed six years back, they suggested increasing the same to Rs 5 lakh.

They also suggested 5% IT for income in the range of Rs Rs 5-10 lakh and 10% from Rs 10-25 lakh. Stating that maximum IT rate should be 25% for income of above Rs 25 lakh, they also sought a further deduction in corporate tax to 15% for all companies.

Regarding GST, they sought four rates at 5, 10, 15 and 20% in place of the existing slabs of 5, 12, 18 and 28%. They said that 20% should only be fixed for sin goods and super luxury cars, adding that the rest should be in the 5-15% categories. Maximum GST for services should only be 15%.

Environmental friendly bio-diesel industry, which uses used cooking oil as feedstock, should be encouraged by reduction of GST from 12% to 15%. Seeking exemption for paper bags, as it is widely used as a viable alternative to plastic covers, they also pressed for reduction of GST on lamp oil from 12% to 5%.

They also emphasised one rate of tax for all goods covered under the same chapter under HSN Code structure under GST to rule out confusion and ambiguity. They also sought withdrawal of state-level authorities for advance ruling to confirm rate of tax for commodities to clear confusion created by differing orders by different state authorities.

“The basic principle of GST that there should be no goods and services without input tax credit benefit is defeated by refusing to grant it for construction of immovable property and vehicles for business use,” they added.

Title: Under present govt, Gandhi reduced to image of his glasses, says Tharoor
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

In comments that are likely to irk the ruling dispensation, Congress MP and author Shashi Tharoor said on Friday the idea of Mahatma Gandhi under the Modi government had been reduced to nothing more than the image of his glasses on the Swachh Bharat campaign, even as he referred the Mahatma as the “first significant martyr of the Hindu-Muslim divide.”

Speaking at the Jaipur Literature Festival, Tharoor was responding to questions about why the legacies of Mahatma Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru were under a “direct and unflinching attack”.

In a pointed reference to “PM Modi and the top echelons” of the ruling party, Tharoor alleged that the current “demonisation” of Gandhi and Nehru was happening because the RSS was fundamentally opposed to Nehru and Gandhi because they were against religion being the principal determinant of nationhood or identity.

“In the nationalist movement, the one big split every one knows about is the one that led to Partition. That split was not about ideology, but over a simple question about whether religion should be the determinant of nationhood. Those on the Muslim side who believed in it created Pakistan. And the vast majority on the Indian side, led by mahatma Gandhi, Pandit Nehru and many others, said religion does not determine our identity or nationhood. They wrote a constitution that embodied that,” Tharoor said.

The Thiruvananthapuram MP also alleged that it was the Hindutva movement, led by VD Savarkar and MS Golwalkar that rejected the Constitution, reiterating Congress’ oft-repeated charge that Savarkar was the “first advocate of the two-nation theory”, three years before the Muslim League passed a Pakistan resolution in Lahore in 1940.

“There could be nothing further from the vision of Gandhiji, who was a deep and profoundly believing Hindu but was influenced by the ethics, values and teachings of every other faith…Gandhi was killed by the RSS because he was believed to be putting the Muslim interest ahead of Hindu interest. That make Gandhi the first significant martyr to the Hindu-Muslim divide that the British had assiduously cultivated for a 100 years,” Tharoor said.

He also claimed that the RSS tradition “taught” its members all that was “wrong” about Gandhi. “Golwalkar would ask what this talk about Ahimsa was, arguing that every Hindu God was shown with a weapon. Gandhi was believed to fundamentally wrong about the value of non violence…No wonder Mahatma Gandhi has been reduced to his glasses. His ideas values, principles and his life have been tossed aside, but his glasses, because of the brand value of the Gandhi name, are the symbol of the Swachh Bharat campaign,” he said.

Title: GRSE lays keel for second advanced stealth frigate
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolkata: The keel of the second advanced stealth frigate under the Navy’s Project 17A was laid at Garden Reach Shipbuilders and Engineers (GRSE) in Kolkata on Friday by D Santra, structural fitter of the shipbuilding shop. Among those present were: Vice Admiral G Ashok Kumar, vice chief of naval staff, Rear Admiral (retd) V K Saxena, CMD, S S Dogra, director (finance), Cmde (retd) Sanjeev Nayyar, director (shipbuilding) and Cmde (retd) P R Hari, director (personnel), GRSE .

GRSE has been awarded the Rs 19,294 crore contract for construction of three of these stealth frigates on February 20, 2015. The three ships are to be delivered in 2023, 2024 and 2025. Keel-laying is the first step in shipbuilding. These frigates are are149-metre-long, with a displacement of nearly 6,670 tonne and a speed of 28 knots.

GRSE is deploying the latest integrated construction methodology with enhanced pre-outfitting to enhance quality and reduce build periods considerably. It has also appointed Fincantieri, Italy, as the knowhow provider for technology upgrade and capability enhancement.

“New initiatives are being undertaken at GRSE to meet future challenges and deliver quality ships on time. We are enhancing our capacity to build 20 warships to 24 of them concurrently over the next few years,” Rear Admiral (retd) Saxena said. Vice Admiral Kumar commended GRSE’s commitment and said that the shipyard continues to build complex ships under stringent timelines.

Title: Two sanitary workers held in murder case
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Tirupur: The city police on Friday arrested two sanitary workers in connection with the murder of a 23-year-old man.

K Arun Kumar of Pattukottaiyar Nagar was found murdered with cut injuries. He was working in a knitwear unit. He did not return home after going out on January 17. His corpse was found in the bushes in Velliyangadu on Sunday. The Tirupur south police registered a case.

Investigations found that Arun was murdered over previous enmity. M Muniappan, 49, of Pattukottaiyar Nagar was working as a temporary sanitary worker in the city corporation. Arun had hit him in a quarrel a few weeks ago. In a separate incident, Arun's mother had also quarreled with Muniappan's family, a police officer said.

Muniappan along with Gajendran, 40, a permanent sanitary worker in the corporation, and Muniappan's son Prem Kumar and Gajendran's relative John planned to eliminate Arun. Prem and John were friends of Arun, and they asked him to meet them on Friday night at Velliyangadu, where all of them murdered him. Muniappan and Gajendran were arrested while the other two accused are absconding.

Title: Married man elopes with neighbour’s wife in Jinsi
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A man’s two-month-long search for his wife , who left home leaving behind a note saying she would end her life, ended in shock when he realised that she had eloped with a neighbour, her long-time admirer.

According to the police, the couple was married for past 16 years and has two children. About two months back, the woman left home, leaving behind a note indicating that she was headed to an undisclosed destination and would take the extreme step.

Her husband immediately rushed to the Jinsi police station and lodged a missing complaint. With his help, the police began looking for her. Around the same time, he noticed that one of his neighbours, a married man, who would otherwise meet him frequently, was also missing. He alerted the police about his observation and they tracked down both the missing people to another city.

Inspector Vyankatesh Kendre of Jinsi police station told TOI, “After returning, the woman was counselled but in vain. Even her husband was ready to accept her, but she did not budge. We have recorded her statement and closed the missing case.”

According to the police, the complainant and his wife had recently shifted to a new locality. One of their neighbours was a man, who had proposed to the woman 18 years back. The marriage proposal did not materialise then. The two allegedly rekindled their friendship and eloped.

“They are both adults. As per law, even the police cannot do much, when two consenting adults decide to live together,” said a policeman privy to the missing case.

Title: Karnataka: Schoolgirl suffers heart attack during dance practice, dies
Content:
Poojitha

KOLAR: A class 9 student from T Gollahalli, Bangarpet taluk, died after suffering a heart attack while practising dance steps at her school on Thursday. The incident took place on Thursday afternoon when a group of students was rehearsing for the annual day function scheduled on Saturday.Poojitha, 14, from Vimala Hrudaya High School, collapsed while dancing in the auditorium, said K Rathnaiah, deputy director of public instruction. “School authorities took her to nearby primary health centre, where doctors referred her to another hospital. The authorities and her parents then rushed her to Jalappa Hospital where she was declared brought dead,” he added.Dr V Lakshmaiah, medical superintendent of Jalappa Hospital, said it was a natural death. “The girl succumbed to a massive heart attack,” he added. Incidentally, the girl was the granddaughter of Dr Lakshmaiah’s elder brother. The doctor said she was healthy and hadn’t complained of chest pain in the past.In Video: Shocking! Schoolgirl suffers heart attack during dance practice in Karnataka, dies

Title: ‘Mahatma would have stood with students against CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

There are hundreds of students sitting in protests against CAA and standing up for Hindu Muslim unity today. If Gandhiji was here, he would have been sitting with the students, said activist Ruchira Gupta as she opened a session on the Father of the Nation at the Jaipur Literature Festival on Friday.

Gupta, along with writer Makarand Paranjape, filmmaker Ramesh Sharma and historian Talat Ahmed were discussing the relevance of Gandhi in current times.

“Gandhi has remained incredibly influential particularly in relation with bringing about social change. Other leaders, including Marx, Lenin and Che Guevara have been tainted with their support of violence. But Gandhi stuck to his idea of non-violence,” said Ahmed, adding that his ideas find resonance in young people.

“Several movements across the world, including the extinction rebellion in the UK, have been inspired by the civil disobedience movement that Gandhi led. Even after 70 years of his death, he remains relevant,” she said. Paranjape, while agreeing with her in principle, added that Gandhi’s “afterlife is greater than his life.”

The panelists also deconstructed Gandhi’s life and assassination, obliquely touched upon the rise of right-wing fundamentalism in India, criticised attempts to “rewrite” history, and called out the whitewashing of certain groups, including the RSS.

Through the hour-long session, the panel discussed and debated, agreed at times, but also often differed in their opinions, especially when it came to contextualizing and placing Gandhi in the present political scenario. But they also concurred that Gandhi’s legacy would withstand the tests of time.

Responding to a question about how Gandhi would respond to Prime Minister Modi, Sharma said he would likely go on an “indefinite fast”. “Modi would join that fast,” quipped in Paranjape amid audience cheers, but Gupta was ready with a comeback. “The PM still has an option to join protestors at Shaheen Bagh,” she said, while referring to a neighbourhood in south-east Delhi, which has become the face of the protests against CAA and NRC, with women of all ages staging a 24*7 sit-in. But amid dissenting voices, which the panelists said Gandhi stood for, they also reached a consensus about what the young can back take from him.

“If the young had to learn one thing from Gandhi, it should be sustainability. They can learn how to keep movements alive by showing the world not just what they are standing for, but also what they are against,” said Gupta.

Title: VBA bandh affects life in Marathwada
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Aurangabad: The Maharashtra bandh called by the Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) against the CAA-NRC and NPR received a considerable response in the Marathwada region on Friday.

The police had made adequate security arrangements and patrolling to maintain law and order during the bandh period.

In most of the areas, including Aurangabad city, the shopkeepers kept their shutters down in response to the VBA’s bandh call.

Video clips by VBA activists were quickly shared on social media platforms, resulting in the bandh being observed across the city.

Amit Bhuigal, an office-bearer of VBA in Aurangabad, said, “We pleaded with folded hands to everyone to support the bandh, as we had decided not to indulge in any kind of violence. The shop keepers at many places responded to our plea.”

However, some parts of the region reported minor incidents of stone pelting including in Aurangabad city, where a state transport bus became a target of the protesters. There were no injuries reported during the event.

VBA activists were seen shouting slogans, holding placards against NPR, NRC, and CAA. Led by Prakash Ambedkar and backed by over 35 social and trade unions, and 100 groups saw a successful bandh being implemented.

Adding further Bhuigal said that not only Muslims but also those belonging to reserved categories, be it Dalits or Hindus will be at the receiving end of the bill. “People are trying to show it is Muslim versus others but they are misleading Indians at large.”

Nanded reported that at least two different incidents of stone-pelting were reported, following which police swung into action and rounded up the suspects. In some places, police had to use force to disperse unwanted gatherings.

Even at places like Jalna, Parbhani, Hingoli, and Beed, attempts were made to galvanize a response to the bandh by making sit-in agitations, blocking roads and stopping the state transport services.

Things started returning to normalcy after VBA chief withdrew the bandh at about 4 pm. Senior police officers in the the region maintained that some of the incidents have been taken on record and those who have indulged in any kind of illegal activities, will face action?

Title: Loose-door alert forces GoAir B’luru-Phuket flight to return
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bengaluru: A GoAir flight from Bengaluru to Phuket (G8 41) returned 30 minutes after taking off from Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) at 2.30am on Friday, following a technical glitch.

This, however, was only the beginning of the ordeal for 173 passengers on board. Due to prolonged inspection, unavailability of crew members and dense fog, they could take to the sky only eight hours later in another aircraft.

Sources said while in the air, the Airbus A320 Neo aircraft received a ‘doors-not-secure’ warning, due to which pilots initiated a precautionary turnaround. Data from online flight tracker flightradar24 revealed the plane did multiple rounds in the air before landing.

On returning, passengers waited inside the aircraft for over six hours for inspection. They said the crew meant to operate the flight took leave, stating they had completed their duty hours. Fog, which caused airport operations to be suspended, also played spoiler. The aircraft is now under inspection at KIA. The passengers were accommodated in another plane, which departed for Phuket at 10.44am.

Earlier, after spending hours inside the aircraft under inspection, irked passengers stepped on to the runway on learning the crew had left. Some took to Twitter to air their grievances. “GoAir G8 41 A malfunctioning plane mid-air, followed by return to tarmac and changeover of plane, then changeover of pilot and crew, 8 hours on tarmac, badly managed communication with passengers, no extra care. Customer service is dead (sic),” tweeted @skatyal1, a passenger.

“@goairlinesindia thanks for ruining our trip. Aircraft on ground since past 6 hours. First it lands because of technical faults. Then der is delay in paperwork, then low visibility. Now when there is visibility, the whole crew is being replaced. Do u care abt our schedule? G8-41 (sic),” tweeted @hemalkanani09.

Many passengers were stranded at the Phuket airport as well, waiting for the incoming aircraft from Bengaluru to arrive.

“GoAir flight G8 041 from Bengaluru to Phuket with 173 passengers on board did a precautionary air turn back in the interest of safety due to a technical glitch...It landed safely at Bengaluru airport. The aircraft was changed and departed with the passengers for its destination at 10.44am,” a GoAir spokesperson said in a statement.

Box: Low visibility delays 77 flights

Dense fog and low visibility conditions near KIA disrupted operations of over 77 flights, while three others were diverted to the Chennai airport. Operations at KIA were temporarily suspended between 5.40 and 5.45am, during which 60 departures and 17 arrivals were delayed. The weather in Bengaluru impacted flight schedules at other airports to.

Title: Addl EO Dharma Reddy appointed SVBC chief
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Tirupati: In a move to streamline administration at the Sri Venkateswara Bhakti Channel ( SVBC ), the TTD trust board has appointed additional executive officer AV Dharma Reddy as managing director of the channel.

Earlier this month, Tollywood actor Prudhvi Raj stepped down from chairmanship of SVBC after an audio clip in which he allegedly made sexual advances to a female employee at the channel surfaced.

In an attempt to control the damage caused by the leak and streamline administration, the TTD trust board appointed Dharma Reddy as the managing director of the channel.

Following his appointment as additional executive officer at Tirumala, Dharma Reddy had cracked the whip against the black marketing of seva and VIP break darshan tickets, irregularities in accommodation and prasadam at the temple town, as well as taken action against other corrupt practices.

Taking all this into account, the TTD trust board was learnt to have been inclined towards choosing him for the post of managing director at its devotional channel.

Title: Now, Fraser Town does a Shaheen Bagh in 48-hr stir
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bengaluru: Fraser Town turned into Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh of sorts, as hundreds of women sat on a 48-hour protest outside a mosque on Mosque Road on Friday demanding repeal of the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), 2019.

The women-only protest began at 3pm on Thursday as a 24-hour campaign, but was extended by another 24 hours on Friday afternoon after necessary permissions were granted.

The spirited protest, organised by Hum Bharat ke Log, witnessed round-the-clock distribution of food, water and snacks. While children sat amid the crowds colouring and drawing, the women took turns to take to the stage and express their views on CAA.

Women of all age groups — starting with college students to centenarians — turned up for the stir.

“Being part of a democracy, all we can do is protest. Senior citizens, young mothers and college students aren’t only attending protests, but also sitting for such long hours. What kind of a government do we have that can’t address the concerns of of its citizens? Why won’t they revoke the law? Are they running an authoritarian government,” asked the women.

Among the protesters were several activists from AIDSO (All India Democratic Students Organisation). Sithara HM, district president of AIDSO, said, “This is something that the government is doing in order to divert the country’s attention from other pressing issues like unemployment and starvation.”

Tehmina Farial, a student, asked, “How can the government ask people to show documents when they themselves can’t produce Rafale documents? When there are more important issues in the country, why don’t they focus on those?”

Scores of young volunteers worked 24x7 to ensure the protest didn’t disrupt traffic in the area. Protesters were seen waving placards reading — ‘No CAA/NRC/NPR’, ‘I’m an Indian and India is my home’ and ‘We stand united against the governments decisions’. Some were spotted waving the national flag.

The government’s cold response appeared to rattle many. “The government has brought us to a situation where we are standing on the road fighting for our basic rights. We are fighting for space in our own home,” lamented one protester.

Title: NMC snaps 200 water connection over dues
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ), in the last three weeks, has snapped connections of over 200 water tax defaulters.

A civic official said that despite sending notices the defaulters did not clear their dues. Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game has directed the water department to take strict action against tax defaulters for not clearing their dues.

Game has also directed all six divisional offices to snap around 50 connections of water tax defaulters every week in each division.

“The NMC has set a water tax collection target of Rs 64 crore for the current financial year. So far, we have collected around Rs 40 crore and are falling short of Rs 24 crore to achieve the target,” the official said.

“We have intensified our drive against water tax defaulters and are continuously taking action against them by snapping their connections. Connections are restored after the defaulters clear their dues,” he added.

Of the 200 water connections snapped, 70 are from Panchavati division, while the remaining 130 are from Satpur, Cidco, Nashik West, Nashik East and Nashik Road divisions.

In August and September last year, the NMC, for the first time, had initiated a drive against water tax defaulters by snapping over 2,500 water connections. Later, supply was resumed for those who cleared their dues.

“The drive was stopped because of the state assembly elections. But now we have again been started taking action against the defaulter for the past one-and-a-half month. There are a total of 1.96 lakh water connections in the city — including 1.88 lakh residential, 4,000 commercial and 4,000 non-commercial connections,” the official said.

Last month, the civic body also introduced amnesty scheme for property tax defaulters that will be into effect till February 10. Under this scheme, the penalty on property tax dues is to be waived if defaulters clear their tax dues.

The civic body has however received poor response as it has so far collected only Rs 15 crore through the amnesty scheme.

The NMC is now planning to create awareness about the amnesty scheme among residents across the six divisions. The civic body is in the process to hire autorickshaws for making announcements about the amnesty scheme via loudspeakers.

Title: Woman dies in suicide bid with son
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Tirupur: A 90-year-old woman died after she along with her son attempted to commit suicide due to depression in Dharapuram in the district.

The deceased was identified as S Ulsalma Beevi of Shankar Mill Street in Dharapuram, and she was living along with her son Mohammed Ismail, 47. After he suffered from ailments including tuberculosis, Ismail did not go to work properly, and his mother was also not well, said a police officer.

Both were frustrated due to the ailments and attempted to commit suicide by consuming poison on Tuesday. As they did not come out of their house for a long time on Wednesday morning, their neighbours checked and found them unconscious. They were rushed to the Dharapuram government hospital. Beevi died on Thursday while Ismail was referred to the Coimbatore medical college hospital. The Dharapuram police have registered a case.

Title: In a first, Bengaluru’s pourakarmikas to march at Republic Day parade
Content:
Pourakarmikas take part in the R-Day rehearsal

TimesView Including pourakarmikas in the Republic Day parade is a fitting tribute to the unsung foot soldiers who sully their hands to clean the city. However, the gesture also smacks of tokenism with BBMP intending to gain brownie points ahead of Swachh Survekshan. Instead of waking up at the 11th hour, it should have worked through the year to improve the city’s solid waste management system. As far as giving pourakarmikas their due is concerned, the agency would do well by heeding their long-standing demand for regularisation of services and timely payment of wages.

2.5k police personnel to keep watch on R-Day

BENGALURU: The 71st Republic Day parade at Manekshaw Parade Grounds on Sunday will feature a new troop. Thirty-one men and women who are on the front line of Bengaluru’s battle against garbage will participate in the march past .The first-ever initiative involving pourakarmikas in the R-Day fete is being driven by Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) to spread the message of cleanliness under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. Addressing mediapersons on Friday, BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said the pourakarmikas will carry placards to create awareness on a cleaner city. Twenty-seven women and four men will be part of the Swachh battalion.These pourakarmikas have been picked from various zones and trained for two days to march perfectly. Appu, the platoon commander of Swachata Yodharu BBMP, told TOI the opportunity has created a lot of excitement among the sanitation workers. “It’s a matter of pride for us to participate in the parade, that too in our uniforms. People will recognise us with our green coats amid the marching platoons,” he said.The initiative is also a part of BBMP’s effort to improve its standing in Swachh Survekshan — city rankings based on cleanliness — under the under the mission.The pourakarmikas will be part of a 34-unit 2,000-member contingent, including schoolkids, NCC cadets, scouts, CRPF and BSF personnel and the dog squad, participating in the fete. One armed force battalion from Goa will also take part like every year.The parade and cultural programme on January 26 will be inaugurated by governor Vajubhai Vala.To ensure the venue is sanitised, 75 police personnel have been keeping vigil at the ground for 15 days. They are also keeping an eye out for suspicious visitors at hotels, guest houses and other spots around the area.The area will be under close watch through 85 CCTV cameras and hundreds of police personnel. “As many as 1,200 police personnel will be deployed on D-Day, who will be monitored by nine DCPs,” police commissioner Bhaskar Rao said, adding 10 Karnataka State Reserve Police (KSRP) teams, one Rapid Action Team and one Garuda Force will be also be stationed.For security reasons, all invitees and the public have been requested not to bring mobile phones, helmets, cameras, radio and umbrellas among other things.

Title: Madurai: Kid swallows battery, doctors remove it
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

An X-ray revealed that the coin-shaped battery that was roughly around 20 mm in diameter and around 2 mm in he... Read More

MADURAI: Doctors at the pediatric department of Government Rajaji Hospital in Madurai safely removed a lithium button cell or watch battery without surgery from a two-year-old boy from A.Kombai village in Dindigul district after he had accidentally swallowed it on Thursday.

The child, A Aadheeswaran, the fourth child of his parents, A Alagarsamy and A Periyakandhi, on Wednesday, swallowed a button cell by accident when he found it while playing at his house with friends. It was the size of a one-rupee coin. His parents, who are woodcutters, were at work when the incident happened. “As one of the children in the group noticed that my son swallowed the battery, they immediately called us for help. We rushed him to the Dindigul Government Hospital as he was having breathing difficulties but then he was referred to GRH in Madurai for better facilities,” Alagarsamy told TOI.

An X-ray revealed that the coin-shaped battery that was roughly around 20 mm in diameter and around 2 mm in height was lodged vertically in the lower part of the boy’s oesophagus or food pipe. “A team of doctors from the pediatric department and the department of gastro-enterology performed a minimally invasive procedure on Thursday afternoon to remove the foreign body,” said GRH dean Dr J Sangumani.

The doctors said that an endoscopic tube was inserted through the boy’s mouth to remove the battery. There was no complications post the procedure and the boy could also breathe without any respiratory support, doctors added. However, he has been advised not to intake any liquid or solid food for a few days and is being given IV drips.

Title: West Bengal: PWD starts work on two VIP Road underpasses
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Workers dig up VIP Road for the proposed underpass at Lake Town

KOLKATA: The state public works department ( PWD ) has started the work of setting up two underpasses on VIP Road — one at Lake Town and the other at Dum Dum Park. These underpasses were planned to ease the movement of pedestrians at the two busy crossings.

Tenders for the work were floated in July last year while a detail survey of the locations was conducted by the officials to check the underground utilities. Both the underpasses will be constructed with the advanced box-jacking technique .

“No traffic restriction would be required on the road as the technique would create underground tunnels with minimal damage to the surface,” said an official. However, the service road off VIP Road may be blocked and a pedestrian traffic plan may be required during the work.

According to plans, the underpasses will be about 68-metre long with 6.5-metre width and 2.7-metre height. The construction cost of the two underpasses has been pegged at Rs 23 crore. The long-term plan behind the underpasses is to dismantle the old foot overbridge at Lake Town crossing for the proposed flyover from Dakshindari to Dum Dum Park. The PWD officials have already prepared a project report for the flyover plan and are waiting for approval from the state cabinet.

Title: Jaleel takes dig at Raj for ‘Hindutva turn’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Aurangabad: MIM state president and Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel on Friday expressed displeasure at MNS chief Raj Thackeray’s “shut off the loudspeakers on masjids” comment on Thursday while introducing his party’s new flag consisting warrior king Shivaji Maharaj’s insignia.

“People turn up in large numbers for listening to his speeches, but these large gatherings do not turn in to votes,” Jaleel said.

He added that blaming Muslims would not give Raj the desired political mileage as gone are the days when people used to “readily fall prey to divisive politics”. Jaleel said, “People now are more concerned about constitutional rights, development, quality education, health facilities and transparency in the city.”

Jaleel also raised question over the timing of the MNS chief’s comment. “He has been in politics for long, but how come he has started facing issue with Azaan,” he said.

“Just before the assembly elections, the MNS chief had been opposing BJP and raising questions over PM Narendra Modi, home minister Amit Shah and other BJP functionaries with his dialogue of ‘Lav re te video’. Now, in an attempt to cash in on the Hindu votes, the MNS chief has relaunched his party by raising questions on Muslims,” Jaleel added.

Raj on Thursday came out in support of CAA and asked local Muslims why they were protesting in favour of Pakistani and Bangladeshi Muslims. Religion, he said, was a personal thing. Targeting Muslims, Raj said, “Keep your religion in your house. Shut off the loudspeakers on masjids. Our aarti does not trouble, why should namaz trouble others?”

Title: We have to find ways to secure our data: Sautoy
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Personal data is being harvested by social media giants, leading mathematician and author Marcus du Sautoy said, adding that mobile phone apps talk to each other.

“Such is the case that your WhatsApp is telling your Facebook account what’s going on and this is the reason that you are getting lots of advertisements. They give us the illusion that your communication is secured which is not. But we can find ways to secure our data,” said Sautoy, who is globally known for his work in group theory and number theory.

Others panelists in the session included authors John Lanchester and Jaspreet Bindra. Explaining the dangers of data harvesting and surveillance, Lanchester talked about how China is keeping a data of its 1.5 billion population, including facial recognition. “You can imagine the dystopian outcome of the situation. In China's Xinjiang province, they are using algorithm based processes to identify the radicals attending mosques or children with Islamic names,” said Lanchester.

Sharing the upcoming trends, Bindra said like wealth managers, we will have data managers as we are generating data all around. “The data managers will evaluate your data and sell it to the right places. This is one job that AI is going to create rather than destroying.” TNN

Title: Capital shift leaves fate of expressway in limbo
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Amaravati: The decision of the state government to shift the capital out of Amaravati has raised concerns over the future of the proposed Amaravati-Anantapur expressway .

Notification for land acquistion for the project had been published in 2019 and the state government had agreed to bear 50 per cent of the cost of land acquisition and obtain statutory clearances for environment, forests and wildlife.

The project, which is a partnership between the central and state governments, proposes a greenfield expressway connecting Amaravati with the Rayalaseema region and was floated to accelerate industrial development and generate employment in drought-affected districts in the state. The route will also minimise travel time and was intended to have brought the Rayalaseema districts closer to Amaravati.

Senior state government officials are of the opinion that the Centre will raise queries about the project as it is yet to formally take off. “Although Amaravati will continue to be the legislative capital under the new scheme of things, vehicular movement may not be as dense as estimated in the draft plans,” said a senior official on condition of anonymity.

Local farmers, meanwhile, have already raised objections over the land acquisition process for the project. Farmers in some villages in Vinukonda and Chilakaluripet constituencies in Guntur district have filed written objections stating that with the shift of the executive capital to Visakhapatnam, there is no need for an expressway in the region.

Minister for energy, forest and environment Balineni Srinivasa Reddy said, “We will convince the Centre and go ahead with the project after readying the detailed project report (DPR).” The state government has already directed district collectors of Guntur, Prakasam, Kurnool, Kadapa and Anantapur to publish the draft notification for land acquisition by January 29 after completing a survey.

Sources said that the plan for the expressway is believed to have changed after the YSR Congress assumed power in the state. The final stretch of the expressway may now be connected with National Highway (NH)-16 between Guntur and Ongole, unlike in the original plan.

The expressway will stretch for a distance of 371 km and cut travel time between Amaravati and Anantapur by two hours. The project, however, has faced opposition from environmentalists and farmers in the past on account of the threat posed to agricultural land and potential damage to forest areas.

Title: Liquor worth Rs 1.7 crore seized at Tivim, Sancoale
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The legal metrology department seized brandy and rum bottles worth Rs 1.7 crore for quantity violations, during raids conducted at two industrial estates on Friday.

In a case booked against a liquor bottling plant at the Tivim Industrial Estate, the legal metrology team, which was led by assistant controller Gulam Gulbharg, seized 42,000 packages of brandy worth of Rs 1.5 crore for filling 4.5ml less in statistical average in each bottle, in violation of the Legal Metrology Act and Rules, a press note said.

In a raid on a bottling and blending plant at Sancoale Industrial Estate, Zuarinagar, the team seized 4,200 packages of rum bottles of 750ml each, totally worth Rs 21.5 lakh, for filling 20ml less in statistical average in each bottle.

Another packaged commodity case was booked at the Meta Strips Complex, in Upasnagar, Mormugao.

The legal metrology team seized 37 packages of sealing ring retainer and radial shaft sealing ring of a reputed truck company worth of Rs 22,000 for not bearing the month and year of manufacture or pre-packing date, as well as country of origin, which is in violation of Section 18(1) of the Legal Metrology Act, 2009, read with Rule 4, 6 and 18(1) of the Legal Metrology (Packaged Commodity) Rules, 2011.

Three enforcement cases were also booked at Upasnagar and Zuarinagar for using unverified weighing instruments and for not exhibiting verification certificates at the trading premises.

Title: Global warming: Why the choices we make are crucial to our survival
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Planet Earth, as we all know, is burning, drowning and choking its way to destruction. So, how do we save it? In the session, ‘Client Earth’, on day two of the Jaipur Literature Festival, the panelists attempted to find light amid the darkness, and squeeze some hope from an impossibly bleak situation.

David Wallace Wells, climate-change journalist whose ‘The Uninhabitable Earth: Life After Warming’ can be seen as an elegy for the planet, stole the show with an impassioned plea to people and governments, to act and act fast. “The picture is weak across the world. We need to be doing much, much more, and more quickly and more universally,” he told a receptive audience.

“As a New Yorker, I didn’t perceive climate change as a threat but I was profoundly deluded. My life contains the entire story of the destruction of the planet,” added the 37-year-old. Because climate change, he continued, is not a legacy of our ancestors but the work of one generation – ours.

But, despite the prognostications of humankind hurtling towards extinction, it’s not all doom and gloom. Certainly, the experiences of environmental lawyer Martin Goodman (who co-wrote ‘Client Earth’ with James Thornton) show that grass-roots activism can be a force for good. “There is an evidence-based narrative of hope,” he shared, giving examples as far apart as Poland, where farmers came together to successfully oppose the building of coal-fired power plants, and in the African continent, where activists, armed with a knowledge of the laws, confidently argued with government officials.

Former environment minister Jairam Ramesh insisted that the ‘grow now, pay later’ model of economic progress can never be an option, simply because it is unsustainable in the Indian context – as demonstrated by the land and air pollution that blights cities and also rural areas. “Our veneration for nature has clashed with development; we’ve made the wrong choices not out of lack of awareness or sensitivity, but because of demographic challenges and because of development,” said Ramesh, explaining the dilemma that India faces.

The speakers also pointed out the sheer inequality of global warming, in that it adversely impacts those countries that contribute the least to it. The poorest, in other words. For all the pessimism that surrounds us, Wallace Wells stressed on the importance of being activated and engaged on the issue. “Because Planet Earth is the only home we have, and the only one we’ll know,” he reminded.

Title: Truck with five tonnes of tea dust seized in Mettupalayam
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Coimbatore: The food safety department on Thursday confiscated a truck laden with five tonnes of tea grinding waste, which is often used to adulterate tea powder, in Mettupalayam.

The truck neither had the permit to ply in the state nor required documents for the consignment.

The owner of the truck and the person who procured the contaminant are being interrogated by the food safety department. However, the owner of the truck claimed that the tea waste was procured to produce manure.

Acting on a tip, officials of the food safety department on Thursday inspected the truck which was parked near Madheeswaran temple in Mettupalayam since Tuesday night.

“Five tonnes of tea waste, known to be used for to adulterate tea powder, were found in the truck,” an officer said.

The officials identified the owner of the truck as Arun Kumar, a resident of Thevanapudhur.

Kumar confessed that the powder was bought and procured from Assam by a person named Manikandan.

“Kumar claims that the tea waste was bought to manufacture farm manure. Since making manure is also a logical reason and way to use the waste, we are conducting further investigation,” food safety officer Aruchamy said.

While Manikandan and Arun Kumar were questioned, officials informed the revenue and transport departments about the truck. “Though the truck had Tamil Nadu registration number, the owner was not able to produce permit and fitness certificates of the vehicle. So, we alerted appropriate authorities,” Aruchamy said.

Officials believe that the seized tea waste was bought to be mixed with tea powder that comes in tonnes from Nilgiris. The adulterated tea dust is then packaged and sold to small bakeries and tea shops for a lesser cost than genuine tea powder.

Title: Coronavirus: 7 who travelled to China under observation
Content:
An official uses a thermal camera at the Suvarnabhumi Airport as a measure to prevent the spread of coronaviru... Read More

MUMBAI/PUNE: Seven persons from Maharashtra who recently travelled to China and Hong Kong have been placed under observation amid the novel coronavirus (nCoV) outbreak that has so far claimed 26 lives and infected over 800 people in China and some other countries.Four are from Mumbai and three from Pune, both cities adding one person each to Thursday’s count of five. But, in good news, the health ministry tweeted late on Friday that two samples from Mumbai have tested negative for the virus.Earlier in the day, a 65-year-old Briton, who came from Hong Kong on January 10, was admitted to Kasturba Hospital in Chinchpokli, the designated isolation facility in Mumbai. A 31-year-old Nalasopara woman and a Kalyan man who had gone to China have been under watch since their hospitalisation on Thursday. BMC officials said throat swabs and blood samples of the Briton and two others quarantined on Thursday have been sent to the National Institute of Virology in Pune.Two of the samples have tested negative for nCoV. “ICMR-NIV Pune has informed that 4 samples (2 from Mumbai, 1 each from B’luru & Hy’bad) have tested negative for nCoV. One of Mumbai patients has tested positive for rhinovirus, a routine common cold virus,” it tweeted.The fourth person under observation in Mumbai is a Jogeshwari resident, who hasn’t showed cold symptoms and is on a telephonic follow-up from home. State epidemiologist Dr Pradeep Awate said the three in Pune are asymptomatic as well.Colleagues of the UK national said he had returned to the city from Hong Kong after spending Christmas in the UK. On Friday, he went to the Asian Heart Institute with complaints of cold and sore throat, and the doctors referred him to Kasturba after learning he had been to Hong Kong. “Doctors at Kasturba insisted on admitting him and getting the tests done,” said a colleague, adding that the Briton shuttles between Mumbai and Hong Kong on work. The two from Nalasopara and Kalyan had travelled to China’s Foshan and Guangzhou cities, both about 1,000km away from Wuhan , the epicentre of the outbreak.Public health minister Rajesh Tope said the state government is taking all preventive steps. “As on Friday, 1,789 passengers travelling from China have been screened through thermal scanner at the international airport. No positive cases have been registered so far. There is no panic situation in Maharashtra.”Awate said naso-pharyngeal and lower respiratory tract swabs will be used for testing. “A naso-pharyngeal swab is used to sample secretions from the back of the nose and upper throat to help identify what pathogens are present and what could be causing symptoms or disease. But for more confirmatory report, lower respiratory tract swabs are preferred for the diagnosis of nCoV,” said Awate.Civic officials said while the patients may be allowed to go home after their reports arrive from NIV, they will continue to be under observation for at least 28 days. Since the coronavirus is new, a long watch is being implemented.Kasturba Hospital’s Ward 30, the city’s only public isolation facility, is humming with life since Thursday evening after two patients were admitted. Ward 30 comprises a room with six glass cubicles and four standalone rooms. A nurse on Friday said they have been provided with protective gear to be worn every time they enter the rooms to tend to the patients.The Britisher’s colleague said he was allowed to meet him after donning an N95 mask. Besides Kasturba, Pune’s Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital has been designated as a treatment and isolation centre.

Title: Empower local communities to address climate change threat
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Despite the decibel level of the denialists, climate change is a reality that none of us can avoid. On day two of the Jaipur Literature Festival, the session, ‘Flood and Fury’, turned the spotlight on government complicity in the flooding that devastated a city (Chennai, 2015) and large parts of a state (Kerala, 2018).

“When I was the environment minister, I was confronted by the truth that sea levels were rising which, because of India’s long coastline, increased the probability of flooding,” explained Jairam Ramesh. “And we have seen an increase in the frequency of floods, which is a manifestation of climate change and global warming.”

Krupa Ge is not an environmentalist but the Chennai calamity changed everything for her. “I found myself asking a lot of questions but not getting the answers,” she told the audience. The state, Ge argued, was an active participant in the erosion of resources that contributed to Chennai being inundated.

“We’re all fighting extremes of weather because of climate change,” continued Ge, author of ‘Rivers Remember’, which probed the reasons behind the deluge, a traumatic memory for residents of the southern metropolis. “Climate change is a reality which we’re not addressing,” complained Viju B, the title of whose book, ‘Flood and Fury: Ecological Devastation in the Western Ghats’, unequivocally pinpoints the reason behind the disaster in Kerala.

Viju described how instances of moderate rainfall in Kerala have decreased, while cases of intense precipitation have increased. But it’s not just in Kerala; in Chennai, the population suffered because three months of rainfall fell in one night. The culprit? Climate change, again.

The sobering truth, however, is that very few places in India are immune to excessive rainfall. Ramesh said the annual problem of flooding in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar won’t be solved unless afforestation takes place in the upper catchment areas in Nepal, which have been stripped of their canopies. “Flood control in India can’t be successfully addressed unless you bring in Bangladesh, Nepal and Bhutan — because rivers don’t have political boundaries,” he insisted, adding, “The Indus river system is integrated and crucial to both India and Pakistan, but both countries don’t recognise its importance.”

What, then, is the solution? Besides formulating a policy for disaster management, the panel agreed that the key lies in empowering local communities and institutions, both rural and urban. Viju called for supporting the tribal populations, who are leading conservation efforts. “We should empower the gram sabhas and the local communities, and empower people closest to the land – that is the only way to counter the vested interests and lobbies,” he maintained.

Title: Lisa Ray on her life
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Edited

Jaipur: “I am an accidental actress,” said model-turned-actress-turned-author Lisa Ray while speaking at a session at Jaipur Literature Festival on Friday.

Ray, a cancer survivor, said in her memoirs she had “broken her ribs and served her heart on a platter” after being diagnosed with this ailment.

Ray (47) was diagnosed in 2009 with multiple myeloma, a cancer of the white blood cells, which is considered incurable and fatal.

“I had suicidal thoughts, had a lot of self-flagellating thoughts, a lot of self-loathing. On the one hand I was experiencing the prime of my success and fame in India and privately I was going through the deepest, darkest tunnel that you can imagine. It was the darkest night of the soul,” she said on finding fame very early in life but not having the inner peace.

“There is no doubt that going through cancer has changed and transformed the trajectory of my life, and I am still processing that on some level. There has been a pre-cancer and post-cancer life,” she said.

“I have been in the glamour industry since I was 16. It was the darkest period of my life. I had suicidal thoughts, self-loathing and also bulimia. It was due to the fact that some part of me felt not worthy and unlovable. I could never live up to the image of myself. The more I shrunk, the more I was celebrated,” said Ray while interacting with Sanjoy Roy, the festival producer.

Speaking about the identity crisis in today’s scenario, Ray said, “I migrated from India to Canada and my identity was not just defined by blood, but also by movement as well as people’s perception. However, I managed to travel often. I don’t think migration is easy anymore. The borders created in our minds is creating issues for migration.”

Ray said most of her life she ‘ran away’ from situations which she could not handle after being diagnosed with cancer.

Title: Passenger amenities body visits city railway station, lauds new initiatives
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vijayawada: Members of the passenger amenities committee ( PAC ) inspected Vijayawada railway station here on Friday morning. The committee checked the functioning of the 76 CCTV cameras in the railway station and inspected other security aspects at the station.

The committee also checked other amenities, such as food and book stalls, foot-over-bridges (FOB) and toilets and gathered feedback from passengers. In an interaction with the media, L Nagwani, one of the six members of the committee, explained that Vijayawada would have a high ranking among the 180 stations they had inspected across the country.

Nagwani added that some initiatives undertaken at the station—such as the fish pedicure stall on platform one—should be highlighted. The stall is part of the New Innovative Non-Fare Revenue Idea Scheme (NINFRIS), under which several initiatives have been coming up, including the health kiosk at the station.

The committee advised Vijayawada divisional railway manager P Srinivas to implement a passenger information system, similar to the one at Anakapalle railway station.

“The information system gives the passenger information as to where their coach will arrive without the need to be present on the platform,” Nagwani said. The team also suggested introducing battery-operated cars to help old or people with disabilities commute.

“There is also a need for a round-the-clock medical shop on platform one. Currently there is a medical store on platform six, of which many passengers are not aware. The shop is also not open throughout the day,” Nagwani said.

The committee also took note of the absence of baggage scanners and metal-detecting frames in the station and said a recommendation would be sent to the DRM.

The PAC also visited two other stations under Vijayawada railway division – Eluru and Tenali and expressed satisfaction on their functioning.

Title: Idealism is dead, says Pavan Verma
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Painting a grim picture of the state of the democracy in India, diplomat-turned-politician Pavan Varma said on Friday idealism was dead and that politics was turning cynical. The JDU leader who has been at loggerheads with his party chief and Bihar CM Nitish Kumar over the party’s apparent support to the Centre on the CAA, however, steered clear of any references to his recent sparring and referred to a more general “unravelling” of the Indian democratic systems.
