Varma argued that the central message of Hinduism, one which was derived from the three key texts — the Upanishad, the Bhagavad Gita and the Brahmaputra — was to engage in dialogue and to regard the whole world as one family, was under threat. Writer and literary critic Rakshanda Jalil attributed the atmosphere of “bigotry” to 1990s in the aftermath, she said, of BJP leader and former deputy PM LK Advani’s Rath Yatra.

Activist Harsh Mander, however, countered Varma and Jalil’s cynicism by saying that it was upto the people of the country — who had taken to the streets in protest against the controversial CAA — to ensure that the unfinished business of the freedom struggle now be completed.

“When those who want the country divided on religious grounds say that they are completing the unfinished business of partition, I say that it is we the people of India who have taken to the streets to complete the unfinished business of the freedom struggle — to keep India united,” he said. tnn

Title: Nearly 5 years on, Tiracol bridge gets NGT nod
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has given the green signal for the construction of a bridge over the Tiracol river, almost five years after work was stalled over the CRZ clearance granted for the project.

The tribunal has allowed the construction of the bridge connecting Tiracol to Keri provided the government follows recommendations of the National Institute of Ocean Technology (NIOT), Chennai.

“Having regard to the fact that Tiracol bridge may be a matter of public utility and the same can be constructed without any adverse damage to the environment, there is no justification to stop the same in absence of any illegality being shown,” the NGT stated in the case filed by the NGO, Goa Foundation .

“Accordingly, we dispose of this application with a direction that the construction of Tiracol bridge may proceed after taking all due precautions in accordance with law, particularly all the observations and recommendations of the NIOT,” the order further stated.

Goa Foundation had approached the NGT stating that the bridge was partly being erected on the Keri beach, in violation of the CRZ Notification which requires prior approval from the Union environment ministry and the State Environment Impact Assessment Authority.

Goa Foundation had stated that the construction, specially of pillar no. 6, was in a no-development zone and that no mitigation measures were taken against the possible adverse consequences on fishing.

Tiracol, which is a ward of the Keri village panchayat, is connected to the mainland only by ferry boat. In a peculiar situation, it residents are required to travel via Maharashtra if they seek to come to the mainland.

Title: Amarnath condemns LC decision
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Anakapalle MLA Gudivada Amarnath condemned the legislative council’s decision to refer the capital decentralisation bill to the select committee on Friday.

Amarnath, who is also the official spokesperson of YSRC asserted that this was only a temporary setback and would only delay the decentralisation process for two to three months.

Speaking to the media, Amarnath alleged that TDP has been indulging in ‘unethical and undemocratic practices’ to stall the passing of the bill in the legislative council. He reiterated that despite the delay, Vizag will become the executive capital. Lashing out at the TDP chief, he said, “Naidu was remote controlling (sic) the proceedings in the council, directing the chairman of the council to do his bidding. The chairman could have used his discretion instead of towing Naidu’s line.”

Amarnath further said that the day the bill was stalled in the council would be remembered as a black day in the history of the state as the council had gone against the will of the people and had undermined the basic principles of democracy. “ tnn

Title: Female speakers to take centrestage at ‘Festival of Ideas’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Panaji: The 13th edition of the D D Kosambi Festival of Ideas , scheduled to be held from January 27 to 30, will feature all female speakers .

Olympic medallist and retired Indian weightlifter Padma Shri Karnam Malleswari, the first Indian woman medallist in Paralympic Padma Shri Deepa Malik , the first woman sarpanch with an MBA Chhavi Rajawat and managing director and CEO of Northern Arc Capital Kshama Fernandes, will speak at the festival.

Art and culture minister Govind Gaude said a conscious decision was taken to give women achievers a platform. Invitations are being sent out to educational institutions and it is the duty of heads of institutions and parents to send students for the lectures, he said.

Title: Tirupati MLA flags off bike rally to raise awareness on road safety
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Tirupati: Tirupati urban police wing flagged off a bike rally in Tirupati on Friday. Tirupati MLA Bhumana Karunakar Reddy and SP Dr Gajarao Bhupal who took part in the valedictory session of the road safety week celebrations, later flagged off and took part in the road safety bike rally.

Speaking to reporters, Karunakar Reddy expressed concern about fatal road accidents taking place despite stringent laws being in place. “Over-speeding and reckless driving are some of the key reasons for road mishaps. Every driver must strictly adhere to road safety norms to avoid accidents,” he asserted. tnn

Title: Prawns worth Rs 11 lakh stolen
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vijayawada: Unidentified persons intercepted a truck carrying prawns worth Rs 11 lakh, near Komaravole village of Pamarru mandal in Krishna district on Friday.

According to Pamarru police, the incident happened at around 2 am, when the truck was transporting the consignment from Bhimavaram to Tamil Nadu .

Cops said CCTV footage revealed the persons followed the truck and intercepted the vehicle at Komaravole. Two persons then dragged the driver out of the truck and tied him to a tree. They then got another vehicle into which they shifted the trays filled with prawns. The duo then drove away with the truck and abandoned it near Vuyyur. Locals rescued the truck driver who alerted the cops.

Title: West Bengal: Girl falls off terrace, hangs for 50 minutes as her leg gets stuck
Content:
The balcony where Richa Gupta was stuck

(With inputs from Mayukh Sengupta)

KOLKATA: Sheer stroke of luck , timely intervention by a plumber and extraordinary coordination among 100-odd residents of a housing complex on VIP Road saved the life of an 18-year-old girl, who accidentally toppled over the terrace parapet but remained hanging in the air for about an hour as her left leg got wedged in the grilles of the balcony below.Richa Gupta, a first-year college student and a chartered accountancy aspirant, was literally shaking at the end of the rescue operation, being lowered down with the help of protection harnesses. But she escaped with scratches and cuts on her left leg and was allowed to go home after being administered preliminary treatment at a local nursing home.The incident took place at VIP Enclave, a posh residential complex near Kaikhali, around 4pm on Thursday. Police said Gupta was speaking on mobile while strolling on the terrace. “The girl said she was resting against the cement parapet, when she suddenly felt dizzy and fell sick and somehow toppled over. But her fall was arrested as one of her legs got stuck in the iron grille of the balcony below the terrace,” said a senior officer at Bidhannagar Commissionerate.Shortly after she fell, it was a 24-year-old plumber who first spotted her. “I was washing my feet at a tap on the complex, when something suddenly fell on me. I looked up to find the girl hanging from the balcony, screaming for help. I raised an alarm and ran upstairs,” said Balaram Karmakar, a plumber employed at the residential complex. As Balaram knocked on the flat, from where Richa was hanging, the family and other neighbours immediately rushed to the balcony. They held on to her from inside and managed to strap her to the grilles with whatever they could.By then, a crowd had gathered below, watching the rescue operation with bated breath and prayers on their lips, hoping the girl would be saved.While some of the residents still fumbled about how to rescue Richa, Balaram and his father, Babu, chalked out a quick plan. The residents followed their instructions but before that, they called the local police station. “We went to the terrace and dropped a rope. Balaram climbed down to the ledge above the balcony and tied it to the girl. All the while, we held her tightly till more help arrived,” said Babu, also a plumber. Soon, some residents carried out mattresses and blankets from home and prepared a cushion platform on the ground below, in case the rope snapped and Richa fell. The cops came in with a safety harness, like the ones highrise glass-cleaners wear at work, and strapped Richa with it to the grille.Though the police had alerted the fire brigade, Babu had by then cut a portion of the iron grille. Though the gap, him and the other neighbours pulled Richa inside to safety. As she sat shaken, people splashed water on her face and fed her a little before carrying her to a local nursing home on a special chair. A doctor checked her and allowed her to go home after preliminary medication. TOI tried to speak to Richa and her mother but they were still too traumatised.“The girl is a bright student but she is on medication for an illness. Her father was murdered 10 years ago, and ever since she has been a patient of depression. We are not sure if it was an accident or she jumped by herself. But we are just thankful that she is alright,” said a neighbour, close to the family.For the residents, this was something that they had never witnessed earlier, “I still can’t believe what played out in the evening. We are thankful to our local heroes—the father-son plumber duo—and I boast of the extreme level of coordination shown by the residents of our complex in rescuing the girl,” said Ashok Jha, president of the residents’ association.In Video: On cam: Girl falls off, hangs from terrace ledge for 50 minutes, escapes alive

Title: Former DIG made new chairman of Guntur agriculture market yard
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Amaravati: Senior YSRC functionary Chandragiri Yesurathnam has been nominated as chairman of the governing council of Guntur agriculture market yard. A former DIG of AP Special Police, Yesurathnam lost the recent assembly election from Guntur West assembly constituency as YSRC nominee.

Interestingly, Maddali Giridhar, who defeated Yesurathnam, was made honorary chairman of the governing board as the local legislator. Giridhar had recently ditched the TDP and decided to work with the YSRC government.

Posts in the governing board of Guntur market yard are coveted as the market committee is sitting over cash reserves of nearly Rs 50 crore. tnn

Title: Goa: ‘FIR against fraudsters of Visionaries Urban co-Operative’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Minister for cooperation Govind Gaude on Friday said an FIR will be filed against those responsible for committing fraud at the Visionaries Urban Co-Operative Credit Society.

“The registrar of cooperative societies has already dissolved the board. We have appointed a new administrator and a new auditor. The auditor has been given 30 days to prepare a report. Once this audit report comes in, we will file FIRs against those who have committed the fraud. The case will also be handed over to the economic offences cell,” Gaude told reporters.

Title: Metro, city bus projects face uncertain future
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nashik: The Metro and city bus services — two pet projects of former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis — face an uncertain future with the state government warning the civic body of the “grave financial consequences” it might face due to implementation of the twin ventures.

Following the request of urban development minister Eknath Shinde, Nashik guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal on Friday held a meeting in Mumbai with city mayor Satish Kulkarni, Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) standing committee chairman Uddhav Nimse and municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game.

“I am not against these projects. But the two projects will have serious financial implications for the NMC. The state government cannot take the responsibility if the two projects suffer financial losses. The state government has to spend huge amounts on the scheme to wave the farmers’ loan and Nagpur-Mumbai expressway project,” Bhujbal told TOI.

Following Fadnavis’s instructions, the NMC had decided to take over the city bus services from the ailing MSRTC and operate 400 buses through private operators in phases. In the first phase, 200 buses were to be deployed.

Similarly, the Nashik Metro project was announced by the former CM and MahaMetro finalized its DPR at over Rs2,000 crore. The erstwhile Fadnavis government had approved the DPR and sent it to the Centre for approval. The Union and state governments and NMC were the stakeholders of the project.

“On the Nashik Metro project, I told the NMC functionaries that a review of it should be done later to ascertain whether the mass transit system is at all need for the city. My feedback is that the similar projects in Nagpur and Mumbai are not that popular. Moreover, roads have to be dug up. This will cause much problems for the road users,” said Bhujbal.

On the city bus project, the district guardian minister said the presentation the NMC functionaries gave about the project revealed that the civic body would have to bear a loss of about Rs13,000 a day for operating one bus.

“The civic body has to create infrastructure such as bus depots and stands. This will mean an expenditure of around Rs80 crore. I have told them that unless they increase their revenue generation, it will be difficult for the NMC to sustain the bus project and also spend on sectors such as roads, water and hospitals,” Bhujbal said.

He said it would be virtually impossible for the government to financially support NMC on the bus project since the state has to spend on the farmers’ loan waiver, Samruddhi road project and implementation of the Seventh Pay Commission.

Nimse said, “We have told Bhujbal that the NMC has issued work orders for rolling out the 400 buses to the contractors. If the project is withdrawn, NMC has to pay the contractors 80% of the project cost for violation of the contract. If the state government is willing to provide this huge amount, NMC can roll back the city bus service.”

Title: Kolkata: 40% flyers cancel trips to China amid coronavirus scare, more may follow
Content:
Flyers from China being checked with thermal imager at Kolkata airport

KOLKATA: Around 40% flyers scheduled travel to China from Kolkata over the next one week have cancelled their journey, ostensibly after the outbreak of coronavirus in that country.The Indian government has already issued advisory, asking people visiting China to take precaution against the disease. More cancellations could follow over the next few weeks amid fears that the contagious virus would spread to other Asian countries, say city travel agents. Kunming, Ghuangzao, Shanghai and Beijing are the most frequently visited by travellers from Kolkata; coronavirus cases have been reported from Shanghai and Beijing so far.“This will hit tourism hard since China is both a leisure and a business destination. It is close to India and is well connected by flights operated by several airlines. But already, more than 40% flyers have cancelled their journey,” said Joydeep Mukherjee of Meghdootam Travels. An estimated 4,500 people travel to China from Kolkata every week but the number could drop to 2,000 by next week, said Travel Agents Federation of India chairman (east) Anil Punjabi. “As of now, we are asking those who have booked with us to wait and watch. But it will not be fair to ask them to take a risk. So, we might advise them to stay away from China within the next few days,” said Punjabi, who also owns Ares Travels, which sends around 100 travellers to China every week. He added it would lead to a huge loss for the tourism sector since Southeast Asian countries, too, are likely to be affected next. “Cases have been reported from Thailand and Japan, apart from Saudi Arabia. Since it is difficult to check the spread, travel will be affected across the region,” said Mukherjee. There is no travel advisory for Southeast Asian countries so far.Four airlines fly to three destinations in China directly from Kolkata; while IndiGo and China Eastern Airlines run daily flights from Guanzhou and Kunming, Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon operate flights to and from Hong Kong. Airline officials pointed out that beside the coronavirus scare, there was another reason for the passenger slump: the lunar new year and spring festival in China are celebrated now, when most shops and stores shut for around two weeks.China Eastern Airlines and IndiGo officials confirmed a significant drop in passenger count . “The inbound flights are running full. But the outbound traffic has significantly been down,” said an airport official.But doctors welcomed the advisory. “The virus has spread to all corners of China and it can’t be prevented merely by screening flyers at airports. There could be scores of infected patients travelling to and from China with no symptoms and it could be dangerous,” said an infectious diseases expert.

Title: PULLING MAN OUT OF THE DRAIN
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Blue Water Company

Founder: Snehit Prakash

Location: Bengaluru

Objective: Design, build and operate plants to treat faecal sludge so that they can be reused for various applications like hoticulture, basic agriculture, etc

Impact: Treated about 10 million litres of faecal sludge across Jammu and Kashmir and Odisha

Road Ahead: To target larger fractions of waste water, apart from faecal sludge, over the next few years; also look into ways of reuse of water

“Water is precious. Roughly, one litre of water reused can save seven litres of fresh water. Our mission is to try and generate a larger volume of water through treatment”

Snehit Prakash

Water, Sanitation & Hygiene Institute

Founder: Arumugam Kalimuthu

Location: Kodaikanal

Objective: On-the-spot treatment of liquid waste from septic tanks using small trucks; water made suitable for secondary use

Impact: A low-cost solution that can arrest the haphazard dumping of untreated waste, thus curbing environmental degradation

Road Ahead: In the process of commercialising the product. Orders received from several stated including Bihar, UP, Assam, Rajasthan

“There are many towns in India that either do not have treatment plants or have STPs set at very far-away places. To ensure that the waste in these places is not arbitrarily disposed, we have come up with this solution”

Arumugam Kalimuthu

Jalodbust

Founder: Rakesh Kasba

Location: Bengaluru

Objective: To put an end to manual scavenging by replacing man with machine to clean septic tanks

Impact: Restore dignity of labour among sanitation workers. Turn them into operators or entrepreneurs.

Road Ahead: To bring out 10,000 machines — each the size of a vacuum cleaner — over the next three months

“What started from the Indus Valley Civilization has continued until recently. We have reached Mars, but we haven’t been able to pull the man out of the drain. Our effort is to eradicate manual scavenging, using technology”

Rakesh Kasba

Banka BioLoo

Founders: Namita Banka and Sanjay Banka

Location: Hyderabad

Objective: Operate and maintain bio toilets (where the waste is treated within a bio-digester tank placed next to the toilet) in trains, schools, communities, workplaces across India. Treat faecal sludge through a geotube system

Impact: Recycled faecal waste turned into soil conditioner for agriculture; waste water available for domestic and industrial purposes.

Road Ahead: To set up 10 to 11 plants in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh soon. In talks with other states

“We often do not realise that most of our waste — human or kitchen — is a resource that can be re-used through appropriate treatment. This initiative is our way of giving back to nature”

Sanjay Banka

Title: Transport officer booked in stolen trucks case
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: An assistant regional transport officer has been booked by city police for illegally registering five trucks that were stolen from Mizoram.

The matter was being investigated for the past seven days following which a case was registered by deputy regional transport officer Sanjay Maitrevar with Vedantnagar police station.

The transport officer, along with other suspects, has been booked on charges of cheating, criminal breach of trust, forgery and criminal conspiracy. In addition, several sections of Central Motor Vehicle Act have also been slapped against them.

Sources informed that the role of some officers from Mizoram is also being probed as the case papers strongly indicate the same. An officer privy to the probe said despite discrepancies in the make of the vehicle and the documents, the transport officer in Aurangabad went ahead and sanctioned transfer of the stolen vehicles .

“Five trucks were stolen from Mizoram in the year 2019 and their chassis, engine and registration numbers were tampered before being transferred at Aurangabad regional transport office (RTO),” a police officer said.

After learning about registration of stolen vehicles at Aurangabad RTO, crime branch of the city police unearthed the racket following which a departmental inquiry against the suspect assistant transport officer was initiated.

As per findings of the probe, the suspect officer, while heading the licensing section, exceeded his authority and went on to grant registration of these vehicles that had serious contradiction in the documents, engine and chassis numbers.

“In the internal probe, RTO officials have found that the suspect officer bypassed all laid down mandatory norms that are to be followed while transferring of vehicles from one state to another,” the officer said.

Crime branch inspector Madhukar Sawant said the suspect officer and people, who reportedly bought these vehicles, had turned up for questioning. “But soon after they learnt about registration of offence, the officer has gone underground,” he said.

Sources in the department suspect that the case is just a small portion of the larges inter-state vehicular theft racket allegedly being assisted by RTO official in more than one state.

Title: Valuables, cash worth Rs 4L stolen
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nashik: Cash and other articles worth Rs 4 lakh were stolen in two house break-ins in the city. While cash and household articles worth Rs 90,500 were stolen from a house in the Peth Road area of Panchavati, LED flood lights worth Rs 3.71 lakh were stolen from a stadium in Indiranagar.

According to Panchavati police, an unidentified person entered a closed house in the Datta Nagar area of Panchavati along Peth Road sometime between 10 pm of Wednesday and 8 am of Thursday by breaking the lock and stole a TV set, gold jewellery and cash — all worth Rs 90,500.

Police said that they are investigating the case in details and will soon nab the suspect involved in the incident.

In another incident, a similar case of theft was registered with the Upnagar police in which LED flood lights were stolen by an unidentified person from the Chhatrapati Krida Sankul of the Nashik Municipal Corporation.

Police said that the theft took place sometime between August 1, 2019, and January 11, 2020.

“We are investigating the case in details,” said a police officer attached with the Upnagar police station.

Title: AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi slams BJP over poha remark
Content:
Asaduddin Owaisi

Labourers should not have Poha but only HALWA & HALWA & will be called Indian ,Bharat ka Shehri otherwise B........… https://t.co/Fdzz9eqHy2 — Asaduddin Owaisi (@asadowaisi) 1579857631000

HYDERABAD: Political parties continued to spar over food, with AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi slamming the BJP. A day after BJP leader, Kailash Vijayvargiya doubted nationality of workers for eating poha, Owaisi took a jibe at the BJP, pointing out to the ‘halwa ceremony’, which is held ahead of every budget presentation by the Union finance minister.On Friday, Owaisi tweeted: “Labourers should not have Poha but only HALWA & HALWA & will be called Indian, Bharat ka Shehri otherwise (sic) hope “9pm Nationalist” will not take offence.”At a meeting in Karimnagar earlier this week, he said, “I want to ask BJP members that where does word ‘halwa’ originate from? This (halwa) is an Arabic word, and the word is neither Hindi nor Urdu. Now, did you guys become Arab. Shun the Arabic word. Halwa is an Arabic word, right? But finance minister is doing a Namaste to halwa...”

Title: Madras HC asks DGP for report on ways to check derogatory posts
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Taking note of increasing incidents of anonymous defamatory and derogatory statements/videos being uploaded and circulated on social media , the Madras high court on Friday directed the Tamil Nadu Director-General of Police to apprise it on the mechanism available to tackle the issue.

Justice M Dhandapani also directed the DGP to file a comprehensive report on the action taken against such persons by January 29.

The judge passed the interim order while hearing the bail application moved by A Maruthachalam of Coimbatore who was arrested for uploading a video denigrating a sitting judge of the high court.

When the plea came up for hearing, the petitioner submitted that he had no role in uploading the video and claimed he had been falsely implicated in the case.

Noting that the contention of the petitioner was not satisfactory, Justice Dhandapani said, “In recent days, defamatory statements criticising persons holding constitutional posts and their families are being circulated by several persons without any evidence to substantiate their claims.”

To curb such illegal activities it would suffice to issue directions to the cybercrime branch of police to ascertain whether there was any mechanism available to nab such offenders, the judge said and directed the DGP to file the report.

Title: CBI court orders Andhra Pradesh CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy to attend January 31 hearing
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

YS Jaganmohan Reddy

HYDERABAD: Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy was directed by principal special judge BR Madhusudan Rao of CBI courts, Hyderabad, to be present before the court during the next hearing on January 31 in the quid pro quo case .

The judge said this on Friday while allowing a plea to dispense with Jagan’s presence for the day’s hearing as he was preoccupied with important meetings in Amaravati . However, the judge made it clear that the chief minister must appear before the court at the next hearing. In a separate order, the judge, who is also acting as a special judge for Enforcement Directorate cases, dismissed the plea of Jagan seeking permission of the court to allow a co-accused in ED cases to represent him in the ED court.

CBI had made Jagan accused No. 1 in 11 chargesheets it filed in the quid pro quo case where he was facing allegations of influencing his late father YS Rajasekhara Reddy in doling out public assets to select industrialists and businessmen when YSR was chief minister of unvided AP between 2004 and 2009.YSRC MP V Vijayasai Reddy, who was arrayed as accused No. 2 in all the chargesheets, however, appeared before the court on Friday.

Earlier, brushing aside the objections of IAS officer Manmohan Singh, who was made an accused in the Vanpic chargesheet in the quid pro quo case, the judge took into cognisance the role played by the accused officer in the case under section 19 of the Prevention of Corruption (PC) Act of 1988.

Manmohan’s counsel argued that since the state had refused to accord sanction to prosecute him, the Centre’s subsequent decision to grant a sanction order should not be taken into consideration. However, CBI counsel K Surender contended that the central government was the competent authority to accord sanction or reject it in respect of IAS officers since they are appointed by the Centre. “The state’s decision either way in such matters is inconsequential,” he argued.

The judge agreed with the CBI counsel’s argument and dismissed the plea of Manmohan. Now, the IAS officer will be tried under the provisions of PC Act too. Manmohan Singh was present in the court on Friday. The judge also dismissed the plea filed seeking removal of the names of Eswar Cements and Sajjala Diwakar Reddy from the accused list as the company is no more in existence. The company was merged with Dalmia Cements, which was made an accused in the Dalmia Cements chargesheet. Surender argued that criminal liability would remain with the original accused and it cannot be done away with because the company was merged with some other entity.

Title: Teen goes missing on way from Dahod to city
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 13-year-old boy of Isanpur went missing on Tuesday from a bus coming from Zalod taluka of Dahod district. Isanpur police registered a complaint on Thursday for kidnapping under Section 363 of IPC.

According to the complaint lodged by the boy’s father, the teen — a student of class VII — lives in Zalod with his grandfather. “The grandfather got him seated in the bus with a sack of corn. The boy was to get down at Isanpur Crossroads where his parents were supposed to pick him up at 4:30pm,” said a police official. According to the police, the bus arrived at the scheduled time but the boy was missing.

After searching for him at different places, the parents filed the complaint. “The parents waited for the bus to return at Isanpur Crossroads after going to Bavla. They found the corn sack from the bus, but could not find their son,” the official added.

Title: BJP condemns attack on party’s office in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: BJP MLC N Ramachander Rao on Friday condemned the attack on the party office on Thursday night, and demanded that the state government order an inquiry into the incident.

He said that a group of unidentified persons, suspected to be AIMIM activists , entered the state BJP office. He said the police reached the spot on being informed about the attack and took some of the persons into custody.

“Owaisi brothers are trying to vitiate the atmosphere in the name of CAA , NRC and NPR for political gains,” he said.

Title: Telangana: Conditional HC nod to MIM meet
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Justice T Vinod Kumar of Telangana high court on Friday gave conditional permission to United Muslims Action Committee (UMAC) and AIMIM to conduct the meeting planned to oppose Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens, at Khilwat grounds near Charminar in Hyderabad on January 25.

The judge ordered that the meeting be held between 6pm and 11pm, National flag should not be hoisted, and volume levels of loud speakers should be within permissible limits. The order also said no rallies, or bike rallies should be held. The number of participants should not cross 3,500, the judge said in his order that trimmed the permission accorded by Hyderabad police commissioner to the organizers of this meet.

The judge gave this order after hearing the 3 Lunch Motions moved by Swamy Vivekananda Youth Welfare Association, Hyderabad and two other petitioners, opposing the meeting, even at Khilwat grounds. Agreeing with some of the contentions of the petitioners, the judge said that if the meet is allowed to be held past midnight, then the police would be under severe pressure because the next day happens to be Republic Day and police will be on alert on that day too.

Replying to a query, state counsel Sarat Kumar said that they received certain inputs from the central intelligence officials and the Telangana police are coordinating with them.

Title: Tow away vehicles parked on roads in front of houses: Punjab and Haryana high court
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vehicles parked on roads is a common sight in residential areas.

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab and Haryana high court on Friday directed the Chandigarh Police to tow away vehicles parked on roads in residential areas and banned the pasting of stickers on government and private vehicles , telling the traffic police to implement these orders within 72 hours in the Tricity.

The court observed all traffic-related problems would be solved if vehicles are parked at designated parking spaces outside houses and not on the roads. The court said the traffic police should take out all their cranes and tow away vehicles parked on roads in residential areas.

A special bench of Justice Rajiv Sharma and Justice Amol Rattan Singh made it clear that there is no restriction on pasting parking stickers on government and private vehicles, but stickers referring to the post of any officer, emblem, profession like Army, doctor or press, or department are banned.

Observing that everyone is equal on the road, the bench said how could someone write a post and department on vehicles. Mentioning that charity begins at home, Justice Rajiv Sharma gave directions to his staff to immediately remove a sticker mentioning high court judge from his government vehicle. Justice Rajiv Sharma had passed these directions in 2018 as well while he was posted at the Uttarakhand high court. The court said it is surprising that some people have even pasted stickers such as relative or neighbour of MLA or DC to showcase their supremacy over others.

The court also directed the UT administration to consider writing down names of martyrs on underpass connecting the Rose Garden in Sector 16 to Sector 17. The court observed the walls could be converted into war memorials by inscribing names of those who had laid down their life for the nation. The court directed DCs of Chandigarh, Mohali and Panchkula to convene a meeting regarding installation and working of CCTV cameras in school buses.

‘Parking Policy in 3 months’

To streamline and regulate flow of traffic in city, the Punjab and Haryana high court has directed the UT administration to implement the parking policy within three months

The UT senior standing counsel told the court that draft parking policy is ready and other formalities would be completed

The court told the administration to publish the draft policy within a month, invite the objections in the second month and dispose of the objections in the third month

The court directed the administration to submit the final parking policy before implementing it

Title: Dalam member arrested
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A dalam member of Communist Party of India (ML) New Democracy was arrested by Bhadradri-Kothagudem police on Friday.

Police said that K Nagesh alias Naganna (24) was allegedly involved in attacking and opening fire on the police.

Officials said that they are focussing on cracking down on members of New Democracy underground cadre since they are indulging in extorting money from contractors, businessmen and government officials.

Title: Collector warns staff for failing to curb illegal mining
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nashik: The district collector Suraj Mandhare has warned the revenue department field staff for their failure in cracking down on illegal mining being carried out in the district.

The move comes after three tractors were seized by the squad led-by district mining officer Anand Patil, where few offenders threatened the officials.

The DMO team was inspecting the mining sites in the Sayane area of Malegaon taluka on Thursday evening at the time of the incident.

“The officer led the squad and confiscated three tractors carrying minor minerals illegally from the quarries. As he was about to move on, some people came there and they picked up an argument with the officer. They threatened them and even pelted a stone. No one was injured in the incident,” collector said.

Mandhare further said that the first information report (FIR) was filed with the the concerned police station at Malegao. At the same time, a stern warning was issued to the field staff for its failure to plug in illegal quarrying in the district.

“At the time when the district administration is ready to resolve issues of the miners, they should come forth and take proper permissions which are delivered in a stipulated time. But it seems the people are not willing to pay taxes to the government. This cannot happen and hence I have warned the field officers to be strict against such miners,” the collector said.

The field staff has a primary responsibility to curb such practices. “The the district-level team is in the supervisory mode. If the local team is unable to stop the menace and if the district level teams find such cases in the same areas, the field officers will have to justify their failure in taking action against the illegal miners,” the officer said.

Title: City police yet to trace identity of woman found killed in 2018
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Coimbatore: The city police have approached their counterparts in other states to identify the woman who was found murdered in a waterbody in the city in July 2018. The body, which was mutilated beyond recognition, was found in a decomposed state.

“We have prepared many sketches based on the photos of the decomposed body of the victim and shared them with police officials in other states. We are trying to trace the identity of the deceased. If we succeed in that, we will nab the accused soon,” said a police officer, who didn’t want to be named.

The officer said the woman’s body was found at Selvampathy tank on July 25, 2018. “The chopped body parts were kept inside a gunny bag. We suspect that the murder was committed outside the city.”

Pointing out that toe rings were found in the body, he said it was common among Bengali women to wear such type of toe rings.

Title: Village panels hold meetings, take up issues like sewerage
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chandigarh: The village development committees of the Chandigarh municipal corporation was held for Kishangarh village on Friday.

During the meeting, various issues were discussed, including upgrading infrastructure facilities like sewerage, storm water, water supply, electrical and carpeting of roads and streets etc. Issues regarding provision of regular water, power connection, re-carpeting village roads, removal of debris from open points, cleaning of sewer through super suction machine etc, were also take up during the meeting.

In the meeting of Khudda Ali Sher meeting, the committee members discussed the provision of civil dispensary at the village, wastage of drinking water, overhead electrical wires be replaced, repair of streetlights and roads. The committee members will visit the village on January 28.

During the meeting of Khudda Jassu village, the committee members discussed the issue of laying storm water line, repair of village guest house, stopping open defecation, provision of community toilets and changing sewer line.

Since recently, governor Punjab and administrator UT V P Singh Badnore has made the nominated municipal councillors as chairmen of the committees of the villages’, nominated municipal councillors Kamla Sharma, Charanjiv Singh and Sachin Lohatiya chaired the meetings of all the three committees on Friday. The representatives, who are also the members of the committees, gave their inputs and told about the required works needed on the ground for the development of the villages.

Title: Old Goa police station receives more complaints of illegal garbage dumping
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

A few days ago, Old Goa and Carambolim locals filed complaints over CCP dumping loads of garbage in a private ... Read More

PANAJI: While the state’s garbage management is being closely monitored by the high court and the state government is assuring the court that it is collecting door-to-door garbage, multiple complaints are being filed at the Old Goa police station over trucks illegally and clandestinely dumping waste.

After villagers filed police complaints and police seized trucks dumping CCP’s waste at Carambolim ten days ago, locals on Friday were again forced to complain to police after alert villagers caught a truck driver red handed while dumping what is suspected to be waste from a five-star hotel.

Pornem Goemcho Nagrik Monch-Old Goa on Friday complained to police over the “continuous dumping of garbage” in Old Goa as well as the burning of garbage. The complaint filed by president of the association Ambar Amonkar stated that, on January 1, at 9.30am a truck was found “dumping garbage in the jurisdiction of the village panchayat of Carambolim and Old Goa near Healthway Hospital”.

“The panchayat of Old Goa has not given any permission for such activities,” the complaint stated.

Sarpanch of the panchayat of Carambolim also complained to police over truck dumping garbage, stating that it had not been given any permission for such activities.

Only ten days ago citizens of Old Goa and Carambolim filed complaints over CCP’s dumping of 50 truck loads of garbage at Carambolim in a private property, posing a threat to the heritage fortress wall that runs through the two villages.

The Goa Heritage Action Group and villagers of Carambolim and Old Goa on Monday appealed to the North Goa collector to put a stop to the “wonton desecration of our priceless heritage” as the historic heritage landmark fort wall on the Kadamba plateau area is being used as a garbage dumping place.

Title: Hyderabad traffic cops conduct carpooling awareness event
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Traffic police conducted an awareness programme to promote carpooling for employees of Black Knight IT company campus at Begumpet on Friday.

This is the first time the traffic police organised an awareness programme to promote carpooling in the city.

Title: Agra IG orders removal of unauthorized roadside eateries on Yamuna expressway
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Agra: After back-to-back robberies, Agra IG range has asked for the removal of all unauthorized roadside eateries on Yamuna expressway on Friday. However, it took 13 letters from Jaypee infratech - the private concessionaire operating the Yamuna expressway - and nine cases of robbery since 2019, to compel UP police to take action against such eateries along the 165-km-long route.

Agra IG range Satish Ganesh, who ordered SSPs of Agra, Hathras, Mathura, Aligarh and Noida to remove eateries along the expressway, said, “I have conducted extensive patrolling on the stretch and spotted all the areas which pose a security threat to commuters. I have asked local police to take appropriate action.”

According to private concessionaire, there are at least 25 roadside eateries in over 10 villages on both sides of the expressway which includes Awalkheda, Jrailiya, Barauta, Makrand, Lukhriya, Palkheda, Mirpur, Suraj, Kapur, Mirthana, Gadsauli and Aagai.

Here, truck drivers, private bus operators, private taxis and others often take a break from their journey - which is prohibited due to continuous fast movement of traffic. Sources claimed that unauthorized eateries are located at several milestones.

Speaking to TOI, Major (retired) Manish Singh, in-charge coordinator of Yamuna expressway (Mathura-Agra) section, said, “The robbers, we suspect, usually select their targets in these eateries. Most of the criminal activities recorded are also near these eateries. And they access the Yamuna expressway by cutting through the barbed wire. In a majority of such cases, shocked victims prefer to drive away, instead of waiting for police help. On several occasions, we wrote letters to local police stations - Naujheel, Mannt, Baldeo, Yamunapar, Surir and Mahavan - requesting them to take action against unauthorized eateries.”

According to private concessionaire in 2019, robberies were reported at some of the milestones between February and September. A majority of the targets were buses, trucks, taxi operators, tourists and bikers.

“They first throw sharp-edged wedge on the stretch and wait for tyres of vehicles to deflate, thereby forcing the victims to come out. The armed gang then suddenly appears to rob them,” Singh added.

Robberies were reported at milestone 75, Naujheel, in June and September last year. In June, a woman from Mauritius, along with her two Indian friends, heading to Agra to visit Taj Mahal were allegedly robbed at gunpoint, while in September, two trucks were robbed by a gang, who then fled in their sedan.

Notably, 12 sub-inspectors, 42 constables, a dozen of Japyee Infratech security personnel are posted on the stretch between Noida and Agra. They patrol in vehicles around the clock.

Title: Bhumi puja for integrated bus stand at Vellalore held
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Coimbatore: Bhumi puja for the integrated bus stand at Vellalore was held on Friday in the presence of local administration minister S P Velumani. Speaking at the event, he said the new bus stand would help reduce traffic congestion on Pollachi Road, Palladam Road, Mettupalayam Road and Sathy Road.

“This will become the main bus stand for all mofussil and town buses. We will be constructing 112 ideal parking stations and 18 roads away from the parking area, so buses can pick and drop passengers easily,” the minister said.

A corporation official said the project would help decongest all the roads to and from other bus stands in the city.

Velumani said the state-of-the-art bus stand, spread across 61.61 acres, will have all required facilities, including parking lot for 104 cars and 1,200 two-wheelers, and retiring rooms and restrooms for bus drivers and conductors. “The facility will also house an information centre, first-aid centre and police booth, among others,” he said

The minister also unveiled the plans to construct retiring rooms for travellers. “It would benefit the travellers who arrive or depart late in the night.”

Title: UT to give commendation certificates to 23 on R-Day
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chandigarh: The Chandigarh administration will honor 23 people who will be given commendation certificates by the administration during the Republic Day function at Sector 17 parade ground on January 26.

UT adviser Manoj Parida will give awards to achievers, including Dr Honney Sawhney, senior medical officer, GMSH, Sector 16, Chandigarh; Parminderjit Kaur Thind, nursing sister, GMSH, Sector 16, Chandigarh; Jaspal Sharma, administrative officer, Government Medical College and Hospital, Sector 32, Chandigarh; constable Inderjit Singh, police department, UT Chandigarh; Kiran Rana, senior assistant, UT secretariat, Chandigarh administration; Jaswinder Kaur, personal assistant, UT secretariat, Chandigarh administration; Jatinder Kumar Verma, senior scale stenographer/PA, environment department, UT Chandigarh; Sandeep Sethi, section officer, director higher education, UT Chandigarh; Pawan Kumar, superintendent grade II, Government College of Arts, Sector 10, Chandigarh; Binu Dogra, principal, P G Government College for Girls, Sector 42, Chandigarh; home guards Sukhveer Singh and Gurvarinderjit Singh, office of commandant general home guards, UT Chandigarh.

From municipal corporation, Naveen Kumar, fireman, will be awarded.

Besides, Surender Singh of Chandigarh Transport Undertaking (CTU) and Dhyan Singh, junior engineer of the UT engineering department, will also be awarded.

Binesh Bhatia of Panjab University; Guneet Singh Assi, a resident of Sector 44, and Ravinder Singh, a resident of Sector 24, will be awarded in the field of social service.

In the field of art and culture, Nikhar, a resident of Sector 43, and Mukesh Sharma, a resident of Manimajra, will be awarded.

Sanjay and Maninder Singh of Chandigarh Hockey Academy, Sector 42; and Ranveer Duggal, a resident of Sector 32, have been selected in the field of sports.

14 city cops to get

police medal

Fourteen police personnel will be awarded with administrators’ medal for their distinguished and meritorious services on Republic Day at the Sector 17 parade ground.

Manoj Parida, advisor to the UT administrator, will confer the medals to the cops.

DSP Udaypal Singh, inspector Asha Sharma, ASI Inderjeet Singh, head constable Harbikh Kumar, head constable Ashwani Kumar and head constable Gurdev Singh will be awarded for their distinguished services.

Inspector Baldev Kumar, inspector Pawan Kumar, sub inspector Sukhdev Singh, ASI Surya Parkash, ASI Om Parkash Singh, ASI Bijender Singh, head constables Kanwal Pal and Satish Kumar will get award for meritorious service.

Title: People told to take part through social media
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chandigarh: The Chandigarh municipal corporation on Friday appealed to the citizens of Chandigarh to participate in the Swachh Survekshan 2020 through social media platforms.

In a meeting held on Friday under the chairmanship of additional municipal commissioner S K Jain, all the officers and officials of the MC were deputed to create awareness among people regarding the citizen feedback on social media platforms.

According to the format of active participation, citizens will have to post an experience related to Swachh Survekshan and add #SwachhSurvekshan2020Chandigarh in their post and share it on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter accounts by ensuring the post is public.

He said citizens could share their swachhta experience in the form of pictures, stories or any change they felt the Swachh Survekshan movement had brought to the system, on their social media platforms.

Title: TRS’ apathy will push Hyderabad into ICU, says BJP
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: BJP national manifesto sub-committee and state executive member Karuna Gopal on Friday criticised IT and Industries minister KT Rama Rao for hard-selling Hyderabad in Davos and pitching for investments from pharma companies, when the pharma firms present in and around the city are polluting the lakes .

He said that the government’s apathy will push Hyderabad into ICU (intensive care unit) and turn it from ‘bhagya nagaram to durbhagya nagaram’ (city of fortunes to city of misfortunes).

Gopal, who is also the president of Futuristic Cities, expressed concerns over the increasing encroachment of lakes and ponds in Telangana .

Expressing concerns over the increasing encroachment of lakes and ponds in Telangana, she said that the state would soon face a situation like that in Jaisalmer if steps to check pollution and encroachments are not taken. “In Jaisalmer, an individual is given half a mug of water to take bath,” she said.

She added that the TRS government’s proposal to scrap GO 111, which prohibits any construction activity within 10-km radius of Osmansagar and Himayatsagar reservoirs, has resulted in rampant encroachment of the catchment areas of the two water bodies.

Title: VBA bandh: Little impact in rural areas, city unaffected
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nashik: The state-wide bandh called by Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) on Friday to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) was observed peacefully across the district.

The bandh had no impact in the city, but in rural areas like Igatpuri, Manmad and Nandgaon, the markets remained closed. Also, no untoward incident was reported from any part of the district.

VBA president Prakash Ambedkar had called for the bandh on Friday appealing people to join the protest against CAA and National Register of Citizens (NRC), claiming that they were targeted at minorities and were anti-constitutional.

On Friday morning, several people gathered at Nashik Road and Nashik City areas appealing the people to join the bandh. At Nashik Road, a rally was organized, while in the city some people had gathered near the statue of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar, raising slogans against the CAA and the NRC.

Life in few pockets of Igatpuri, Manmad and Nandgaon was affected for few hours owing to the bandh. As the shops, hotels and restaurants in main markets were closed in Manmad, people coming from outside the town had a tough time searching for eateries.

Title: Man arrested for misappropriation of employees’provident fund
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 33-year-old human resource (HR) manager of a private firm was arrested on Thursday on charges of claiming the provident fund of employees by forging documents.

While the affected employees are yet to lodge a police complaint in this regard, C Prakash, 33, of Thottampalayam near Sathyamangalam in Erode district, was arrested based on a petition submitted by Velraj, inspector, Employees Provident Fund organization.

An investigation officer said Prakash was employed with an apparel firm. “He affixed photos of employees on the application forms to claim provident fund and provided his bank account details and that of his wife.”

Prakash, however, said he provided their bank account details as the employees were not having own bank accounts. “The money was paid to them later.”

The preliminary inquiry revealed Prakash had withdrawn a total of Rs 1.5 lakh from four employees’ provident fund accounts.

“While scrutinizing applications, Velraj came to know that the cheques had not reached the respective employees. He subsequently lodged a complaint with the Race Course police,” the officer said.

Police registered a case under Sections 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 471 (using as genuine a forged (document or electronic record) of the Indian Penal Code and arrested Prakash on Thursday.

“He was produced before a judicial magistrate court and lodged in jail under judicial custody the same day,” the officer said.

Title: Chandigarh: Convent schools hold draw of lots for nursery admissions
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

A child takes out a slip during the draw of lots at St Anne’s School, Sector 32, Chandigarh.

By: Mayank Chhabra

CHANDIGARH: Many parents celebrated and while others had to return disappointed as the city’s four most sought-after convent schools -- St Anne’s Convent School , Sector 32; Sacred Heart Convent School, Sector 26; St John’s, Sector 26; and Carmel Convent School , Sector 9, conducted draw of lots for admissions to entry-level classes on Friday.

At St John’s School, draw of lots was held for 95 seats out of a total 160 seats. At Carmel Convent School, 58 out of a total 120 seats, were decided through a draw.

At Sacred Heart School, draw of lots was held for 101 seats out of a total 160 seats and at St Anne’s, 87 seats out of a total 200 seats were decided through draw.

All the four schools witnessed a huge rush of parents. As the draw began, parents restlessly waited for their kids’ names to be announed. While the lucky ones celebrated with their kids, the ones whose wards couldn’t find a place had to leave broken-hearted.

Harpreet Singh, a city resident whose daughter got admission in Sacred Heart School, said, “I am very happy. We had tried in other schools but couldn’t get admission. We got lucky here.”

However, Harvinder Singh, another city resident, was not so lucky as his daughter’s name didn’t come in the draw.

“I am disappointed. But it’s all about luck. We will try in some other school in the city,” said Harvinder.

While schools offered more than half the seats through draw of lots, the rest of the seats are reserved for preferred categories, including wards of staff and alumni and siblings of already studying students.

While this year, these four schools offered 341 seats out of a total 640 seats, last year the schools had opened 320 seats out of a total 640 seats.

In 2018, 354 seats were offered through draw of lots and in 2017, 341 seats were offered through draw of lots.

Title: Commando force formed to handle forest fire in TN
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Coimbatore: Tamil Nadu Fire and Rescue Services department has formed a commando force to control forest fire across the state.

C Sylendra Babu, director of the department, said the force has a strength of 700 firemen, who would be given special training in handling forest fire.

He was in the city on Friday to inspect Coimbatore South fire station. Addressing the media, he said the department had received 25,400 fire and another 26,800 rescue calls last year. He said firemen had rescued 250 people from various natural calamities in the state.

Pointing out that the department has been working with the forest department to douse forest fire, he said, “Our firemen had put out the forest fire at Thuckalay in Kanyakumari district recently. To curb forest fire, we have formed commando forces. Initially, 700 firemen will be given special training in bringing forest fire under control.”

Sylendra Babu said the department had been focusing on western districts, where 140 firemen in the commando force were ready to beat forest fire.

He said they were conducting awareness campaign on fire safety for school students. “We have conducted 3,600 awareness campaigns in the state so far and taught the students what to do when an LPG cylinder catches fire.”

According to Sylendra Babu, there are 329 fire stations and two rescue stations in the state, with a manpower of 7,300. The rescue stations are in Hogenekal and Kotagiri.

The state government is, meanwhile, all set to open fire stations at Thondamuthur and Periyanaickenpalayam in the district. “The buildings and fire tenders are ready. We are waiting the government nod to open them,” he said.

Coimbatore South fire station covers more than 25-30km till Chadivayal. In the case of any fire incident in Poondi or surrounding areas, it would take more than 30-40 minutes for the fire tenders to reach the spot. Similarly, Periyanaickenpalayam area falls under Kavundampalayam fire station limits and it would take 30 minutes for firemen to reach there. “The two new fire stations would bring down the response time considerably.”

Title: Kolkata likely to get drizzle on Saraswati Puja
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The city may receive a light drizzle on Saraswati Puja under the impact of a western disturbance, said the Met office on Friday. The western disturbance could lead to rain in and around the city between January 28 and 30, and Saraswati Puja will be celebrated on January 29.

Also, a temperature drop is in the offing with the northwesterly winds getting stronger in Kolkata on Friday. The weekend could be chilly with the minimum temperature sliding to around 12 degrees Celsius from Friday’s minimum of 15.1 degrees, said the Met office. “It will remain 12-13 degrees till Sunday. But the mercury will start rising from Tuesday as the western disturbance approaches. We expect clouds on Tuesday and a few rounds of drizzles in the latter half of the day. But the drizzles could be more steady on Wednesday as the city celebrates Saraswati Puja,” said Regional Meteorological Centre director G K Das. “The mercury will rise as clouds float in. But the day temperature will be low in the absence of sunlight. The northwesterly, however, will lose strength by then.”

With the northwesterly winds returning, the mercury is set to slide down. “But as we are in the second half of January, the northwesterly is unlikely to be stinging and won’t last beyond the weekend,” added Das.

Title: PGI to soon get IPR cell
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: An Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) cell will soon be established at the PGI. The proposal approved by various committees within the institute has been finally sent to the governing body to be chaired by the Union minister of health and family welfare. Research is one of the mandates of the tertiary care centre.

“We would want to translate ideas into products which are affordable and accessible to all. That is why the IPR proposal has been sent to the governing body. This shall enable facilitation of patents, commercialization and other processes that are required for this translation,” said Prof Arvind Rajwanshi , dean academics, PGI.

The IPR already exists in Panjab University which is for the university researchers and scientists. “In the absence of such centre it gets tough for us to move forward. There is a huge patient rush and despite that when we try and find time for research, such processing without any assistance hampers the translation,” said a faculty.There are over 500 faculty and 1,200 resident doctors in the PGI. “But there are hardly any patents or products in the PGI. We have huge publications in high impact journals. These publications seldom turn into any product or technology,” said a faculty. The PGI has started focusing on research after it had a separate dean for research and academic activities. There are two incubation centres, one of which will soon start functioning.

“These incubation centres also have facilities for innovation and marketing of the product. Once there is a dedicated IPR cell, things will work at a faster pace,” said Prof Rajwanshi.

The aim of the IPR cell will be to provide protection of research and patented technology or idea. It will guide the scientists on how to obtain and sustain patents. It will work out on modalities on behalf of the PGI for commercialization of patented technologies.

Title: AIIMS library gets lift for disabled students after three decades
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

BB Dikshit library, AIIMS. (Photo: https://www.aiims.edu)

NEW DELHI: After over three decades of its existence, the BB Dikshit library at AIIMS is being retrofitted with a lift to make it accessible for the disabled students . The hospital’s engineering division has started the work, a source said.

According to Dr Satender Singh, a disabled rights activist, the action follows years of follow up with the authorities that had initially suggested that the building was too old for such retrofitting. “Several areas in AIIMS are not disabled friendly, including the library, hostels and select areas of the new private ward. I have been highlighting this issue since 2013,” he said.

He added that the issue of lack of accessibility for disabled in medical colleges and hospitals across the country was also taken up with the Medical Council of India and National Human Rights Commission, among others.

The library came into existence in 1957. Originally, it was accommodated on the ground floor of the pre-clinical block, but in 1973, it was shifted to its current premises and was called Dr B B Dikshit Library — after the founder director of the institute. It consists of two floors with a carpet area of 27,000 sq feet and seating capacity of 300 persons.

“The books, journals and seating area are on the first floor. I found it difficult to access it but somehow managed. But many of my colleagues who were dependent on crutches never got to access the library,” said Dr Ish Kumar, former student of the institute, who suffers from post-polio paralysis. He added that installing a lift was a necessary action and similar steps should be taken to make the hostels and other areas disabled friendly.

In 2018, Resident Doctors’ Association of AIIMS had also written to the institute director over the issue of non-accessibility of library and hostels for Divyang residents.

Title: Complete works by January-end: Min
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

V Srinivas Goud

MEDARAM (WARANGAL): Expressing displeasure over the delay in completion of works, Telangana tourism minister V Srinivas Goud and PR minister E Dayakar Rao told officials that all works should be completed by January-end and stated that officials would be suspended if they are found to be negligent in their duties.

Goud also inaugurated a resort in Mulugu district on Friday. Later, he visited the Sammakka Saralamma platform along with Dayakar Rao and offered prayers.

The ministers inspected facilities being provided to the devotees. They also urged the devotees to use cloth and jute bags instead of plastic bags during the jatara .

Mulugu ASP Chaitanya Kumar said that one-way traffic rule has been implemented from Pasra to Tadwai highway due to repair on NH 163.

So, he asked devotees to be cautious while heading to the Jatara venue. tnn

Title: Solar power plants bring fame to city
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Coimbatore: The city corporation on Friday bagged an award from the ministry of housing and urban affairs for conserving the urban environment by installing two solar power plants with a capacity of one megawatt each.

Corporation commissioner Sravan Kumar Jatavath received the award comprising a certificate and a cash prize of Rs5 lakh at a function that was held in Vishakhapatnam.

The award ceremony was organized by the ministry to recognize the excellence of cities that were selected for the smart city project in areas such as water management, good governance and conservation of urban environment, among others.

The city corporation had spent around Rs11 crore on the solar power plants. According to a source, the award also recognized the civic body’s plans to utilize the places that were once dump yards for setting up the solar power plants.

The first plant at Ukkadam, which was set up at a cost of R 5.5 crore, has 3,168 panels with a capacity of 320 watts each. Inaugurated in March last year, it today supplies electricity directly to the Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation’s Ukkadam substation. The plant mainly helps the city corporation offset the electricity cost to operate the water pumping station at Velliangadu. According to the source, the plant helps the city corporation save around Rs7.91 lakh on electricity bills a month.

The work on installing the second solar power plant is underway at Kavundampalayam.

The civic body has also plans to create a study centre at Ukkadam solar power plant, where students could come and study more about renewable energy and benefits. “We want to create more awareness among students and motivate them to move towards renewable forms of energy either in their houses, places of work or business in the future,” the source said.

Title: State govt increases lease rate of civic properties
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nashik: The lease rate for properties owned by of civic bodies across Maharashtra has been increased from 2.5% to 8% of the existing Ready Reckoner (RR) rates by the state government.

All civic bodies, including Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC), have been directed to start levying the new lease rates. Moreover, the state government has also rejected the proposal sent by NMC to lease out its properties to social outfits and NGOs at 1% of the existing RR rate.

A civic official said that the NMC received the communique on this issue from the state government in the first week of January. “We will table a proposal in this regard during the upcoming general body meeting to be held next month for approval,” the official said, adding that the NMC will start levying new lease rates after getting approval from the general body.

There are over 2500 properties, including 1,900 commercial outlets and remaining 900 study halls, community halls, libraries, laughter clubs, gymnasiums that have been leased out to different parties by the NMC.

Few months ago there was a controversy after city-based educationist Ratan Luth had filed a PIL at the Bombay high court (HC) over misuse of NMC properties.

During a hearing in April last year, the HC had directed the civic administration to submit a status report on properties that were given to social institutes and NGOs at nominal rates on May 3.

However, the NMC failed to submit the report and was pulled up by the HC for not maintaining records of its properties. The court also directed municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game to remain present during the next hearing.

Following this, the NMC started taking action against properties being misused and sealed 382 of its 945 properties across six divisions. Later, all political parties had urged the civic chief to soften its stand against the properties which were being run for social cause.

The civic body then decided to relieve those properties that were being used directly by the public and also renew agreements of those properties being used by social outfits and NGOs at lease rate of 2.5% of the RR rate. Around 270 civic properties are still locked.

Last year, the general body had decided to levy only 1% of RR rates on properties given to social outfits for social cause. The resolution of the GBM was later sent to the state government for approval. The policy also includes a fine of 2% per month on the lease amount for delay in clearing dues.

Title: Man succumbs to injuries 4 days after accident
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Mohali: A 32-year-old man succumbed to injuries four days later after he was hit by a two-wheeler. The deceased has been identified as Harish, a resident of Sohana village in Mohali, who hails from Bihar.

According to the police officials, the incident took place on Sunday when Harish was on his way to home after work.

“A two-wheeler rammed into Harish and the miscreant fled from the spot leaving his vehicle behind. Harish was taken to GMCH-32 hospital where he succumbed to his injuries on Thursday night,” said ASI Amrik Singh, investigating officer. The police said the motorcycle was in their custody and they would nab the accused. tnn

Title: Development of coronavirus vaccine initiated under 3 programmes
Content: Mumbai: Three programmes, involving two US biotech companies, have initiated development and fast-track of vaccines against the dreaded coronavirus (nCoV-2019), the first such step taken by a global entity to tackle the outbreak, which has reportedly infected hundreds and raised fears of a pandemic. Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (Cepi), a global alliance financing and coordinating the development of vaccines against infectious diseases, will fund these “pioneering technologies” to speed up the development of vaccines against emerging threats like nCoV-2019, Gagandeep Kang, vice-chairperson of Cepi, told TOI here on Friday.The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared the new coronavirus an emergency for China with several deaths reported in the country, but stopped short of declaring it a global epidemic.Coronaviruses a family of viruses that can lead to respiratory illness including severe acute respiratory syndrome, are transmitted between animals and people, and can evolve into strains not previously identified in humans. On January 7, a new coronavirus was identified as the cause of pneumonia in Wuhan (China), and additional cases have been detected in a growing number of countries, including Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, and US.US-based companies Inovio and Moderna, and Brisbane-based University of Queensland will leverage rapid response platforms (in separate programmes) already supported by Cepi as well as a new partnership, to advance vaccine candidates for coronavirus, into clinical testing as quickly as possible. “Our aspiration with these technologies is to bring a new pathogen from gene sequence to clinical testing in 16 weeks – which is significantly shorter than where we are now,” Richard Hatchett, CEO of Cepi, said.Cepi, launched at Davos in 2017 to develop vaccines to prevent epidemics, is also working on vaccines against Chikungunya, Ebola, MERS and Lassa viruses.Speaking on the sidelines of the Indian Society for Clinical Research conference here, Kang, who is also executive director, Translational Health Science and Technology Institute (Department of Biotechnology), said the idea at Cepi is to be prepared for what may be the next outbreak, instead of being reactive.The organisation awarded Inovio a $9 million grant to develop a vaccine against the recently emerged strain of coronavirus. The initial funding will support Inovio’s preclinical and clinical development through Phase 1 human testing, according to a company statement. Further, Cepi will invest up to $10.6 million in University of Queensland to develop a “molecular clamp” vaccine platform, a transformative technology that enables targeted and rapid vaccine production against multiple viral pathogens, the release adds.Under the agreement, Cepi announced a new partnership with Moderna and US-based National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases to manufacture an mRNA (messenger RNA) vaccine against 2019-nCoV.Also, Cepi invests in platform technologies that can be used for rapid vaccine and immunoprophylactic development against unknown pathogens (ie, Disease X). Till now, it has committed to investing over $456 million in vaccine and platform development, according to its website.

Title: 220 students take part in Panjab University hackathon
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: In a run up to the Smart India Hackathon 2020, the Institution Innovation Council (IIC) of University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Panjab University , conducted a 12-hour internal hackathon on Friday.

A total of 33 teams comprising of 220 students participated in the hackathon. 23 teams have worked on software problems and the remaining 10 focused on hardware problems.

Four teams from GCET Jammu participated in the event. Problem statements by ISRO, DRDO, MHRD like smart agriculture, health care management, smart traffic management, indoor navigation, e-commerce, SOS surveillance and social media analytics were targeted by the teams.

Seven best teams were shortlisted by the jury of domain experts from CSIO and Infosys. These teams will be nominated for Smart India Hackathon 2020.

The teams Error 404 and The Turings 2.0 from software and hardware, respectively were the overall winner of the internal hackathon. The hackathon provided students an ideal platform to showcase their ideas.

Title: Mohali: 2 held for immigration fraud
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

MOHALI: Tightening its noose around illegal immigration firms, Mohali police have booked four men for illegally operating a consultancy firm and duping people on the pretext of sending them abroad.

All the four accused have been identified as Sanjeet, Pawan, Narinder and Lakhwinder. The police said the accused were operating the firm from past three to four months and they had recovered four passports and one laptop from their possession.

“While Sanjeet and Pawan have been arrested during a raid on Thursday, Narinder and Lakhwinder are absconding. Hunts are on to nab them,” said SHO Gurwant Singh.

Both the arrested accused were produced in a court on Friday and were sent to judicial custody. tnn

Title: Kochi: Water Metro to be launched in November
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Proposed site for water metro jetty at Marine Drive

KOCHI: Even as the Kochi Metro Rail Limited ( KMRL ) proposes to commission the first boat under the Kochi Water Metro project in November, the metro agency has set an internal deadline to launch the project. Officials and employees will have to work towards launching the project in October.

Kochi Metro officials said construction work of water metro progressing at a fast pace at Vyttila , Kakkanad, Mattancherry and near High Court junctions. Land acquisition has been completed in these places. The plan is to launch the first boat in November. The remaining boats will be brought in later. However, officials cited an internal deadline. “It is to facilitate the launch by October,” said a KMRL official.

Meanwhile, the German ambassador to India Walter J Lindner, who visited Kochi Water Metro sites on Friday expressed satisfaction on the progress of Kochi Water Metro project. He said he would be glad to be in the city during the launch of the project. The sanctioned cost of the project is Rs 747.28 crore and is being implemented with the support of German funding agency KfW.

While interacting with metro officials ambassador Lindner also expressed his desire to attend the Kochi Biennale in December. The envoy along with KMRL managing director Alkesh Kumar Sharma travelled in the Kochi Metro. They boarded the train from Maharaja’s Metro Station at 9.30am and travelled till Vyttila. Sharma and top KMRL officials of accompanied Lidner to the water metro sites. “We briefed him on the progress of Water Metro and our plans to inaugurate the project later this year. We also discussed the Indo-German partnership,” said Sharma.

On special purpose vehicle for Kochi Water Metro, officials said that they have submitted the proposals to the state government. “It is pending before the government. Further decision will be taken once the government gives a green signal,” said an official.

Title: Civic body to hire agency to demolish illegal structures
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) has decided to rope in a private agency to demolish illegal structures which are more than one storied buildings.

The agency will engage its own machinery and manpower to demolish structures and remove the debris. The move was taken due to short of employees in the civic body.

The NMC is looking to establish a two-year contract with the contractor. “We are facing manpower crunch to conduct demolition drive against illegal encroachments in the city. It is very difficult when we have to demolish illegal structures on the first floor or multi-storied buildings,” said an NMC source.

After illegal structures, the NMC would be diverting their attention to illegal hoardings. “We would need manpower for the illegal hoardings drive. Most of the illegal hoardings are large with an iron skeleton,” said an official.

The civic body has already floated the tender and the agency is expected to be finalised within a month. “Further, there is also an issue of abandoned vehicles on the roads. It will also be the responsibility of the agency to lift these vehicles,” added the official.

The process has already started and the last date for filing the bid is February 7. The tenders will be then opened on the same day after 4.00 pm.

Last month, the civic body identified over 300 illegal hoardings, but it could remove only 200 illegal hoardings in the area. Around 100 illegal hoardings are yet to be removed by the civic administration which was put up on dividers, electric poles and traffic islands.

Out of the pending hoardings, many were a large and iron skeleton. Lack of equipment on the NMC part further delayed the process.
