Also, the NMC had to temporarily stop the drive against illegal hoardings as most of the staff was busy in Swachh Survekshan 2020.

Title: All India Congress Committee scouts for new Telangana Congress chief
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

N Uttam Kumar Reddy

HYDERABAD: The Congress leadership in Delhi has started the consultation process to appoint a new candidate to lead the party in Telangana, replacing N Uttam Kumar Reddy who has been holding the office for nearly five years. The All India Congress Committee ( AICC ) has invited several senior leaders from Telangana to Delhi for consultation and to zero in on the candidate to lead the party.

AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao, who is in the race for the TPCC chief’s post, has been demanding that the party leadership this time appoint a leader from BC community to the top post in the state. Ex-MP Madhu Yashki Goud is also one of the frontrunners for the post.

A senior AICC leader said the Congress leadership is also getting a survey conducted to find out which party leaders have a huge following among the people and can bring the party to power in 2023 in Telangana.

Title: West Bengal: Sergeant assaulted by rule-flouting biker
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Infuriated on being stopped and booked by a traffic sergeant for flouting a signal at Shyambazar five-point crossing on Thursday afternoon, the 35-year-old chef riding the bike allegedly snatched the officer’s bike keys, heckled and abused him before tearing off his name tag and the uniform’s pocket. Shyampukur police immediately arrested Sadique Hossain Sid, a Kamarhati resident, and slapped him with non-bailable charges.

According to sources, sergeant Sekhar Chandra Biswas noticed that a biker coming from Central Avenue flouted a signal and turned towards RG Kar Road. “I intercepted and tried to prosecute him. He, however, appeared very abusive and kept denying the fact that he had violated any traffic rule. I asked for his driving licence, which he refused to hand over. He also kept saying he would not pay the fine,” Biswas said.

“I then took the necessary photograph and walked towards the Shyambazar five-point crossing to draw up the legal proceedings. He followed me to the spot, snatched the key to my bike and threw it away. He kept abusing me verbally and even tore my pocket and name tag. He then tried to push me. My seniors and colleagues soon rushed to the spot and detained the person. He was handed over to Shaympukur police.”

Police said the accused has been remanded in judicial custody.

Title: 31 Delhi Police personnel awarded for gallantry, services on R-Day eve
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

New Delhi: Thirty-one personnel of Delhi Police were conferred police medals for their services on the eve of the Republic Day. They would be honoured during the Republic Day celebrations on Sunday.

While 12 officers were awarded police medal for gallantry, two got president’s police medal for distinguished service and 17 got police medal for meritorious service.

Police medal for meritorious service was given to Kumar Gyanesh, additonal DCP (south-east) for his role in cracking down on organised crime. While DCP Pramod Kushwah was given police medal for gallantry. Kushwah, now posted with the Special Cell, was awarded medal for gallantry for his role in cracking down on terror outfits. Along with Kushwah members of his team too were awarded the medal.

The president’s police medal for distinguished service was conferred to Tamang Hibu, now posted with Delhi Police. He was the first officer to raise an anti-terror commando unit for Arunachal Police. He also rescued the son of Arunachal Pradesh chief minister from captivity of Bodo UG groups in Assam, who had kidnapped him for ransom. Hibu played a key role in standardising the operating procedure for the investigation of crime cases and effective redressal of public grievances.

The other recipients of police medals for meritorious service were DCP Mohammad Ali, ACPs Mukesh Tyagi, Ram Kumar Rathi and Dinesh Keshav.

Apart from this, Delhi Fire Service (DFS) chief Atul Garg was awarded the president’s medal for distinguished services for his role in dealing with major fire tragedies that took place in the city in the past one year, including four major fires. Garg had been recently appointed as director of fire services.

Garg had also received fire service medal for meritorious services on Independence Day in 2009. The DFS receives around 30,000 calls annually. Last year, the fire department carried out major rescue operations, including the one at Anaj Mandi in which 44 people had died.

Garg graduated in 1988 from National Fire Service College, Nagpur, in fire engineering. He had served as deputy commandant in Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) before joining DFS as divisional officer in 2002, through UPSC.

Meanwhile, Northern Railway constable Jagbir Singh Rana was posthumously awarded police medal for gallantry for saving the lives of three children at Adarsh Nagar in 2019.

Title: Devotees charged for temple entry in Salem
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Salem: Hundreds of devotees at Sri Sugavaneswarar temple in Salem city were shocked on Friday after officials from the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment (HR&CE) collected Rs 150 as entry fee to enter the temple premises to carry out ‘Thai’ Amavasai special puja for their forefathers.

“We did not know about the entry fee and many of us did not come with sufficient money,” P Jayakumar, one of the devotees told TOI. The officials were strict about collecting the entry fee and some devotees returned back as they did not have enough money, he said.

The devotees lamented that, the temple officials had not collected any such amount on previous occasions. When contacted by TOI, the assistant commissioner of HR&CE P Ramesh said they have started collecting fee at Sri Sugavaneswarar temple after ‘Puratasi’ Ammavasai in 2019.

“Every month on Amavasai, the officials at the temple will collect the fee,” he said, adding that, people those who were coming to the temple every month will know this. He also added that they had started collecting fee in other temples as well including Sri Sangameswarar temple in Bhavani in Erode district.

Title: BJP cadres protesting with Lord Ram’s pics detained in Salem
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Salem: Tension prevailed for a while at Shevapet area in Salem city on Friday after BJP cadres attempted to carry out protest with Lord Ram’s pictures.

The Salem city police detained the cadres for protesting without police permission.

Salem district BJP decided to carry out the rally to pay their respect to those deities on Friday.

Salem city police asked the BJP cadres to disperse citing they did not get any permission for the rally.

District BJP president R P Gopinath, Former MLA K N Lakshmanan, and other cadres refused to so. When they attempted to carry out the rally, the police officials stopped them. Irked over this, they started arguing with the police officials.

Lakshmanan said that, Periyar and his supporters humiliated Sri Ram and wife Sita by garlanding their pictures with sandals in 1971 rally.

“We protested to condemn that rally,” he said, adding that, this rally will be a starting point for Ram temple which will be constructed at Ayodhya.

Finally, police officials overpowered the cadres and detained 62 of them and lodged them in a marriage hall. The arrested people were released on the same evening.

Title: Egg price to be fixed thrice a week instead of every day
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Namakkal: The National Egg Coordination Committee (NECC) has changed its price fixation pattern once again from daily basis to thrice a week. The change was implemented from Thursday onwards.

The NECC, the rate fixation committee for eggs, has been functioning from Namakkal district. The committee earlier fixed the price once in a week. This was practised for more than 40 years. Later, in July 1, 2017, the price of an egg was fixed for three times in a week.

The rate which will be fixed on Monday will be in effect for Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. This pattern also was changed four months ago and changed to every day around 7 pm. The price was applicable until next evening 7 pm.

The poultry farmers across the state have accepted NECC’s thrice a week price fixation pattern. They had started opposing it after it got changed to everyday.

According to poultry farmers, the retailers usually buy eggs at least 30 paise from the NECC rate. It also urged the poultry farmers to sell their eggs on the NECC rate and asked them not to drop their products’ price.

“The retailers were badly affected in the everyday rate fixation pattern as they could not sell their eggs due to rate fluctuation,” S Balaji, one of the poultry farmers. Talking to TOI, he also said that, the retailers refused to buy the eggs without slashed rates.

One of the members of the rate fixation committee said that, the new rate fixation pattern will help regulate the egg trade industry in Namakkal as it is the main hub for egg production which produces about 4 crore eggs every day.

Title: Kochi: 8-month-old baby undergoes liver transplant
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: A liver transplant was performed in a city hospital on an eight-month-old baby , who weighed about 6kg. Normal weight of a healthy child would be 9 kg.

Rabeeh Noufal was not only underweight but also had underdeveloped lungs and suffered from recurrent infections.

In 2019, the child was brought to VPS Lakeshore hospital with jaundice, the bilirubin level 42 times the normal. He also suffered from a rare condition called biliary atresia for which he had undergone a unsuccessful surgery earlier.

A team of doctors led by Dr Abhishek Yadav evaluated him and decided that the only possible option was liver transplantation . “Liver transplantation in the baby was very risky as the child had low weight and was extremely malnourished, had underdeveloped lungs and suffered from recurrent infections,” said Dr Abhishek.

The major challenge was to find a piece of liver to fit inside the child’s small belly and rid the child of the ventilator support after a 14-hour surgery. So first, a very small part from the left side of the father’s liver was removed and transplanted into the baby. “The second problem was much trickier as the child needed a long time to gain strength to breathe on its own after the transplantation due to his underdeveloped lungs. It was unthinkable to put the child on ventilator for so long,” said Dr Abhishek.

So after the transplant, they created an artificial passage to the child’s wind pipe by tracheostomy, to enable the child to breath easily. The child is now fine and back home.

Title: 30 school teachers sacked in Firozabad over fake marksheets
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Agra: Firozabad district basic education office terminated the services of 30 primary school teachers, after the special investigation team found that educational certificates and marksheets furnished by the accused teachers were fake. The education department further ordered local police to lodge FIR against the terminated teachers.

According to termination notice issued to the teachers, the accused had furnished fake marksheets for BEd session 2004-05. The matter came to light while SIT in its ongoing investigation of Agra university fake marksheet scam found that scores of men and women working as teachers in government schools had furnished fake documents.

The department will also recover the salaries paid to the accused teachers for over a decade.

Majority of terminated teachers were posted in Tundla, Shikohabad, Khairgarh, Narkhi, Firozabad city, Arav and Madanpur.

Title: Goa: Fruit vendor held for raping 11-year-old girl
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

Title: Salem: Two killed in road accident
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: Two persons including a 5-year-old boy died in a road accident after a government bus rammed their bike near Hosur in Krishnagiri district on Friday.The deceased have been identified as P Manjula, 35, of Bengaluru and her son Anil, 5.

“They came to Annadhanapatty in Salem city to buy grocery items,” an official from the Shoolagiri police station said. They were returning to Bengaluru on the same scooter Friday afternoon.

When they neared Shoolagiri on Chennai-Bengaluru national highway, a government bus that was also heading to Bengaluru, rammed the scooter from behind.

“Both succumbed to their injuries on the spot,” the official said.Commuters alerted Shoolagiri police . They retrieved the bodies and sent to the government hospital in Hosur for post-mortem.A case was registered and further inquiry is on. tnn

Title: Two US firms in race to develop vaccine
Content:
File image used for representative purpose.

MUMBAI: In the first step taken by a global entity to tackle the coronavirus outbreak that has raised fears of a pandemic, three programmes involving two US biotech companies are trying to fast-track potential vaccines against the rampaging nCoV-2019.Cepi, a global alliance financing and coordinating development of vaccines against infectious diseases , will fund these "pioneering technologies" to speed up the development of vaccines against emerging threats like nCoV-2019, Gagandeep Kang, its vice chairperson, told TOI here on Friday.The World Health Organisation has declared the new coronavirus an emergency for China, where several deaths have been reported, but stopped short of declaring it a global epidemic Coronaviruses can lead to respiratory illness, including severe acute respiratory syndrome, and are transmitted between animals and people. They can evolve into strains not previously identified in humans. On January 7, a new coronavirus was identified as the cause of pneumonia in the Chinese city of Wuhan. Additional cases have been detected in a growing number of countries, including Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and the US.US-based companies Inovio and Moderna, and the University of Queensland in Brisbane, will leverage rapid-response platforms (in separate programmes) already supported by Cepi along with a new partnership to fast-track coronavirus vaccine candidates into clinical testing."Our aspiration with these technologies is to bring a new pathogen from gene sequence to clinical testing in 16 weeks, which is significantly shorter than where we are now," Richard Hatchett, CEO of Cepi, said.Cepi (Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations) launched at Davos in 2017 to develop vaccines to stop future epidemics. It is also working on programmes for vaccines against the chikungunya, Ebola, MERS and Lassa viruses.Speaking on the sidelines of the Indian Society for Clinical Research conference here, Kang said the idea at Cepi was to be prepared for what may be the next outbreak, instead of being reactive.The organisation awarded Inovio a $9 million grant to develop a vaccine against the new strain of coronavirus. The initial funding will support Inovio's pre-clinical and clinical development through Phase 1 human testing, according to a company statement. Further, Cepi will invest up to $10.6 million on University of Queensland's programme to develop a "molecular clamp" vaccine platform, a transformative technology that enables targeted and rapid vaccine production against multiple viral pathogens, the release adds.Under the agreement, Cepi announced a new partnership with Moderna and the US-based National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases to manufacture an mRNA (messenger RNA) vaccine against 2019-nCoV.

Title: Four arrested for Odhav armed robbery
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: City crime branch on Saturday arrested four men — Sanju Sharma, 46, of Jalod in UP, Bhupesh Yadav, 28, of Morena, MP, Jiten Bhogiram Kori , 38, of Madhya Pradesh and Umesh Patel , 30, of Odhav — for allegedly robbing a jeweller of Rs 3,51,000 cash and jewellery worth Rs 6 lakh in Odhav on January 8.

Senior superintendent of police Deepan Bhadran, said that a team lead by inspector J N Chavda was deployed to crack the case.

“After scanning through several mobile numbers, a few numbers were shortlisted and through technical surveillance and human intelligence, we learned that the perpetrators were from other states. We also learned that they were in Gwalior, MP,” Bhadran said.

ACP crime branch B V Gohil said they immediately contacted Gwalior police and learned that the accused were from a gang from Morena and Ambaha districts.

“We also learned that some members of the gang were in Gujarat,” added Gohil. Investigators said they got a tip-off, that the gang members involved in the Odhav armed robbery are presently in Gujarat. “We learned that they had pistols and country-made weapons and were near the Odhav fire station, with the robbed jewellery,” said a crime branch official.

A team lead by inspector J N Chavda was dispatched to the spot and the accused were nabbed. “We recovered one pistol, two country-made handguns and 24 rounds some of 7.65mm calibre, one magazine, three mobile phones and one motorcycle,” said a crime branch source.

Title: Goa pulled up for not constituting state finance body, CM Pramod Sawant assures to comply
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant and state officials were left squirming in their seats on Friday when the 15th Finance Commission questioned the laxity shown by the government in constituting the state finance commission.

After the commission, which is headed by N K Singh, raised the query, Sawant assured the panel that the state finance commission would be set up within 30-45 days.

“We did bring to the notice of the state government that (concerning) the constitution of the state finance commission, which is a mandatory requirement, Goa needs to give it some degree of attention and priority,” said Singh. The commission briefed reporters after meeting all stakeholders.

The finance commission was in the state for a three-day visit, and over the past two days, it met representatives of local government bodies, industry bodies and political parties. Panchayats and urban local bodies, in their closed door meeting with the commission, informed the commission that grants were not reaching them.

“Strengthening the third tier of government was one of the issues that came up,” said Singh. According to Singh, the first report of the state finance commission has been under examination for 19 years, the second report has yet to receive final approval, and the third report has not been filed even though the time to do so has already lapsed.

“In line with their directions, we are appointing the state finance commission as early as possible and as per their recommendations, urban local bodies and panchayats which don’t get performance grants will receive the funds,” said Sawant after meeting the commission.

Panchayats and municipal bodies struggle for funds, and if funds are granted by the finance commission, the money rarely reaches the end user in time, said officials of local governing bodies. Release of funds is often stalled as panchayats and municipal bodies fail to submit utilisation certificates or performance reports on time.

“More robust functioning of the third tier of government through the state finance commission is a priority which I think deserves all our support,” said Singh.

Title: 56% schoolchildren have unhealthy BMI in Chennai
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: About 56% of schoolchildren surveyed in the city have an unhealthy body-mass index (BMI). The national survey aimed at understanding the overall health and fitness levels of children in schools .The survey assessed the children on fitness parameters such as body mass index, aerobic and anaerobic capacity (musculoskeletal force that does not require oxygen), flexibility, core, upper and lower body strength. Sportz Village, an organisation that trains schools students in various sport, covered more than 1.4 lakh children between 7 and 17 years from 364 schools across 250 cities and towns.Although more boys in Chennai had a better body mass index, upper body strength and flexibility, girls outdid the boys in lower body strength and aerobic capacity. While 49% boys were found to have a healthy BMI compared to 46% girls, aerobic capacity of girls was 41% compared to 23% in boys. They were equal in anaerobic capacity (66%) and abdominal strength (84%).At the national level, the survey found that every other child had an unhealthy BMI. An almost equal number did not have adequate lower body strength. The survey also found a gap between students of government and private schools. Children in private schools had better BMI (47%) compared to children in government schools (35%), besides parameters such as upper and lower body and abdominal strength. Students who went to state-run schools had better flexibility, aerobic and anaerobic capacity.“Poor fitness is a cause for concern. They need more physical activity,” said Saumil Majmudar, CEO, Sportz Village. This requires structured in-school physical education programmes that are age-appropriate and inclusive, he said.Weekly physical education periods, according to the survey, were crucial. Children with more than two physical education periods per week had significantly higher aerobic capacity. “Most children don’t eat healthy; they exercise little. Getting them to the play field not only makes them fit but also relaxes them,” said S Satish, a physical education teacher at a private school. “Many kids who adopt sport try to practise it after school hours even they are not serious about the game,” he said.Lower student-teacher ratio allows a teacher to manage the physical education class better. “Individual attention is not lost even in group games. We will be able to correct their body postures, enhance endurance, build strength and minimise injuries,” said R Dhananjay, who trains students in badminton.

Title: Prevent polluted water from reaching the lake, monitoring panel tells Maradu municipality
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

SLMC said that debris should be removed in covered vehicles and sought periodical reports from pollution contr... Read More

KOCHI: The state-level monitoring committee (SLMC) on environment appointed by the National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) has asked Maradu municipality to take steps to prevent cement-mixed water from the four sites, where the buildings were demolished, flow directly into nearby water bodies.

“Following the use of sprinklers, it was found that the water containing cement was flowing to the water body, which could affect the fish spawning in the area. Hence, we have issued instructions to take steps to prevent the direct flow of the water into the water body,” said Justice (retd) A V Ramakrishna Pillai .

Either they should take steps to prevent the water directly reaching the water body or store the water in a tank and treat it before releasing it into the lake, he said.

Maradu municipality secretary Muhammed Arif Khan and sub-collector Snehil Kumar Singh were present at the meeting held in Thiruvananthapuram on Friday. SLMC appreciated both for carrying out demolition of the buildings successfully. It has asked the secretary to ensure debris is removed in a time-bound manner following construction and demolition waste management rules strictly and immediately.

SLMC asked the secretary to ensure that barricades are erected around the sites. It also said that debris should be removed in covered vehicles and sought periodical reports from pollution control board regarding the progress of debris removal. PCB chief engineer P Biju has been entrusted with the task of supervising the debris removal and submitting report to the SLMC.

Though the secretary told the committee that municipality council would raise objection regarding issues related to debris, the SLMC said secretary is the authority in ensuring the C and D rules in the local body. “If the council raises objection, it should be intimated to the state government,” SLMC told Khan.

Meanwhile, the local body is likely to witness another election to the post of chairperson soon as current chairperson T H Nadeera will be resigning from the post by this month-end. She will be replaced by Moly James from Kattithara division.

When the current governing body assumed office in 2015, Ajitha Nandakumar was the chairperson. Later, Divya Anil Kumar and Suneela Siby became chairpersons.

Vice-chairman Boban Nedumparambil is also likely to resign with Jinson Peter from Ayurveda Hospital division his likely replacement.

Title: Kerala school teacher murder: Colleague held for teacher’s murder
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

Title: All are winners at this sports meet
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

CHENNAI: This is a sports meet with a difference, where there are no losers and every participant goes back home with a medal. The Alina–MCDS 10th Unified Sports Meet which will be held on Saturday aims to sensitise children on the challenges faced by the disabled.

“Montfort Community Development Society (MCDS) has four community-based rehabilitation centres for special children and youth with a total strength of 95 students,” says Bro Mathew Alexander , project director , MCDS.

In unified sports, mainstream students are partnered with children with disability so that they learn to help each other and work as a team. They participate in sports events and the combined score of both children is taken.

“Unified Sports Day was started in 2005 by late Bro Patrick , founding director of MCDS and Bro George Vazhayil, founding principal of Montfort Matriculation Higher Secondary School, St Thomas Mount, with the technical support of Dr M S Nagarajan, Special Olympics International,” says Alexander, adding the school was established as an inclusive school. “It now has 180 special children,” he says.

About 500 students and youth are expected to participate in the event this year. “Around 70 people from our centres will be participating. We have also invited other organisations working in the field,” says Alexander.

Each special athlete will be paired with student to participate in events such as running, relay, shot put, obstacle race etc. “The event will be held from 8:30am to 2pm and each pair will spend the whole time together. The Unified Partners in fact will bring an extra lunch packet that day, which they will share with their partner, the special athlete as a fellowship lunch at the end of the sports meet,” says Alexander. “There are no losers, every participant will be given a medal.” The highlight this year is an Olympic torch run. “It will start from St Thomas Mount, where the torch will be lit and brought to the venue. About 40 special athletes and their unified partners will participate in the run,” says Alexander.

Title: Man attacks sister-in-law with acid for defaulting on loan
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Mangaluru: A 35-year-old woman sustained severe burns after she was attacked by her brother-in-law with acid that is used to make rubber sheets , at Kodimbala , Kadaba taluk in Dakshina Kananda.

The victim, Swapna , a widow and mother of three daughters, is being treated at Wenlock Hospital, Mangaluru, and her condition is stable, said police.

A row over not paying bank loans resulted in the attack, according to police. The accused is Jayananda, 55, a resident of Kodimbala.

The incident took place on Thursday evening, when Jayananda, an agricultarist, came to the victim’s house and started abusing her in foul language over not paying a bank loan . In the melee, he opened a bottle of acid used for making rubber sheets, and threw it inside the house. The acid fell on Swapna and her daughter, who has sustained minor burns.

Police said that Swapna has received burns on her face, while her daughter has minor injuries on her legs and hands.

Ravi Kumar, the victim’s husband, had taken a loan of Rs 5 lakh against his land, at a cooperative bank, and died in October 2018.

The loan was taken to build a new house and purchase a water pumpset. He died after paying two instalments of the loan.

Accused got bank notices

After his death, Swapna was unable to repay the remaining amount of the loan, and all the bank notices were addressed to accused Jayananda. Swapna eked out a livelihood through the agriculture land which was given to her by her father-in-law.

A case has been registered at Kadaba police station under Indian Penal Code sections 447, 504, 506 and 326A (acid attack) on Friday evening, against the accused.

Title: 2 held for posing as cops, robbing jewellers by planting drugs on them
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Meerut: In a major breakthrough, two men have been arrested for allegedly posing as policemen, hounding unassuming traders carrying costly jewellery by planting drugs in their bags and decamping with their cash and gold.

According to police sources, the two have been identified as residents of Farukhhabad -- Nisar Hussain and Suhail Afridi. They were arrested by Meerut police on a tip-off. Gold jewellery weighing 100 grams, Rs 5 lakh in cash and 500 grams of narcotics were seized from them.

According to Ajay Sahani, SSP, “The two persons arrested are from Farukkhabad and claim to be of Iranian origin. Their modus operandi was simple. They would don policemen’s uniforms and surround an unsuspecting target. One of the thugs would engage the latter in a conversation while the other would plant drug packets inside his bag. This would unsettle the victim and soon enough, after taking him to a secluded spot, he would be robbed.”

A similar incident had taken place in October last year when local jeweller Suresh Chand Rastogi was robbed near the railway station after he was told by “men in khakhi” to undergo a search. Later, his valuables were taken away. Several other incidents had taken place earlier.

“A case has been registered under IPC section 379 (theft), 420 (cheating) and relevant sections of the Narcotics Drugs and Psychotropic Substance (NDPS) Act against the duo,” said station in charge, Delhi Gate thana, Ravinder Singh. Meanwhile, SSP Sahani has issued a letter to SSP Farukkhabad to verify the documents of the duo arrested.

Title: West Bengal: Railway man rescues hungry teenager from Bally station
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Ghanshyam Singh (second from right) being handed over to his uncle Virendra Thakur (left) in presence of senio... Read More

KOLKATA: One evening, while returning home from work at Howrah, railwayman Tapas Bagchi received an SOS from a staffer at Bally station. A girl child was found loitering on the station premises but was unable to say where she lived. Bagchi, who had already embarked on a mission by then to rescue homeless children from stations, got off the local train at Bally and found the girl in distress. There was nobody to take charge of her so late in the evening. Finally, Bagchi took her to his Konnagar home where he lives with his wife and daughter.

Nearly 12 years later, on Tuesday, Bagchi chanced upon a boy scavenging for food at Howrah station. He didn’t look like a vagabond but was clearly very hungry. Bagchi took him aside and offered him food. The teenager opened up gradually and narrated that he is a Class XI student from Durg in Chhattisgarh.

“His name is Ghanshyam Singh and he lost his father a few years ago. He stays in a hostel and studies. He scored nearly 88% marks in his Class X examination. He seems to have got frustrated due to something and boarded a train from Durg. For the next few days, he survived on food given him by people and whatever he could find in dustbins. He was too shy to tell people of his predicament till I approached him,” Bagchi said.

This time, Bagchi did not have to take Ghanshyam home to Konnagar. Bagchi and his friends had come together several years ago to form an organisation named ‘Oistic’. It provides relief to children from poor backgrounds and pavement dwellers in particular. With all his savings, Bagchi purchased a property in Serampore and handed it over to ‘Oistic’ a few years ago. That is now home for six kids. Ghanshyam was provided fresh clothes and put up at this home while his family was contacted.

“His family responded immediately. His mother assured that her brother would reach Howrah on Wednesday with all necessary documents to take his charge. This brings back memories of the girl I took home over a decade ago. She was from Mumbai and stayed with us for four days. Now, she is training to be an air-hostess. We are also very proud of our ‘Oistic’ Home. One of the inmates, Arpit Nath, stood first in his Class VII exams this year,” Bagchi added.

On Wednesday Ghanshyam was handed over to his uncle Virendra Thakur at Howrah station in the presence of Pallavi Goswami , senior rail official.

Title: EBCs to get Rs 10 lakh aid to start businesses schemes: Bihar CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nitish Kumar

PATNA: The state government has launched a new entrepreneurship scheme for the extremely backward classes (EBCs), under which those eligible will be provided an assistance of Rs 10 lakh to set up small businesses.

Chief minister Nitish Kumar launched the ambitious scheme on Friday for the EBCs, who account for nearly 30% of the state’s population, with an eye on the state election scheduled to be held later this year.

“The “Mukhya Mantri Ati Pichhda Varg Udyami Yojana ’ will provide a financial assistance of Rs 10 lakh to any eligible member of EBC communities for setting up a small enterprise,” Nitish said, adding, “Of the total assistance, Rs 5 lakh will be provided as subsidy and the rest Rs 5 lakh as interest-free loan.”

The CM was addressing a programme organized to commemorate the birth anniversary of socialist leader and former Bihar CM Karpoori Thakur, a prominent EBC leader. Nitish also pointed out that sections of the Muslim community also come under the EBC category and “they will also benefit from the new scheme”. The event was organized by JD(U)’s EBC cell at Sri Krishna Memorial Hall here.

Nitish said the scheme is on the lines of the Mukhya Mantri SC/ST Udyami Yojana, which was implemented in the state two years ago. He added that the state government would provide training to the selected applicants before providing the assistance.

“Only yesterday, I discussed the nitty-gritty of the new scheme with the state’s industries minister Shyam Rajak and he has agreed to do carry out the required exercise,” he said with Rajak on the dais with him.

In Bihar, around 130 castes are listed under the state government’s EBC category. Of them, 36 castes, including Ansari, Julaha, Momin, Dhunia, Chirihaar, Bakkho, Rangrej, Madar among others, are from the Muslim community.

Rajak told TOI that the new scheme would come into force from the current financial year after getting a formal approval from the state cabinet. “As announced by the CM, all facilities of the Mukhya Mantri SC/ST Udyami Yojana will be provided to EBCs under the new scheme. The department has listed altogether 101 projects under the SC/ST scheme and members of EBC community can choose any project from the list,” Rajak said.

“The industries department has prepared a proposal for the new scheme. It will soon be sent to the cabinet secretariat for putting up at the next cabinet meeting,” an industries department official said.

Political analysts say it could prove to be a “game changer” during the assembly election as the EBCs form around 30% of votes in Bihar. “The new scheme will bring unprecedented socio-economic change among the members of EBCs because majority of castes under this category are either artisans or having traditional entrepreneurship. The assistance of Rs 10 lakh will lead to their economic uplift,” Arvind Kumar Nishad, an EBC leader told TOI.

Title: CM Naveen Patnaik not to unfurl tricolour in Cuttack
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

CM Naveen Patnaik

CUTTACK: In a departure from tradition, chief minister Naveen Patnaik won’t unfurl the tricolour on Republic Day in Cuttack. Instead, he will be the guest of honour at a state government function in Bhubaneswar where governor Ganeshi Lal will unfurl the national flag. In Naveen’s absence, finance minister Niranjan Pujari will unfurl the tricolour in Cuttack. The tradition of the chief minister unfurling the flag in Cuttack has been decades old. But this time the state intends to follow the Centre in hosting the Republic Day parade. Bhubaneswar will see a parade on Mahatma Gandhi Road where a total of 48 contingents will take part. This year, one of the contingents will be headed by a lady commandant. With a day to go the celebrations, security has been beefed up across the twin cities of Cuttack and Bhubaneswar. “A total of 45 platoons of police force have been deployed in the twin cities to maintain law and order and take care of traffic movement,” police commissioner Sudhansu Sarangi said. Barricades have been put near the parade venue and restrictions imposed on entry of vehicles. “We have installed eight CCTV cameras near the venue to keep an eye on the event,” Sarangi said. “A separate VVIP seating arrangement has been done. All ACPs, station officers and sub-inspectors have been deputed to ensure foolproof security on Mahatma Gandhi Road and Barabati Stadium,” the police commissioner added. In Cuttack, DCP Akhileshvar Singh, along with other district administration officials, are regularly inspecting Barabati Stadium, venue of the Republic Day celebration.

Title: 24-year-old commits suicide in Delhi hotel
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Represenative image

NEW DELHI: A 24-year-old man allegedly committed suicide at one of the rooms of Vivanta by Taj hotel in Lutyens’ Delhi by consuming medicines .

Family members of Karan Chandra told cops that he was suffering from depression due to discord between his parents, who had separated. A suicide note was found beside him when the hotel staffers found his body on Friday. Police said that it seemed that he had committed suicide at least two days before as the body had started decomposing.

The incident was reported on Friday, when the housekeeping staff alerted the hotel management about Chandra, who was not responding to their calls. He had taken a third floor room on rent on January 19 and was staying there since then. On January 20, he had put a ‘do not disturb’ tag on his door.

Since he had booked the hotel room for five days, the hotel authorities started enquiring about him on January 24. According to hotel officials, Chandra was a platinum member of the hotel.

“A call was received at 4.10pm on Friday, about a guest who was not responding despite repeated knocks. Foul smell was also coming out from the room, which was locked from inside. The door of the room was opened with the help of hotel staff and Chandra, a resident of Malviya Nagar, was found in a sleeping posture,” deputy commissioner of police, New Delhi, Eish Singhal said.

Cops also recovered a suicide note and some medicines from the room. In the note the Chandra had written down the lyrics of ‘In the end’, a famous song by an American rock band Linkin Park. The note read ‘In the end, it doesn’t even matter’.

“A crime team inspected the room. The body bore no injury marks and was handed over to family members after post-mortem,” added Singhal.

Title: Onion price rises to Rs 80/kg yet again, traders blame short supply
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolkata: The sudden drop in supply pushed up the onion price to the Rs 80/kg level on Friday. Traders blamed the transition from new crop to the mature lot in Nashik and Bellary — country’s foremost onion producers — for the inconsitent supply, which dropped to eight-nine trucks from the usual 25 to Koley Market.

“This is quite a drastic rise. Even on Thursday, onion price remained at Rs 50-Rs 55/kg. Traders could not give us satisfactory reason behind the abrupt jump in onion price,” said Amiya Gupta, a resident of Behala, who was shocked at the inexplicable rise of onion price.

The spike, market experts said, was temporary and supply would normalise the moment harvesting of mature crop was complete. So far, city markets have received new onion crop, which is highly perishable. The mature crop, which is being harvested now, is less perishable and can be stored for some time. Thus, the mature crop is to stabilise the market.

However, wholesalers alleged that selling onion at Rs 80/kg is unfair. The wholesale onion price on Friday stood at Rs 2,000-Rs 2,200/40kg bag, which translates to Rs 50-Rs 55/kg. “Even if a retailer sells them at Rs 60-Rs 65/kg, there will be a handsome profit,” said Kamal De, president of the West Bengal Vegetable Vendors’ Association and member of the chief minister’s task force on market prices. “But retailers have developed the habit of selling a small amount, keeping a higher margin of profit,” he added.

Significantly, onion price skyrocketed to Rs 150/kg last month. Since then, onion price had gradually dropped to Rs 50/kg.

Meanwhile, after a gap of two weeks, the agri-marketing department has planned to resume sale of onion once again through the network of nearly 1,000 ration shops. This time, onion will be sold at Rs 44/kg. “We hope that the price will come down soon. Moreover, our enforcement wing will be visiting the markets to see whether there is any malpractice,” said an agri-marketing department officer.

According to department sources, there is no dearth of onion in stock. The government is keeping a close watch on the stock and supply and wants the price to stabilise so that ups and downs of onion price do not hit the consumers card.

Title: Rural police to conduct grievance redressal for elderly
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kochi: To make the service of police force more elderly-friendly , the Ernkulam rural police will conduct a grievance redressal forum for elders on Republic Day . The forum will be conducted in all the three sub-divisions —Aluva, Muvattupuzha and Perumbavur— at 9.30am. Elderly people can attend the programme and interact with senior police officers to inform them about the problems they face.

The venue of the forum in Aluva will be the district police headquarters, in Muvattupuzha and Perumbavur it will conducted at the respective DySP offices. District police chief K Karthick will inaugurate the forum in Aluva. tnn

Title: Chain-snatcher held; Rs 12L jewellery seized
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Mangaluru: The run of a chain-snatcher , who was involved in more than 10 chain-snatching incidents in the city, ended on Thursday, after he was arrested by the Mangaluru city police.

The police have recovered around 300 grams of ornaments valued at Rs 12 lakh, a motorbike and autorickshaw from him.

The police said the arrested is Vinay Prasad , 27, a resident of Badaga Ulipady . The accused used to target women walking alone on the streets, snatch their chain, and flee from the spot. According to police, he was reportedly involved in more than 10 cases of chain-snatching.

Five cases against Vinod were registered at Urwa police station limits, two under Kavoor police station, and one each under Barke police station, Mangaluru East police station and Mangaluru Rural police station.

He was produced before a court and remanded in judicial custody.

Title: 5 notorious criminals held
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Meerut: Five notorious criminals, who were absconding since their bails, were on Friday arrested in the district. Each of them has more than 12 cases of heinous crimes registered against them, including that of murder, loot, attempt to murder and robbery. Facing stringent sections like Gunda Act, Gangster Act and Arms Act, the five criminals were active for the last ten years, a police officer said.

They were allegedly involved in some recent crimes in the region, including the robbery in the house of a property dealer in Kavi Nagar area of Ghaziabad, a bank robbery in Hapur, truck loot-cum-murder in Ghaziabad, the officer said.

SSP Meerut Ajay Sahni told TOI, “All these gangsters had come out on bail at different times but never went back for hearing and were absconding. They have conducted three major loots, including that of Rs 50,000 worth of liquor bottles from a shop this month.”

Among those arrested are Pramod Yadav, who has 21 cases registered against him in Hapur, Ghaziabad, Amroha, Haldwani (Uttarakhand), Meerut and Bulandshahr; Naseeruddin, who has 16 cases in Delhi, Hapur, Ghaziabad and Meerut. The gang leader, Mainpal, with 13 cases registered in all above western UP districts, was also arrested. He carried a reward of Rs 50,000 on his head and is among the top-ten criminals of Hapur in police records. Notably, all members of this gang are school dropouts. Police recovered five illegal firearms from their possession including a pistol and several live bullets.

The gang members also revealed that they had planned to rob a businessman in Agra on January 2, but since the home was full with people, the idea was shelved. While returning, the gang looted a liquor shop on Aligarh-Mathura road, police said. The gang also specializes in robbing vehicles from people, which they sold in black market.

Title: Revoke bail of Nithyananda: Complainant
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bengaluru: The high court on Friday ordered notice to the Criminal Investigation Department in a petition filed by K Lenin, the original complainant in the allged rape case involving self-proclaimed godman Nithyananda .

Justice John Michale Cunha adjourned the hearing to next week to enable CID to file objections.

Lenin, who once worked as a driver to the godman, sought cancellation of the bail granted to Nityananda, contending that he has been skipping trial.

According to Lenin, though the godman has fled the country with an expired passport, in the exemption applications filed before the trial court, it is still being contended that Nityananda is in India undertaking a religious tour. TNN

Title: BJP targets Asaduddin Owaisi
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

HYDERABAD: BJP MLC N Ramachander Rao said that Asaduddin Owaisi did not even spare a sweet dish such as “halwa” from his communal politics, and recalled that Owaisi had stated that halwa is an Arabic word.

“Indians always respect all languages, and do not differentiate on religious basis, the BJP MLC said.

Title: Kerala governor to summon all files on anti-CAA suit
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kerala governor Arif Mohammad Khan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With the government making no move to withdraw the suit from the Supreme Court over the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) even after governor Arif Mohammad Khan taking serious exception to the government’s decision citing the rules of business, the governor is learnt to have decided to pursue the matter legally.

It is reliably learnt that the governor would soon summon all files that were originated and circulated in the government departments concerned for deciding to approach the Supreme Court against the Citizenship Amendment Act. The suit filed by the state government in SC a few days ago was given number by the SC registry on Friday.

Governor Khan has taken a strong exception to the government’s move as he was kept out of the loop, against the norms set in rules of business.

As per the rule 36 (a) of the rules of business, the chief minister shall “cause to be furnished to the governor such papers, records or information relating to the administration of affairs of the state and proposals for legislation as the governor may call for”. This would mean that the government is bound to submit the files before the governor if he asks for it, and 36 (b) says that, “if the governor so requires, submit for the consideration of the council any matter on which a decision has been taken by a minister but which has not been considered by the council”.

According to the rule 34 (4), cases which affect the relations of the state government with the government of India, any other state government, the Supreme Court or the high court, should be submitted by the chief minister to the governor prior to making a move. The governor had repeatedly quoted this clause to prove that the government’s move was not legal.

The government had deputed chief secretary Tom Jose to give an explanation before the governor regarding the matter that it was done to allay the concerns of the people of the state, but the governor had refused to buy the argument. He had clearly said that he will consider the matter to be closed only if the illegal action is reversed.

It is no reliably learnt that the governor has taken up the matter seriously and has decided to explore the possible legal actions in the matter. In his last visit to New Delhi, the governor had met legal and Constitutional experts and discussed the further course of action with them, sources said.

Title: After NGT rap, Centre asks UP to take ‘necessary step’ towards notifying Hastinapur a sanctuary
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Meerut: Over a month after National Green Tribunal (NGT) issued contempt notices to the Centre and to the UP government for not notifying Hastinapur wildlife area as a protected sanctuary despite its order, the Union ministry has asked the state to take “necessary steps” as directed by the green body.

Union ministry of environment and forest (MoEF), in a letter to the state government, has now “requested” it to “take necessary action as per NGT and also update the ministry about the same.” The letter, accessed by the TOI, was issued by Rakesh Kumar Jagenia, DIG, Wildlife, MoEF. It has been addressed to UP’s principal secretary (Forest) and to state’s chief wildlife warden.

The letter also encloses the copies of NGT's May 2019 order as well as contempt-cum-execution notice issued on December 18, 2019 for non-implementation of its earlier order in which the Tribunal had given six months to respondents to notify Hastinapur under Wildlife Protection Act.

The Hastinapur wildlife area is commonly referred to as a sanctuary. But, with the lack of proper government notification on it, the area does not enjoy the protection needed to check poaching and various other threats to the wildlife. Human habitation and construction activities are not allowed in the protected area. If implemented, the move will weed out several industrial zones, luxury resorts and even Bijnor DM’s official bungalow posing threat to flora and fauna of the UP’s largest forest region.

In 1986, the government had issued a primary notification declaring Hastinapur forest area a sanctuary. However, no final government order notifying the 2,073 square-km area a protected zone has come from the government since then.

Irked over it, the NGT had last year asked the forest department to explain to it the reason behind over 30 years of delay in proclaiming Hastinapur wildlife area as a protected sanctuary. It gave six months to follow the order. Then, on December 18 last year, the NGT issued contempt notices to Union Ministry of Environment and Forest, UP government and others over non-implementation of its earlier order.

The Tribunal was responding to a plea filed by Centre for Wildlife and Environmental Litigation (CWEL) through its secretary Bhanu Bansal.

According to Bansal, “On May 31, NGT had directed the MoEF and to the UP government to issue notification under Wildlife Protection Act within six months. It was meant to protect and conserve biological diversity, environment and wildlife of the area.

“However, even after the expiry of six months, situation on ground remained the same. Then the Tribunal issued contempt-cum-execution notice to Union ministry, UP government and others for non-implementation of its earlier order," he said.

The Hastinapur wildlife area is commonly referred to as a sanctuary and is spread around five districts-- Bijnor, Muzaffarnagar, Meerut, Amroha and Hapur. But, due to lack of proper government notification on it, the area does not enjoy the protection needed to check poaching and various other threats to the wildlife.

The petitioner had 15 respondents in the case, including MoEF, UP government, National Board of Wildlife, National Biodiversity Authority, Forest Conservator UP, DFOs of districts within which sanctuary falls, etc.

Title: State bar council move unites rival groups of western Odisha lawyers
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

File photo of lawyers on strike in Sambalpur

SAMBALPUR: The Odisha State Bar Council’s (OSBC)s recommendation to the Bar Council of India (BCI) advocating disciplinary action against office bearers of 17 bar associations of western Odisha has brought agitating lawyers from the region closer.

The Balangir bar association and the central action committee (CAC), comprising the bars of several western Odisha districts, have decided to bury their differences over the place where the place where the high court bench should come up.

For years, Balangir bar association has been pressing for a high court bench in the district even as others questioned the rigidity.

This led to differences between the two groups of lawyers. But Thursday’s Balangir meeting, which was attended by 23 bar associations across western Odisha, signalled a thaw in the rivalry.

“It is a fight for the right of lawyers. The direction of the Supreme Court is beyond its administrative jurisdiction. We are united to fight against the injustice against the lawyers of western Odisha,” said Pradeep Bohidar, chairperson of the action committee of Sambalpur bar association.

The demand for the establishment of a high court bench in western Odisha dates back to more than five decades. However, the lawyers in the region were making the demands separately. But in 2006, as many as 37 bar associations of western Odisha, including that of Sambalpur and Balangir, organised a meeting in Bargarh and the central action committee of all Western Odisha Bar Associations was formed.

The lawyers continued the agitation under the leadership of the CAC demanding the establishment of the high court bench anywhere in western Odisha. In 2007, the lawyers gheraoed the assembly over their demand. Subsequently, chief minister Naveen Patnaik called on a delegation of CAC and later recommended the establishment of HC benches in Berhampur and Sambalpur.

But the choice of Sambalpur did not go down well with Balangir bar association and it parted ways from the CACthe same year. Since then the Balangir bar association has been pressing for the establishment of the HC bench in the district separately.

But the OSBC move has changed the entire dynamics brought rival groups together after more than a decade.

Title: NHAI to start piling work for flyover
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: When the national highway authority of India (NHAI) gave letter of appointment to contractor Rameshwar Dayal & Son-Cherian Varkey Construction Company ( RDS-CVCC ) in April 6, 2019, it was bound to hand over encumbrance-free land within three months for the construction of Kazhakoottam flyover . However, so far the NHAI was not been able to fulfil their promise.

Now, as the district administration has agreed to divert traffic in 400m-stretch in the 1.12km Kazhakoottam junction to CSI mission hospital side, the contractor will be able to start piling work.

The district administration has given sanction for traffic diversion on the stretch from February 1 to March 30. The vehicles to Kollam side will be diverted through the market road during this time. This will enable the contractor to start the work on the stretch. NHAI has sought 6 months to complete construction of around 7-8 piers in the portion.

Though NHAI had approach the police and district administration for a traffic diversion in the entire 1.12km stretch for the flyover construction, permission was not granted. The authorities cited lack of service roads as a major reason to deny traffic diversion.

Meanwhile, the local traders have approached the high court and secured an interim stay demanding compensation for displacement. They argued that not just land owners, the traders who will be displaced too are eligible for compensation under the land acquisition act. Sources in NHAI said that they were ready to provide compensation if there is a 100% displacement. “However, only a portion of the builings are razed for widening. The shops can function in the remaining portion of the buildings,” sources said.

The deadline for completion of Kazhakoottam flyover is April 2021. With NHAI losing several months due to delay in land acquisition, there are concerns of timely completion of the project.

The work of the flyover on the Kazhakoottam-Technopark side is on track as NHAI has begun placing girders. Traffic in this portion is diverted through the service road.

The 2.71km Kazhakoottam flyover is a standalone project and is not part of the Kazhakoottam-Karode national highway widening. Union minister for road transport and highway Nitin Gadkari had approved the flyover during the inauguration of Kazhakoottam-Mukkola NH widening work. The flyover was suggested to bypass the traffic congestion in Kazhakoottam and Technopark area.

Title: Case against BJP MP Karandlaje
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Malappuram: Kuttippuram police registered a case against BJP leader and Udupi-Chickmagalur MP Shobha Karandlaje over her tweet alleging that a section of people in Kuttippuram panchayat were not being given water because they supported Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The case has been registered under Section 153(A) of IPC (Promoting enmity between different groups on the ground of religion, race etc) based on a complaint lodged by Subash Chandran, an advocate with Supreme Court, with the Malappuram police chief U Abdul Kareem.

The police chief said that the case was registered because the tweet by MP was misleading. “The preliminary investigation shows that the family stopped the water supply to colony residents after they received a direction from KSEB authorities over drawing of water from a well near a paddy field using a pump for non-irrigation purposes. We will continue the investigation to bring out the truth and we will also investigate the allegation that there were call to boycott people who attend pro-CAA event,” he said.

Kuttippuram police have also registered case against Seva Bharathi workers in Painkannur area of the panchayat for raising the same allegation. tnn

Title: Coronavirus: Kerala health department issues guidelines to hospitals
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

(With inputs from Kottayam, Kochi and Thrissur)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The health department has issued a set of WHO-approved guidelines and treatment protocols to all hospitals and medical practitioners to prevent the outbreak of coronavirus in Kerala, said health minister K K Shailaja on Thursday.Also, three persons who arrived from China have been quarantined at hospitals in Ernakulam and Thrissur as they exhibited symptoms of fever.“Preventive steps have been taken, including screening of people coming from China and others who had recently-travelled in the region. Special isolation wards have been set up at all medical colleges, district and general hospitals,” she said.The department has issued orders to sanitize all wards and operation theatres as a precautionary measure. All field workers, paramedical staff and doctors were told to wear protective masks and gloves while treating patients. Kerala Medical Services Corporation was told to provide medicines, masks, gloves, and protective suits. Instructions were also issued to send samples of suspect patients immediately to the virology lab.Shailaja said strict vigil was enforced at airports and ports to identify those with preliminary symptoms of coronavirus. If symptoms are noticed, screening team will shift the person to hospitals with isolation wards. For passengers without symptoms, steps will be taken to monitor them at home for 28 days.Meanwhile a youth, who arrived in Kochi from China with symptoms of fever was admitted to Ernakulam Medical College’s isolation ward and his blood samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology in Pune for examination. Another person is kept in isolation at a private hospital in Ernakulam.In Thrissur, DMO Dr K J Reena said seven people are currently under observation at various hospitals.“One of them is in an isolation ward in a government hospital. These seven people came from countries with confirmed coronavirus cases. We are following the instructions given by the government,” she said.Also, 24 passengers were screened at Cochin International Airport and nobody was reported to be ill. Six more people are being observed at home, said the medical officer in Ernakulam.In Kottayam , two individuals who arrived from China and one from Saudi Arabia, were advised to remain at home for 28 days.Collector P K Sudheer Babu met officials to take stock of the situation. He said they will be subjected to medical test in government hospitals.

Title: GST: Fake invoices worth Rs 10,000 crore unearthed
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: With searches carried out in different parts of the country, the directorate general of GST intelligence (DGGSTI) has unearthed cases of fake invoices worth over Rs 10,000 crore in the current fiscal.

The main purpose of the DGGSTI raids was to probe fraudulent claims of input tax credit (ITC), leading to GST evasion. However, tax sleuths have also found that in 35% of the cases, fakes invoices were issued to fudge up the turnover with no GST evasion. This has helped many firms to avail bank loans for which they may not have been eligible in the normal course given their actual financials.

In a sizeable number of invoices, no ITC was availed through the fake invoices but it either led to avoiding income tax on the basis of recording fraudulent purchases in the books or at the other end it helped in bloating the turnover. Fakes invoices were used as a mode to route unaccounted funds too.

The DGGSTI is now taking up the job to sensitize the income tax department and even banks about such cases. There have been cases where firms with poor financials have been able to get huge loans on the basis of fake entries and have later turned NPAs, said A K Pandey, special secretary to the ministry of finance and member of Central Board of Indirect Tax and Customs (CBIC). He was in the city for an official visit.

He said a system of directly issuing invoices through the GST-network (GSTN) is being worked out too. There are chances that it may be implemented in a few months as the fine tuning of the plan is under way.

With this, the sale and purchase invoices of a business having a turnover above a certain limit may have to be directly generated through the system. This will ensure easier matching of the purchases and sales of the opposite parties, he said.

Huge mismatches have also been found in the GST liability calculated by an assessee in the GSTR1 returns and the amount paid through the GSTR3B format.

GSTR 1 is a record of sales and GSTR3B is a summary return on the basis of which a final liability is discharged. At times, low sales, compared to that mentioned in GSTR1, is shown in GSTR3B by the same assessee.

Cases of mismatch over Rs 40 crore may be handed over to the DGGSTI which is a specialized investigation wing whose officers have all India jurisdiction. The rest of the cases will be taken up by the respective commissionerates, he said.

ANATOMY OF SCAMS

Fake invoices used for money-laundering and increasing purchases too

Firms availed loans on the basis of fudged up turnover through fake invoices.

Banks and income tax to be sensitized on the cases

Plant to have system generated invoices

Title: Teachers, students burn the midnight oil
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Hard work: Night classes being held at a school in Karkala taluk

Mangaluru: Eight schools in Karkala taluk of Udupi district, including four government schools, have introduced night classes to help slow learners appearing for SSLC exams this academic year. The three-hour classes are held between 6pm and 9pm.

Speaking to TOI, Karkala Block Education Officer (BEO) G S Shashidhar said that classes are being conducted in four government, three aided and an unaided school in the taluk. The School Development and Monitoring Committee (SDMC), local organisations and associations have extended support to this programme.

“Parents have to give their consent in writing before sending their children for night classes and have to take the responsibility to pick and drop them to and from school. The programme will focus on slow learners who are also taught basic relaxation techniques and how to attain pass marks. Children who are unable to study at home too can join in. At the open-air theatre of Uppala Higher Primary School, students from five nearby schools attend night classes,” Shashidhar explained.

Venkataramana Kalkura, SSLC nodal officer, has inspired many schools to launch similar projects. At this venue, three girls from Karnataka Public School, Muniyalu, too, attend classes. Uppala Friends Cricketers are sponsoring snacks for students every day, he added.

No classes in interior areas

Narayana Shenoy, maths teacher and president of Karkala Taluk High School Assistant Teachers Association, has been motivating and encouraging teachers. “About 20 students attend these classes in each school and SDMC members including presidents, or local body members and officials from the education department visit schools regularly,” said BEO Shashidhar who has come forward to sponsor a week’s snacks at a school.

However, night classes depend on the local conditions. They are not held in interior areas which is surrounded by forests. Parents and students of Hermunde and Kervashe had requested for night classes, but due to the presence of wild animals in the area, they had to turn down the request. Schools in the town area conduct classes between 7and 10pm. This programme is part of Mission 100 Karkala, aimed at securing 100 per cent results in the SSLC exams.

Title: After restarting operations in December, Zuari Agro shuts down NPK plant due to lack of materials
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

PANAJI: Barely a month after recommencing production, Zuari Agro Chemicals Ltd (ZACL) has shut down its NPK plant due to lack of ammonia and phosphoric acid, said company officials.

Officials said that both the NPK plants of ZACL are shut, though the urea fertilizer plant remains operational.

Zuari Agro Chemicals Ltd restarted one of its NPK plants at Zuarinagar in December last year, and resumed production of fertilizers after the Centre’s department of fertilizers released subsidy amounts.

“Zuari Agro Chemicals Ltd has announced that the NPK - a plant of the company has been shut down due to non-availability of raw material,” the company said in an official statement.

ZACL’s NPK plants need ammonia and phosphoric acid to prepare NPK (nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium) fertilizers. The fertilizers are used to increase crop productivity.

The company stopped operations of its urea and ammonia plant on July 4 last year after a leakage was reported in the ammonia plant. Later the NPK-B plant was shut down from April 27 except for a five-day period in September, due to lack of funds to purchase raw material and natural gas.

ZACL was forced to shut down its plants in 2019 because of non-availability of natural gas, owing to non-payment of dues to Gas Authority of India Limited (GAIL). Delay in release of subsidies from the department of fertilizers (DoF) in earlier quarters led to a shortage of funds with the fertilizer manufacturer, which in turn led to delay in payments to suppliers.

Title: Odisha: To facilitate industries, government speeds up land acquisition
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The state government has fast-tracked land acquisition for major industrial and infrastructure projects. In the past one month, it has initiated the process of acquiring land for two mega projects.

While the government has assigned Odisha Industrial Infrastructure Development Corporation (Idco) to acquire around 3,320 acres for a petrochemicals complex to be set up by Haldia Petrochemicals Limited in Balasore, it gave the nod to Bhadrak district administration to acquire 274 acres for a commercial airstrip by Dhamra Port Company Limited in Dhamra. It would be the first airstrip in north Odisha, sources said.

Land hurdle was one of the reasons for the delay in implementation of the 25-year-old Khurda Road-Balangir railway line. But now this has been expedited with continuous follow-up by authorities from the state and Centre. Also, land acquisition for the heritage corridor project around the Jagannath Temple in Puri was completed in a record four months.

“Some of the recent policy decisions like land bank scheme and pro-activeness at the top level of administration are some of the reason as to why land acquisition is on fast-track. Besides expediting the acquisition process, the state government should also ensure expeditious registration of land in favour of the industrial house. The registration process is quite slow in Odisha,” opined Ramesh Mohapatra, president of Utkal Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

Posco and ArcelorMittal had earlier pulled out of their Odisha projects attributing inordinate delay in land acquisition. To overcome such hurdles, Idco has come up with the land bank scheme to create a ready-to-use land of around 1.3 lakh acres for industrial purpose. Of this, around 70,000 acres have already been brought under Idco’s possession. Land acquired for South Korean steel giant Posco was brought under the land bank after the company pulled out of the project.

“As the acquired land was kept under the land bank, the state government managed to allocate around 2,900 acres to JSW Steel for an integrated steel project. The land transfer process is at an advanced stage. The public hearing process has passed off peacefully for the JSW project,” said a senior industries department official.

“The idea behind land bank is to provide ready-to-use land to investors. Because of land bank, investors, especially small and medium industries, are getting land without much hassle. They can acquire land by completing the formalities and paying the premium,” industries minister Dibya Shankar Mishra said.

Land bank scheme apart, the state government has been creating sector-specific clusters like Infovalley near Bhubaneswar, food processing park in Khurda, Deras sea food park in Khurda, petroleum chemicals and petrochemicals investment region (PCPIR) in Paradip, national investment manufacturing zone (NIMZ) in Kalingnagar and an aluminium park in Angul to facilitate downstream industries.

Title: SSKM steps in after row over transgender patient
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolkata: A 27-year-old transgender, who is undergoing treatment at the state-run SSKM Hospital, had to be shifted to a cabin from the general ward for woman after patients raised objections. The humiliation faced by Sankari Mondal (name changed to protect her identity) has raised concern among activists, who felt it’s time hospitals had a separate ward for transgender patients.

Born an intersex variation (genitals of both sex), the primary schoolteacher from Maheshtala was admitted to the hospital on Thursday for a sex reassignment surgery, which would transform her to a woman. Since Mondal, a graduate, is referred as a ‘female’ in all her official documents, she was initially admitted to the endocrinology department’s female ward, where she would undergo a series of hormonal test before the surgery.

“On Friday morning, I found some cash missing from my wallet. When I brought the matter to the notice of nursing staff and the ayahs in the ward, they, along with other patients, started misbehaving with me,” narrated the patient. Some patients later complained to the hospital authority saying they were feeling unsafe with a ‘male’ staying in their ward. Hospital officials then reportedly told her to take a discharge and come back when a cabin is arranged for her.

“I felt let down by the system. But I put my foot down and got in touch with Ranjita Sinha, who is a member of the West Bengal Transgender Board,” Sankari told TOI.

Sinha then approached cops from the Bhowanipore police station and urged them to take necessary action so that the patient was not denied her right to medical care.

“Each time someone from the transgender community needs hospitalisation, this issue crops up. I wish the women and child department under which the transgender board functions raise awareness in hospitals. Government hospitals in many states already have a separate ward for people from the community. Why can’t we have the same here?” asked Sinha.

Officials at the hospital said they had to walk a tight rope, keeping in mind the ‘inconvenience’ other patients were facing. Finally, Mondal was shifted to a cabin in the cardiology department after MSVP Raghunath Misra’s intervention.

Title: ‘Gather data on foreign tourists, their duration of stay in Goa’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant (ANI Photo)

PANAJI: The 15th Finance Commission has asked Goa to collate data on foreign tourist arrivals, including the time spent by them in the state, chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Friday.

The suggestion was made after the state government asked it for funds to improve Goa’s tourism infrastructure.

“The commission chairman has asked us to collate data on how many foreign tourists come to Goa and to see how many days they spend in Goa,” Sawant said.

“Once we prepare the data, it will be useful when we ask for funds for tourism infrastructure.”

While trying to convince the commission of the need for funds for the state’s tourism sector, Goa government officials pointed out that foreign tourists contribute to the country’s foreign exchange earnings.

“I have already asked the tourism secretary to prepare the data for the same. In comparison with other parts of the country, (foreigners) definitely spend more time in Goa. We have not used our natural resources for tourism. There is scope for hinterland tourism,” the chief minister said.

Title: Goa: AIIMS doctors revisit Felix Dahl case, report in 2 months
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: A team of doctors from All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) visited the crime scene where Finnish national Felix Dahl , 22, was found dead in Canacona on January 28, 2015 before giving its second opinion on postmortem report to the central bureau of investigation (CBI).

The probe agency had sought the second opinion from the Department of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, AIIMS on the postmortem.

The 3-member team came to Goa on Tuesday and visited the spot on Wednesday.

CBI had provided relevant documents, including photos, of the case to the AIIMS doctors . “Doctors have assured to give their second opinion within two months,” sources said.

The first postmortem was conducted at Hospicio hospital at Margao . Last year, the Central Forensic Science Laboratory (CFSL), Delhi had reconstructed the crime scene. CFSL will soon submit its report to the CBI, stating whether Dahl’s death was a homicide, a murder or an accident. “We are waiting for the report,” sources said.

The CBI investigation had revealed that Dahl was assaulted and it resulted into his death. To reconfirm their investigation, CBI had asked CFSL to reconstruct the crime scene.

In July 2018, the high court had transferred the case to the CBI in the ‘interest of justice’, while castigating Goa police for its failure to examine the case in a fair and impartial manner.

The deceased’s mother Minna Pirhonen had filed a petition seeking transfer of the case to central probe agency doubting the findings of the Canacona police

Title: Schools can’t teach single religion: Kerala high court
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

KOCHI: No school that requires recognition from the state government under Right to Education (RTE) Act has the right to impart religious instruction of one religion alone, the high court has held. The court also said the government’s approval is required even for teaching religious pluralism.

Justice A Muhamed Mustaque gave the ruling on a plea by Hidaya Educational and Charitable Trust of Thiruvananthapuram challenging government’s decision to close down the school as it promotes exclusive religious instruction.

In the judgment, the court said, “Exclusivism or preference of one religion over others by State or public functionaries or private bodies, while discharging public functions, strikes at the very root of the fundamental values of our Constitution , namely, secularism. It negates neutrality, promotes discrimination and denies equal treatment. Private schools which are required to have recognition from State must not promote one religion over others. The exclusive promotion of a particular religion by private educational institutions defies the secular character of the Constitution...”

Differentiating between the right of a person or a group and that of a group discharging public function, the judgment said, “An individual or a group or a denomination have the freedom to express and to promote and practice their religion. That freedom is not available to a private body while discharging a public function. In a pluralist society like India, which accepts secularism as the basic norm in governing secular activities including education, there cannot be any difficulty in imparting religious instruction or study based on religious pluralism. What is prohibited is exclusivism.”

Rights of minorities under the Constitution do not allow them to dilute the secular nature of education, the court said. Pointing out that RTE Act mandates that the curriculum and evaluation procedure should be as laid down by the state government, the court said, “In such circumstances, no school which is required to have recognition shall impart any religious instruction or religious study without permission from the State Government.”

Title: Over 15 schools of Rishikesh operating in dilapidated buildings
Content: Haridwar: After the recent death of a 16-year-old boy who was crushed after the dilapidated wall of a government school building fell on him and two others earlier this week in Rishikesh, a spot survey of government school buildings in the town has revealed that around 15 primary and junior high schools in Rishikesh area are operating in old buildings, which are in bad shape.
