Even though CM Trivendra Rawat instructed the education department officials to ensure that such incidents are not repeated, the state of many school buildings puts a serious question mark on the safety of students studying in these buildings.Speaking to TOI, a local resident, Mahaveer Singh Negi, said, “The government is not interested in strengthening the basic education system. Many schools are being run in buildings which can collapse anytime. Due to the apathy of the administration, a boy has already been killed. Is anybody going to take responsibility for his death?” Despite the tragedy, the education department has drawn no plans to shift or rebuild the buildings of the school where the incident happened. When queried, district education officer (basic) Rajendra Singh Rawat told TOI, “ We are conducting technical assessment of all the schools after which renovation works would be done as soon as possible.”

Title: Bomb scare-accused taken to airport for spot inspection
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visiting crime scene: Accused Aditya Rao at the Mangalore International Airport, as a part of the investigatio... Read More

Mangaluru: Aditya Rao ,36, will be in 10-day police custody for triggering a bomb scare at Mangalore International Airport (MIA). He was taken to the airport and various other places for spot mahajar on Friday.

On Friday, under heavy police cover, he was taken to a salon in Kenjar, where he had placed his bag first, before dropping the backpack with an IED in it at MIA. “The accused was cooperative throughout the spot mahajar,” a source added.

Aditya procured materials required for making the IED from an online portal based in Chennai. “If time permits, Aditya will be taken to Chennai for the investigation,” the source added.

Aditya Rao, an engineering and management graduate, was the mastermind behind the bomb threat incident at MIA, and was arrested at Bengaluru and later brought to Mangaluru. He has earlier served a jail term for making hoax threat calls to Kempegowda International Airport, Bengaluru.

Title: Students in China hope to return home soon
Content:
A medical staff moves bio-waste containers past the entrance of the medical treatment center in Wuhan, China, ... Read More

KOCHI: Students trapped at the college of medicine, Wuhan University , said they were in touch with officials from the Indian embassy. “We spoke to officials over the phone and gave them our details. As Wuhan has been closed due to the spread of coronavirus , it is not possible for them to meet us. We hope to return home,” said Faisal Nazar , a final-year student.Students are trying to reach out to a larger Indian population stranded in the closed city. However, Nazar said they were unable to figure out the exact people trapped in Wuhan. “Some people responded positively to our efforts. Around 40 Indians in Wuhan have expressed interest in returning home. Others with business interests are keen to stay back in China,” he added.Meanwhile, Aswanth Krishnan and roommates, who left for Changsha airport from Wuhan University reached the airport. Krishnan and team have tickets and they will fly to India soon.Another final year medical student, Manasa Manoj of China Three Gorges University in Yichang said she reached Kunming airport, which is located 1,300km away from the university. “Seventeen of us are travelling to Kolkata. We took a taxi to the airport. Air tickets are available and we will be flying out at 9.10pm (IST) to Kolkata,” she said, adding their temperatures were checked at the airport.She said that transport services in areas near their university were shut. “Our friends at the university are trying to move out before Chinese authorities close airports,” she said.At the same time, responding to a tweet from a Bengaluru-based parent, secretary to external affairs ministry Sanjay Bhattacharyya wrote, “We share your concern. Have spoken to @EOIBeijing. They are monitoring the situation closely. Senior consular official Aravind Kumar will provide local update.” The embassy of India in Beijing said they were receiving queries from Indians in Hubei province as well as their relatives in India in connection with the evolving situation of coronavirus infection in China.

Title: Jeweller dupes customers, flees with Rs21.86 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: A jeweller duped 12 customers to the tune of Rs Rs21.86 lakh by luring them into investing in a gold scheme between December 2015 and October 2019.

The accused, identified as Pradip Dhomne, has been booked for fraud by the Old Kamptee police. A search operation has also been launched to nab Dhomne who allegedly fled the city four months ago.

According to the police, Dhomne operated from his jewellery shop in Old Kamptee. He took money from customers in instalments and in return, promised them jewellery, cheaper than the market rate.

The accused allegedly collected Rs21.86 lakh, including Rs3.5 lakh from one Jubair Kalam, to make gold ornaments. He did not fulfil his commitments and fled the city with the money.

When the fraud came to light, Jubair went to the Old Kamptee police station and filed a complaint. It is learnt that cops had gone to Dhomne’s residence, but he wasn’t there.

Title: Compensation, no charges likely for Smart City PAPs
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: Hundreds of project-affected-persons (PAPs) of Smart City Project are likely to get compensation for the entire or part of the land proposed to be acquired for the project. Also, they are likely to get exemption from paying high Town Planning Scheme (TPS) charges. But the move is likely to hamper the project if the compensation is not paid by the state or central government.

Supriya Thul, the state government appointed arbitrator, has recently completed hearing the PAPs of Smart City Project. After the 10-month-long process, the arbitrator has tabled findings and recommendations before the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) for finalizing TPS. This will form the basis for development of the Smart City Project in Pardi , Punapur , Bharatwada and Bhandewadi in East Nagpur.

In the draft TPS prepared in 2018, Smart City Project special purpose vehicle Nagpur Smart and Sustainable City Development Corporation Limited (NSSCDCL) had approved flats to compensate for houses to be acquired completely for roads. NSSCDCL proposed to take over 40% of total plot area of over 30% land owners. Also, NSSCDCL proposed to recover regularization charges of Rs56 per sq ft from unauthorized plots and buildings. The SPV also proposed to levy hefty TPS charges on all plot owners, including those giving 40% of total plot area. Apart from all these, NSSCDCL proposed to recover charges for giving additional floor space index (FSI) and other benefits to plot owners.

NSSCDCL’s move created havoc among PAPs, and politicians, including BJP MLA from East Nagpur Krishna Khopde, corporators and activists of Congress and Sena registered their strong opposition.

Thul’s recommendations stress the need to give compensation to land owners for acquiring 40% of their total plot area as per Land Acquisition Act 2013. Also, the arbitrator recommended not to recover TPS charges from plots with construction, since they will not get any additional benefits from the project as their plots already have constructions. The arbitrator also felt no need to recover regularization charges from plots regularized by Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) earlier. Also, the arbitrator recommended no reservation on regularized plots.

Now, NMC general body will take a decision on arbitrator’s recommendations and submit it to the state government for final approval of TPS. If the general body approves arbitrator’s recommendations as it is, the opposition to the project is likely to end.

BJP city president and corporator Pravin Datke told TOI all PAPs will get proper compensation. “Also, hefty TPS charges will not be recovered from people residing in Smart City Project area. People are in favour of the project and only need is to resolve their problems. It is a good project and will be implemented successfully. After consulting Khopde and our other leaders, necessary decisions will be taken in general body next month,” he said.

But the project will be left hanging unless and until state or central government provide the additional funds required to implement Thul’s formula. Covering an area of 1,730 acre, estimated cost of the project is Rs3,303 crore. NSSCDCL will get only Rs876 crore from centre, state and NIT. NSSCDCL had expected remaining cost of Rs2,427 crore from land to be acquired from PAPs free of cost, TPS charges, regularization fees and FSI benefits.

Now, the state or centre will have to provide Rs2,427 crore as NMC cannot bear it due to its cash-strapped condition. In case of any setback from state and centre, the project will not happen at all.

Datke said NMC office bearers under their leaders Union minister Nitin Gadkari and leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis will ensure funds from the government.

FATE DEPENDS ON GOVT FUNDS

* 1,730 acre in Pardi, Bharatwada, Bhandewadi and Punapur in East Nagpur proposed to be converted into Smart City

* Cost of project is Rs3,303 crore

* Central, state and NIT will give only Rs876 crore

* SPV proposed to raise remaining Rs2,427 crore by acquiring 40% of plots free of cost, hefty TPS charges, regularization charges and FSI benefits

* PAPs, politicians raised strong objections

* Arbitrator issued notices to all PAPs, held hearings and submitted recommendations to NMC

* Arbitrator recommended compensation to PAPs, exemption from hefty TPS charges etc

* NMC general body likely to approve recommendations

* State and centre will have to provide Rs2,427 crore to take the project forward

Title: Soon, you can book drinking water online
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: As part of the Smart City project , the city corporation has proposed to introduce various essential services in digital platform from next month. This follows the 100-day plan announced by mayor K Sreekumar.

Addressing a news conference on Saturday, Sreekumar said that request for services such as drinking water, septage collection, etc, can be raised online via Smart Trivandrum portal smarttvm.corporationoftrivandrum.in from next month.

Tankers with corporation licence will be permitted to distribute drinking water from KWA vending points in the city. A total of 94 water tankers are registered under the corporation and will be available round the clock. The corporation in association with KWA will arrange water for agriculture and construction purposes from Muttathara STP and STP installed in various flats and large buildings and other vending points.

“It will ensure that tankers distribute only water taken from KWA’s vending points. The water samples from treatment plants, filling stations and water tankers will be checked regularly and results will be published on the Smart Trivandrum web portal. Following the direction from WHO, the drinking water tankers will be cleaned and super chlorination will be conducted every three months. The movement of tankers will be monitored using GPS,” said the mayor.

Drinking water tankers will sport blue colour while tankers supplying water for agriculture, business and construction purposes will have brown colour.

Poultry waste will be directly collected by authorised agencies from shops and disposed of at poultry waste rendering plants. As many as 19 service providers are arranged for biowaste collection and four service providers for non-biodegradable waste collection from institutions in the city.

A complaint redressal cell will function at the corporation office from 9am to 6pm. The complaints can be sent to complaints.tmc@gmail.com or as WhatsApp message to 7034232323. Also, a help-desk managed by retired staff of corporation will be set up. . Minister A C Moideen will inaugurate the water tanker registration, poultry waste collection, Subhojanam and other projects on January 28.

Title: Last rites performed on student died in Manali
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolhapur: The last rites were performed of the 20-year-old student Samarth Raj Shekhar , who died on Tuesday after falling ill due to high-altitude sickness in Manali.

Family members, relatives, and friends had gathered in numbers to bid him adieu at his native place in Wagdari village, around 60 km away from Solapur on Friday evening.

Eldest among three siblings, the youngster was pursuing B.Sc Agriculture at Jalgaon-based college and was on a field trip to the North-Indian hill-station. He was feeling unwell of when the group led by three teachers reached their hotel in Manali on January 21 at about 6:30 pm.

According to the residents of Wagdari village, he was very close to his grandfather and was pursuing an Agriculture course to look after the farm after completing his degree.

Malkappa Conaji, another resident of the village said that the body of the deceased were received on Friday evening due to heavy snowfall in Manali. “It was a very emotional moment for all of us. The family member including the father of the boy is very polite to everyone,” he said.

Title: Speeding car falls into gorge after hitting four students
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

UTTARKASHI: A speeding car fell into a 200-metre-deep gorge after hitting four school-going children in Chinyalisaur region of Uttarkashi district on Friday.

The four students and the driver sustained injuries in the accident .

Three critically injured persons, including the car driver, were later referred to a medical facility in Dehradun after being administered primary treatment at the local community health centre. The condition of the other two injured is said to be stable and they are out of danger, according to doctors.

Sources said that the driver of the car, identified as 19-year-old Mohit, was heading to Chinyalisaur on Friday morning but he lost control of the vehicle and the car fell into the gorge after hitting the children going to school.

Soon after the accident, locals rushed to help the injured and took them to the nearest community health centre.

Devendra Patwal, district disaster management officer, told TOI, “No FIR has yet been lodged in the matter. However, we have begun to ascertain the exact cause of the accident.”

Title: Shivbhojan Thali at Rs 10 per plate at 4 centres in city from tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolhapur: Four centres in the city will provide Shivbhojan Thali at Rs 10 per plate from January 26. The centres will be inaugurated by district guardian minister Satej Patil.

The state government has reserved quota of 600 thalis for Kolhapur to be served at Rs 10. The centres that will provide thalis are Hotel Shivaj in front of the district collector’s office, Mahalaxmi Annachhatra Trust at the Kapiltirth Market, Rudraksha Mahila Bachat Gat near Savitribai Phule Hospital and Hotel Sairaj at the Skyes Extension area in Rajarampuri.

The district administration had received 30 proposals for providing Shivbhojan Thali, of which four have been finalised. The centre operator has been asked to ensure that they provide ample sitting area to accommodate 150 people and at the same time ensure quality food.

A team from the food and drugs administration (FDA) will conduct random inspections at these four centres to assess the quality of raw materials, dishes prepared, sanitation and other cleanliness measures.

District collector Daulat Desai said, “All the arrangements are in place. The food will be served between 12pm to 2 pm. We have provided aequate training to the staff at these centres.”

“A mobile application will record the visitors and the number of thalis served. The app is connected to the main server and provides real-time data to the state government, ” he said.

Officials claimed that the visitors are not required to produce any document to get food at subsidised rate. The operators have to ensure that adequate seats should be reserved for visitors. The sites have been finalised considering the number of transit places nearby. The officials expect that people, especially economically weaker sections, will benefit from the food service at subsidised rate.

“The state government will pay Rs 40 per thali to the centre operator. The operators should not compromise on the quality and quantity of food,” said Desai.

Title: Gold worth Rs 18L seized at airport
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Customs officers seized gold worth Rs 18 lakh from a passenger at Trivandrum International Airport on Thursday night. The passenger was identified as Rijas, a native of Kozhikode.

The passenger had arrived in Air India Express flight IX 374 around 10.30pm. The flight from Doha has a stopover at Kozhikode airport. He was intercepted by officers of AIU unit at the airport based on suspicion. On inspection, two packets of gold were recovered from the bag carried by the passenger. The gold in form of four biscuits was covered in cellophane tape. The value of the gold is 18.9 lakh.

“The passenger said he was unaware about the gold and someone might have kept it in his bag when he went to the washroom during flight. He claimed to have reached Thiruvananthapuram in search of job. As he had travelled in the domestic leg, we suspect someone might have handed over the gold when the flight reached Kozhikode. A case has been registered and investigation has been launched,” said AIU officer.

The seizure was conducted by assistant commissioner Anil and superintendents Rajeeb, Ramalekshi, Sasi Kumar and inspectors Gulshan, Aman and Gopiprashanth. tnn

Title: Provide inputs to DGP, Satej Patil tells Raj Thackeray
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolhapur: Minister of state for home Satej Patil on Friday said if Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) chief Raj Thackeray has inputs regarding conspiracy being hatched against the country then he should provide those inputs to director general of police for speedy action.

Raj is going to hold a rally at Mumbai in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) on February 9. While speaking to party cadres in Mumbai on Thursday, Raj alleged that he has some information that in some of the mohallas (Muslim-dominated localities) conspiracy is being hatched against India.

“I am not going to provide the entire inputs I am having. I just say that in some mohallas serious conspiracy is going on. I will meet home minister Amit Shah and chief minister to take action against them,” Raj had said.

Responding to the allegation made by the MNS chief, Patil said, “We receive such inputs several times. If Raj is having some inputs he should share it with the director general of police so that precautionary measures can be taken and swift action is initiated. As per his conspiracy allegations, I think it was part of his political speech. He has changed his views after Lok Sabha and state elections. I won’t talk on this but, if there is any input let him share it with police.”

Raj in his speech had said that there are many areas in the state capital where police cannot enter. He also added that a large number of Muslim infiltrators have entered the big cities and they need to be thrown out of the country.

Title: Cold winds improve Delhi’s air quality to ‘moderate’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

At 151, the AQI on Friday was in the moderate category. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Cold winds swept through the city on Friday with the minimum temperature settling at 8.2 degrees Celsius — one notch above the normal — while the maximum touched 21.1 degrees, normal for this time of the season. The wind, however, improved the air quality in the city. At 151, the AQI on Friday was in the moderate category, a major improvement from Thursday’s 211 in the ‘poor’ zone.

Track the pollution level in your city

“Wind speed as fast as 20-22km/hour was witnessed during the day along with spells of gusty wind up to 35-36km/hour. There was mist in the morning and visibility was up to1,300m,” a MeT official said.

Saturday is likely to see mainly clear sky with moderate fog in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 20 and 6 degrees Celsius, respectively, while the wind speed will decrease significantly to below 10km/hour, the official added. On Sunday, moderate fog is expected in the early hours, while a few pockets may also see dense fog from 5.30 to 9.30am, he said.

CPCB’s central control room data showed Delhi NCR’s average PM2.5 level to be 65.7 micrograms per cubic metre at 7pm on Friday. The average PM10 level at the same time was marginally above the safe standards at 136.6 micrograms. The ‘emergency’ benchmark for these pollutants under GRAP is, respectively, 300 and 500 micrograms per cubic metre while the safe standards are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre.

According to a SAFAR report, high surface winds are likely to continue for the next 24 hours, following which it will dip to moderate levels. “The high ventilation helped flush out the pollutants and improve the AQI. However, marginal deterioration in AQI is likely by Saturday night, but it will remain in the ‘moderate’ category. The AQI is likely to deteriorate to ‘poor’ category by Sunday,” it added.

An AQI between 0-50 is considered ‘good’, 51-100 ‘satisfactory’, 101-200 ‘moderate’, between 201 and 300 is classified as ‘poor’, between 301 and 400 is classified as ‘very poor’ and between 401 and 500 is ‘severe’ on CPCB’s index.

Title: 200 people including women, AMU & Jamia students, booked in Aligarh
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

According to police, 204 people were booked as they had violated prohibitory orders imposed in the city.

AGRA: Aligarh police on Friday booked around 200 unidentified people, including women and students from AMU and Jamia Millia , along with four identified persons for violating prohibitory orders while protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the city a day earlier.

An AMU students’ leader was also booked for allegedly provoking the crowd while delivering a speech against CAA on the campus on Wednesday.

According to police, 204 people were booked as they had violated prohibitory orders imposed in the city. They had been given permission for holding protests for two days at Shahjamal area on Tuesday and Wednesday but many girls and boys, claiming to be students of AMU and Jamia, gathered there for protest against CAA on Thursday also, said police.

When the protesters were stopped from shouting slogans, many women and men gathered there and sat on the road, said police.

Circle officer Anil Samaniya said that all protesters were booked under sections 283 (danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 147 (riot), and 145 (joins or continues in an unlawful assembly) of IPC at Delhi Gate police station. Those who were named in the FIR include Anees Noniwala, Moin Qureshi, Shamshad Bhogli and Muddasir Qureshi, he said.

AMU students’ leader Faizul Hassan, who is former president AMUSU, was also booked by the police under section 153 A (provocation with intent to cause riot) of IPC at Civil Lines police station, confirmed Samaniya.

Title: Kerala: Gang kills man using earthmover
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Members of an alleged land mafia used an earthmover to kill Kattakkada resident Sangeeth (37) after an altercation early on Friday morning. Kattakkada police took Vijin (29) from Kulathummel into custody in connection with the case.

Police said that a probe had begun to track down the remaining four members of the gang that attempted to mine and smuggle the red earth from Sangeeth’s home at Kanchiravila early on Friday. Sangeeth, a non-resident Indian who recently settled in Kattakkada, had started a poultry farm near his home.

Neighbours, who rushed to the spot, on hearing the altercation saw Sangeeth lying on the ground, struggling to breathe. Though they rushed him to a nearby hospital, he died. His relatives alleged that Kattakkada police did not arrive on time though Sangeeth had informed them about the unauthorized entry by the gang on his property.

Kattakada station house officer inspector Bijukumar D said the accused had previously worked as contract workers of forest department and Sangeeth had made an agreement that allowed mining of red earth from his property.

“The contract expired long ago but as the accused men knew the source of red earth, they arrived with a JCB late on Thursday night and attempted to mine earth. Sangeeth was not at home when they came. Soon, his wife informed him about the unauthorized entry by the gang. He reached there and confronted the gang. As Sangeeth tried to block the earthmover, he was hit by the front part of the vehicle. He sustained injuries on his head and chest that proved fatal,” said Bijukumar.

Police took Vijin into custody as they suspect that he was the one who operated the earthmover.

Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran told reporters that the government will take up the case seriously.

“It is very unfortunate that a landowner who questioned unauthorized entry on his land was murdered in such a brutal way. Stringent action will be taken against the mafia groups who engage in such heinous activities. It is high time that such groups were brought under control,” he said.

Kattakkada MLA I B Sathish also sought an inquiry to know if the police were vigilant and tried to reach the spot quickly.

Sangeeth’s body, kept at the medical college hospital mortuary after autopsy, will be handed over to relatives on Saturday.

The cremation is scheduled on Saturday as Sangeeth’s mother and sister who are settled in the Gulf are on their way home. Sangeeth leaves behind his wife Sangeetha, son Sreehari and daughter Sangeerthana.

Title: UP: Youth flees after raping minor, booked
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

Title: Bull dies after falling into 60-ft well in Tirupattur dist
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Vellore: A bull of a farmer that took part in a bull race held at Kothakottai near Vaniyambadi in Tirupattur district died after falling into a 60-ft-deep farm well on Wednesday.

On the occasion of the recent pongal festival, bull race in which native breeds took part was conducted in various parts of the integrated Vellore district, including Vellore, Tirupattur and Ranipet districts.

On Wednesday, a bull race was organised at fives places, including in Nimmiyampattu, Kothakottai and Kothur in Tirupattur district, Melmaayil near Gudiyattam and Ariyoor in Vellore district.

A senior police officer said that at the bull race held at Kothakottai, as many as 178 bulls took part.

R Raman, 25, of Chinnapallikuppam in Ambur brought his bull to the race. The animal which was let loose in the arena, on seeing the crowd became terrified and could not be stopped at the finish line by the owner.

The panicked bull entered a farm land located about 500 metres away from the finish line and accidentally fell into the well belonging to Chinnasamy, a farmer of Kothakottai. The incident happened around 11am.

On information, a team of fire tenders from the Vaniyambadi fire station reached the spot and began the rescue operation, along with police personnel.

The rescue team tied a rope around the body of the bull and lifted it out of the well.

Police sources said the bull had sustained severe injuries in the fall and died. Vaniyambadi deputy superintendent of police (DSP) Balakrishnan and Vaniyambadi taluk inspector Mangayarkarasi reached the spot and held an inquiry.

Following the incident, bull owners and bull race enthusiasts urged the district administration and event organizers to ensure the safety of the animals to avert further tragedies.

Vijayaraj, 48, a bull race enthusiast, said that bull race was being conducted in villages near Vellore and Tirupattur districts for more than a century.

“When there was a ban on holding bull race by the state government, we were among those who participated in a protest against it. Though we are happy that the government has been providing permission to conduct the bull race without creating much hassles to the organizers, they should form a team to ensure the safety of the bulls participating in the race and to spectators,” he said.

Title: MSEDCL cuts power of five industrial units
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolhapur: The Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited ( MSEDCL ) has terminated power supply to five industrial units in Ichalkaranji and surrounding areas following the directives of the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB).

MPCB officials said that the decision was taken after these units failed to comply with the MPCB’s industrial sewage treatment norms, resulting in pollution of the Panchganga river.

Sachin Akiwate, deputy executive engineer, Ichalkaranji rural unit of the MSEDCL, told TOI that these type of actions are regularly taken every year.

“When these industrial units discharge untreated water into the river, it causes pollution affecting water bodies and fishes in it. There have been several instances when one could see dead fishes floating on water or a pile near the river bank. These units are issued frequent notices and, despite that, when they fail to comply, terminating their power supply is the only option,” he said.

He added that such industrial units, especially textiles, have to take clearance from the MPCB with all the required compliance. Once the MPCB gives nod, power supply can be restored.

Akiwate said that such actions have been initiated in the past as well.

According to district administration officials, collector Daulat Desai had visited river bank villages in the Hatkanagale and Shirol taluka last week and had instructed MPCB officials to initiate action against errant industrial units. MPCB officials conducted a survey of a few industrial unitsin the said areas and observed that some units failed to comply with the sewage treatment compliance.

Ichalkaranji has been a major textile hub in the country and sends ready cloth to Ahmedabad, Mumbai, Madhya Pradesh, Delhi, West Bengal, and Karnataka.

The industries here engage in looms, yarning, sizing as well as processing. Since the first textile unit was set up in Ichalkaranji in 1904, the town has thrived on the booming cotton trade that caters to the needs of major national and international brands.

Title: 30k enumerators, 6k supervisors to help in first phase of census 2021
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Dehradun: Registrar General and Census Commissioner Vivek Joshi held a video conferencing session with state officials to discuss the preparations for population counting process. Chief secretary Uptal Kumar Singh along with senior state and census attended the meeting.

Director census Vimmi Sachdeva said that for the work of the first phase of the census 2021 which comprises listing of houses and enumeration of houses and updating of the National Population Registrar, the time has been set from May 01, 2020, to June 15, 2020. For the purpose a total staff of 30,000 enumerators and 6,000 supervisors would be deployed.

She added that a portal would be developed for the management work, training and honorarium. To promote the concept of digital India, the census count would be stored in mobile app besides the paper document.

Singh directed education director to ensure timely deployment of personnel required for this task. The schedule of training of personnel posted in the census has been fixed in the month of April.

Title: Kukke temple will adopt two shrines
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Mangaluru: Muzrai minister Kota Srinivas Poojari said two temples in Dakshina Kannada district will be adopted for five years by Kukke Sri Subrahmanya Temple, which is the highest revenue earning temple in the state.

Ammaje Sri Durgaparameshwari Temple in Shiradi village of Puttur taluk and Bailangadi Sri Somanatheshwara Temple in Kotatthadi village of Belthangady taluk, which belong to C Grade under endowment department, will be adopted and developed by Kukke Temple.

As per the Karnataka Hindu Religious Institutions and Charitable Endowments (Amendment) Act, those two temples will be developed for five years.

Accordingly, Kukke temple may spend a maximum of Rs 50 lakh each for the development of the two temples, the minister said.

On the criteria of the selection of the temples’, the minister said based on requests from C Grade temples, the district administration has finalised the list, and the same was sent to the government.

Poojari said the department has plans to introduce e-administration for all the 34,562 temples under the department. The main objective of introducing e-administration is to protect the moveable and immovable assets of muzrai temples, store valuable documents and manage day-to-day affairs, transparently, using e-office, web and applications or software, he said.

To rejuvenate temple ponds and lakes, the department will soon launch a new scheme titled ‘Jalabhisheka’. Under the scheme, temples can take up works related to development or rejuvenation of its ponds and lakes, through its funds, or through public participation. Works can also be taken up through the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme.

A circular in this regard will be issued soon, he said.

Rajyotsava Award

ceremony on January 26

Poojari said the government will distribute Rajyotsava Awards to achievers on the occasion of Republic Day on January 26.

The Dakshina Kannada district administration had cancelled the distribution of District Kannada Rajyotsava Awards in the wake of the model code of conduct being in force in Mangaluru city, since the election for the Mangaluru City Corporation council, held on November 12.

Title: Gujarat: Man assaults sister for refusing to get divorce
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 35-year-old woman from Juhapura on Thursday filed a complaint at Vejalpur police station alleging that her elder brother assaulted her because she refused to divorce her husband and marry his friend.

Rehanabanu Syed, a resident of Shabnam Society, in her FIR stated that she married in 2002 and has two children, 17 and 12. On May 22, 2019, she had a fight with her husband and moved to her parents’ house. Her brother, the accused, Mohammed Yunus Shaikh, 40, rented a house for her in Palanpur and told her to move there.

Shaikh had also introduced her to his friend, Ejazkhan Mirza, 30, a resident of Dariapur.

On January 1, 2020, Syed’s husband called her up and told her that he would not fight with her and asked her to live with him. She her brother this and he got angry. He warned her not to tell Mirza that her husband wants to live with her.

Shaikh also told her that she should marry Mirza and divorce her husband. As she refused to do so, Shaikh and Mirza came to meet her got into a heated argument with her.

As she rejected the idea of divorcing her husband and marrying Mirza, they began assaulting and verbally abusing her. Shaikh threatened to kill her if she did not marry Mirza.

Syed filed a complaint for causing hurt, using abusive language, criminal intimidation and abetment.

Title: On 27 routes, Aapli Bus earns under Rs1k per day
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: The Aapli Bus has everything an urban commuter might need from regular interval service and five exclusive electric buses for women only and affordable fares. Yet, it does not have enough takers on 27 routes, revealed a survey carried out by Aapli Bus programme manager Delhi Integrated Multi-Modal Transit System (DIMTS).

“These routes generate less than Rs1,000 per day,” DIMTS report submitted to transport committee chairman Narendra Borkar stated.

Following Borkar’s directives, DIMTS recently carried out a study of crew duty-wise earning on 115 routes. During analysis of duty-wise earning on these routes, it came to fore that 27 routes earn less than Rs1,000 per day, whereas the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) spends a minimum of Rs10,000 per day per bus, Borkar told TOI.

“Even during morning and evening peak hours, it is common to find more than half the seats empty on all these routes. After the evening rush hour, the number of passengers drops to 10. At night, it is merely 5-7 commuters,” said Borkar.

The bus service between Medical Square and Lalganj-Raut Nagar generates lowest revenue of Rs60 per day. The highest revenue on this route was Rs271. The service from Sitabuldi to Ayachit Mandir via Railway Station also evoked poor response. The revenue generated on this route hovers around Rs310.

The lowest revenue-generating routes include Sitabuldi to Defence Gate number 1 and 3, Sitabuldi to CRPF, Maharajbagh to Shanti Nagar and Panchsheel Nagar to Bhagwan Nagar.

But the major reason for commuters not using the service is that most prefer using private vehicles. “The culture of using public transport is yet to develop in the city,” admitted Borkar.

Of these 27 routes, 11 are mostly used by school or college going students. “So we could not stop the service on those routes,” he said. “I have directed DIMTS to shut Aapli Bus service on other routes with poor commuter response,” he said.

At present around 1.50 lakh passengers commute in 370 Aapli Buses plying on 115 different routes. The monthly expenditure of the NMC to provide city bus services to citizens is around Rs13 crore, while it earns only Rs5 crore from it.

Official sources said the revenue loss has gone up by Rs6.5 crore per month to Rs7 crore and had incurred a loss of Rs84 crore per annum. “The NMC is incurring losses in running Aapli Bus service, but that does not mean we will stop the services,” Borkar said and added that NMC’s transport department need to be serious to curb losses and increase revenue of the Aapli Buses.

Poor run

370 | Aapli Buses

115 | Routes

27 | Routes earn less than Rs1,000 a day

Rs5 cr | Revenue generated through bus tickets per month

Rs13cr | Expenditure per month

Title: Cane official’s sting unearths cane weighing fraud via remote control
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Bijnor: A sting operation conducted by officials of the state sugarcane department disguised in farmer’s clothes, has unearthed a cane weighing scam operated via remote control at the collection centre of Barkatpur sugar mill. Farmers, already bitter over delayed payment, are livid they are being cheated during the weighing.

With crushing season at full swing, thousands of tonnes of harvested crop get weighed at various authorised collection centres and move to the mills. The sting was conducted at the Narayanpur centre, where the weighing clerk used a remote control to under-calculate farmer’s produce on the weighing scale.

According to district cane officer Yashpal Singh, “The clerk would switch on the remote and the machine would underreport the weight to the tune of 100-150 kg, which means every weighing exercise would lead to a loss of Rs 325-500 for a farmer.” There have been recurring disputes at collection centres, where farmers have claimed under-weighing of their produce.

Singh continued, “Some farmers had complained about the doctored weighing machines at sugarcane purchasing centers. We conducted the sting to check the veracity of the complaints filed by the farmers.

Our team reached the Narayanpur centre on Friday morning. They parked their car around 100m away from the centre. One team member, Vikal Bharti, wearing the kurta pyjama and flip-flops that farmers usually wear, stood close to the weighing machine, acting as if he was a curious passerby. He noticed that the clerk posted at the centre would put his hand in his pocket again and again while weighing a loaded tractor trolley. Suspecting his actions, Bharti held him and asked him to reveal what he had in his pocket, but he refused. We sensed there was something amiss and rushed to unearth the secret by force, and recovered a remote control unit from his pocket. We have seized the remote and the indicator into which he had tapped clandestinely.”

Singh continued, “The clerk, Mahendra Singh, used to switch the remote on and off while weighing sugarcane, to under-report the weight of the produce. The device was activated by the remote, cheating the farmers. This centre is owned by Barkatpur sugar mill. Farmers claim the clerk was earlier cheating them at the rate of 50kg per cart. Once he got the remote system, he began underreporting by 100-150kg per cart.”

“The clerk’s license will be suspended and strict action will be taken against him. We have also asked the mill authorities for an explanation. Perhaps, this is the first case of cheating via remote control in the state,” Singh claimed.

According to sources, there are over 800 purchasing centers in Bijnor district linked to nine sugar mills. All centres have electronic weighing machines.

Digambar Singh, state president of BKU’s youth wing, said, “We had filed several complaints against mills and demanded a fair probe. If cane department conducts such stings, more such malpractices will surface.”

Title: Cops retrieve knife from Thampanoor bus stand
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The team of Tamil Nadu police Q Branch CID , investigating the murder of TN special sub-inspector Y Wilson who was shot dead near Kaliyikkavila checkpost on January 8, recovered a knife reportedly used by the assailants to attack Wilson from Thampanoor central bus station.

The weapon was recovered during an evidence collection on Friday made in the presence of Abdul Shameem of Nagercoil and Taufeeq of Thuckalay, the two prime accused. The police team had earlier recovered a gun reportedly used for killing Wilson from a drain in Kochi on Thursday. Before shooting at the-sub inspector the duo had injured Wilson with the knife, police said.

The police team also recovered a bag which the two had left at Neyyattinkara. The bag was recovered from the house of Jaffer at Pathamkallu near Nedumangadu. Police claimed they had recovered some leaflets from the bag which showed their alleged links with the IS. The bag which was dropped at Neyyattinkara was taken away by Jaffer, police said.

The investigation team led by T O Ganesh, DSP, Q Branch CID and Colachel ASP Vishwesh took the accused to areas where they had travelled in the district. There were taken to Karamana, Balaramapuram and Neyyattinkara where they had come before leaving for Kaliyikkavila.tnn

Title: Rain, AP water have Red Hills brimming
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Chennai: The city’s water managers are relieved. The level of water at the reservoir at Red Hills is 88% of its capacity, while the level at three other lakes is half the capacity. Metrowater executive director T Prabhu Shankar said the 6,064 million cubic feet (mcft) of water in the four reservoirs is enough to supply the city’s residents for the next six months without difficulty.

On Thursday, the Poondi reservoir had 1,497 mcft of water against the capacity of 3,231 mcft, Red Hills had 2,890 mcft against the capacity of 3,300 mcft, Chembarambakkam 1,605mcft against the capacity of 3,645 mcft, while Cholavaram, the smallest reservoir, had just 72 mcft against the capacity of 1,081 mcft. The current situation, Prabhu Shankar said, was a great improvement on the situation during the same period last year when the combined storage in the four reservoirs was just 1,112 mcft, mainly due to a failure of the northeast monsoon which accounts for about 60% of the city’s annual rainfall.

Water from the Krishna river in Andhra Pradesh flows from Poondi reservoir into both Red Hills and Chembarambakkam through open canals, Prabhu Shankar said, adding that the combined storage level in the reservoirs at Srisailam, Somasila and Kandaleru in Andhra Pradesh from where water is released to Tamil Nadu under Telugu Ganga agreement, is 252 thousand million cubic feet (tmcft) of water. “They [Andhra Pradesh] are releasing water regularly. Even on Wednesday, about 400 cusecs of water was realised at zero point,” he said. The Tamil Nadu government had asked for 8 tmcft from Andhra Pradesh which has, however, released only 4.25 tmcft so far, a Metrowater official said. “With reservoirs in that state having good storage levels, we hope they will release at least another 3 tmcft,” he said.

The rain last year had helped improve the groundwater table in many areas of the city where water levels are measured from shallow observatory open wells by Metrowater, said the official.

Asked if Metrowater had any plans to increase piped water supply to residents in the core city areas, the official said there was no such plan now. The next step would be to provide water connections in added areas and the work is on in full swing.

Title: Electricity not at subsidised rates for new UPCL employees
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Dehradun: Employees being recruited in the state’s electricity firms — Uttarakhand Power Corporation Limited ( UPCL ), Power Transmission Corporation Limited (PTCUL) and Uttarakhand Jal Vidyut Nigam Limited (UJVNL) — after April 1 2020 will not get the benefits of subsidised electricity.

Besides, authorities have also decided to put a cap on subsidised electricity to employees and officers.

A proposal in this regard was given green signal in a meeting of board of directors headed by secretary Radhika Jha on Thursday.

The Uttarakhand high court had sought a reply from UPCL over the subsidised electricity given to the power department employees. Following which, the three corporations had prepared a proposal, which was approved in a three-hour meeting of board of directors.

As per the change, the Class IV employee would get 6,000 units of subsidised power supply, whereas the cap for others has been set for 9,000 units per annum. If usage is beyond the set cap, normal charges will be applicable for power department employees.

Title: AMU staffers appeal to protesting students to appear in exams
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

AGRA: Over 100 staffers of Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) have appealed to the protesting students to appear for examinations which have been rescheduled twice. The pending examinations are scheduled to start from Monday.

Initially, the examinations were scheduled after the university opened following extended winter vacations due to the December 15 violence that erupted on the campus. However, it was postponed due to continuous protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) by students who also demanded the vice-chancellor and registrar to resign from their posts as they failed to protect students on the ill-fated day.

“We the members of CWC project, CIC/GPS surveyors and non-teaching staff appeal to the students to save their future by appearing for the exams and not let vested interests damage the image of AMU,” coordinator, GIS/GPS Work of Waqf Board Properties, ‘Qaumi Waqf Board Taraqqiati Scheme’, Interdisciplinary Department of Remote Sensing and GIS Applications, Prof Shadab Khurshid said.

A signed memorandum said: “Our country is globally respected for democratic credentials, freedom to protest, commitment to pluralism and a progressive and secular constitution. We caution all our peace loving and cultured students against false propaganda and fake news and to exercise maximum restraint to maintain peace and tranquility on the campus.”

Title: Madras HC orders notice to fisheries varsity VC, registrar
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has ordered notice on a plea moved by the Fisheries University Teachers Association against the vice-chancellor (VC) and registrar of Tamil Nadu Dr J Jayalalithaa Fisheries University, Nagapattinam, for mismanagement in administration.

In her petition, the Tuticorin-based association’s general secretary R Jeyashakila stated that VC S Felix and registrar A Srinivasan were involved in total mismanagement of administration, student admissions, staff recruitment and financial misappropriation at the university. She stated that the main objective of establishing the university was the development of fisheries and research in fisheries sciences. The university has affiliated colleges at Tuticorin , Ponneri, Nagapattinam and Thalanayeru.

Jeyashakila said the VC started nine self-financial colleges offering 10 different degree courses within two and a half years, without the approval of the government which was mandatory under the Tamil Nadu Fisheries University Act. Under the Act, no new college imparting education in fisheries science can be established as a constituent or affiliated college of the university. She stated that by starting these self-financing colleges, the VC had diverted a huge sum of money from the university corpus fund and other government funds due to which the regular degree programmes are deprived of sufficient funds.

She further said that there were malpractices in the recruitment process as the VC and registrar had created new university officer posts. The VC had also issued 83 transfer orders in the two and a half years without following procedures. Since the VC would retire on April 21, it was necessary to initiate an inquiry against him and the registrar in this regard. She stated that she had also submitted representations to the authorities concerned, but no actions were taken so far.

Hence the petitioner moved HC Madurai bench seeking inquiry against the VC and registrar under the provisions of the Act. When the petition was heard on Friday, Justice M S Ramesh ordered notice to the VC and registrar of the university and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: Till when tanks will remain empty, corporators to KMC
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolhapur: The corporators questioned the spending on the high rise tanks constructed by the KMC as the water scarcity continues to hamper the citizens of Shahupuri and Market Yard area.

The tank at both places was constructed two and three years respectively but both tanks are yet to receive any water since the construction. In the total of 12 tanks are constructed as part of the project-Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation. Some corporators in the standing committee meeting held on Friday claimed many of the water tanks do not fill.

“Till when these high rise tanks will remain empty? What is the use of these tanks? Why the water supply system not upgraded to ensure these tanks are filled and water is supplied at adequate pressure to the localities?. The citizens are suffering from inadequate supply every day,” said Puja Naiknaware, corporator from Shahupuri area

Vijay Suryawanshi, Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) corporator said, “The water supply cannot be normalised with the current situation. The systemic changes need to be carried out. For the last three years, the high rise tanks are not filled to their full capacity which leads to inadequate supply to the area.”

Responding to the issue, the water supply officials in the meeting claimed that the high rise tanks cannot be filled with the old system in place. “At present the tanks cannot be filled properly. Once the water supply through the direct pipeline project starts then only these tanks will be filled to their full capacity. Meanwhile, we have undertaken several measures such as changing the timings of the supply to ensure each locality gets adequate water,” said the official in the meeting.

Senior corporator claims fraud

Senior corporator Bhupal Shete alleged that the hours for which the heavy machinery used at the dumping site has been inflated to gain the monetary benefit. He said that while the machineries are used for six hours, the staff records 12 hours in the register for which the bills of Rs 14,000 is released for a day’s work.

Civic panel chief demand sealing of a hospital

Chairman Sharangdhar Deshmukh said claimed that even after the opening of the basement parking of a hospital from Rajarampuri, the visitors are not allowed to park their vehicles in the basement. He sought the photographs of the current situation and if the staff finds that the vehicles are still parked on the road, the hospital should be sealed.

Title: AMU students to launch ‘Wake Up India’ outreach program on January 26
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

AGRA: Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) students have decided to launch a month-long public outreach programme called ' Wake Up India ' on January 26 to create awareness among people across the nation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the proposed NRC and NPR. The programme aims to target 30 lakh people across the country.

Students’ leader Salman Imtiaz , former president of AMUSU , said that students of the varsity will lead the campaign explaining people about CAA/NRC/NPR. He said that during this campaign, students will approach five lakh people in Aligarh and over 30 lakh people in India through handbills/posters/booklets/videos.

He said, “Students will be sent to different parts of the country to address people and tell them about the fallout of the law.”

He said the struggle against CAA-NRC-NPR and the demand for resignation of AMU VC and registrar will continue.

Title: Agra IG orders removal of unauthorized roadside eateries on Yamuna expressway
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: After back-to-back robberies, Agra IG range has asked for the removal of all unauthorized roadside eateries on Yamuna expressway on Friday. However, it took 13 letters from Jaypee infratech - the private concessionaire operating the Yamuna expressway - and nine cases of robbery since 2019, to compel UP police to take action against such eateries along the 165-km-long route.

Agra IG range Satish Ganesh, who ordered SSPs of Agra, Hathras , Mathura , Aligarh and Noida to remove eateries along the expressway, said, “I have conducted extensive patrolling on the stretch and spotted all the areas which pose a security threat to commuters. I have asked local police to take appropriate action.”

According to private concessionaire, there are at least 25 roadside eateries in over 10 villages on both sides of the expressway which includes Awalkheda, Jrailiya, Barauta, Makrand, Lukhriya, Palkheda, Mirpur, Suraj, Kapur, Mirthana, Gadsauli and Aagai.

Here, truck drivers, private bus operators, private taxis and others often take a break from their journey - which is prohibited due to continuous fast movement of traffic. Importantly, sources claimed that unauthorized eateries are located at milestones ‘61.750’, ‘68.100’, ‘72.500’, ‘73’, ‘75.100’, ‘75.500’, ‘75.600’, ‘77.800’, ‘92.400’, ‘92.750’, ‘107.800’, ‘107.900’, ‘108.100’, ‘113.200’, ‘118’, ‘118.800’, ‘130.400’, ‘130.700’, ‘131.600’, ‘133.160’, ‘133.170’, ‘133.500’, ‘133.780’, ‘134.160’ and ‘134.440’.

Speaking to TOI, Major (retired) Manish Singh, in-charge coordinator of Yamuna expressway (Mathura-Agra) section, said, “The robbers, we suspect, usually select their targets in these eateries. Most of the criminal activities recorded are also near these eateries. And they access the Yamuna expressway by cutting through the barbed wire. In a majority of such cases, shocked victims prefer to drive away, instead of waiting for police help. On several occasions, we wrote letters to local police stations - Naujheel, Mannt, Baldeo, Yamunapar, Surir and Mahavan - requesting them to take action against unauthorized eateries.”

According to private concessionaire in 2019, robberies were reported at milestones ‘65’, ‘75’, ‘84.100’, ‘75.600’, ‘116.500’ and ‘102’ between February and September. A majority of the targets were buses, trucks, taxi operators, tourists and bikers.

“They first throw sharp-edged wedge on the stretch and wait for tyres of vehicles to deflate, thereby forcing the victims to come out. The armed gang then suddenly appears to rob them,” Singh added.

Robberies were reported at milestone ‘75’, Naujheel, in June and September last year. In June, a woman from Mauritius, along with her two Indian friends, heading to Agra to visit Taj Mahal were allegedly robbed at gunpoint, while in September, two trucks were robbed by a gang, who then fled in their sedan.

Notably, 12 sub-inspectors, 42 constables, a dozen of Japyee Infratech security personnel are posted on the stretch between Noida and Agra. They patrol in vehicles around the clock.

Title: Happy Republic Day 2020: Do you know why Republic Day is celebrated on January 26?
Content: January 26, 2020, marks the 71st Indian Republic Day. It was on this day in 1950 that the esteemed constitution came into effect and India was declared an independent republic country.Most of us have grown up with fond memories of the day. 26th January is the day when many sit and watch the parade, the tableaus from various states and ministeries go by, people bestowed with the prestigious bravery awards and it is the day when we all hoisted our tricolour flags and celebrated our country's independent spirit. But, do you know the exact reason why Republic Day is celebrated on January 26 and not any other day?Here is a little history behind the same...January 26 was chosen for a specific reason as it was a significant event in India's struggle to gain freedom from British rule. On January 26, 1930, Congress passed the Poorna Swaraj resolution or the Declaration of Independence.Though India gained freedom from the British rule after a long struggle on August 15, 1947. Sadly, as valued as this freedom was, it did not come along with democracy or gave people the right to choose their own elected Government. Since India didn't have an official Constitution then, our country was a constitutional monarchy under the rule of King George VI even after Independence. It was finally after two and half years later on January 26, 1950, when the Indian Constitution came into effect thus making India one of the biggest democracies in the world. It was on this day when India was declared as a sovereign, socialist, secular, democratic republic.The committee worked tirelessly for many months and submitted their first draft of the Constitution on November 4, 1947, to the Constituent Assembly. It took exactly 2 years, 11 months and 18 days to finally adopt the Constitution with the necessary amendments.When the Constitution of India was adopted on 26th November 1949, many considered it necessary to celebrate the document on a day associated with national pride. Poorna Swaraj Day was considered to be the best available option and henceforth, came into being celebrated as Republic Day.

Title: ‘Tibet holds strategic and cultural importance to India’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Nagpur: If you see the map of the world, especially from the perspective of India, the longest border India shares with any neighbouring country is that of Tibet. India and Tibet have a very important and significant relationship, said Prof Anand Kumar. He was speaking at a lecture organized at Lohiya Adhyayan Kendra on ‘Tibet Mukti Andolan’ on Thursday evening.

He said, “Tibet today is a very important centre for Buddhism. The introduction of Buddhism in Tibet was done by Indians only.”

Kumar, who is a popular sociologist in Delhi, then stated, “It is commonly known that a Tibetan king had once sent some people to the famous university of Nalanda to develop a Tibetan language and a script. That language is still spoken in Tibet today as its official language.”

Kumar then pointed out that there are three main aspects which tie India to Tibet. “The first aspect is that of culture and religion. The second relation is of security. Tibet is a gate to India for the world. So there is a lot of army deployment in that region.”

“The third relation pertains to use of natural resources,” said Kumar. “Many rivers emerge from Tibet which supply water to the country. Since China has occupied Tibet, they have exploited the region very selfishly which has resulted in melting glaciers and reduction in water level.”

According to Kumar, Tibet is the heart of the Himalayas. “It is the home of Dalai Lama and an important centre for Mahayana Buddhism. This particular sect of Buddhism is spread to Ladakh, Sikkim, Bhutan and as far as Mongolia from Tibet making it an important cultural region.”

Speaking about China’s colonization of Tibet, Kumar said, “In Tibet, today children are being forced to learn Chinese in schools along with Marxist and Communist ideologies. Dalai Lama wants Tibet to be a free country but does not want to become enemies with China. The Dalai Lama wants Tibet to be a zone of peace nestled in the Himalayas.”

He stated that it is very unfortunate that when colonization in the world was ending and countries were rebelling against the tyranny of colonisers like France, England, Portugal etc, China’s colonization of Tibet was just beginning.

ends

Title: Kalapani: Nepal pushes for talks for third time
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: Nepal continues to apply pressure on India for talks on the Kalapani territorial dispute which flared up last year after India’s new political map, following the reorganisation of J&K, showed the region as belonging to India. It has, for the third time, proposed talks between the foreign secretaries on the issue, official sources said.

It had twice earlier proposed dates for dialogue on Kalapani, most recently on January 15. India was perhaps constrained by the fact that foreign secretary Vijay Gokhale is retiring this month but Nepal is hoping that with his successor Harsh Vardhan Shringla taking charge next week, India will finally agree to having a dialogue on Kalapani.

The Nepal government continues to maintain that Kalapani, located at the India-Nepal-China trijunction, is a part of Nepal and allowing the issue to fester will not help bilateral ties. Nepal foreign minister Pradeep Gyawali was quoted as saying in Kathmandu on Friday that if India could resolve its boundary issues with Bangladesh, it could certainly do the same with Nepal.

Gyawali went on to say that the issue needed to be settled “so that no unresolved baggage can be the obstacle for cordial relations between Nepal and India’’.

“Nepal’s current boundary was demarcated, fixed by the Sugauli Treaty of 1816 and the consecutive complementary treaties of December 1816, 1860 and 1875. There are three other agreements which are related to the treaty which categorically say that Nepal’s western border is demarcated by the Kali river… so in the historical evidence (sic), documents and maps that Kali, in Nepal we call it Mahakali river, is the western boundary river of Nepal,” Gyawali said.

“So, Nepal wants to settle this unresolved or pending issue according to the Sugauli Treaty and other correspondence at that time, historical maps and evidence. I do believe that both the countries have strong political stability, leaders are visionary and they have good personal contacts as well and commitment to resolve pending issues through diplomatic process," he added.

Significantly, the Nepal foreign minister said Nepal was not just ready but also “very, very eager’’ to have the next Saarc summit. Nepal is well aware that India is unlikely to yield to any call for an early Saarc summit because of its strained ties with Pakistan over the issue of cross-border terrorism. The summit, which was to be held in Pakistan in 2016, was delayed as India refused to participate because of the involvement of terrorists from across LoC in the Uri attack which left 19 Indian soldiers dead.

Title: 40% of girls aged 15-18 not attending school: Report
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: Ten years after the Right to Education (RTE) Act came into being, nearly 40% of adolescent girls in the age group of 15-18 years are not attending school while 30% of girls from poorest families have never set foot in a classroom, according to status report.

According to the report by Right to Education Forum and Centre for Budget Policy Studies with support of the World Bank and UNICEF , poor compliance of RTE —12.7% across India— has been primarily due to the downward trend in financing school education which has come down from 4.14% in 2014-15 to 3.40% in 2019-20.

RTE Act of 2019 mandates compulsory education for children between the age of 6-14 years under Article 21A of the Constitution.

The report also cited that education and empowerment index are directly related to per-child expenditure. Kerala tops the index with a spending of Rs 11,574 per child per year with Bihar at the bottom with a spending of just Rs 2,869. Himachal Pradesh , with a spending of Rs 17,921 per child per year, features second among 17 large states.

The report released on the occasion of International Day of Education and National Girl Child Day on Friday stated that while Sustainable Development Goals seek to achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls, India is home to millions of ‘out-of-school’ children, with girls accounting for a substantial chunk. Raising concerns over the fact that girls are twice less likely as boys to receive at least four years of schooling, 30% of girls from the economically disadvantaged groups have never set foot inside a classroom. The literacy rate of women in India is only at 65%.

According to Ambarish Rai, national convenor, RTE Forum, with over 60 million children lacking education in India, insufficient funding for school education has been the bottleneck in achieving benefits under the RTE Act “which is an important tool for universalisation of elementary education”. “The status of girls’ education in the country is a matter of grave concern,” he said.

As per the report, studies have shown strong correlation between public investment in education and child development and empowerment. The report said each additional year of schooling raises earning by 8%-10% (with larger increase for women), meaning that education not only helps to grow the economy but also fight poverty.

Among the 17 states cited in the report, 11 states whose EEI has been 0.5 or more are those which spent Rs 6,000 or more per child annually.

Highlighting the fact that states alone cannot deal with the need for higher public expenditure to meet education goals laid out in the National Education Policy, the report raised concern over excessive dependence on education cess.

“Cess is an emergency and variable source of government funding meant to aid and cushion expenditure sources from tax revenue/ budgetary support. Since 2015, with the decline of budgetary support for education expenditure, cess funded 70% of the total education expenditure. This means that the emergency cess has become a regular way of funding,” it said.

Title: 150 prominent citizens write to President over CAA
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

President Ram Nath Kovind (File Photo)

NEW DELHI: Throwing their weight behind the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, the National Population Register and the National Register of Citizens , over 150 prominent citizens have written to President Ram Nath Kovind seeking action against “forces” resorting to violence in the name of CAA.

These citizens want the government to take steps to “protect democratic institutions” and the letter has been endorsed by former judges, civil servants, armed forces officers, academics and doctors. It was submitted to the President after a delegation met him on Friday.

“We strongly feel that there is also an external dimension to the disturbances being created. We, therefore, request the government to look into this matter with all seriousness and safeguard the democratic institutions of the country and take stern action against such forces,” they said.

The list of signatories includes 72 bureaucrats , including former defence secretary Yogendra Narain , former chief secretaries of Delhi, Punjab, Haryana, Kerala, Manipur and Puducherry among others. Fifty-six armed forces officers, including former deputy chief of Army Gurmeet Singh, also signed the letter.

Title: Suspected stalker stabs Tamil Nadu student at Canada university
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Angeline Rachel

COIMBATORE: A student from Tamil Nadu pursuing a PG course in Canada ’s York University was stabbed by a suspected stalker on her way back home from the institute on Thursday. She was admitted to an intensive care facility and is believed to be critical. The suspect has been arrested.

Canadian authorities who contacted the parents of Angeline Rachel, 23, from Coonoor in Nilgiris, have advised them to come to Canada immediately. The parents are waiting for their visas and are likely to leave on Saturday. Foreign minister S Jaishankar has asked MEA officials to help with the family’s visa request.

Rachel, who was pursuing a one-year course in masters in supply chain management, was staying in an apartment near the university. She is scheduled to complete the course in April.

“My daughter was an outstanding student. She did her schooling in Coonoor and completed her UG at Christ University, Bengaluru. She was working for three years before she got selected for the PG programme,” said her father Albert Rajkumar. “She was very active on social media and a student who seemed like an Indian would often disturb her on social media. I spoke to my daughter on Thursday morning (IST) and she was fine. But later that night, we got a call from Canadian authorities saying that she was stabbed by an unidentified man who looked like an Indian,” Rajkumar said.

“The suspect has been arrested by the Canadian police,” he added.

Title: 44 special trains to clear rush
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

Forty-four special trains will be operated between Secunderabad and Machilipatnam in order to clear extra rush of passengers. The trains will run from Narsapur to Hyderabad, Hyderabad to Vijayawada, and Secunderabad to Barauni.

These special trains will consist of one AC II Tier, three AC III Tier, seven Sleeper Class and five General Second Class Coaches and will start services from February 2.

Title: Getting smarter: Vizag bags two awards at Smart Cities conference
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The city has won two significant awards at the 3rd Apex Conference of Smart Cities. Represented by the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC), Visakhapatnam got an award in the ‘recognition of performance’ category as well as under the ‘innovative idea’ category for its 2MW floating solar plant on Mudasarlova reservoir.

M Vinay Kumar, superintending engineer, GVMC ( smart city ) said that the civic body has proposed projects worth Rs 1,050 crore. “Projects worth Rs 278 crore have already been completed while projects worth Rs 450 crore are under various phases of execution,” he said.

The 2 MW floating solar power project, which was set up with about Rs 13.4 crore on Mudasarlova, has been saving nearly Rs 2.3 crore on electricity bills annually. According to the GVMC officials, the solar floating power projects reduce demand for land and make use of the unutilised surface area of the reservoir. The solar panels will also help in reducing water evaporation from the reservoir to an extent, they informed.

Meanwhile, at a time when the state government is set on branching out capital powers among three cities of Andhra Pradesh instead of the incumbent capital Amaravati , the latter has received an award under the ‘recognition of performance’ category.

Amaravati ranked first among all 100 smart cities in spending the funds released by the Union government under the Smart Cities Mission. However, the overall rank of the city witnessed a decline, as it slipped from the 10th place in February 2019 to the 19th place in January 2020.

Speaking to TOI on the sidelines of the conference, P Lakshmi Narasimhan, commissioner of Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority said that the Amaravati Smart and Sustainable City Corporation Limited had proposed various projects worth Rs 2,050 crore.

Seven different awards have been conferred upon smart cities under seven themes. Besides these seven awards, the best performers from winning cities of each round of the Smart Cities Mission challenge walked away with ‘recognition of performance’ awards.

These cities include Visakhapatnam and Ahmedabad from among round-1 cities, Vadodara, Ranchi and Kanpur from among round-2 cities, Sagar, Amaravati and Rajkot from among round-3 cities and Erode from among round-4 cities.

Title: ‘Smart cities are labs, will come up with models for the country’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

GVMC commissioner G Srijana takes the ‘innovative idea’ award from DS Mishra, secretary, ministry of housing a... Read More

Visakhapatnam: The Smart Cities Mission (SCM) is just the beginning of what Indian cities are going to be, said Durga Shanker Mishra, secretary, ministry of housing and urban affairs. Mishra was speaking at the two-day 3rd Apex Conference of Smart Cities being held in Visakhapatnam.

Speaking to the media, Mishra said, “We think of smart cities as lighthouses. If you ask me why only 100 smart cities, I can say that you cannot have so many laboratories. These 100 laboratories are going to come up with new models, things, initiatives which can be replicated in other cities.”

“The SCM has witnessed tremendous progress in implementation of projects in the last one and half years. There has been a 223% growth in the number of projects tendered, 285% growth in projects grounded and 387% growth in number of projects completed,” he added.

Mishra further said that works of 45 integrated command and control centres have already been completed and have been made operational under SCM.

“32 more ICCCs are at various stages of implementation. 155 smart road projects have been completed and 395 smart road projects are at the tender/implementation stage. Similarly, the smart solar, smart water and vibrant public spaces projects are heading towards progressive paths,” said Mishra.

The secretary of ministry of housing and urban affairs also discussed the way SCM has progressed over the years. He said that the first apex conference was organised in Bhopal in May, 2018 to give a boost to implementation of smart city projects, peer-to-peer learning which was followed by the second conference in New Delhi in February, 2019.

Title: Win for road safety: Over 90% city bikers now wear helmets
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In what comes as a major win for the Port City’s road safety situation, official data have shown that nearly 90% two-wheeler riders in the city are wearing helmets. Both the road transport authority (RTA) and the city traffic police have attributed this positive development to effective policing.

Speaking to TOI, GC Raja Ratnam, deputy transport commissioner, RTA said, “We have registered 90% helmet usage among two-wheeler riders in the city. This has been possible with the collective efforts of all stakeholders and public support.”

He further said, “Our intention has never been to just collect fines. We have sought to inculcate the practice of wearing helmets as safety gear to prevent road mishaps.”

M Ramesh Kumar (ADCP, traffic) said that traffic cops no longer stop people violating the helmet rule. Instead, the cops take pictures of those violating the rule, he said.

Nearly 530 traffic cops are engaged in regulating traffic in the city daily. Of these, 300 cops check to see if people are wearing helmets and take pictures of those violating the rule.

“We send around 2,000 challans to rule violators with a penalty of Rs 135 per violation. The efforts have helped us get desired results,” Kumar told TOI.

A campaign focussed on making people wear helmets was launched in October 2019. Since then, the police have been conducting vigorous checks and are imposing penalties.

A significant number of such drives were conducted at Siripuram Junction, Jagadamba Centre, Gajuwaka, Kancharapalem, Hanumanthwaka Junction and RK Beach among other places.

The wearing of helmets while riding two-wheelers is mandatory as per Section 129 of the Motor Vehicles Act. The helmets must conform to the quality standards set by the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS).

Title: Tata lays claim on safest car-maker tag
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolkata: Tata Motors has claimed that it has the safest range of passenger cars with four products in its portfolio receiving high safety certification by Global New Car Assessment Programme (Global NCAP), a UK-based foundation that tests the level of protection for passengers in the event of a crash.

After its compact SUV Nexon and recently launched premium hatch Altroz received 5-star, the highest safety rating for adult occupant protection, two more cars — hatch Tiago and sedan Tigor — have achieved 4-star rating. This makes Tata Motors the only Indian manufacturer with four cars with high NCAP rating in its portfolio. Mahindra & Mahindra has two cars that have high safety rating: compact SUV XUV 300 that received 5-star and MPV Marazzo that was given 4-star rating.

Global NCAP had launched #SaferCarsForIndia Campaign in 2014 with the aim of promoting safer vehicles in the country. Between 2014 and 2020, Global NCAP has completed more than 37 safety assessments that have led to safety improvements of Indian cars.

Tata Motors vice-president (global design) Pratap Bose said the company was confident full-size premium SUV Harrier and the future line of products, including Gravitas, the seven-seater SUV, small SUV codenamed H2X and the sedan on the Alpha-ARC platform would achieve high safety rating from Global NCAP. Tata Motors is the only Indian car manufacturer with a crash test facility.

“We are committed to make not just stylish cars that are great to drive and ride but also the safest cars. When we upgraded the Tiago and Tigor from BS IV to BS VI, we also enhanced the safety features, including pedestrian protection features, to make the cars safer for both occupants and pedestrians,” said Bose.

Sources said efforts were underway to make the safety upgrade in all passengers cars that would continue in the portfolio, including MPV Hexa. Manufacture of Harrier, Hexa, Safari Storme and compact sedan Zest have been suspended since last month-end as the company makes the switch to comply with BS VI emission norms. The company is yet to take a call on introduction of a BS VI Zest that is popular in the commercial vehicle segment.

In fact, the company has decided not to introduce diesel variants of Tiago and Tigor as it feels the premium that one has to pay for a BS VI diesel vehicle will not make sense given the narrowing of the petrol-diesel price gap. “We will continue with diesel for premium and large vehicles with higher engine displacement for the high torque it delivers,” he said.
