Three years ago, seven out of 10 cars that Tata Motors sold were diesel variants. Now, seven of them are petrol. “Going ahead, a number of cars in the portfolio will also have electric variants,” said Bose. Both the Alpha and Omega platforms are ready for electric.

Title: Major gaffe: Cheetah turns tiger, then cheetah again!
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Comedy of errors: Uday K Patta, youth president of Vizag Development Council tweeted the image on the left of ... Read More

Visakhapatnam: A cheetah turned into a tiger overnight. And then it had to be turned into a cheetah again by the city’s civic body.

Towards the end of the year, the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) was busy revamping the Beach Road in preparation for Visakha Utsav. In course of the attempt, a cheetah’s statue got painted with black and yellow stripes of a Royal Bengal Tiger.

Locals were irked at this transformation. Their familiar cheetah statue was donning the skin of the tiger.

Consequently, a complaint was lodged with the GVMC, asking them to fix the mess.

One such irked resident was Uday Kiran Patta. Speaking to TOI, Patta said, “The cheetah statue has been there for the last 10-12 years. It was ridiculous. The shape of the statue is slim like a cheetah’s body and in no way looks like a tiger.”

TOI asked civic body officials what made them turn the cheetah into a tiger. Officials said that the colours on the statue had faded when they went to repaint it. They assumed that statue was that of a tiger and re-painted it with black and yellow stripes by mistake.

“But once we received the complaint on our Twitter handle on January 9, we immediately decided to take action. However, it took a few days to repaint the statue because of the Sankranti holidays,” said a GVMC official.

Once the statue was fixed and the leopard cheetah, Patta, who is the youth president of Vizag Development Council re-tweeted his earlier tweet and thanked municipal commissioner G Srijana for the restoration.

Title: Espionage case: Mumbai woman sent hawala money to sailors
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Navy sailors involved in the alleged espionage case provided vital information like movement of warships and submarines to Pakistan’s ISI, according to National Investigation Agency (NIA) sources.

A 47-year-old woman from Mumbai, identified as Sheikh Shahista, was the key conduit in sending money to the accused through hawala channel, the sources added.

It may be recalled that NIA had taken custody of 13 persons for five days with the permission of the court. The 13 include the 10 sailors, a hawala operator from Mumbai identified as Sayyed, alias Masoom Ali, besides the woman. The five days of custody ended on Thursday.

During their interrogation, NIA sleuths found that the arrested sailors had passed on important information about the movement of naval warships and submarines.

The woman, who reportedly runs a garments business, used to receive money through hawala operator Sayyed, who in turn handed it over to the accused sailors. The woman, who reportedly hails from Pakistan, has been illegally staying in Mumbai for many years. The sailors were arrested on Dec 20 last year. Three of them are from the Eastern Naval Command in Visakhapatnam .

Title: Advocate lashes out at those opposing CAA, calls them ‘pseudo-secularists’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Dharwad: Against a backdrop of unrelenting opposition to the Citizenship (Amendment) Act across the country, advocate Anup Deshpande sought to offer a contrarian perspective on the controversial law on Thursday. “CAA has been introduced in order to accord citizenship to those who have been fleeing due to religious persecution from Pakistan , Afghanistan and Bangladesh. There are no provisions in the law that needs to make people think that their Indian citizenship is in peril,” said Deshpande.

The advocate, participating in a symposium organised by the Gandhi Peace Foundation on CAA , lashed out at those opposing the Act. Dubbing critics of the Act ‘ pseudo-secularists ’, Deshpande said, “These are people acting out of ulterior motives and creating confusion about the objectives of the CAA. Gullible citizens are being incited to protest against the Centre . Those opposing the Act are either ignorant of its provisions or deliberately indulging in a campaign of misinformation to further their ends.”

Quoting Mahatma Gandhi on the subject, Desphande said that the former too had expressed a wish to accord citizenship to those willing to come to India. “He had wanted such people to enjoy a decent, dignified life here. After Partition, Pakistan declared itself as an Islamic Republic, and members belonging to minority communities such as Hindus, Jains, Buddhists and Parsis were subjected to persecution. The BJP-led NDA government is doing what the previous Congress-led governments failed to by providing justice to these people,” said the advocate.

‘No rules yet on NRC’

Deshpande pointed out that the central government was yet to frame rules or guidelines for the implementation of the National Register of Citizens (NRC), and urged people not to fear such a prospect. “The NRC was rolled out in Assam, but will not be implemented across the country. The government will not ask citizens to furnish documents to prove their citizenship, but rumours are being spread to create confusion among the public,” he added.

Siddangouda Patil, however, sought to contradict the observations made by Deshpande. “Those coming to India from neighbouring countries are not fleeing due to religious persecution, but running away because of gross violations of human rights. They are not infiltrators. People coming to India in search of better prospects are being projected as infiltrators. There have already been reports of tents of such people in Bengaluru being demolished. They are now unemployed, and have no roof over their heads, and being left to starve,” said Patil.

He urged the government to step up efforts to identify the real infiltrators. “They are the ones who must be sent to detention centres,” said Patil, questioning the haste with which the CAA was passed in mere three days without a careful consideration of its alignment with the values of the Constitution.

“Had this Act been discussed in the public domain, we would not have witnessed such public outcry against it,” he said.

Title: Murugha Mutt decked up for annual fair
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Dharwad: The weeklong spiritual, literary and cultural programmes preceding the Rathotsava at the century-old Murugha Mutt in Dharwad will commence from Sunday.

The present pontiff Sri Mallikarjun Swamiji who took over the reins in January 2010 under controversial circumstances has continued the works initiated by the founders. Apart from continuing the traditional and religious activities, he has laid emphasis on publication of books that propagate spiritualism and Basava’s philosophy.

The annual fair of Murugha Mutt is unique in the sense that apart from religious ceremonies there are events to create awareness about social and cultural issues and to promote literature and art. “In a way it is an event that promotes social and communal harmony,” said Mallikarjun Swamiji..

The celebrations began on January 21 with the lecture series on the life of Sharanas. The main functions will commence on January 26 with hoisting of the ‘Shatsthala’ flag and books release. The Mrutyunjaya-Mahant Award will be presented to business tycoon Vijay Sankeshwar on January 29. The car festival (rathotsava) will be held on January 30. Several pontiffs from various mutts in the region, political leaders, litterateurs, achievers will participate in the five-day celebrations.

Title: Exclusive cargo flight service from Vizag
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: SpiceJet has agreed to start operating an exclusive cargo flight from Chennai to Kolkata via Visakhapatnam, informed members of the Andhra Pradesh Air Travellers’ Association (APATA). The cargo flight is expected to carry 20 tonnes weight daily. It is expected to start operation from February 2020, subject to approvals.

APATA has been pursuing exclusive cargo flights from Visakhapatnam for quite some time. In this regard, Vizag MP MVV Satyanarayana also spoke to various airlines for cargo flights from Visakhapatnam, given the enormous scope of exports from Vizag.

On the other hand, air cargo rates (Air India) have reduced. When the issue was brought to the notice of APATA that cargo rates of Air India in Visakhapatnam were lower than in Hyderabad, the association took up the issue with Daggubati Purandeswari, independent director of Air India Ltd.

She reportedly met the Air India CMD on Thursday and impressed upon them to reduce the rates.

Title: Belagavi traffic police mulling over proposal to make a stretch of Fort Entry Road one way
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Belagavi: The road passing through the Belagavi Fort is among the thoroughfares in the city that is particularly nightmarish for traffic police to monitor vehicular movement on, and in a bid to ease congestion there, they are contemplating turning the stretch into a one way at the fort’s entrance.

Traffic police started thinking along these lines after the defence wing in the city withdrew the traffic controller inside the fort. The land where the the fort is located belongs to the Indian military. The decision to do away with a traffic controller at the fort was taken following objections raised by the public. Consequently, traffic on this busy stretch has not been monitored for nearly a year.

Residents who use the road regularly are understandably frustrated with the traffic pile-up that has become painfully common on the thoroughfare. Ashok Chanaragi, one of the regular users, said, “The road has become a mess. There is no order to entry and exit to and from the road respectively. Motorists just come from everywhere, leading to congestion,” he said.

Chandaragi said that defence personnel who monitored traffic on the road ensured that vehicular movement was hassle-free. “There are more than 100 houses, government offices, a church, a temple and the office of the Ramakrishna Mission inside the fort, and the number of people using the road is always high. The deputy commissioner must take cognisance of the problem and appoint a traffic controller at the earliest,” he added.

Belagavi city police commissioner BS Lokeshkumar admitted to traffic police mulling over a proposal to turn the road leading to the entry of the fort into a one-way. “We are examining the viability of turning a 150m-stretch of the road into a one-way. But traffic will be allowed in both directions at the other end. We think this will ease traffic movement. If implemented, motorists will not be able to exit the fort from the entrance, rather move out from the exit gate itself.” Lokeshkumar said.

Traffic police are also considering deploying a cop outside the main entrance of the fort, where vehicles are allowed in both the directions. Lokeshkumar attributed the persisting problem to the unwillingness of the defence personnel to cooperate with them in solving it.

An official with the Ministry of Defence (MoD) said that complaints from a section of the people, including residents and regular visitors to the fort, they had been compelled to remove the traffic controller at one of the entrances to the structure. “Someone has to shoulder the responsibility to manage traffic movement. The MoD is willing to deploy a traffic controller at the entrance even now, but the Belagavi police commissioner will have to make a formal request to that effect,” the official told TOI.

Title: Savadi calls on farmers to adopt organic farming
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Belagavi: Exhorting farmers to adopt organic methods of agriculture, deputy chief minister Laxman Savadi on Friday emphasised the role of ryots in creating a healthy society.

Savadi, who flagged off the ‘Millet Walk’ here on Friday, said that the state government was trying to convince farmers to increasingly take to organic modes of cultivation. Millet Walk is being held as a curtain raiser for the two-day Millet Mela beginning from Saturday.

Savadi, Karnataka agriculture minister, rued the excessive reliance of farmers on pesticides and chemical fertilisers, which he pointed out was detrimental to their future, besides having an adverse impact on the health of those who consumed their crops. “The use of fertilisers have also resulted in markedly reducing the fertility of the soil, and the land grows less arable as a result with each passing year,” the deputy CM said.

Dubbing organic farming a ‘healthy practice’, he said, “The need of the hour is to make more farmers aware of the benefits of organic cultivation, besides encouraging them to take up growing of millets . Increased consumption of organic food helps people stay healthy.”

Savadi called on farmers and residents of Belagavi to ensure the success of the Millet Mela.

Title: 1.2km overhead cables removed in Parel, Worli
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

The action won applause from Worli MLA Aaditya Thackeray.

MUMBAI: Declaring war on the city-wide eyesore of dangling overhead utility wires, over 1.2km of unauthorised cables were removed by civic authorities from trees, poles, monorail pillars and every other conceivable perch in a special drive over the last fortnight in Lower Parel, Worli , and Haji Ali areas.

Teams from G South ward visited Pandurang Budhkar Marg, Dr Annie Besant Road, Senapati Bapat Marg and N M Joshi Marg with an electrician to cut off cables. BMC plans to carry on the drive.

The action immediately won accolades from local MLA and minister Aaditya Thackeray. "Most important for all our cities across Maharashtra. Illegal overhead wires and cables to be removed," he tweeted.

The BMC rule book clearly states that overhead cables are illegal and should be laid underground after obtaining the required permissions. The action came after civic authorities had repeatedly asked service providers over the past few months to take the cables underground. Sharad Ughade, assistant municipal commissioner of G South ward said overhead cables are permitted only as an emergency arrangement. "In all other cases, permission should be taken to lay cables underground," he said.

Civic officials said the dangling overhead cables are a threat to oversize motor vehicles as well as flying birds but are preferred over trenching as it involves no road excavation and reinstatement.

Title: 3 documentaries critical of govt snubbed for film fest?
Content: MUMBAI: The Bombay high court on Friday called for records pertaining to the selection process of three documentaries at the Mumbai International Film Festival (MIFF) after a petition alleged that the three were rejected as they are critical of the Centre. The festival is to be held from January 28 to February 3.The petition by awarding-winning documentary filmmakers Anand Patwardhan and Pankaj Kumar, urged the high court to direct MIFF, the Films Division of India, and the I&B ministry to screen their documentaries.The petition states that Patwardhan’s film Vivek (also titled Reason) covers the murders of rationalist Narendra Dabholkar, Communist leader Govind Pansare , Kannada writer MM Kalburgi and journalist Gauri Lankesh , investigating the connection of these crimes to sectarian outfits. It states that it also looks at the violent attacks on Muslims and Dalits in the name of cow protection, caste-based discrimination that led to the suicide of student leader Rohith Vemula at Hyderabad University, and “numerous other outbursts of violence… connecting them to present an overview of the turmoil that India is presently witnessing”.Pankaj Kumar’s Janani’s Juliet follows the story of a Puducherry theatre group, which disturbed by a spate of honour killings, sets out to introspect the implications of caste, class and gender. His other entry, Two Flags, chronicles the life and politics of Puducherry.Senior advocate Mihir Desai, for the duo, said in court, “We don’t know if they were viewed and rejected or not viewed at all. Out of the three films, two were shortlisted for the Oscars… According to me, they have been rejected because they are critical of the ruling dispensation.” Additional solicitor general Anil Singh and advocate Advait Sethna, representing the Films Division and the I&B ministry, said the filmmakers had agreed to abide by festival regulations and participated in the selection process till the results were out. “Now, at the fag end, when the film is not selected, you file a petition challenging the regulations,” said Singh.The bench, of Justices Satyaranjan Dharmadhikari and Riyaz Chagla, referred to Patwardhan’s earlier challenges to “arbitrary restrictions” on his films and ensuing landmark judgments. The judges remarked that Patwardhan’s works were kept away even during non-BJP governments. “He is apprehensive because of the content. (That) the content (will not be) allowed to be exhibited at all,” said Justice Dharmadhikari.To a court query, Singh replied, “We have viewed all the films for their presentation, treatment, technology and overall impact.” The judges said selection process records of the three films in question must be produced on Monday. “If the selection committee has seen them, we’ll accept it. We are not going to curtail anybody’s freedom to select,” said Justice Dharmadhikari. “Some are lucky on occasion, others are not so lucky. You take away that apprehension from them (the petitioners),” Justice Dharmadhikari added.

Title: Government suggests Maharashtra DGP as next police chief of Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Subodh Kumar Jaiswal

Title: Court 'reprieve' for Ukrainian in Mumbai since 2013 on short-term visas
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A Ukrainian national, Nataliya Yesauenko (34), approached the Bombay high court to challenge 'repeated' short-term visas issued to her and argued that she was eligible for a long-term five-year visa as she has been in India since seven years.

On Friday, she argued in person that she had applied for the extension in time and questioned a Rs 5,000 penalty for 'overstaying' by a couple of months.

A bench of Justice S C Dharmadhikari and Justice Riyaz Chagla asked the Centre to issue the visa at regular visa fees and not impose the penalty.

The high court will pass orders on January 27.

The Centre's counsel, Sandesh Patil and DP Singh, argued that Yesauenko has 'violated' the spouse visa condition by having worked in the 2016 film 'Mohenjo Daro' as she is prohibited from taking up work or doing business on this visa.

The government's affidavit also said that "she continues to work in contravention of the Foreigners Act with utter disrespect for the law of the land" and she "keeps changing" her residence. But Yesauenko claimed that they had showed no proof that she was working in India.

The HC bench said, "We will ensure right now that you are not thrown out of India. They (Foreigners Regional Registration Officers) are giving you a three-month visa and within that time, they will consider your application for the five-year visa." Yesauenko insisted that she would not pay the penalty since she had applied in time last June, but Patil said the visa application was considered filed when she submitted all documents, two months later, hence the additional amount. But she argued that they wanted to 'extort' documents and money from her.

In her petition, Yesauenko had said that she had come to India in July 2013 on a tourist visa, and in November, it was converted for a year to a Spouse 'X' category visa after she "converted to Hindu religion...and got married" in August 2013.

Title: Insurance company officer held for Rs 12 crore fraud
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The city economic offences wing (EOW) has arrested a family of three, including a development officer attached to the Borivili branch of a prominent insurance firm, his wife - a clerk in the same branch - and their son, for duping dozens of investors after promising to double their money in 90 days.

The fraud amount, currently estimated at Rs 12 crore, is likely to go up to Rs 50 crore, said police.

Those arrested include Sanjay Rasal, 55, Reshma, 49, and Yash, 24.

Sanju Pandit, an insurance agent, had lodged a complaint with the MHB police in November 2019 stating he had lost Rs 46 lakh in a Ponzi scheme run by the Rasals. He said Rasal convinced him to invest in a scheme floated by Keshneel Enterprises.

He assured investors double returns within 90 days and said his son was a director and proprietor of the firm. "Initially, the complainant invested a small amount and he got double returns within 90 days. He again invested and, gradually, more insurance agents joined the scheme," added an officer.

Rasal stopped paying the investors in July 2018.

Title: Amit Shah: BJP will spend Rs 1 lakh crore on Delhi if it wins state election
Content:
Amit Shah in Mustafabad

Shah claims Delhi’s water quality poorest in country

NEW DELHI: Pledging to make Delhi the world’s best capital if BJP wins the assembly polls, Union home minister Amit Shah on Friday said BJP would spend Rs 1 lakh crore to improve the city’s civic infrastructure if voted to office.At Shiv Vihar in Mustafabad constituency, Shah said, “Modi has done so much for Delhi... but we can’t improve your roads or construct parks in unauthorised colonies or schools or set up dispensaries, as these projects can be implemented by the state government and need around Rs 1 lakh crore. Modi government aims to spend this money for Delhi. If we win the election, all efforts will be made to improve the quality of air and reduce pollution.”Speaking at a rally in Mustafabad, Union home minister Amit Shah on Friday highlighted the need to overhaul roads and improve the quality of water and condition of schools in the city. “While coming to Mustafabad, it was difficult to find a road between the potholes,” he said sarcastically.Shah questioned AAP government’s plan to clean up the Yamuna. “It is still dirty. We aim to develop the riverfront and arrange for permanent ghats so that the people of Mustafabad and neighbouring constituencies don’t have to go for makeshift arrangements every year during Chhath Puja,” he said.On city government’s free power and water schemes, he said: “People are getting bills of Rs 5,000-Rs 6,000 despite the scheme promising free power till 200 units. Kejriwal government claims to supply water in all colonies, but its quality is the poorest in the country.”Shah accused the Kejriwal government of not implementing various Central schemes, fearing it will earn praise for PM Narendra Modi.He said under Ayushman Bharat scheme, people can get health treatment up to Rs 5 lakh, but the city government doesn’t want Delhiites to get its benefits. “We introduced 112 schemes for public welfare, especially for the poor, including Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojna. But Delhiites are not getting their benefits due to the adamant attitude of the state government. We promise to provide two-room-set houses in place of jhuggis and implement Ayushman Bharat scheme and PM Awas Yojana in Delhi after winning the elections,” said Shah.He said Modi government had provided ownership rights to 50 lakh residents of 1,731 unauthorised colonies in Delhi, something that neither Congress nor AAP could do.“In fact, they were dilly dallying... After winning Lok Sabha elections, we took the responsibility and started the process of giving ownership rights to people in the unauthorised colonies. Over 70,000 people have already applied for registry,” he added.Shah addressed backto-back meetings in Karawal Nagar and Mustafabad.“This fight is between those (Kejriwal government) who do not fulfil their promises and those (BJP) who do more than they promise,” Shah said. “They promised to construct colleges and schools, bring in 5,000 DTC buses and install 15 lakh CCTV cameras, but I couldn’t find any camera on the roads here. AAP claims to have improved the education system but their results in Class IX show something else,” said Shah.Attacking AAP and Congress over CAA, Shah said a third of people in Delhi were refugees from Pakistan and Delhiites accepted them like brothers. “They (AAP and Congress) started inciting Muslims and instigating riots in Delhi. They are still saying — we support Shaheen Bagh. Congress leaders visit Shaheen Bagh regularly,” he said.Shah highlighted Modi government’s achievements in abrogation of Article 370 and securing a positive Supreme Court judgment for constructing Ram temple in Ayodhya in four months.”For 500 years, all Indians wanted a Ram temple in Ayodhya. But whenever the case came up for hearing, Rahul Baba and his lawyer, Kapil Sibal, obstructed it. Now a towering, grand Ram temple will be constructed in Ayodhya in four months.”Shah accused Kejriwal and Rahul Gandhi of backing the “Tukde Tukde gang”. “We have sent such people behind bars. But now, the Kejriwal government is not giving sanction to prosecute them,” he added.

Title: Amit Shah: BJP will spend Rs 1 lakh crore on Delhi if it wins state election
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Amit Shah in Mustafabad

Title: BMC plans Rs 4.4 crore sponsorship for wilderness meet in Rajasthan, opposition fumes
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

BMC headquarters

MUMBAI: BMC plans to be the main sponsor of the 11th World Wilderness Congress to be held in Jaipur from March 19-26, and spend nearly Rs 4.4 crore to showcase Mumbai's flora and fauna, along with the wildlife at the civic-run Byculla zoo, a decision that has run into criticism from the opposition. Objecting to the plan, opposition leaders said "showcasing the city's wilderness is not BMC's primary duty".

On January 22, the BMC had tabled the sponsorship proposal at the standing committee meet, along with a plan to display the exhibition at Byculla zoo after the Jaipur meet. The proposal was not taken up for discussion; it is expected to be tabled again next week. "Through the exhibition...delegates from across the country will get to know that Mumbai is not a concrete jungle, but has greenery, including a national park. This is very rare for a mega metropolis," said a civic official.

Opposition party leader Ravi Raja of Congress said the money could instead be used for development works in the city. "This is a waste of taxpayers' money for an event that is not taking place in the city," he said. NCP leader Rakhi Jadhav said showcasing Mumbai's wildlife is not BMC's core competency. "They would have to hire an event management firm... which means additional expense. We plan to oppose the plan when tabled next week." SP leader Rais Shaikh said he too was "not in favour of the sponsorship plan".

Title: Andhra Pradesh capital shift leaves fate of Amaravati-Anantapur expressway hanging
Content:
The route was intended to have brought the Rayalaseema districts closer to Amaravati

AMARAVATI: The decision of the AP government to shift the capital out of Amaravati has raised concerns over the future of the proposed Amaravati-Anantapur expressway . Notification for land acquistion for the project had been published in 2019 and the state government had agreed to bear 50 per cent of the cost of land acquisition and obtain statutory clearances for environment, forests and wildlife.The project, which is a partnership between the central and state governments, proposes a greenfield expressway connecting Amaravati with the Rayalaseema region and was floated to accelerate industrial development and generate employment in drought-affected districts in the state. The route will also minimise travel time and was intended to have brought the Rayalaseema districts closer to Amaravati. Senior state government officials are of the opinion that the Centre will raise queries about the project as it is yet to formally take off. "Although Amaravati will continue to be the legislative capital under the new scheme of things, vehicular movement may not be as dense as estimated in the draft plans," said a senior official on condition of anonymity. Local farmers, meanwhile, have already raised objections over the land acquisition process for the project.Minister for energy, forest and environment Balineni Srinivasa Reddy said, "We will convince the Centre and go ahead with the project after readying the detailed project report (DPR)." The state government has already directed district collectors of Guntur, Prakasam, Kurnool, Kadapa and Anantapur to publish the draft notification for land acquisition by January 29 after completing a survey.Sources said the plan for the expressway is believed to have changed after YSR Congress assumed power in the state. The final stretch of the expressway may now be connected with National Highway (NH)-16 between Guntur and Ongole, unlike in the original plan.

Title: Statue of Periyar E V Ramasamy defaced near Kanchi
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Police cover the statue of Periyar E V Ramasamy at Kaliyapettai near Salavakkam in Kancheepuram district

CHENNAI: Miscreants early on Friday vandalised a statue of Dravidian stalwart and social reformer Periyar E V Ramasamy at Kaliyapettai near Salavakkam in Kancheepuram district .

The right hand of the statue was found broken and there were minor cracks on the head, police said.

The incident came to light around 6.15am when a resident found the statue damaged. The defaced portions have been covered. A huge posse of policemen has been deployed at the spot. Senior police officers visited the scene and carried out a detailed investigation.

Villagers, who gathered at the scene, alleged that fans of actor Rajinikanth could be behind the incident. Some of them condemned the daring act. However, police pacified the villagers, promising action against those responsible.

Local functionaries of Viduthalai Chiruthaigal Katchi lodged a complaint with the Salavakkam police following the incident. Police are examining CCTV camera footage in the locality and further investigations are on to trace the culprits.

The 4-ft tall statue was installed by local residents in 1988 and was inaugurated by Dravidar Kazhagam leaders.

The incident has come in the wake of organisations gearing to hold protests against Rajinikanth for his recent speech regarding the antisuperstition rally attended by Periyar in Salem in 1971. Security was also stepped up at the actor’s residence in Poes Garden here to prevent untoward incidents. Police personnel have been deployed near some other statues in Kancheepuram district.

Meanwhile, DGP J K Tripathy warned that police will take strict action against antisocial elements who vandalise statues of Periyar or those of other leaders in the state.

Title: ‘It is the Almighty who sings and listens’
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Pt Jasraj

KOLKATA: The lemon-yellow-flecked rays of the winter sun streams in like an uninvited guest, bathing the silver strands of his hair in an iridescent chiaroscuro. His weathered face glows with the golden stripes cast by the lazy morning sun. Slowly, he takes a sip of his coffee, bites into a multigrain bread toast, lifts his head and smiles, saying: “Jai Ho!”

A lot changes with age. More so, when one is knocking 90. The lists of don’ts increase, almost exponentially. Yet, what makes Pt Jasraj uniquely different from his peers is his ability to perform as perhaps the oldest globetrotting musician of the world. Few can fathom how he still manages to travel across continents, reach a concert venue way before time, sit upright for more than an hour, remember the bandishes, sing in tune and keep listeners transfixed.

Searching for his elixir, he insists, is an exercise in futility. One has to first understand his approach towards art to fathom how he has been doing it all from the age of 22, when he gave his first public concert at the darbar of King Tribhuvan Bir Bikram Shah of Nepal. As remuneration, he had received 5,000 mohurs — an amount that was more than what he could count then.

Those days of receiving mohurs have vanished. Today, acknowledgement comes in the form of a minor planet (Panditjasraj, which whirls between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter) being named after him. It is numbered 300128 — a nod to the day he was born, January 28, 1930.

That recognition is extra special, since a minor planet has also been named after Rabindranath Tagore. “Well, Gurudev will always remain where he is. But a recognition that associates me with him makes me happy,” he smiles.

Ask him what his dreams are now made of, and he gives a dismissive smile. “I have started getting what I had never dreamt of. That’s why I have given up on dreaming.” So, how would he want to be remembered 100 years from now? “Honestly, I don’t want to dwell on that. If people remember, it’s fine. If they don’t, that’s fine as well,” he says, in a detached way.

But he loves talking about how performing on stage is akin to a game of hockey. “There are days when I can understand that I am singing well and there is very good coordination with my students, which the audience is receiving well. We are a part of a team playing a game of hockey. I catch something and then pass it on to someone, who dribbles with it and then we will score a goal,” he says, eyes twinkling with childlike innocence.

However, describing how he feels while walking from the greenroom to the stage is difficult. “Sometimes, I can’t even recognise known people and they get puzzled. The mind is then in automatic gear,” he says, eating a slice of ripe papaya.

Some four or five times, the walk back from the stage to the greenroom had become a meditative experience. On those occasions, he completed his performance and left the stage without saying anything. Once inside the greenroom, he either went completely silent or started to weep.

Has he ever experienced that in Kolkata? “No,” he says. “The listeners’ love is so overwhelming that one can’t cross over and be aloof.” But Kolkata, he insists, has given him a lot. Memories of doing 14 hours of riyaaz during his stay in the city as a 20-year-old, the encouragement that he received from Som Tiwari (he addressed her as Ammaji) who was a disciple of his ‘bade bhaisaab’ (Pt Maniram) and the camaraderie with Dr Mukund Lath are fresh in mind. Back then, he used to play the tabla but good friend Ujjwal Roy would say he shouldn’t, as that would not help him grow as a vocalist. “They protected me and were like a banyan tree,” he recalls.

Then, there are memories of attending nightlong concerts, standing on tramlines.

On one occasion, he remembers 10,000 people had gathered outside Basusree to get a glimpse of Pt Ravi Shankar. “The last performer had taken more time, leaving only 45 minutes for Dada (Pt Ravi Shankar). Once over, the crowd wanted to catch a glimpse of him, but the organiser suggested he leave through the backdoor. However, Motilal Ranga and I, who were there with him in the greenroom, suggested that he go down,” he recalls.

His eyes still glisten when he remembers how Ranga had picked Shankar up and placed him on his head. “Dada sat in the lotus pose and soon he was transported from one person’s head to that of another while moving in front of Basusree in a circle,” he remembers, adding, “I do not think any artiste will experience this ever again. Recently, I had a similar experience in Rajkoth, where some 11,000 people waited outside with 2,000 inside the theatre. Their love was palpable and I sang for some two-and-a-half hours.”

It is evident that he has perfected the art of keeping the audience engrossed without diluting the purity of form. “Those who dilute on purpose will go the wrong way. But if deviations happen spontaneously, there are chances of something good emerging out of it,” he says.

Does he like listening to music himself? “Yes, I listen to everyone across the board,” he says, emphasising on Lata Mangeshkar. “She is the only lady whose songs are sung by four generations.”

Does he see any rationale behind sticking to time-based ragas when one is performing indoors? “There is something in the air during an hour which goes with the raga. When we record ragas inside the studio, we do not follow timings. It’s not that much of a great experience for the performer. But the listener derives a lot of pleasure if the same raga is played, keeping the timing in mind.”

Dissecting such experiences to find the reasons no longer interests him. Staring at the sliver of light peeping through the window, he wants to talk about the deeply spiritual process of transmission of music. “Many say that my face changes when I start singing. I don’t know about that, but one thing is certain. I neither sing, nor do you listen. It is the Almighty who sings and listens. Only the Supreme Power is aware of how and in which form the sound travels from the microphone to the audience.”

Half-closing his eyes, he talks about the strange experience on good performance days, when people come backstage and say: ‘Aaj kya ho gaya Panditji?’ Then, there have been days of overwhelming response from the audience when, in reality, he has struggled to hunt for a sur to be woven into raga. Reclining his head a little while bathing in the mellow light, he softly starts to hum a bandish and then pauses. “That’s when I realise that it is neither me who is singing nor the audience that is listening. We are mere instruments doing what the Almighty wants done,” he says.

Title: Almost Famous: Meet five rising stars of Indian classical music from Kolkata
Content:
Debanjan Bhattacharya

KOLKATA: None of them are star-kids. Yet, the sound of their music has already travelled far and wide. Meet five rising stars of Indian classical music from Kolkata who are waiting in the wings to create unique spaces of excellence for themselves.Debanjan Bhattacharya | sarod playerAge | 33Gharana | Senia MaiharDisciple of | Ustad Aasish Khan, late Vidushi Ameena Perara, late Ustad Dhyanesh KhanAbout him | A post-graduate in electronics and communication engineering from Indian Institute of Engineering, Science and Technology, Debanjan is a recipient of the President of India’s Gold Medal Award in 2008. He has already performed in 18 countries and has represented India at the United Nations Congress 2012 (Bahrain), where he performed in front of the then UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and His Excellency the King of Bahrain. “I also conceived a new form of recital called Dhrupad Sarod, where the sarod is accompanied by a pakhawaj. I have presented this recital in front of Prime Minister Narendra Modi,” Debanjan says.Why we should watch out for himHe is one of the most promising torchbearers of the Maihar gharana. He has got good talim and his music is a beautiful blend of both technical brilliance and aesthetic appeal. He is very good with laya and maintains a good balance between melody and rhythm. The fact that he took up music as a career despite being a qualified engineer also shows his seriousness and passion for our music — Pt Tejendra Narayan Majumdar | sarod playerAyan Sengupta | sitar playerAge | 29Gharana | Senia MaiharDisciple of | Pt Partha Chatterjee,Pt Ajoy ChakrabortyAbout him | An ITC Sangeet Research Academy musician scholar, Ayan has been pursuing music from the age of eight. In 2003, he won the Government of India’s junior scholarship. “I started learning from my grandfather, Subimal Sengupta, and have also received lessons from Pt Manilal Nag and Pt Kushal Das,” Ayan says. Described as a sensitive, serious and hardworking musician, Ayan has also performed at various concerts in India, the UK and Bangladesh. He has also been a part of a television show, where he was a part of a band by sitarist Purbayan Chatterjee.Why we should watch out for himAyan has tremendous potential to grow into a responsible sitar player if he continues with his present thought process, his riyaaz and the assimilation of all the repertoire he has acquired so far while exploring further depths of Indian music, including sitar music. I like his maturity, which is seen through his thehrao (poise). At a time when plenty of compromises are being done by youngsters to achieve quick popularity, Ayan stands out because of his seriousness and restraint. People with such qualities last longer in the music scene — Pt Nayan Ghosh | sitaristHe shows great promise. I would be happy to see another Bengali come up in the field of sitar — Kaushiki Chakraborty | vocalistPratik Srivastav | sarod playerAge | 32Gharana | MaiharDisciple of | Pt Rabi Chakraborty, Dr Rajeeb Chakraborty, Pt Ajoy Chakraborty, Pt Tejendra Narayan MajumdarAbout him | Pratik was just 12 when he received the Ånun Lund Rej Memorial Foundation Scholarship from Norway. Apart from playing at various festivals in India, he has the distinction of performing in countries like Jordan, France, Germany and the UK. In 2001, he went to Australia to play at the Woodford Folk Festival. Last year, he performed in Paris at a tribute concert to legends Pandit Ravi Shankar and Phillip Glass. “The concert had six Indian musicians along with Anoushka Shankar and the Orchestre de Chamber de Paris. Together, we presented all the compositions from Panditji and Phillip Glass’s world famous album titled Passages,” said Pratik, who has also been invited to perform at the forthcoming centenary concert for Panditji in the UK and the US.Why we should watch out for himAmong young sarod players, I like his sense of aesthetics. He tries to present a raga in a picturesque way — Pt Ajoy Chakraborty | vocalistHis playing is mature for his age. His tonality is special and his style has the emotions that can connect with the audience — Kaushiki Chakraborty | vocalistAnubhab Khamaru | vocalistAge | 17Gharana | PatialaDisciple of | Pt Ajoy ChakrabortyAbout him | Anubhab was initially trained by his father. Subsequently, he joined Shrutinandan and then ITC Sangeet Research Academy as a junior scholar. A rare talent, Anubhab’s YouTube video has received more than 2 lakh views. Curiously enough, many have even misidentified him as Pt Bhimsein Joshi’s grandson. “I am a student of Mathurapur High School and will write my HS exams this year. My guruji insists I maintain my individuality. That’s what I try to do,” Anubhab says.Why we should watch out for himMusically, Anubhab is extremely gifted. He doesn’t have the mind-set of learning music to become famous. I would want him to shape up as a unique musician. Only time, destiny, luck and perseverance can say where he will go — Kaushiki Chakraborty | vocalistHis taans and gayaki remind me of Rashid (Ustad Rashid Khan) during his younger days — Pt Tejendra Narayan Majumdar | sarod playerSreemoyee Acharya | vocalistAge | 12Gharana | PatialaDisciple of | Pt Ajoy ChakrabortyAbout her | Sreemoyee, a student of Mahadevi Birla World Academy, started to learn singing from her parents when she was just two-and-a-half years old. Having already earned acclaim for her performance in Mumbai and Delhi, she has also performed at 2019’s ITC Sangeet Sammelan. “I try to balance music and studies. My daily routine includes five hours of riyaaz,” says Sreemoyee, whose primary aim is to become a professional singer while being a doctor on the side.Why we should watch out for herHer father was my student. Her mother sings well too. One day, she had come home and I heard her sing. She was so good that I invited her to sing at the Saraswati Puja programme that I organise at home. It’s a blessing that she has such a sweet and tuneful voice. She is also very flexible. It is rare to come across a child who can attempt the kind of high-level ornamentations that she does at her age. If she is trained well and maintains her cool, Sreemoyee will have a bright future — Pt Swapan Chaudhuri | tabla playerI hope she has the strength, perseverance and commitment to make it, come what may, as a girl — Kaushiki Chakraborty | vocalist

Title: Immigrants entering B’desh up, but it’s no exodus: BSF
Content:
This story is from January 25, 2020

Kolkata: The number of illegal Bangladeshi immigrants trying to leave India through the porous land border has increased substantially but does not amount to an “exodus-like situation”, Border Security Force has said.

BSF troops along the 913-km south Bengal frontier apprehended 268 Bangladeshi nationals — nearly 90% of them going back to Bangladesh from India — in the first 23 days of 2020, BSF inspector-general (South Bengal Frontier) Y B Khurania said in Kolkata on Friday. Most of them used the international border in North 24 Parganas’ Ghojadanga, he added.

Prodded by journalists whether this rise could be attributed to the CAA, Khurania said that might be the case. “We believe that it is because of our increased vigil that fewer people from Bangladesh are trying to enter India illegally. Most of those without valid documents apprehended by us near the border were on their way out. But there seems to be no exodus-like situation. We apprehended 1,677 Bangladeshis without valid papers in 2018 (or a daily average of 4.5) and 2,194 in 2019 (or a daily average of 6) and most of them were India-bound. But, in 2020, we have already apprehended 268 Bangladeshis and 90% of them were returning to Bangladesh,” Khurania said. This amounts to almost 12 people daily.

Officials said the figures pertained to the south Bengal frontier (about a fourth of the total length of the India-Bangladesh border). Fewer people may have tried to cross over to India from Bangladesh illegally, fearing detection by agencies after the passage of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, they said, adding that was when the outward movement started.

Both Khurania and BSF deputy inspector-general (South Bengal Frontier) S S Guleria stressed that eastern border was much more difficult to manage than the west. Nearly 60% of the border remains unfenced and there are few floodlights. BSF efforts have brought down cattle-smuggling by nearly 95% but criminals have turned their attention to narcotics and use women and schoolchildren.

“We have tried to fence the border with our own resources at some places. And, at 20 locations where borderline or zero-line villages exist, we have proposed a single-row fence that will take up less space and cannot be cut. However, this fencing will have to be within 150 metres of the border. We have taken up the matter with the Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) and joint inspections have been held at two locations. BGB is yet to give its consent after which work can start. We are raising awareness on prohibitory orders under Section 144 that is in place along the border,” Khurania added.
